Authors: Funk E.E., Chauchard E.A., Lee Chi H., Rhee M.J.
Title: 80 kW pulse generation by a photo-conductive semiconductor-opening-switch inductive pulsed power system
Authors with affiliations: Funk, E.E.; Chauchard, E.A.; Lee, Chi H.; Rhee, M.J.
Abstract: Generation of an 80-kW, 2-kV pulse has been demonstrated with a GaAs photoconductive semiconductor switch (PCSS) in a current charge transmission line (CCTL) inductive energy storage pulsed power system. The CCTL configuration provided a power gain of 45 and a voltage gain of 6.7. This is the highest power gain achieved to date with a CCTL and PCSS. Power gain is achieved by discharging a capacitor through the GaAs PCSS into a shorted transmission line, the CCTL. If the power gain is taken as the ratio of the peak power which would be delivered into the load from the capacitor, the corresponding power gain is 45.
Index Keywords: Capacitors--Energy Storage; Electric Switches, Semiconductor; Photoconductivity; Semiconducting Gallium Arsenide; Current Charge Transmission Lines; Inductive Pulsed Power Systems; Pulse Generators

Authors: Sarangapani S., Forchione J., Griffith A., LaConti A.B., Baldwin R.
Title: Some recent studies with the solid-ionomer electrochemical capacitor
Affiliations: Giner, Inc., 14 Spring Street, Waltham, MA 02254-9147, United States; NASA Lewis Research Center, Cleveland, OH 44135, United States
Authors with affiliations: Sarangapani, S., Giner, Inc., 14 Spring Street, Waltham, MA 02254-9147, United States; Forchione, J., Giner, Inc., 14 Spring Street, Waltham, MA 02254-9147, United States; Griffith, A., Giner, Inc., 14 Spring Street, Waltham, MA 02254-9147, United States; LaConti, A.B., Giner, Inc., 14 Spring Street, Waltham, MA 02254-9147, United States; Baldwin, R., NASA Lewis Research Center, Cleveland, OH 44135, United States
Abstract: Giner, Inc. has developed a high-energy-density, all-solid-ionomer electrochemical capacitor, completely free of liquid electrolyte. The novel features of this device include (i) a three-dimensional metal oxide-particulate-ionomer composite electrode structure and (ii) a unitized repeating cell element. The composite electrode structures are bonded to opposite sides of a thin sheet of a solid proton-conducting ionomer membrane and form an integrally bonded membrane and electrode assembly (MEA). Individual MEAs can be stacked in series as bipolar elements to form a multiple cell device. The discharge characteristics and energy storage properties of these devices are described. Typical capacitance measured for a unit cell is 1 F/cm2. Life testing of a multicell capacitor on an intermittent basis has shown, that over a 10 000 h period, the capacitance and resistance of the cell has remained invariant. There has been no maintenance required on the device since it was fabricated. Other multicell units of shorter life duration have exhibited similar reliable performance characteristics. Recent work has focused on increasing the capacitance of the unitized structure and improving the low-temperature characteristics. The approaches and experimental results will be presented. Some possible advanced NASA applications for these unique all-solid-ionomer devices will be discussed. © 1991.
Index Keywords: Capacitors--Energy Storage; Electric Batteries, Secondary--Aerospace Applications; Electrochemical Capacitors; Pulsed Charges; Solid Ionomers; Aerospace Engineering

Authors: [No author name available]
Title: Conference Record of 1991 IEEE Particle Accelerator Conference
Source title: Conference Record of 1991 IEEE Particle Accelerator Conference
Abstract: The Conference' fifth volume contains 196 papers. The following topics are covered: synchrotron radiation sources/free electron lasers, low- and medium-energy accelerators and rings, high-energy accelerators and colliders, accelerator technology, RF power sources and power supplies, linear accelerators, pulsed power supplies, and linear colliders.
Index Keywords: Accelerators - Colliding Beam; Accelerators - Storage Rings; Accelerators, Linear; Light Sources; Synchrotron Radiation; EIREV; Free Electron Lasers; High-Energy Accelerators; Linear Colliders; Pulsed Power Devices; Synchrotron Radiation Sources; Accelerators

Authors: Kiefer Philip, Vernon Wayne
Title: Lattice studies for a small storage ring
Source title: Conference Record of 1991 IEEE Particle Accelerator Conference
Affiliations: Phys Dept, Univ of California, San, Diego, CA, USA
Authors with affiliations: Kiefer, Philip, Phys Dept, Univ of California, San, Diego, CA, USA; Vernon, Wayne, Phys Dept, Univ of California, San, Diego, CA, USA
Abstract: A study is made of the configurations of magnetic elements in order to maximize the beam brightness of a small e- storage ring for use as a component in a Compton scattered X-ray facility. The design goal was a single bunch current of 20 mA at a beam energy of 125 MeV. The design produced a low emittance beam (εx = 10-7 m-rad) with a reasonable lifetime. The authors plan to use NdBFe permanent magnetic driven dipoles in an attempt to reduce the overall cost of the storage ring facility, and the design used their properties for the bends in the lattice. Parameters varied include the RF voltage, the lattice structure, and the number and size of the bend elements. In particular, the effect of intrabeam scattering at such a low energy was studied.
Index Keywords: Accelerators - Magnets; Accelerators - Storage Rings; Bend Magnets; Compton Scattered X-Ray Source; Intrabeam Scattering; Quadrupoles; X-Ray and Gamma Ray Production

Authors: Davenport R.J., Schubert F.H., Grigger D.J.
Title: Space water electrolysis: space station through advanced missions
Affiliations: Life Systems, Inc., Cleveland, OH 44122, United States
Authors with affiliations: Davenport, R.J., Life Systems, Inc., Cleveland, OH 44122, United States; Schubert, F.H., Life Systems, Inc., Cleveland, OH 44122, United States; Grigger, D.J., Life Systems, Inc., Cleveland, OH 44122, United States
Abstract: Static feed electrolysis technology has long been recognized as being important in meeting the National Aeronautics and Space Administration's requirements for life support within the Space Station 'Freedom' and future, advanced missions. The static feed electrolysis technology makes it possible to very efficiently generate oxygen to sustain the crew, and hydrogen for the efficient and economical operation of other space systems. More recently, additional applications for the static feed electrolysis technology have been evaluated and tested. This paper summarizes the results of those studies. The applications addressed here are those involving energy storage, propulsion, extravehicular activity and other, specialized applications, such as providing support for experimentation and manufacturing. The environmental control and life support system application is included for comparison. © 1991.
Index Keywords: Space Stations--Life Support Systems; Water--Electrolysis; Oxygen Generation; Space Systems; Static Feed Electrolyzers; Aerospace Engineering

Authors: Zimmerman A.H.
Title: The effects of platinum on nickel electrodes in the nickelhydrogen cell
Affiliations: Chemistry and Physics Laboratory, The Aerospace Corporation, El Segundo, CA 90245, United States
Authors with affiliations: Zimmerman, A.H., Chemistry and Physics Laboratory, The Aerospace Corporation, El Segundo, CA 90245, United States
Abstract: Under conditions of nickel precharge in nickelhydrogen cells, it is possible for platinum complex ions to form at the platinum catalyst electrode when no hydrogen is present. Platinum complex ions have been shown to interact with the active material in the nickel electrode to catalyze the formation of a nickelcobalt compound within the active material lattice. This compound is readily identified by its characteristic voltage signature. A mechanism for the formation of this compound is proposed, and the effects that this compound has on the performance of the nickel electrode in the nickelhydrogen cell are described. © 1991.
Index Keywords: Aerospace Engineering--Energy Storage; Active Materials; Nickel Electrodes; Nickel-Hydrogen Cells; Electric Batteries, Secondary

Authors: Pandy Marcus G., Anderson Frank C.
Title: Storage and utilization of elastic strain energy during jumping
Affiliations: Univ of Texas at Austin, United States
Authors with affiliations: Pandy, Marcus G., Univ of Texas at Austin, United States; Anderson, Frank C., Univ of Texas at Austin, United States
Abstract: Muscles and tendons have elastic properties which may be exploited by humans if strain energy can be stored during one stage of an activity and recovered during another. To investigate the role of elastic energy storage when humans perform countermovements, we have used a detailed musculoskeletal model for vertical jumping to find the optimal controls for a maximum-height, countermovement jump (CMJ) and squat jump (SJ). In the CMJ, our model and subjects began in a relaxed, standing posture, and were free to countermove to any position prior to upward propulsion. In the SJ, the initial body-segmental angles of our model and subjects were selected to be the same as those attained at the bottom-most position of the CMJ; and from this initial configuration, no further countermovement was permitted. The model reproduced the major features of an actual CMJ and SJ (i.e., body-segmental angles, ground reaction forces, muscle activation patterns, and jump height). We found that all the muscles delivered nearly the same amount of energy to the skeleton during both jumps, which explains why the difference in jump height predicted by our model is only 1 cm. The contractile elements (CE's) dominate the work done on the skeleton. These structures contribute almost 65% of the total energy, while the elastic tissues account for the remaining 35%. Only through a detailed analysis of our optimal control solutions were we able to reconcile the minor difference in jump height between the CMJ and SJ predicted by our model. The reasons are that: firstly, energy losses in the CE's during the CMJ far outweigh those which occur in the SJ; and secondly, the CE's deliver much more energy to the elastic tissues in the SJ, and this energy is then delivered to the skeleton.
Index Keywords: Biological Materials - Muscle; Biological Materials - Tendons; Abstract Form Only; Elastic Strain Energy; Ground Reaction Forces; Jumping; Muscle Avtivation Patterns; Biomechanics

Authors: Anfinogenov V.B., Afanas'yev A.I., Zil'berman P.Ye., Mal'tsev V.A., Rudyy Yu.B., Finkel'shteyn Yu.Kh.
Title: Resonance attenuation of electromagnetic waves in an yttrium iron garnet film slow-wave system structure of the 'meander' type with weak delay
Source title: Soviet journal of communications technology & electronics
Authors with affiliations: Anfinogenov, V.B.; Afanas'yev, A.I.; Zil'berman, P.Ye.; Mal'tsev, V.A.; Rudyy, Yu.B.; Finkel'shteyn, Yu.Kh.
Abstract: Weakly delaying structures consisting of a transmission line of the 'meander' type on an yttrium iron garnet (YIG) film and placed in a tangential magnetizing field were studied experimentally. A series of deep attenuation lines of an electromagnetic wave (EMW) passing through the structure as well as reflection lines and steep jumps in phase accompanying a change in frequency within the indicated lines were observed and interpreted. It is shown that Bragg reflection of the excited spin waves (SWs) and storage of spin-wave energy in the structure can significantly reduce (by an order of magnitude) the widths of the attenuation lines. The reflection lines and steep jumps in phase are caused by hybridization of the space harmonics of the EMW with the SWs and restructuring of the spectrum of the hybrid waves. The resonance effects are nonreciprocal.
Index Keywords: Films - Electronic Properties; Microstrip Devices; Microwaves - Propagation; Electromagnetic Propagation; Microwave Transmission Lines; Resonance Attenuation; Slow Waves; Yttrium Iron Garnet Film; Electromagnetic Waves

Authors: Raju G.R.Govinda, Sussi M.A.
Title: Storage and decay of electrical charge in high temperature dielectrics
Source title: Proceedings of the Electrical/Electronics Insulation Conference
Authors with affiliations: Raju, G.R.Govinda; Sussi, M.A.
Abstract: The results of research into charge storage and its decay are reported for aromatic polyamides which are high-temperature dielectrics. Both thermal poling and corona charging techniques are used. Thermal poling is also carried out at various electric fields and TSD (thermally stimulated discharge) currents are measured by varying several parameters, such as the heating rate, material thickness, and storage temperature. The activation energy for the release of charges is determined by the plots of current and reciprocal of the temperature. The TSD current shows a peak at 135° for a rate of heating of 1 K/min and shifts to a higher value. The charge released to the external circuit is proportional to the poling field. The relaxation time for the delay of charges has been measured by a new experimental procedure, and it is concluded that the material shows dipolar relaxation at 135°C. A positive corona discharge in a point plane gap in air at atmospheric pressure is used for corona poling.
Index Keywords: Electric Corona; Electric Discharges; Electrostatics--Electric Charge; Charge decay; Charge storage; Corona polling; TSD currents; Dielectric Materials

Authors: Nakhamkin M., Swensen E., Schainker Robert, Pollak Robert
Title: Compressed air energy storage: survey of advanced CAES development
Affiliations: Power Consultants, Inc, Mountainside, United States
Authors with affiliations: Nakhamkin, M., Power Consultants, Inc, Mountainside, United States; Swensen, E., Power Consultants, Inc, Mountainside, United States; Schainker, Robert, Power Consultants, Inc, Mountainside, United States; Pollak, Robert, Power Consultants, Inc, Mountainside, United States
Abstract: This paper gives the reader an overview of the currently developed compressed air energy storage (CAES) plant concepts, discusses their salient features and applications, presents a comparison of the major plant characteristics, performance, and capital costs versus those of the conventional CAES plant. The paper includes the following CAES concepts: 1) conventional CAES plant, 2) CAES plants with steam generation (combined cycle or steam injection), 3) CAES with thermal energy storage, and 4) CAES plants using coal as primary fuel (circulating fluidized bed combustors or integrated air saturation/coal gasification/CAES plants).
Index Keywords: Advanced Compressed Air Energy Storage (CAES); CAES Combined Cycle Plant (CAES/CC); CAES with Steam Generation; CAS Thermal Energy Storage; Conventional CAES; Compressed Air

Authors: Uhm Han S.
Title: High accelerating-gradient accelerator based on magnetic field decay mechanism
Source title: Conference Record of 1991 IEEE Particle Accelerator Conference
Affiliations: US Naval Surface Warfare Center,, Silver Spring, MD, USA
Authors with affiliations: Uhm, Han S., US Naval Surface Warfare Center,, Silver Spring, MD, USA
Abstract: The author proposes a novel concept for an accelerating device, where the magnetic field energy is efficiently stored in a specially prepared material by a continuous electric current. If the current drops abruptly to zero, the magnetic field stored inside the material decays, thereby generating an accelerating electric field. A high-current electron beam with relatively low energy propagates through a hole along the axis of a cylindrical field-storage device, sustaining an azimuthal magnetic field in the field-storage material. A theory of the magnetic field diffusion is developed in order to estimate the accelerating gradient whenever the sustaining electric current drops to zero. According to a theoretical calculation, a high-accelerating electric field occurs at the axis, which can be a substantial fraction of megavolt per centimeters for optimized values of the magnetic permeability and conductivity of the field-storage material.
Index Keywords: Electric Fields; Electron Beams; Magnetic Fields; High Accelerating Gradient Accelerators; Accelerators

Authors: Chen C.S., Sheen J.N.
Title: Design and implementation of an eutectic salt cooling energy storage system for load management
Source title: 1991 IEEE Industry Application Society Annual Meeting
Authors with affiliations: Chen, C.S.; Sheen, J.N.
Abstract: An air conditioner system with 1800 RT-HR eutectic salt energy storage tank was built for the demonstration of the cooling energy storage (CES) system. Six operation modes are designed to meet different cooling load requirements. By computer simulation, it was found that 38.7% of the electric peak demand has been reduced and 37% of the energy consumption has been shifted from peak hours to off-peak hours by the CES-system. A mathematical model of an eutectic salt CES-system has been developed for the computer simulation of the energy storage system. It is found that the optimal capacity of the storage tank is determined by the off-peak time period, and the largest annual electric charge saving could be obtained by applying the smallest normal chiller size under the optimal operating conditions. The payback period of the test system is estimated to be 3.83 years, considering the additional investment cost and the electricity charge saving of the CES-system.
Index Keywords: Electric Power Systems - Load Management; Energy Storage - Mathematical Models; Air Conditioners; Chillers; Cooling Energy Storage; Air Conditioning

Authors: Kapoor Kamiesh, Jaluria Yogesh
Title: Penetrative natural convection flow due to an isothermal vertical surface immersed in a thermally stable two-layer environment
Source title: American Society of Mechanical Engineers, Heat Transfer Division, (Publication) HTD
Affiliations: Rutgers Univ, New Brunswick, United States
Authors with affiliations: Kapoor, Kamiesh, Rutgers Univ, New Brunswick, United States; Jaluria, Yogesh, Rutgers Univ, New Brunswick, United States
Abstract: An experimental investigation has been carried out on the penetrative natural convection flow over and the resulting thermal transport from an isothermal vertical surface immersed in a thermally stable, two-layer, ambient medium, in which an essentially isothermal heated layer overlies a relatively cooler isothermal layer of the same fluid. This flow is frequently encountered in many practical problems of interest, such as heat rejection, energy storage and enclosure fires. However, not much work has been done on such penetrative convection problems. In the present study, an isothermal vertical plate is exposed to an extensive two-layer thermally stable environment, resulting in a natural convection flow adjacent to the surface due to the temperature differences that exist. Detailed measurements of the thermal field are carried out for several surface temperatures and the corresponding isotherms obtained to characterize the penetration of the wall flow. The surface temperature is taken as lower than the upper layer temperature in this study so that a downward natural convection flow is generated adjacent to the surface in the upper zone. If the wall temperature is equal to the lower layer temperature, it is found that the natural convective wall flow penetrates into the lower cooler region, becomes negatively buoyant and then rises toward the interface between the two layers. It again becomes negatively buoyant in the upper zone, drops down toward the interface and finally flows outward, away from the vertical surface, staying close to the interface. Velocity and temperature profiles are measured at the interface of the two-layer environment and the mass flow rate penetrating downward across the interface as well as that penetrating into the upper zone are estimated.
Index Keywords: Flow of Fluids--Thermal Effects; Fluids--Thermal Properties; Heat Transfer--Testing; Surfaces--Heat Transfer; Isothermal Surfaces; Natural Convection; Penetrative Flows; Two Layer Environments; Vertical Surfaces; Heat Transfer

Abstract: This conference proceedings contains 226 papers. Authors: Kirchgessner J., Barnes P., Gerlack R., Moffat D., Padamsee H., Rubin D., Shu Q.S.
Title: Prototype 500 MHz planar RF input window for a B-factory accelerating cavity
Authors with affiliations: Kirchgessner, J.; Barnes, P.; Gerlack, R.; Moffat, D.; Padamsee, H.; Rubin, D.; Shu, Q.S.
Abstract: The Laboratory of Nuclear Studies is proposing an upgrade to the existing CESR electron-positron storage ring to make possible the study of CP violation of B meson decays. This B-Factory, because of the required luminosity and the resultant high beam current, will require very high RF power levels to replace the synchrotron radiation and the HOM (higher order mode) energy losses of the beams. The proposed design would require 16 superconducting cavity structures, each with an RF input power of approximately 400 kW at 500 MHz. The design requirements and the feasibility of a planar waveguide vacuum window are considered. Low-power and high-power measurements are described. The test results are provided.
Index Keywords: Radio Transmission--Applications; Superconducting Devices--Applications; Waveguide Components--Applications; B Meson Decays; B-Factory Acceleratring Cavity; CESR Electron-Positron Storage Ring; Planar RF Input Window; Planar Waveguide Vacuum Window; Superconducting Cavity Structures; Accelerators, Synchrotron

Authors: Burks B.L., Armstrong G.A., Butler P.L., Boissiere P.T.
Title: Combined long-reach and dexterous manipulation for waste storage tank applications
Source title: Conference on Robotics and Remote Systems- Proceedings
Affiliations: Oak Ridge Natl Lab, Oak Ridge, United States
Authors with affiliations: Burks, B.L., Oak Ridge Natl Lab, Oak Ridge, United States; Armstrong, G.A., Oak Ridge Natl Lab, Oak Ridge, United States; Butler, P.L., Oak Ridge Natl Lab, Oak Ridge, United States; Boissiere, P.T., Oak Ridge Natl Lab, Oak Ridge, United States
Abstract: During the summer of 1991, a robotics technology testbed (RTT) for waste storage tanks (WST) was assembled at the U.S. Department of Energy Hanford site in Richland, Washington. Oak Ridge National Laboratory (ORNL) provided a long-reach, high-capacity manipulation system for the RTT. The base positioning system serves as a platform for a dexterous manipulator supplied by Sandia National Laboratories (SNL). The base manipulation system is controlled with the ORNL-designed Modular Integrated Control Architecture (MICA). The dexterous arm is controlled with the SNL-designed Knowledge-Based Review and Intervention to Impose Constraints (KRITIC) controller. Both systems are integrated into the master control system using the SNL-designed Generic Intelligent System Controller (GISC).
Index Keywords: Control Systems; Industrial Wastes - Hazardous Materials; Materials Handling - Manipulators; Generic Intelligent System Controller; Storage Tanks; Waste Storage Tanks; Robotics

Authors: Gomei Y., Kawai M.
Title: The condition of γ-ray emission by electrons interacting with the wall in medium energy electron storage rings
Authors with affiliations: Gomei, Y.; Kawai, M.
Abstract: The condition of γ-ray emission is reported on medium energy electron storage rings. The electrons interact with the wall during injection and after being scattered by residual gas molecules or by mutual Coulomb interaction while circulating in the ring. It is shown that the location where heavy interaction occurs can be determined from the injection condition and the design condition of the electron orbit. The angle at which the electrons impinge on the wall is usually about 1° or less to the surface. The γ-ray emitted to the side of building walls in this case can be effectively shielded by the material located along the beam ducts. An important point is that, in the shallow impinging of electrons, convergent γ-ray emission occurs in the backscattering direction of electrons. By installing additional shielding materials for this convergent emission, the thickness of building shielding walls can be effectively alleviated.
Index Keywords: Electrons; Gamma Rays; Convergent Emission; Electron-Wall Interaction; Gamma Ray Emission; Medium Energy Electron Storage Rings; Mutual Coulomb Interaction; Accelerators, Synchrotron

Authors: Ren Z.X., Xu J.Z., Wang Y.C., Shen K.M., Li J.M., Ning Z.Y., Tang T.S., Zhang S.Q., Shi Q., Sun S.H., Li Y.H., Dai S.Y., Cheng J., Nie L.X., Wang X.J.
Title: Experimental progress at the ELL Electromagnetic Launch Facility
Authors with affiliations: Ren, Z.X.; Xu, J.Z.; Wang, Y.C.; Shen, K.M.; Li, J.M.; Ning, Z.Y.; Tang, T.S.; Zhang, S.Q.; Shi, Q.; Sun, S.H.; Li, Y.H.; Dai, S.Y.; Cheng, J.; Nie, L.X.; Wang, X.J.
Abstract: The Electric Launch Laboratory (ELL) in the Institute of Plasma Physics, Academia Sinica, China was established in 1987 to keep track of development of electromagnetic propulsion techniques and to evaluate electromagnetic launcher components and systems. At first, the propelling mechanism of several electrothermal launchers was investigated. Both experiments and theories showed that the propelling force of the accelerated projectile comes from the thermal pressure of the high-temperature neutral gas formed in the discharge. A modeling electromagnetic launch facility built in September 1987 with a 25-mm square bore consisted of a 0.8-m long-barrel electrothermal launcher and a 1-m long-barrel rail launcher in tandem. A 3-MJ capacitor bank was built at the beginning of 1988 and has been applied to the development of an electromagnetic launcher. In 1988, a project involving the building of a round-bore 25-mm round and 3-m long barrel rail launcher was begun. The goals of the program are to develop the plasma armature and the solid armature for the round-bore rail launcher.
Index Keywords: Capacitors--Energy Storage; Plasma Devices; Capacitor Banks; Electrothermal Launchers; Plasma Armatures; Summary Only; Electromagnetic Launchers

Authors: Kopylov S.I.
Title: Effect of sectioning on stored energy in superconducting windings
Affiliations: Moscow Power Engineering Inst, Moscow, Russian Federation
Authors with affiliations: Kopylov, S.I., Moscow Power Engineering Inst, Moscow, Russian Federation
Abstract: This paper deals with the problem of optimizing superconducting windings by the critical performance of superconductors, by mechanical stresses, and by deformation. Sectioning of superconducting windings provides a more efficient use of the superconductor through an equal distribution of current. The most regular criteria of efficiency are the ratio of current to its critical value, the mechanical stresses and the deformation of winding sections or any combination of these factors.
Index Keywords: Deformation; Efficiency; Electric current distribution; Electric windings; Energy storage; Optimization; Stresses; Equal current distribution; Superconducting winding sectioning; Superconducting magnets

Authors: Green M.A., Byrns R.A., St. Lorant S.J.
Title: Estimating the cost of superconducting magnets and the refrigerators needed to keep them cold
Affiliations: Univ of California, Berkeley, United States
Authors with affiliations: Green, M.A., Univ of California, Berkeley, United States; Byrns, R.A., Univ of California, Berkeley, United States; St. Lorant, S.J., Univ of California, Berkeley, United States
Abstract: The cost of superconducting magnets and the refrigerators needed to keep them cold can be estimated if one knows the magnet stored energy and the amount of refrigeration needed. This report updates the cost data collected over 20 years ago by Strobridge and others. Early cost data has been inflated into 1991 dollars and data on newer superconducting magnets has been added to the old data. The cost of superconducting magnets has been correlated with stored energy and field-magnetic volume product. The cost of the helium refrigerator cold box and the compressors needed to keep the magnet cold can be correlated with the refrigeration generated at 4.5 K. The annual cost of 4.5 K refrigeration can be correlated with 4.5 K refrigeration and electrical energy cost.
Index Keywords: Compressors; Correlation methods; Costs; Electricity; Energy storage; Estimation; Refrigerators; Field magnetic volume product; Helium refrigerator cold box; Superconducting magnets

Authors: Mao Dean, Chen Pah I.
Title: Mathematical models of sawmill carriage hydraulic drive systems
Affiliations: Swing Shift-Brudi Inc, Vancouver, United States
Authors with affiliations: Mao, Dean, Swing Shift-Brudi Inc, Vancouver, United States; Chen, Pah I., Swing Shift-Brudi Inc, Vancouver, United States
Abstract: The sawmill carriage is a major piece of equipment in a lumbermill. This paper presents the mathematical models for two types of hydraulic drive systems. Both carriage systems are analyzed according to their dynamic equations. The time response of the systems was found basically the same in magnitude and mainly depends on the ratio of force against mass. But due to the addition of the flywheel energy storage unit, the power consumption per working cycle of the enhanced system was found to be greatly reduced. Both systems were modelled numerically by using dynamic simulation software.
Index Keywords: Flywheels - Applications; Hydraulic Drive - Efficiency; Mathematical Techniques - Numerical Methods; Sawmill Carriage; Hydraulic Drive

Authors: McCarthy K.W.
Title: Facades and thermal storage. Passive and active control of building energy
Source title: National Conference Publication - Institution of Engineers, Australia
Affiliations: Meinhardt Axon
Authors with affiliations: McCarthy, K.W., Meinhardt Axon
Abstract: To illustrate passive and active energy control an example of each is given and the design procedure for each is developed to demonstrate how they are incorporated in the overall design and total engineering of a project. Passive energy control by means of the building facade and active energy control by means of thermal storage is illustrated. To demonstrate the effect of different facades four basic facade types have been used: strip glazing with plain glass; strip glazing with double glazing; strip glazing with external shading; glass curtain wall with performance glass. Regarding the active energy control, it is shown that the thermal storage most suitable for air conditioning (cooling) purposes is ice storage.
Index Keywords: Air Conditioning; Facades; Glass; Ice--Energy Storage; Solar Energy; Building Energy Control; Thermal Storage; Buildings

Authors: Uberall H., Faraday B.J., Maruyama X.K., Berman B.L.
Title: Channeling radiation as an x-ray source for angiography, x-ray lithography, molecular structure determination, and elemental analysis
Source title: Proceedings of SPIE - The International Society for Optical Engineering
Affiliations: SFA, Inc, 1401 McCormick Drive, Landover, MD  20785, United States; Department of Physics, Naval Postgraduate School, Monterey, CA  93943, United States; Department of Physics, George Washington University, Washington, DC  20052, United States
Authors with affiliations: Uberall, H., SFA, Inc, 1401 McCormick Drive, Landover, MD  20785, United States; Faraday, B.J., SFA, Inc, 1401 McCormick Drive, Landover, MD  20785, United States; Maruyama, X.K., Department of Physics, Naval Postgraduate School, Monterey, CA  93943, United States; Berman, B.L., Department of Physics, George Washington University, Washington, DC  20052, United States
Abstract: Synchrotron radiation of 33 keV (A 0.4 A) has been tentatively employed for coronary angiography studies; the results were successful, but so far lack clinical quality. Synchrotron radiation has also been proposed as a source for microlithography and the efficient production of integrated circuits, using energies of 0.5-2.5 keV 5-20 A). This application, although not yet carried out in earnest, appeared promising enough so that a number of synchrotron sources dedicated to this purpose are now being set up worldwide. Such applications require storage rings for GeV electrons, costing 20 to 60 million each. Less expensive, lower energy linacs, affordable by individual hospitals or smaller institutions, can produce key channeling radiation suitable for microlithography and angiography. Channeling-radiation intensities, especially for x-ray energies of some tens of keV and higher will surpass synchrotron-radiation intensities. We have carried out quantitative studies confirming the above conclusions regarding the comparison of channeling radiation and synchrotron radiation. We found that < 5MeV electron linacs costing less than 1 million can generate few-keV channeling radiation intensities comparable to that of synchrotron radiation, suitable for microlithography and calcium-based angiography, as well as x-ray diffraction structure analysis and elemental analysis by x-ray fluorescence. (For iodine-based angiography, 20 MeV linacs are required.) If transition radiation were used for the same purposes, more expensive linacs of an order of magnitude higher electron energy would be needed. © 1991 SPIE. All rights reserved.
Index Keywords: Angiography; Complexation; Costs; Electron energy levels; Germanium compounds; Linear accelerators; Synchrotron radiation; Synchrotrons; Wavemeters; X ray lithography; Accelerators, Synchrotron; Biomedical Engineering--Angiography; Integrated Circuit Manufacture; Lithography; SYNCHROTRON RADIATION; Channeling radiation; Coronary angiography; Quantitative study; Structure determination; Synchrotron source; Transition radiation; X ray fluorescence; X-ray diffraction structure; Radiation; Accelerators, Linear; Microlithography; X-ray lithography

Authors: Takashima K., Nomura E., Matsui K., Matsumaru Y., Lijima S., Matsuo Y., Sato K., Furuta S., Hirabayashi T.
Title: Present status of the 1MW/8MWh Na/S battery energy storage demonstration plant
Source title: Mechanical and corrosion properties. Series A, Key engineering materials
Affiliations: Yuasa Battery Co, Takatsuki, Japan
Authors with affiliations: Takashima, K., Yuasa Battery Co, Takatsuki, Japan; Nomura, E., Yuasa Battery Co, Takatsuki, Japan; Matsui, K., Yuasa Battery Co, Takatsuki, Japan; Matsumaru, Y., Yuasa Battery Co, Takatsuki, Japan; Lijima, S., Yuasa Battery Co, Takatsuki, Japan; Matsuo, Y., Yuasa Battery Co, Takatsuki, Japan; Sato, K., Yuasa Battery Co, Takatsuki, Japan; Furuta, S., Yuasa Battery Co, Takatsuki, Japan; Hirabayashi, T., Yuasa Battery Co, Takatsuki, Japan
Abstract: Yuasa Battery Company, in collaboration with NGK Spark Plug Company, Kansai Electric Power Company and Toshiba Corporation, is now constructing a 1MW/8MWh sodium-sulfur battery energy storage plant for utility load leveling, as the final stage of the national research program sponsored by the Agency of Industrial Science and Technology, under the administration of the New Energy and Industrial Technology Development Organization. The assignment of Yuasa Battery Company and NGK Spark Plug Company is the development and construction of a 1MW/8MWh sodium-sulfur battery. So far, a half of the battery has been manufactured and installed in the plant, and is now under testing while the remainder of the battery is being manufactured. The half of the battery has been cycled, with the DC/AC converter which Toshiba Corporation has provided, up to 70 cycles, and is scheduled to be tested until the remainder of the battery becomes available, when the full plant at a rating of 1MW/8MWh will be put into a test.
Index Keywords: Alumina - Ionic Conduction; Electrolytes, Solid; Beta-Alumina; Beta-Batteries; Sodium-Sulfur Electric Batteries; Electric Batteries

Authors: McElroy J.F.
Title: SPE® water electrolyzers in support of Mission from Planet Earth
Affiliations: United Technologies Corporation, Hamilton Standard Division, Windsor Locks, CT 06096, United States
Authors with affiliations: McElroy, J.F., United Technologies Corporation, Hamilton Standard Division, Windsor Locks, CT 06096, United States
Abstract: Although the Mission from Planet Earth is still in the early planning stage, several unique and potentially enabling uses of the SPE water electrolyzer have been identified. The maturity of the SPE water electrolyzer cells gained from the Naval applications should give mission planners the confidence to take advantage of the leveraging effects of the SPE cell technology. Although the inherent capabilities of this technology have been proven, significant development effort remains to package these cells for the Mission from Planet Earth applications. © 1991.
Index Keywords: Aerospace Engineering--Energy Storage; Electric Batteries, Secondary--Research; Fuel Cells--Electrolytes; Membranes--Ion Exchange Membranes; Oxygen Generators; Propellant Generation; Regenerative Cells; SPE Electrolyzers; Water

Authors: Archie Chas N., Uythoven Jan
Title: Tracking studies for the Oxford Instruments compact electron synchrotron
Source title: Conference Record of 1991 IEEE Particle Accelerator Conference
Affiliations: IBM T J Watson Res Center, Yorktown, Heights, NY, USA
Authors with affiliations: Archie, Chas N., IBM T J Watson Res Center, Yorktown, Heights, NY, USA; Uythoven, Jan, IBM T J Watson Res Center, Yorktown, Heights, NY, USA
Abstract: Simulating electron trajectories (tracking) in a realistic compact ring introduces special problems because the magnetic bending radius can be as little as twenty times the horizontal displacement. Common simplifying approximations in tracking codes may not be appropriate. Results are presented from a thin lens tracking code which correctly handles the small bending radius virtual forces and real magnetic forces to octupole level. Nonsymplectic behavior is controlled by highly segmenting the Oxford superconducting dipoles. A qualitative comparison with experimental results is made.
Index Keywords: Accelerators, Electron Ring - Beam Tracking; Electron Lenses; Equations of Motion; Particle Accelerators; Physics - High Energy; Superconducting Devices; Electron Trajectories; Superconducting Electron Storage Ring; Synchrotron; Accelerators, Synchrotron

Authors: Bowman Jr. R.C., Freeman B.D., Phillips J.R.
Title: Application of vanadium hydride compressors for Joule-Thomson cryocoolers
Affiliations: Aerojet Electronic Systems Div, Azusa, United States
Authors with affiliations: Bowman Jr., R.C., Aerojet Electronic Systems Div, Azusa, United States; Freeman, B.D., Aerojet Electronic Systems Div, Azusa, United States; Phillips, J.R., Aerojet Electronic Systems Div, Azusa, United States
Abstract: The Joule-Thomson expansion of hydrogen gas offers efficient and reliable cryocoolers to produce temperatures between 10 and 50K. A critical component to the development of these devices is the metal hydride storage bed that provides a nonmechanical method to compress hydrogen gas via the reversible absorption by appropriate metals or alloys. A thermodynamic model has been used to calculate the impact of operational parameters such as input/output pressure ratios and bed temperature on energy balance and system efficiency. Detailed comparisons are reported for a compressor which utilizes vanadium metal as the sorbent for either hydrogen or deuterium where the unusually large isotope differences between the phase diagrams and thermal properties for VHx and VDx have been considered. The sensitivity of heat input requirements to the uncertainties in primary variables are described.
Index Keywords: Absorption; Compressors; Efficiency; Hydrides; Hydrogen; Mathematical models; Phase diagrams; Thermodynamic properties; Vanadium compounds; Bed temperature; Input/output pressure ratio; Joule-Thomson cryocoolers; Metal hydride storage bed; Nonmechanical method; Cryogenic equipment

Authors: Krock Hans-Jurgen, Zapka Manfred J.
Title: The Hawaiian International Hydrogen Energy Pilot Project: A concept for the commercial implementation of non-fossil hydrogen energy in the Pacific Ocean area
Affiliations: Ocean Eng, SOEST, Univ of Hawaii,, HI, USA
Authors with affiliations: Krock, Hans-Jurgen, Ocean Eng, SOEST, Univ of Hawaii,, HI, USA; Zapka, Manfred J., Ocean Eng, SOEST, Univ of Hawaii,, HI, USA
Abstract: Summary form only given. The Hawaii International Hydrogen Energy Pilot Project is presented as a concept where hydrogen technology developed internationally by companies and institutions is implemented in a larger scale commercial pilot project which thereby would generate operational experience and real world performance data. The project addresses all important aspects of a future economy based on solar derived hydrogen. Unit processes would include hydrogen production, storage, transport and utilization technologies. The concept of hydrogen generation by ocean thermal energy conversion (OTEC) is discussed as a particularly promising production scenario. The whole project is evaluated in the context of the tropical Pacific social and economic conditions.
Index Keywords: Energy Resources; Hydrogen; Ocean Engineering; Power Generation; Technology - Economic and Sociological Effects; Hawaiian International Pilot Project; Hydrogen Energy; Hydrogen Generation; Ocean Thermal Energy Conversion

Authors: Barletta William A., Calderon Manuel, Wong Robert, Jenkins Theodore
Title: Design of the vacuum system for the high energy ring of an asymmetric B-factory based on PEP
Source title: Conference Record of 1991 IEEE Particle Accelerator Conference
Authors with affiliations: Barletta, William A.; Calderon, Manuel; Wong, Robert; Jenkins, Theodore
Abstract: The multi-ampere current required for high-luminosity operation of an asymmetric B factory leads to extremely stressing requirements on a vacuum system suitable for maintaining long beam-gas lifetimes and acceptable background levels in the detector. The authors present the design for a Cu alloy vacuum chamber and its associated pumping system for the 9-GeV electron storage ring of the proposed B factory based on the Positron-Electron Project. (PEP). The excellent thermal and photodesorption properties of Cu make it possible to handle the high photon flux in a conventional, single-chamber design with distributed ion pumps. The X-ray opacity of the Cu is sufficiently high that no additional lead shielding is necessary to protect the dipoles from the intense synchrotron radiation generated by the beam. The design allows chamber commissioning in <500 hr of operation.
Index Keywords: Copper And Alloys; Electrons; Vacuum Technology; X-Rays; Asymmetric B-Factory; Positron-Electron Project; Accelerators

Authors: Nakhamkin M., Patel M., Andersson L., Abitante P., Cohn A.
Title: Analysis of integrated coal gasification system/compressed-air energy storage power plant concepts
Affiliations: Consultants, Inc (ESPC), Mountainside, United States
Authors with affiliations: Nakhamkin, M., Consultants, Inc (ESPC), Mountainside, United States; Patel, M., Consultants, Inc (ESPC), Mountainside, United States; Andersson, L., Consultants, Inc (ESPC), Mountainside, United States; Abitante, P., Consultants, Inc (ESPC), Mountainside, United States; Cohn, A., Consultants, Inc (ESPC), Mountainside, United States
Abstract: This paper presents the results of a project targeted at developing cost effective power plant concept with integrated Coal Gasification System (CGS) and with Compressed Air Energy Storage (CAES) plant. The developed concepts, denoted as CGS/CAES, provide for continuous operation of CGS and the reheat turboexpander train which are high temperature components, thus improving their operation and extending life resource. A parametric thermodynamic analysis is performed for several CGS/CAES concepts differentiated by their turbomachinery parameters, CGS arrangements, operating cycles, and hours of daily generation. A qualitative cost estimate is made using a variety of sources including published EPRI reports and extensive in-house cost data. A technical and cost comparison is made to the Integrated Gasification Combined Cycle (IGCC) plant.
Index Keywords: Compressed Air - Energy Storage; CGS/CAES Plant; Compressed Air Energy Storage (CAES); Computerized Plant Integration Procedure; Integrated Coal Gasification System (CGS); Integrated Gasification Combined Cycle (IGCC) Plant; Coal Gasification

Authors: Nakhamkin M., Whims M., Weiner D., Swensen E.C., Vadasz P., Abitante P., Brokman S.
Title: Conceptual engineering of a 300-MW CAES plant. Part 2: conceptual engineering and cost evaluation
Affiliations: Consultants, Inc, Mountainside, United States
Authors with affiliations: Nakhamkin, M., Consultants, Inc, Mountainside, United States; Whims, M., Consultants, Inc, Mountainside, United States; Weiner, D., Consultants, Inc, Mountainside, United States; Swensen, E.C., Consultants, Inc, Mountainside, United States; Vadasz, P., Consultants, Inc, Mountainside, United States; Abitante, P., Consultants, Inc, Mountainside, United States; Brokman, S., Consultants, Inc, Mountainside, United States
Abstract: This paper presents the results of Phase 2 of a project performed for the Israel Electric Corporation, Ltd. (IEC). The ultimate objective of the project is to develop the most cost-effective and technically feasible 300-MW CAES-plant concept with underground storage in an aquiferous reservoir. Three conceptually different turbomachinery trains and two underground-storage sites were analyzed. The project was executed in two distinct phases as follows: Phase 1 of the project included the integration and optimization of several CAES-plant concepts and served to identify the most attractive CAES turbomachinery train, including cycle parameters and configuration, and underground-storage site. Phase 2, the subject of this paper, includes conceptual engineering of the overall plant and the development of a budgetary cost estimate for the turn-key supply and construction of the plant.
Index Keywords: Cost Accounting; CAES Plant Integration; CAES Turbomachinery Train; Compressed Air Energy Storage (CAES); Motive-Air System Flow Diagram; Three-Hundred Megawatt CAES Plant; Underground Storage Design; Compressed Air

Authors: Koelle E., Luvizotto Jr. E.
Title: Operational simulation of pumped storage plant, including transient and oscillatory phenomena
Source title: Computer Methods in Water Resources II
Affiliations: Univ of Sao Paulo, Brazil
Authors with affiliations: Koelle, E., Univ of Sao Paulo, Brazil; Luvizotto Jr., E., Univ of Sao Paulo, Brazil
Abstract: The operating success of any Pumped Storage Plant (PSP) depends, first, on the adequate selection of the pump-turbine and, second, on the operational schedule of the plant to optimize energy production and consumption. The possibilities of using pump/turbine with variable speed and constant frequency generation system were presented in recent papers and probably will be the next goal to be achieved in such plants. So, with this type of machine, computer aided operation (CAO) in real time will be an inherent condition to fulfill design optimization. The use of MOC (Method of Characteristics) to obtain permanent (or extended period simulation), transient, and oscillatory conditions of operation are recommended as a basic algorithm to formulate a CAO for those plants and the use of Fourier Series to represent hydraulic characteristics is encouraged as presented in this paper. Cases Studies are presented to illustrate CAO use for the above features.
Index Keywords: Computer Aided Engineering; Flow of Water--Analysis; Hydraulic Turbines; Mathematical Techniques--Numerical Methods; Pumps; Case Studies; Computer-Aided Operation; Method of Characteristics; Operational Simulation; Pumped Storage Plants; Hydroelectric Power Plants

Authors: Fukuda Koji
Title: Construction of a national oil storage complex in Shibushi Bay
Affiliations: Construction Bur Ministry of, Transport, Japan
Authors with affiliations: Fukuda, Koji, Construction Bur Ministry of, Transport, Japan
Abstract: Japan relies on imported oil to satisfy the greatest part of its energy requirements. This fact led to early recognition that Japan needs to establish an oil storage infrastructure which will prevent damage to the economic life of the country in the event of an emergency. In the waters around the oil storage site, winds and waves become turbulent in spring, due to the influence of seasonal air currents. This paper discusses the background behind the national oil storage complex construction project in Shibushi Bay and the national plan for oil storage upon which it is based, and outlines the course of seawall construction and land reclamation in the construction of the artificial island.
Index Keywords: Land Reclamation; Retaining Walls; Storage (materials); Japan; National Oil Storage Complex; Crude Petroleum

Authors: Enderlein G., Korber W., Matheisen A., Proch D., Scholz F.
Title: Investigations on hydrogen contamination of superconducting cavities
Source title: Conference Record of 1991 IEEE Particle Accelerator Conference
Authors with affiliations: Enderlein, G.; Korber, W.; Matheisen, A.; Proch, D.; Scholz, F.
Abstract: All 16 cavities of the energy upgrading program for the HERA storage ring showed increased losses on the second or any successive cool down in contrast to superior values on the first cool down. The authors attributed this deterioration to hydrogen, which contaminates the niobium during chemical polishing. The low oxygen content of the new niobium material, which has a residual resistance resistance ratio (RRR) = 300, allows the hydrogen to diffuse to the surface and to produce NbH precipitation at low temperatures. The hydrogen degassing process at 800°C cannot be applied to these cavities because of the complex construction. The authors investigated chemical polishing methods with respect to hydrogen contamination and tried to find a hydrogen cleaning procedure at room temperature.
Index Keywords: Chemical Reactions; Hydrogen; Niobium And Alloys; Superconducting Devices; Chemical Polishing; HERA Storage Ring; Superconducting Cavities; Accelerators

Authors: Rensfelt K.-G.
Title: Status of the CRYRING project
Source title: Conference Record of 1991 IEEE Particle Accelerator Conference
Affiliations: Manne Siegbahn Inst of Phys, Stockholm, Sweden
Authors with affiliations: Rensfelt, K.-G., Manne Siegbahn Inst of Phys, Stockholm, Sweden
Abstract: The status of the CRYRING project is summarized. The project is centered around a synchrotron/storage ring of maximum rigidity, 1.44 Tm, corresponding to an energy of 24 MeV per nucleon at a charge-to-mass ratio of 0.5. It is mainly intended for highly charged, heavy ions produced by an electron-beam ion source (CRYSIS). Light atomic or molecular ions can also be injected from a small plasmatron source (MINIS). Ions from the ion sources are accelerated electrostatically to 10 keV per nucleon and transported to a radiofrequency-quadrupole linear accelerator (RFQ) which brings them to 300 keV per nucleon.
Index Keywords: Accelerators - Ion Sources; Accelerators, Linear; CRYRING Project; Electron-Beam Ion Source; MINIS Ion Sources; RF Quadrupole Linear Accelerator; Accelerators, Synchrotron

Authors: Jouan A., Frotscher H., Ganser B., Jacquet-Francillon N., Kertesz C., Klein M.
Title: New volume-reduction conditioning options for solid alpha-bearing waste
Affiliations: CEA
Authors with affiliations: Jouan, A., CEA; Frotscher, H., CEA; Ganser, B., CEA; Jacquet-Francillon, N., CEA; Kertesz, C., CEA; Klein, M., CEA
Abstract: The current and future development of nuclear energy requires increasing allowance for nuclear waste treatment: α-bearing wastes destined for geological storage are already conditioned, generally in a cement matrix. Other containment process producing higher quality matrices and allowing volume reduction have been investigated over the last five years by the General Directorate for Science, Research and Development of the Commission of the European Communities. This paper discusses the work on conditioning α-bearing ashes produced by incineration of contaminated combustible materials, and on fuel cladding hulls resulting from spent fuel reprocessing.
Index Keywords: Industrial Wastes - Treatment; Alpha-Bearing Wastes; Ash; Nuclear Waste Treatment; Radioactive Wastes

Authors: Ebeling Jerry A.
Title: Combustion turbine inlet air cooling with thermal energy storage
Source title: International Exhibition & Conference for the Power Generation Industries - Power-Gen
Affiliations: Burns & McDonnell Engineering Co
Authors with affiliations: Ebeling, Jerry A., Burns & McDonnell Engineering Co
Abstract: Thermal energy storage (TES) is perhaps as old as civilization itself. For decades, man harvested ice from frozen lakes in the winter and stored it in caves and ice house for later use. Using TES for combustion turbine inlet air cooling is a new twist to the established industrial and commercial scenarios discussed in the paper. The inlet air cooling is a new concept that is an economically feasible method of increasing the peak capacity rating of combustion turbines. The benefits of delayed installation of new generating capacity, along with the short design/construction schedule and low cost per KW, make it a very attractive option to utilities approaching their peak capacity. The TES technology has been proven, and the operation and maintenance of TES inlet air cooling facility is rather simple.
Index Keywords: Turbomachinery; Combustion turbine inlet air coolingg; Inlet air cooling alternatives; Inlet cooling alternatives; TES cycle; TES turbine design; Thermal energy storage (TES); Energy storage

Authors: Okuda S., Nakanishi T., Ikegami K., Nakata S., Nakagawa T., Tsukishima C., Maruyama A., Tanaka H., Nakamura S., Kodera I., Yamamoto S., Matsuda T., Fujimura S., Itagaki H., Yamada T., Iwamoto M.

Source title: Conference Record of 1991 IEEE Particle Accelerator Conference
