Abstract: A high-energy electron beam facility is under commission. This facility consists of a 20-MeV linac and a 1-GeV synchrotron. The synchrotron is designed to act as a storage ring as well as an injector to a compact storage ring.
Index Keywords: Accelerators, Linear; Accelerators, Synchrotron; Electron Beams; Magnets; High-Energy Electron Beam Facility; Linac Beam; RF System; Accelerators

Authors: Sohn Chang W.
Title: Thermal performance of an ice storage cooling system
Affiliations: U.S. Army Construction Engineering, Research Lab, Champaign, United States
Authors with affiliations: Sohn, Chang W., U.S. Army Construction Engineering, Research Lab, Champaign, United States
Abstract: The U.S. Army Construction Engineering Research Laboratory (USACERL) is field testing diurnal ice storage (DIS) cooling systems for Army facilities. A 1000 ton-hr (12.7 GJ), ice-on-coil DIS cooling system was installed in 1988 on a barracks/dining hall/office facility at the Yuma Proving Ground (YPG), AZ. Its thermal performance was measured during the 1989 cooling season (May 1-October 31, 1989). During this period, 86,250 ton-hr (1091.7 GJ) of refrigeration was produced by an icemaker which consumed 235,030 kWh of electric energy. The system made 3274 tons of ice (78,582 ton-hr, 994.7 GJ) into a storage tank, and 63,661 ton-hr (805.8 GJ) of net cooling was delivered to the building through an intermediate heat exchanger. The storage tank efficiency was measured to be 81% and the seasonal energy efficiency of the system was 2.72 kW/ton.
Index Keywords: Energy Conservation; Heat Exchangers - Applications; Ice - Applications; Army Facility; Ice Storage Cooling System; Ice Storage Tank; Thermal Performance; Buildings

Authors: Knebel David E.
Title: Optimal design and control of ice harvesting thermal energy storage systems
Affiliations: Paul Mueller Co
Authors with affiliations: Knebel, David E., Paul Mueller Co
Abstract: Cool Thermal storage is becoming a widely accepted form of electrical demand load management. From the perspective of the electric utility, the power plant and distribution network are significant investments, which yield the maximum return on investment when continuously used at or near full capacity. Diverse loads such as air conditioning when treated as instantaneous loads violate sound economic practice for the utility. One way of addressing load management for the air conditioning load is through cool thermal storage. The dynamic ice harvester is one technique for producing latent storage with ice. With the dynamic ice harvester ice is built on the exterior of a heat transfer surface and periodically removed from the heat transfer surface by means of a defrost cycle. Minimization of electrical demand and energy consumption requires optimal design and control of the ice harvester chiller system. Optimal design and control requires a hourly balance of the capacity of the ice harvester chiller with the building loads and ambient conditions. This paper addresses the principles of optimal system design and control of the ice harvester chiller using hourly simulation methods. A design procedure for selecting the components of an ice harvesting thermal energy storage systems is developed for a weekly load with a 225 ton peak.
Index Keywords: Buildings - Cooling Systems; Energy Storage; Heat Transfer - Surfaces; Ice - Production; Ice Harvester Chiller System; Thermal Energy Storage; Ice

Authors: Ratnakumar B.V., Attia A.I., Halpert G.
Title: Sodiummetal chloride battery research at the Jet Propulsion Laboratory (JPL)
Affiliations: Jet Propulsion Laboratory, California Institute of Technology, Pasadena, CA 91109, United States
Authors with affiliations: Ratnakumar, B.V., Jet Propulsion Laboratory, California Institute of Technology, Pasadena, CA 91109, United States; Attia, A.I., Jet Propulsion Laboratory, California Institute of Technology, Pasadena, CA 91109, United States; Halpert, G., Jet Propulsion Laboratory, California Institute of Technology, Pasadena, CA 91109, United States
Abstract: Sodiummetal chloride batteries have certain distinct advantages over sodiumsulfur batteries such as increased safety, inherent overcharge capability and lower operating temperatures. Two systems, i.e. Na/FeCl2 and Na/NiCl2 were developed extensively elsewhere and evaluated for various applications including electric vehicles and space. Their performance has been very encouraging and prompted a detailed fundamental study on these cathodes here at the Jet Propulsion Laboratory. A brief review of our studies on these new cathode materials is presented here. The initial efforts focussed on the methods of fabrication of the electrodes and their electrochemical characterization. Subsequent studies were aimed at establishing the reaction mechanism, determining the kinetics and identifying the rate-limiting processes in the reduction of metal chloride cathodes. Nickel chloride emerged from these studies as the most promising candidate material and was taken up for further detailed study on its passivation - a rate limiting process - under different experimental conditions. Also, the feasibility of using copper chloride, which is expected to have higher energy density, has been assessed. Based on the criteria established from the voltammetric response of FeCl2, NiCl2 and CuCl2, several other transition metal chlorides were screened. Of these, molybdenum and cobalt chlorides appear promising. © 1991.
Index Keywords: Satellites--Power Supply; Storage Battery Vehicles--Research; Nickel Chloride; Rechargeable Sodium Cells; Sodium Iron Chloride; Voltammetric Response; Electric Batteries, Secondary

Authors: Kimmel Eitan
Title: Dodecahedron model for parenchymal mechanics. Elastic and hysteretic moduli
Affiliations: Israel Inst of Technology, Haifa, Israel
Authors with affiliations: Kimmel, Eitan, Israel Inst of Technology, Haifa, Israel
Abstract: The dissipation of mechanical energy in lung parenchyma, while subjected to a periodic load, is exemplified in the incremental pressure-volume or force-displacement hysteresis loops. To account for this attribute, as well as for the elastic energy storage, the parenchyma is characterized by complex clastic moduli such as the Young's modulus E* = E (1 + ie), where E is the real modulus and c the tissual hysteresitivity. This modulus, for a given cyclic stress, σ(t) = Real[σoexp(iwt)] and strain ε(t) = Real[εoexp(iwt)], is defined as E* = σo/εo, where σo and εo denote the complex amplitudes and w is the frequency. A variational statement of non-linear structural mechanics is formulated for an individual lung element, in the shape of a regular dodecahedron. Tension members that lump together fibers and alveolar walls, form the dodecahedron edges; surface tension is incorporated to its pentagonal surfaces; and the transpulmonary pressure is simulated by an externally applied hydrostatic pressure. Tension T and length L are related, for each member, by the complex constitutive relation: B* = B(1 + ib) = (σT/T) approximately (σL/L), where B is the incremental stiffness and b is the member hysteresitivity, Similarly, variations of surface tension, T with total surface area of the dodecahedron, S, are given by C* = C(1 + ie) = (δΓ/Γ)/(δS/S). The results show how parenchymal mechanics (e.g., E and e) depend on the mechanical parameters of the microstructural elements (B, b, C and c) and on the inflating pressure.
Index Keywords: Biological Materials - Tissue; Mathematical Models; Abstract Form Only; Dodechahedron Model; Force-Displacement Hysteresis; Parenchymal Mechanics; Transpulmonary Pressure; Biomedical Engineering

Authors: Reid M.A., Loyselle P.L.
Title: Impedances of nickel electrodes cycled in various KOH concentrations
Affiliations: NASA Lewis Research Center, Cleveland, OH 44135, United States
Authors with affiliations: Reid, M.A., NASA Lewis Research Center, Cleveland, OH 44135, United States; Loyselle, P.L., NASA Lewis Research Center, Cleveland, OH 44135, United States
Abstract: Recent work has shown that NiH2 cells cycled in 26% KOH have much longer lives than those cycled in other concentrations. As part of an ongoing program to try to correlate the impedances of nickel electrodes with their life and performance, impedances were measured of a number of electrodes from these tests that had been cycled in concentrations from 21 to 36% KOH. These had been cycled under double-time LEO conditions at 80% DOD to failure. Cell life ranged from about 1000 to 40 000 cycles. After cycling ten times to reduce possible changes due to storage, impedances were measured at five voltages corresponding to low states of charge. The results were analyzed using a standard circuit model including a Warburg impedance term. Lower kinetic resistances and Warburg slopes were found for several electrodes which had been cycled in 26% KOH even though they had been cycled for a much longer time than the others. Interpretation of the data is complicated by the fact that the cycle lives, storage times and failure mechanisms varied. Several other circuit models have also been examined, but the best correlations with life were found with parameters obtained from the simple model. © 1991.
Index Keywords: Aerospace Engineering--Energy Storage; Electrodes, Electrochemical--Chemical Modification; Cycle Life; Cyclic Voltammetry; Electrolyte Concentration; Nickel Electrodes; Electric Batteries, Secondary

Authors: Dale Roger J.
Title: Laser ordnance initiation system
Source title: Proceedings - Annual SAFE Symposium (Survival and Flight Equipment Association)
Affiliations: Hercules Inc, Rocket Center, United States
Authors with affiliations: Dale, Roger J., Hercules Inc, Rocket Center, United States
Abstract: A miniature Laser Ordnance Initiation System (LOIS) is described. It can withstand the rigors of ammunition handling and storage, as well as being fired out of a gun with attendant high g-loads. This extremely simple and reliable system was patented by Hercules and is discussed for potential application in any life-saving system which must be a 'wooden round' where the system is required to be maintenance free with no on-board power storage or power generation sources such as capacitors or thermal batteries, and must operate flawlessly on demand. A ceramic piezoelectric crystal is mechanically struck by a mass. The crystal generates 2-3000 volts of energy which passes through a safe/arm switch to a group of spark gap pyro zirconium pumped (PZP) flash lamps. The PZP flash lamps pump a neodymium-doped glass laser rod with the ends polished and parallel. A focusing lens focuses the laser-produced coherent light energy of 1-2 Joules on the end of the fiber-optic cable or directly onto the pyrotechnic material of an attached initiator. The primary application for LOIS in a man-rated life-saving situation is aircrew seat eject systems.
Index Keywords: Aircraft, Military--Seats; Aircraft--Escape Devices; Explosives; Guns; Aircrew Seat Eject Systems; Laser Ordnance Initiation System {LOIS); Ordnance

Authors: Midkiff K.C., Song Y.K., Brett C.E.
Title: Thermal performance and challenges for a seasonal chill energy storage based air-conditioning system
Affiliations: Univ of Alabama, Tuscaloosa, United States
Authors with affiliations: Midkiff, K.C., Univ of Alabama, Tuscaloosa, United States; Song, Y.K., Univ of Alabama, Tuscaloosa, United States; Brett, C.E., Univ of Alabama, Tuscaloosa, United States
Abstract: A 520 kW (thermal) air-conditioning system based on the seasonal storage of cold water in an aquifer has cooled a student recreation building since 1983. Ambient, 18 C water is pumped from supply wells in a water table aquifer, chilled to 6 C in a conventional cooling tower, reinjected and stored in wells in a different region of the aquifer, and withdrawn during warm weather to provide building air conditioning. This system yields high energy efficiency (COP), utility load shifting from summer to winter, and zero chlorofluorocarbon (CFC) emissions. Presented here are the results of 5 years of study of the aquifer storage system, which is the first successful U.S. application. The fraction of the stored chill recovered for air conditioning has ranged from 40% to 85%. The system Coefficient of Performance (COP) has averaged about 5.0. Inadequate building dehumidification in late summer and the need for improved aquifer storage models are also discussed. Heat transfer improvements in water chilling could yield an annual COP approaching 10.
Index Keywords: Aquifers - Energy Storage; Buildings - Cooling Systems; Coefficient of Performance; Cold Water Storage; Thermal Performance; Air Conditioning

Authors: Hayward James D.
Title: Development of laser bonding as a manufacturing process for inner lead bonding
Source title: Proceedings of SPIE - The International Society for Optical Engineering
Affiliations: Advanced Micro Devices Inc.,, Sunnyvale, CA, USA
Authors with affiliations: Hayward, James D., Advanced Micro Devices Inc.,, Sunnyvale, CA, USA
Abstract: The conventional thermo-compression bonding processes for bonding tape-automated-bonding (TAB) leadframes to silicon die has inherent reliability drawbacks due to the high pressures and temperatures necessary to produce a good metallurgical joint. Whether tin- or gold-plated tape is used, the bonding process can cause damage to the underlying structure of the device which results in device failures. The use of a laser source for inner lead bonding (ILB) has the advantage of providing a very localized temperature input to the bonding site with minimal contact force. The resulting mechanical stresses on the device are consequently low and the overall temperature extreme to which the device is subjected is similarly low. Advanced Micro Devices, Inc., has undertaken a program to qualify a gold/tin laser bonded ILB process as a viable manufacturing alternative to thermo-compression bonding. The initial evaluation has defined thresholds for laser input energy necessary to produce a good fillet around the TAB beam and a void-free interface. This is the first necessary step to provide the degree of gold/tin alloying necessary to prevent Kirkendall voiding during subsequent high temperature storage. Among the parameters critical to the bonding process is the wafer bump surface topography. The quality of the bonding process has been monitored using bond strength data and visual examination before and after high temperature storage and temperature cycling tests. The test samples used were 154 and 160 lead production TAB tape and device designs with ≈ 200 μ lead pitch and a 410 lead experimental tape with 102 μ lead pitch.
Index Keywords: Bonding - Laser Applications; Gold/Tin Laser Bonding; Inner Lead Bonding; Laser Bonder Tape/Die Fixture; Integrated Circuit Manufacture

Authors: Korinek Ken, Clark Paul, Wallace Lori, Swensen Eric, Mehta Ben, Smith Richard, Bullard A.G.
Title: Geological screening for compressed air energy storage sites
Affiliations: Burns & McDonnell Engineering Co, Kansas City, United States
Authors with affiliations: Korinek, Ken, Burns & McDonnell Engineering Co, Kansas City, United States; Clark, Paul, Burns & McDonnell Engineering Co, Kansas City, United States; Wallace, Lori, Burns & McDonnell Engineering Co, Kansas City, United States; Swensen, Eric, Burns & McDonnell Engineering Co, Kansas City, United States; Mehta, Ben, Burns & McDonnell Engineering Co, Kansas City, United States; Smith, Richard, Burns & McDonnell Engineering Co, Kansas City, United States; Bullard, A.G., Burns & McDonnell Engineering Co, Kansas City, United States
Abstract: Faced with decreasing capacity margins, many electric utilities are actively investigating their options, including compressed air energy storage technology (CAES), for generating more power. Recently, Burns & McDonnell Engineering, along with Energy Storage and Power Consultants (a turbomachinery consultant), has performed studies for Carolina Power & Light and Union Electric to determine possibilities for building CAES generation. Both studies identified feasible areas through evaluation of geological formations, including hard rock, existing mines, aquifers and depleted gas fields. Burns & McDonnell enhanced the evaluation process through mapping (digitization) of pertinent geologic data, as well as critical facilities of each utility (power plants and transmission routes). The candidate sites were ranked based on turbomachinery train configuration and characteristics; major underground storage parameters; overall plant performance characteristics including heat rate and off-peak energy requirements; and capital cost estimates. This paper discusses the approach and methods used in identifying and ranking possible CAES generation sites for these two utilities, as well as some of the study results.
Index Keywords: Cost Accounting; Geology; CAES Conceptual Models; CAES Electrical System Data; CAES Geological Screening; Compressed Air Energy Storage (CAES) Sites; Compressed Air

Authors: Surampudi S., Shen D.H., Huang C.-K., Deligiannis F., Attia A., Halpert G.
Title: Advances in LiTiS2 cell technology
Affiliations: Jet Propulsion Laboratory, California Institute of Technology, Pasadena, CA 91109, United States
Authors with affiliations: Surampudi, S., Jet Propulsion Laboratory, California Institute of Technology, Pasadena, CA 91109, United States; Shen, D.H., Jet Propulsion Laboratory, California Institute of Technology, Pasadena, CA 91109, United States; Huang, C.-K., Jet Propulsion Laboratory, California Institute of Technology, Pasadena, CA 91109, United States; Deligiannis, F., Jet Propulsion Laboratory, California Institute of Technology, Pasadena, CA 91109, United States; Attia, A., Jet Propulsion Laboratory, California Institute of Technology, Pasadena, CA 91109, United States; Halpert, G., Jet Propulsion Laboratory, California Institute of Technology, Pasadena, CA 91109, United States
Abstract: JPL is involved in a NASA sponsored program to develop ambient temperature secondary cells for future space missions. After several years of research on various cathode materials, titanium disulfide (TiS2) was selected in view of its intrinsic reversibility and high faradaic utilization. In the last two years, efforts have been focussed on improving the cycle life of the system and developing 1 A h cells. Several approaches including the use of mixed solvent electrolytes, the operation of cells at low temperature, and the cycling of cells under different voltage limits, were initially examined to improve the cycle life performance of the LiTiS2 system. Spiral wound 1 A h cells fabricated incorporating the improvements from the above studies have delivered more than 600 cycles at 50% DOD. Work is in progress to identify alternate anode materials that can improve the cycle life of the cells to 1000 cycles at 50% DOD. This paper summarizes the advances made in the LiTiS2 technology at JPL since 1989. © 1991.
Index Keywords: Aerospace Engineering--Energy Storage; Cathode Materials; Cycle Life; Geo-Syn-Spacecraft; Titanium Disulfide; Electric Batteries, Secondary

Authors: Snyder Patricia A., Munger Robert, Hansen Roger W., Rowe Ednor M.
Title: Magnetic circular dichroism measurements of benzene in the 9-eV region with synchrotron radiation
Source title: Proceedings of SPIE - The International Society for Optical Engineering
Affiliations: Florida Atlantic Univ., Boca Raton,, FL, USA
Authors with affiliations: Snyder, Patricia A., Florida Atlantic Univ., Boca Raton,, FL, USA; Munger, Robert, Florida Atlantic Univ., Boca Raton,, FL, USA; Hansen, Roger W., Florida Atlantic Univ., Boca Raton,, FL, USA; Rowe, Ednor M., Florida Atlantic Univ., Boca Raton,, FL, USA
Abstract: The magnetic circular dichroism and absorption spectra of gaseous benzene were measured using the four meter normal incidence monochromator and the Aladdin storage ring at the Synchrotron Radiation Center, University of Wisconsin-Madison. This is an extension of benzene magnetic circular dichroism measurements to higher energies than was previously possible. The magnetic circular dichroism gives additional information about the electronic structure of benzene. An initial interpretation of the magnetic circular dichroism results are presented and compared to proposed assignments. Various methods for extending to higher energies circular dichroism and other measurements that need a source of intense variably polarized electromagnetic radiation are summarized. Plans for extension of measurements to higher energies are also described.
Index Keywords: Electromagnetic Waves; Gases; Magnetic Measurements; SYNCHROTRON RADIATION; Gaseous benzene; Magnetic circular dichroism; Benzene

Authors: Rinderle James R., Subramaniam Bala L.
Title: Automated bond graph modeling and simplification to support design
Source title: American Society of Mechanical Engineers, Dynamic Systems and Control Division (Publication) DSC
Affiliations: Carnegie Mellon Univ, Pittsburgh, United States
Authors with affiliations: Rinderle, James R., Carnegie Mellon Univ, Pittsburgh, United States; Subramaniam, Bala L., Carnegie Mellon Univ, Pittsburgh, United States
Abstract: Designs evolve from a preliminary concept by a process of iterative evaluation and refinement. Every cycle of this process requires the assessment of the extent to which functional specifications have been satisfied. It is hypothesized that an automatic modeling and analysis tool which relates individual component characteristics to device behavior would aid the conceptual designer by facilitating the consideration of more varied alternatives. In this paper we discuss automated modelling in support of design including issues of modeling relevance and model simplification. We propose a framework for automatic modeling based on the modular aggregation of bond graph fragments corresponding to components and connections. Although a component based modeling paradigm is convenient for the designer, a simplistic application of this approach leads to bond graph models which are difficult to analyze and comprehend due to the presence of redundant, irrelevant and circuitous structure and due to a high degree of dependency among energy storage elements. Bond graph simplification methods have been developed that mitigate these problems. These techniques make it possible to identify and eliminate, via junction structure characteristics, assemblies which are kinematically constrained to remain motionless and to greatly reduce dependency among energy storage elements by employing Lagrangian invariance. The application of these methods makes it possible to apply standard equation formulation techniques and results in simple bond graph models which can more easily be interpreted by the designer.
Index Keywords: Mathematical Models; Automated Modeling; Bond Graphs; Design Techniques; Lagrangian Invariance; Mathematical Techniques

Authors: Morales H., Hower N., Cummings U., Golceff P., Li W., Safranek J., Voss J., Wiedemann H.
Title: Vacuum chamber for the 3 GeV SPEAR injector synchrotron
Source title: Conference Record of 1991 IEEE Particle Accelerator Conference
Affiliations: Stanford Synchrotron Radiat Lab, CA, USA
Authors with affiliations: Morales, H., Stanford Synchrotron Radiat Lab, CA, USA; Hower, N., Stanford Synchrotron Radiat Lab, CA, USA; Cummings, U., Stanford Synchrotron Radiat Lab, CA, USA; Golceff, P., Stanford Synchrotron Radiat Lab, CA, USA; Li, W., Stanford Synchrotron Radiat Lab, CA, USA; Safranek, J., Stanford Synchrotron Radiat Lab, CA, USA; Voss, J., Stanford Synchrotron Radiat Lab, CA, USA; Wiedemann, H., Stanford Synchrotron Radiat Lab, CA, USA
Abstract: A 3-GeV booster has been constructed at the Stanford Synchrotron Radiation Laboratory to function as a dedicated, full energy injector into the SPEAR storage ring. Electrons are injected at 120 MeV and accelerated at a cycle rate of 10 Hz to the final energy. The vacuum chamber for this synchrotron has been constructed to avoid eddy current effects due to the rapidly changing magnetic field. The chamber consists of stainless steel tubing of 0.3-mm wall thickness, compressed to an elliptical form, with external stiffening ribs. The suitability of such a vacuum chamber for booster synchrotrons has been tested at cycling rates of up to 15 Hz without intolerable heating or detrimental effects on the magnetic field for the beam.
Index Keywords: Accelerators--Storage Rings; Magnetic Fields; Stainless Steel; Vacuum Technology; SPEAR Injector Synchrotron; Vacuum Chambers; Accelerators, Synchrotron

Authors: Stickland K.F., Ryan K.J.
Title: Building services. Commissioning for longevity
Source title: National Conference Publication - Institution of Engineers, Australia
Affiliations: Rankine & Hill Pty Ltd
Authors with affiliations: Stickland, K.F., Rankine & Hill Pty Ltd; Ryan, K.J., Rankine & Hill Pty Ltd
Abstract: Modern buildings are incorporating technological developments at a rate faster than the training of many of the construction industry technologists. We, as building engineering designers, must therefore be alert to ensure we understand the end results of our designs. The typical modern building must incorporate these developed products and processed materials in order to match the demand for: Minimal energy consumption Maximise flexibility of occupancy Minimise environmental control dependency Ensure that life safety is not compromised Minimising the construction time period Commissioning building systems embracing the developments is too often not adequately planned and executed. It is therefore essential to identify the critical interfacing elements and schedule the individual and combined commissioning needs to ensure occupancy can reasonably take place. Planning must commence during conceptual design phase and ensure identification of the resources, technical qualifications and abilities of the personnel and equipment necessary for successful commissioning.
Index Keywords: Control Systems; Electric Lighting; Energy Conservation; Energy Storage; Office Buildings; Safety; Building Services; Commissioning; Buildings

Authors: Loyselle P.L., Shan X., Cornilsen B.C., Reid M.A.
Title: Raman spectral observation of a 'new phase' observed in nickel electrodes cycled to failure
Affiliations: Michigan Technological University, 1400 Townsend Drive, Houghton, MI 49931, United States; NASA Lewis Research Center, Cleveland, OH 44135, United States
Authors with affiliations: Loyselle, P.L., Michigan Technological University, 1400 Townsend Drive, Houghton, MI 49931, United States; Shan, X., Michigan Technological University, 1400 Townsend Drive, Houghton, MI 49931, United States; Cornilsen, B.C., Michigan Technological University, 1400 Townsend Drive, Houghton, MI 49931, United States; Reid, M.A., NASA Lewis Research Center, Cleveland, OH 44135, United States
Abstract: A 'new phase' is reported in nickel electrodes from NiH2 boilerplate cells which were cycled to failure in electrolyte of variable KOH concentration (21-36%). Raman spectra clearly show the presence of this phase, and these spectra have been used to estimate the amounts present on these electrodes. Ten of twelve electrodes examined contain this new phase. The cycle life at higher KOH concentrations (31 and 36%) was greatly reduced, and nickel electrodes from these cells exhibited extensive amounts of this new phase. The presence of this 'new phase' correlates with cell failure defined by low end of discharge voltages. It is proposed that the lowered capacity and failure of these electrodes was caused by loss of active mass and formation of a phase with reduced electrochemical activity. These results indicate that formation of this new phase is accelerated at higher KOH concentrations. © 1991.
Index Keywords: Aerospace Engineering--Energy Storage; Electrochemistry--Aerospace Applications; Active Mass; Discharge Depth; Nickel-Hydrogen Cells; Electric Batteries, Secondary

Authors: Dwersteg B., Enderlein G., Korber W., Matheisen A., Moller W.-D., Proch D., Renken D., Sekutowicz J.
Title: Status of the superconducting cavity program for HERA
Source title: Conference Record of 1991 IEEE Particle Accelerator Conference
Authors with affiliations: Dwersteg, B.; Enderlein, G.; Korber, W.; Matheisen, A.; Moller, W.-D.; Proch, D.; Renken, D.; Sekutowicz, J.
Abstract: Supeconducting 500 MHz cavities have been developed for the purpose of increasing the electron beam energy of the HERA storage ring. The system consists of 16 cavities, 8 cryostats, and an LHe distribution line. The authors report on the test of the components and give first results of operating experience.
Index Keywords: Cryostats; Electron Beams; Superconducting Devices; HERA Storage Ring; Superconducting Cavities; Accelerators

Authors: Lucas G.M., Singh M.P., McCloskey T.H.
Title: Compressed-air energy storage mechanical design challenges: low-pressure expander
Affiliations: Dresser-Rand Steam Turbine, Motor & Generator Div, Wellsville, United States
Authors with affiliations: Lucas, G.M., Dresser-Rand Steam Turbine, Motor & Generator Div, Wellsville, United States; Singh, M.P., Dresser-Rand Steam Turbine, Motor & Generator Div, Wellsville, United States; McCloskey, T.H., Dresser-Rand Steam Turbine, Motor & Generator Div, Wellsville, United States
Abstract: The first U.S. compressed-air energy storage (CAES) plant was ordered by Alabama Electric Cooperative, Inc. (AEC) in 1988. This facility will be capable of generating 110 MW at full output and will include enough underground air storage to permit 26 hours of generation at 100 MW. The solution-mined storage reservoir is being constructed in the McIntosh salt dome. It will have a volume of 19 million ft3 (538,020m3). The plant is scheduled to begin commercial service in 1991. Dresser-Rand was selected by AEC to provide the turbomachinery and the overall plant controls for this facility. The purpose of this paper is to provide a brief overview of the entire CAES turbomachinery train and also to share some insight into the particular design challenges posed by the low-pressure-expander. Discussion is limited to the mechanical design of the expander. The topics covered include the disc-cavity cooling system, cooled first-stage nozzle, flowpath transient thermal-stress analysis, characterization of the material low-cycle fatigue properties, and life prediction for critical components.
Index Keywords: Computer Software - Applications; CAES Machinery Train; Compressed Air-Energy Storage (CAES) Mechanical Design; First Stage Nozzle Cooling; Low-Pressure Expander; Secondary Flow System Analysis; Software Package CADAM; Compressed Air

Authors: Ito K., Yokoyama R., Shiba T.
Title: Optimal operation of a cogeneration plant in combination with electric heat pumps
Source title: American Society of Mechanical Engineers, International Gas Turbine Institute (Publication) IGTI
Affiliations: Osaka Prefectural Univ, Sakai, Japan
Authors with affiliations: Ito, K., Osaka Prefectural Univ, Sakai, Japan; Yokoyama, R., Osaka Prefectural Univ, Sakai, Japan; Shiba, T., Osaka Prefectural Univ, Sakai, Japan
Abstract: An operational problem is discussed for a gas turbine cogeneration plant in combination with a heat pump/thermal storage system that utilizes time-of-use pricing of the electrical utility. An optimal planning method is presented by which the operational policy of constituent equipment is determined so as to minimize the daily operational cost. An algorithm is proposed to solve this optimization problem efficiently by combining the dynamic programming method with the mixed-integer programming one. A case study is carried out to investigate the effect of introducing a heat pump system into a cogeneration plant.
Index Keywords: Computer Programming--Algorithms; Energy Storage; Heat Pump Systems; Heating--Heat Storage; Optimization; Electric Heat Pump Systems; Thermal Storage Systems; Cogeneration Plants

Authors: Husler Robert O, Weir Thomas J.
Title: Advanced technologies for maintenance of electrical systems and equipment at the Savannah river site defense waste processing facility (U)
Affiliations: Westinghouse Savannah River Co, Aiken, United States
Authors with affiliations: Husler, Robert O, Westinghouse Savannah River Co, Aiken, United States; Weir, Thomas J., Westinghouse Savannah River Co, Aiken, United States
Abstract: An enhanced maintenance program is being established to characterize and monitor cables, components, and process response at the Savannah River Site, Defense Waste Processing Facility. This facility was designed and constructed to immobilize the radioactive waste currently stored in underground storage tanks and is expected to begin operation in 1993. The plant is initiating the program to baseline and monitor instrument and control (I&C) and electrical equipment, remote process equipment, embedded instrument and control cables, and in-cell jumper cables used in the facility. This program is based on the electronic characterization and diagnostic capabilities of the ECAD System 1000, which was modified to include process response analysis and to meet rigid Department of Energy equipment requirements. The system consists of computer-automated, state-of-the-art electronics. The data that are gathered are stored in a computerized database for analysis, trending, and troubleshooting. It is anticipated that the data which are gathered and trended will aid in life extension for the facility.
Index Keywords: Maintenance; Radioactive Wastes - Vitrification; Bad Coax Connectors; Enhanced Maintenance Program; Predictive Maintenance Program; Radwaste Vitrification Facility; Savannah River Site Defense Waste Processing Facility; Radioactive Wastes

Authors: Hablutzel Jurg
Title: On the track of natural laws
Affiliations: Produktbereich Sulzer Chemtech, Switzerland
Authors with affiliations: Hablutzel, Jurg, Produktbereich Sulzer Chemtech, Switzerland
Abstract: The huge detectors which are used for research into the basic structure of matter at CERN (European Organization for Nuclear Research) are named Aleph, Opal, L3 and Delphi. Their task is to detect Z° particles (Fig.1) in the large electron-positron storage ring (LEP). It is intended to increase the rating of the LEP from 50 Giga-electron-Volts (GeV) to 90 GeV, so that W particles can be produced and investigated. Superconductivity is to be exploited in order to decrease loss of energy in the high frequency acceleration cavities which are to be installed. Sulzer is to supply cryoplants to cool these cavities.
Index Keywords: Accelerators--Applications; Physics--Solid State; Leptons; Nuclei; Quarks; Materials Science

Authors: Schauder C., Mehta H.
Title: Vector analysis and control of advanced static VAR compensators
Affiliations: Westinghouse Electric Corp, United States
Authors with affiliations: Schauder, C., Westinghouse Electric Corp, United States; Mehta, H., Westinghouse Electric Corp, United States
Abstract: The Advanced Static VAR Compensator (ASVC) is based on the principle that a self-commutating static inverter can be connected between three-phase ac power lines and an energy-storage device, such as an inductor or capacitor, and controlled to draw mainly reactive current from the lines. This capability is analogous to that of the rotating synchronous condenser and it can be used in a similar way for the dynamic compensation of power transmission systems, providing voltage support, increased transient stability, and improved damping. The dynamic behaviour of the ASVC has been studied in depth. This paper presents a simiplified mathematical model of the ASVC that has made it possible to derive the transfer functions needed for control system synthesis. The resulting control system designs are briefly outlined and further analysis is presented to show the behaviour of the ASVC when the line voltage is unbalanced or distorted. The analysis is based on a vectorial transformation of variables, first described by Park for ac machine analysis, and later, using complex numbers, by Lyon in the theory of instantaneous symmetrical components.
Index Keywords: Control Equipment, Electric; Electric Power Systems--Performance; Harmonic Generation; Harmonic Distortion; SVC (Static VAR Compensators); Voltage-Sourced Inverters; Electric Inverters

Authors: Iwase Y., Takamura H., Urata K., Ohmori M.
Title: The uniformity and reliability of CdTe array radiation detectors
Authors with affiliations: Iwase, Y.; Takamura, H.; Urata, K.; Ohmori, M.
Abstract: A 90-element CdTe array radiation detector was fabricated. An average energy resolution of 6.9 keV and a count rate variation for each detector of less than 11% for 60 keV γ-rays were achieved. Time-dependent instability was obtained with a count rate drift of less than 1% within 1 h after bias application. It is believed that these detectors can be applied to sensors of X- and γ-ray imaging. To achieve these characteristics, a large grain crystal, above 13 mm square in this case, with homogenous distribution of crystal defects, and a reproducible fabrication process and assembly technique, which were mainly accomplished by utilizing machine controlling, were applied. Temperature cycling, humidity cycling, thermal shock, hermetic seal, mechanical shock, vibration fatigue, natural fall, and low temperature storage tests indicated no major problems with the detector under normal conditions. The mean time to failure investigated by the high temperature operating test was estimated to be more than 1 × 106 h at room temperature.
Index Keywords: Crystals - Defects; Gamma Rays; Radiation Detectors - Reliability; Semiconducting Cadmium Compounds; X-Rays; Array Radiation Detectors; Cadmium Telluride Radiation Detectors; Detector MTTF Estimation; Radiation Detectors

Authors: Eyssa Y.M., Huang X., Boom R.W.
Title: Design considerations for high temperature (high-Tc) superconductive magnetic energy storage (SMES) systems
Affiliations: Univ of Wisconsin - Madison, Madison, United States
Authors with affiliations: Eyssa, Y.M., Univ of Wisconsin - Madison, Madison, United States; Huang, X., Univ of Wisconsin - Madison, Madison, United States; Boom, R.W., Univ of Wisconsin - Madison, Madison, United States
Abstract: Practical high temperature (high-Tc) superconductors present new opportunities for improved SMES units, in particular small sizes. At this time, it is important to consider the new design issues associated with utilizing such brittle superconducting materials at 77 K. On the positive side: liquid nitrogen (LN2) cooling would significantly reduce the daily refrigeration energy requirements as a percent of stored energy; and the high specific heats at 77 K (compared to 4.2 K) provide more intrinsic stability against normalizing heat pulses. Negative factors are: the conductor is extremely brittle and requires special structural considerations to limit tensile stresses; the high stabilizer resistivity at 77 K (compared to 4.2 K) increases conductor heating during normalities and makes full stability an expensive cooling option; and the propagation velocity of normal zones is significantly small at 77 K. We conclude that high-Tc superconductors offer the possibility of smaller (0.1 to 10 MWh) and more efficient SMES units.
Index Keywords: Cryogenic liquids; Design; Energy storage; Heat transfer; Refrigerating machinery; Specific heat of solids; Stability; Stresses; Superconducting magnets; Superconductive magnetic energy storage (SMES) system; High temperature superconductors

Authors: Vaidyanathan H., Earl M.W., Kirkendall T.D.
Title: Physical and chemical analysis of a NH2 cell
Affiliations: COMSAT Laboratories, 22300 Comsat Drive, Clarksburg, MD 20871-9475, United States
Authors with affiliations: Vaidyanathan, H., COMSAT Laboratories, 22300 Comsat Drive, Clarksburg, MD 20871-9475, United States; Earl, M.W., COMSAT Laboratories, 22300 Comsat Drive, Clarksburg, MD 20871-9475, United States; Kirkendall, T.D., COMSAT Laboratories, 22300 Comsat Drive, Clarksburg, MD 20871-9475, United States
Abstract: A cycled aerospace nickelhydrogen (NiH2) cell was subjected to destructive physical analysis to determine the reason for a capacity loss after 5967 cycles at 60% depth of discharge. The positive plates in the cell were analyzed in terms of chemical composition, active material utilization, charge efficiency and thickness increase. The microstructure of a cross section of the positive plate was determined by backscattered electron image analysis. The results suggest that the capacity loss in the cell is caused by low charge acceptance and low active material utilization at the positive plate. The oxidized nickel species content of the positive plate increased due to corrosion of the nickel sintered skeleton. This appears to circumvent the orderly reaction of the active material. Microstructural analysis has indicated that a new phase of active material is formed with cycling. © 1991.
Index Keywords: Aerospace Engineering--Energy Storage; Electric Batteries--Service Life; Aerospace Cells; Cycling Voltammetry; Nickel-Hydrogen Cells; Positive Plates; Electric Batteries, Secondary

Authors: Tsutsui Y., Emura K., Miura F., Takada H., Tomimasu T.
Title: The superconducting compact storage ring NIJI-III
Source title: Conference Record of 1991 IEEE Particle Accelerator Conference
Authors with affiliations: Tsutsui, Y.; Emura, K.; Miura, F.; Takada, H.; Tomimasu, T.
Abstract: NIJI-III is a compact electron storage ring using superconducting dipole magnets. It has been in operation since August 1990. The peak wavelength of the synchrotron radiation spectrum is about 5 angstrom, which is set for X-ray lithography. As the result of commissioning, stored beam currents of 400 mA at the injection energy and of 50 mA at 600 MeV were obtained. The lattice performance, including the electron beam wobbling (electron undulating), has been investigated and the design specifications have been nearly achieved.
Index Keywords: Lithography--X-Ray; Superconducting Magnets; Synchrotron Radiation; Dipole Magnets; NIJI-III Storage Ring; Accelerators

Authors: Welch James J., Xu Zhong Xiong
Title: Low loss parameter for new CESR electrostatic separators
Source title: Conference Record of 1991 IEEE Particle Accelerator Conference
Affiliations: Lab of Nucl Studies, Cornell Univ,, Ithaca, NY, USA
Authors with affiliations: Welch, James J., Lab of Nucl Studies, Cornell Univ,, Ithaca, NY, USA; Xu, Zhong Xiong, Lab of Nucl Studies, Cornell Univ,, Ithaca, NY, USA
Abstract: A new separator has been designed for which bench measurements on a full scale mockup indicate one can expect a loss parameter of only 0.123 V/pC--about one quarter the value for the existing separators. A factor of two reduction came from tapering the ends. The other factor of two came from the unique ground electrode structure, which serves to keep electromagnetic energy close to the beam. At the ends of the separator, the taper and ground electrode are blended together in an unusual surface.
Index Keywords: Accelerators - Storage Rings; Particle Accelerators; Particle Beams; Beam Energy Loss; Separators

Authors: Lin Liu
Title: Injection into the LNLS UVX electron storage ring
Source title: Conference Record of 1991 IEEE Particle Accelerator Conference
Affiliations: Lab Nacional de Luz Sincrotron, Campinas, Brazil
Authors with affiliations: Lin, Liu, Lab Nacional de Luz Sincrotron, Campinas, Brazil
Abstract: For injection into the 1.15-GeV electron storage ring UVX, a beam from a linear accelerator, MAIRA, is used. The electrons are injected and accumulated at low energy (100 MeV) until the nominal current of 100 mA is reached and then are ramped to the nominal energy. A study on a conventional injection scheme has been carried out. Two injection modes are investigated: injection with the phase ellipse parameters matched and mismatched to the ring's acceptance. The mismatched mode is optimized to fit the maximum of the injected beam into the acceptance.
Index Keywords: Accelerators - Storage Rings; Accelerators, Linear; Injected Beam Evolution; Injection Time; Mismatched Injection Mode; UVX Electron Storage Ring; Accelerators

Authors: Selph F., Massoletti D.
Title: Operating experience with the ALS linac
Source title: Conference Record of 1991 IEEE Particle Accelerator Conference
Authors with affiliations: Selph, F.; Massoletti, D.
Abstract: The linac injector for the Advanced Light Source (ALS) at LBL (Lawrence Berkeley Laboratory) was recently put into operation. Energy is 50 MeV, and frequency is 3 GHz. The electron gun delivers up to 6 nC in a 3.0-ns bunch at 120 kV. A train of bunches is injected into a 1-Hz booster and accelerated to 1.5 GHz for storage ring injection. A magnetic analysis system is used for optimizing the linac. Measured beam properties from the gun and after acceleration in the linac are described.
Index Keywords: Accelerators - Beam Injection; Accelerators - Storage Rings; Accelerators, Linear; Electron Guns; Signal Processing - Digital Techniques; Advanced Light Source; ALS Linac; S-Band Buncher; Subharmonic Bunchers; Synchrotron Radiation

Authors: Shidara Tetsuo, Honma Hiroyuki, Nakao Katsumi, Anami Shozo, Asami Akira
Title: Performance test of a 65-MW klystron unit relevant to the microwave source upgrade of the KEK 2.5-GeV linac
Authors with affiliations: Shidara, Tetsuo; Honma, Hiroyuki; Nakao, Katsumi; Anami, Shozo; Asami, Akira
Abstract: There is a plan to upgrade the Japan National Laboratory for High-Energy Physics (KEK) 2.5-GeV linear accelerator (LINAC) microwave source, which affects both the asymmetric B-factory two-ring collider project and the 3-GeV operation of the Photon Factory storage ring. The authors describe the upgrading of the microwave source as well as performance tests of a test station which was established in order to confirm the feasibility of this upgrade. The required increase in the injection LINAC energy from the present 2.5 GeV to 4.25 GeV necessitates the replacement of the 30-MW klystrons with new 65-MW units. Since a total modification of the klystron modulator would be expensive, the output voltage and average power of the modulator have remained unchanged. An increase in the klystron beam voltage could only be obtained by increasing the pulse transformer step-up ratio from 1:12 to 1:15. A new test station using a 65-MW klystron was established to confirm stable operation of the modified unit. An output power of 58 MW with a 1-μs duration was successfully generated in a preliminary test.
Index Keywords: Accelerators--Storage Rings; Electron Tubes, Klystron--Performance; Microwaves--Applications; Modulators--Applications; Physics--High Energy; 2.5-GeV Linac; B-Factory Two-Ring Collider Project; Japan National Laboratory; Microwave Source Upgrade; Photon Factory Storage; Accelerators, Linear

Authors: Herzog Claus, Fryszman Amilcar
Title: Perspectives for the utilization of renewable fuels in Latin America
Affiliations: Mercedes-Benz, Brazil
Authors with affiliations: Herzog, Claus, Mercedes-Benz, Brazil; Fryszman, Amilcar, Mercedes-Benz, Brazil
Abstract: This paper gives a broad view over the state-of-the-art in the field of alternative sources of energy for automotive vehicles, mainly those sources whose generation, storage and transportation are made in a renewable way. Whenever possible, focus is made on the specific aspects concerned to the technological, environmental and economical situation of Latin America. The renewable fuels discussed are ethanol, methanol, vegetable oils, biogas, hydrogen and chemical batteries. Direct forms of convertion of solar energy into electricity are also discussed.
Index Keywords: Biogas; Ethanol; Hydrogen; Methanol; SOLAR ENERGY; Vegetable Oils; Renewable Fuels; Automotive Fuels

Authors: Echigo R.
Title: Radiation enhanced/controlled phenomena of heat and mass transfer in porous media
Affiliations: Tokyo Inst of Technology, Tokyo, Japan
Authors with affiliations: Echigo, R., Tokyo Inst of Technology, Tokyo, Japan
Abstract: The paper presents the basic aspect of the effective energy conversion between the flowing gas enthalpy and the thermal radiation, and the transient heat and mass transfer phenomena have been discussed with the phase changes (condensation and evaporation) based on the experimental evidence to reproduce the temperature profile with high accuracy. The studies have been extended to the reciprocating flow system, wherein the energy storage and recovery in the regenerating heat exchanger of Stirling cycle engine are predicted and also the super adiabatic combustion is modelled to demonstrate the enhanced combuation for extremely low heating value mixture by as low as 80 kJ/Nm3. Final study is concerned with the combustion phenomena in porous media, in which the effect of thermal radiation is undertaken. As a result, the combustion mechanism has been clarified and shows the extremely high loaded combustion extended up to more than 105 kW/m3 (approximately 108 kcal/m3h).
Index Keywords: Combustion - Mathematical Models; Energy Conversion; Mass Transfer - Radiation Effects; Porous Materials - Transport Properties; Thermodynamics - Stirling Cycle; Enthalpy; Reciprocating Flow System; Thermal Radiation; Heat Transfer

Authors: El-Bakry M.A., El-Hagry M.T.
Title: Multiprocessor structure for managing multi-nature energy sources
Authors with affiliations: El-Bakry, M.A.; El-Hagry, M.T.
Abstract: A multiprocessor structure is proposed to manage the operation of an integrated power generating system, which includes a photovoltaic generator, a disel generator set, and storage batteries. Economic and ecological considerations are the main factors which determine the choice of the mode of operation of the available unit. The multiprocessor maintains the operation of the whole system as an uninterruptible power supply with minimum total running cost. The proposed multiprocessor structure is not restricted to specific numbers or types of energy sources, but can be applied to any number of energy sources that differ in nature and operation policy. The system considered is suitable for generating power far from a power network.
Index Keywords: Electric power generation; Energy management; Energy resources; Energy sources; Integrated power generation; Multiprocessors; Uninterruptible power supply; Multiprocessing systems

Authors: Aebli E., Schulze R.M., Vogel M., Trajkovic D., Zichy J.A., Horvath I.
Title: Test of forced flow cooled, horizontally mounted current leads
Affiliations: Paul Scherrer Inst, Wurenlingen, Switzerland
Authors with affiliations: Aebli, E., Paul Scherrer Inst, Wurenlingen, Switzerland; Schulze, R.M., Paul Scherrer Inst, Wurenlingen, Switzerland; Vogel, M., Paul Scherrer Inst, Wurenlingen, Switzerland; Trajkovic, D., Paul Scherrer Inst, Wurenlingen, Switzerland; Zichy, J.A., Paul Scherrer Inst, Wurenlingen, Switzerland; Horvath, I., Paul Scherrer Inst, Wurenlingen, Switzerland
Abstract: Recently several large, forced flow cooled magnets have been successfully tested and operated over longer time periods. It is planned for the next generation of large fusion reactor- and energy storage-magnets to operate at currents in excess of 20 kA, and to cool with supercritical helium. In order to reduce the required cooling power, and to alleviate the severe conditions on the design of vapor cooled current leads, a test was performed on a pair of horizontally mounted 1 kA current leads cooled by forced flow helium. This paper describes the current lead, the experimental setup, and the measurements. The tests, performed in the SULTAN test facility, showed that in the investigated pressure range of 5 to 10 bar a mass flow rate of less than 0.06 g/s per kA is needed to operate safely such a current lead. The results are compared to the heat loss through a vertically mounted, vapor cooled current lead.

Title: Intrabeam scattering in the Fermilab antiproton accumulator
Source title: Conference Record of 1991 IEEE Particle Accelerator Conference
Authors with affiliations: Bhat, C.M.; Marriner, J.
Abstract: The growth rate of the horizontal and vertical emittance in the accumulator ring at Fermilab has been measured with 97.8 × 1010 antiprotons starting with a completely cooled beam. It is found that the emittance growth rate cannot be fully explained by the existing intrabeam scattering calculations done including the detailed lattice of the storage ring.

Authors: Siuru Bill
Title: Electric vehicles. Getting the lead out
Affiliations: Mechanical Engineering CIME, New York, United States
Authors with affiliations: Siuru, Bill, Mechanical Engineering CIME, New York, United States
Abstract: Purpose-built electric vehicles have improved safety, performance, and creature comforts compared to cars that have been converted to electric power. However, they cannot become viable competition until their economics are more in line with internal combustion cars. Purpose-built vehicles do not suffer from the problems that often occur when internal combustion engines are converted to electric propulsion. Most of the new electric cars are quite small; they are intended for urban commuting rather than cross-country touring or cargo hauling. Even so, they are more than basic transportation modules.
Index Keywords: Automobiles--Energy Resources; Experimental Hybrid; Extended Range Vehicle; Storage Battery Vehicles

Authors: Demes G.L., Buskirk E.R., Alpert S.S., Loomis J.L.
Title: Energy turnover and heat exchange in mature lean and obese Zucker rats acutely exposed to three environmental temperatures for 24 hours
Affiliations: 119 Noll Laboratory, The Pennsylvania State University, University Park, PA 16802, United States
Authors with affiliations: Demes, G.L., 119 Noll Laboratory, The Pennsylvania State University, University Park, PA 16802, United States; Buskirk, E.R., 119 Noll Laboratory, The Pennsylvania State University, University Park, PA 16802, United States; Alpert, S.S., 119 Noll Laboratory, The Pennsylvania State University, University Park, PA 16802, United States; Loomis, J.L., 119 Noll Laboratory, The Pennsylvania State University, University Park, PA 16802, United States
Abstract: Differences between lean (FA/?, n=6) and obese (fa/fa, n=6) mature male Zucker rats energy turnover and heat storage were compared during a 24-h period when the animals were exposed to ambient temperatures of 30, 15 or 5°C. Energy turnover was examined through measurements of heat production rates via indirect calorimetry and heat loss rates via direct calorimetry. Heat storage rates were calculated as the difference between heat production and heat loss rates. Predicted heat storage rates were also calculated as the product of the change in core temperature and the calculated specific heat of the animal based on body composition (carcass) analysis. A minimal heat loss rate was determined for each animal representing a period of least activity. Various comparisons were made: between groups (lean/obese), temperature (30, 15? 5°C), calorimetry method (indirect/direct), period (light/dark), heat storage (experimental/predicted), and minimal heat loss. Immediately before a test, pretest weight and colonic temperature were obtained. Then, the animal was placed into the calorimeter chamber and remained there unrestrained for 24h. Normal light/dark periods were maintained. On removal from the calorimeter, core temperature and body weight measurements were again obtained. Upon completion of all tests, body composition was analyzed and surface area determined. Energy turnover, i.e. both heat production and heat loss in the lean and obese animals differed among the 30, 15 and 5°C exposures. The obese animals had relatively greater heat production rate and heat loss rate (kcal/day or kcal/kg(FFM)/day than the lean animals at 30, 15 and 5°C. But, on a relative basis, the increments in heat production in the cold environments were greater for the lean animals. Both the lean and obese animals tended to be more active during the dark period when at 30°C, but the difference was less at 15°C and even less at 5°C. Experimental heat storage rates did not differ significantly from predicted values at any of the temperatures with the possible exception of the obese animals at 5°C. It was concluded that the mature obese Zucker rats had no major discernible defect in thermoregulation as revealed by rates of heat production and loss, although three of the obese rats did elicit a drop in colonic temperature during exposure to 5°C, i.e. their excessive subcutaneous adiposity and thermal insulation did not prevent a fall in colonic temperature. A defect in thermoregulation leading to development of obesity in the Zucker rat may occur early in life (perhaps associated with their thermogenic response to feeding), but may be compensated for in the mature animal. What subsequently may be revealed in the elderly obese animal remains unknown.
Author Keywords: Cold exposure; Heat exchange; Heat loss; Heat production; Zucker rats
Index Keywords: animal experiment; animal model; animal tissue; article; body composition; calorimetry; cold exposure; core temperature; environmental temperature; heat exchange; heat loss; lean body weight; male; metabolism; nonhuman; obesity; priority journal; rat; thermogenesis; thermoregulation; Analysis of Variance; Animal; Body Composition; Body Surface Area; Body Temperature Regulation; Body Weight; Calorimetry; Circadian Rhythm; Energy Metabolism; Male; Obesity; Rats; Rats, Zucker; Support, U.S. Gov't, P.H.S.; Temperature

Authors: Cao Y., Faghri A.
Title: Study of thermal energy storage systems with conjugate turbulent forced convection
Source title: American Society of Mechanical Engineers, Heat Transfer Division, (Publication) HTD
Affiliations: Wright State Univ, Dayton, United States
Authors with affiliations: Cao, Y., Wright State Univ, Dayton, United States; Faghri, A., Wright State Univ, Dayton, United States
Abstract: A phase-change energy storage module with a turbulent transport fluid was studied numerically. The forced convection due to the turbulent transport fluid was solved with the k-ε model and coupled with the phase-change solution in the phase-change material (PCM). The numerical results for the turbulent model as well as the phase-change model were first compared separately with turbulent experimental correlations and a purely phase-change solution in the literature, then conjugate numerical calculations for the energy storage module with different cases were conducted. A correlation for the energy storage capacity was derived and its empirical constants were determined by the numerical data. The correlation provided a reference for the module design and parameter optimization.

Source title: Conference Record of 1991 IEEE Particle Accelerator Conference
Affiliations: Brookhaven Nat Lab, Upton, NY, USA
Authors with affiliations: Mane, S.R., Brookhaven Nat Lab, Upton, NY, USA
Abstract: An approximate method that deals with both parent spin resonances and strong synchrotron tune modulation is presented. This approach addresses the problem of slow convergence of the power series expansion for the synchrotron sidebands and may provide a starting point for the eventual development of a suitably fast algorithm to deal with the problem of strong synchrotron tune modulations.
Index Keywords: Particle Accelerators; Physics - High Energy; Synchrotron Radiation; Spin Resonances; Synchrotron; Accelerators, Synchrotron

Authors: Wang X.Q., Jackson G.
Title: Longitudinal instability in the Fermilab accumulator during slow transition crossing
Source title: Conference Record of 1991 IEEE Particle Accelerator Conference
Authors with affiliations: Wang, X.Q.; Jackson, G.
Abstract: Recently the Fermilab Accumulator was modified for use in a medium energy experiment studying charmonium states. The experiment required a circulating antiproton beam with momenta between 6.7 GeV/c and 3.7 GeV/c. During accumulator transition crossing with this coasting beam, longitudinal instability was observed with a resistive wall current monitor and a dedicated longitudinal Schottky detector. Results are presented of measurements in which longitudinal coherent signals and emittance growth were observed. The data are compared to the predictions of a multiparticle computer simulation.
Index Keywords: Accelerators - Storage Rings; Particle Accelerators; Particle Beams - Stability; Antiproton Storage Ring; Fermilab Accumulator; Accelerators

Authors: Iliev A.I., Senichev Y.V.
Title: Racetrack lattices for low-medium-energy synchrotrons
Source title: Conference Record of 1991 IEEE Particle Accelerator Conference
Authors with affiliations: Iliev, A.I.; Senichev, Y.V.
Abstract: We have described an alternative transitionless lattice for low-medium-energy synchrotrons, which have a racetrack shape, and a large enough dynamic aperture. We have shown that a lattice based on beta-modulation is a good solution for medium-energy synchrotrons, and a lattice with modulations of the beta-function together with a missing magnet scheme is most suitable for low-energy rings.
Index Keywords: Accelerators, Synchrotron - Storage Rings; Particle Accelerators; Accelerator Lattice; Beta Functions; Synchrotron; Accelerators, Synchrotron

Title: Conference Record of the 1991 IEEE Particle Accelerator Conference
Source title: Conference Record of 1991 IEEE Particle Accelerator Conference
Abstract: Proceedings represents 1 of 5 parts, incorporating 212 papers. The latter are grouped according to the following subjects: accelerator technology; superconducting components; magnets; low- and medium-energy accelerators and rings; high-energy accelerators and colliders; beam dynamics; acceleration methods; linear accelerators; pulsed power devices; and power supplies. Topics covered include: light sources, optics, particle beams, electrostatic separators, crystals, laser beams, plasmas, SSC (superconducting super collider), electron guns, microtrons, synchrotron radiation, hadrons, protons, positrons, wake fields, induction accelerators, tevatrons, betatrons, beam-beam interactions, beam bunching, accelerator lattices, storage rings, beam extraction, klystrons, and linear accelerators.
