Authors: Reichelt H., Draffehn J., Ruediger St., Gross U., Lederer S., Sauer Silvia, Baum Rosemarie
Title: Blood substitutes made on the basis of perfluorocarbons inhibit intracellular energy generation
Source title: Biomaterials, Artificial Cells, and Immobilization Biotechnology
Affiliations: Military Medical Acad, Bad Saarow, Germany
Authors with affiliations: Reichelt, H., Military Medical Acad, Bad Saarow, Germany; Draffehn, J., Military Medical Acad, Bad Saarow, Germany; Ruediger, St., Military Medical Acad, Bad Saarow, Germany; Gross, U., Military Medical Acad, Bad Saarow, Germany; Lederer, S., Military Medical Acad, Bad Saarow, Germany; Sauer, Silvia, Military Medical Acad, Bad Saarow, Germany; Baum, Rosemarie, Military Medical Acad, Bad Saarow, Germany
Abstract: Although perfluorocarbons are chemically inert, toxic reactions are observed on using them as fluorocarbon emulsions in blood substitutes. Studies on long-term survival after blood replacement with blood substitutes in conscious rats revealed that the animals showed pathobiochemical changes and died after 6-12 hours despite a high intraarterial oxygen pressure. These changes indicate a disturbance of intracellular energy generation, which is characterized by a decrease in ATP, and an increase in ADP, inorganic phosphate and lactate. Impurities in the perfluorocarbons and surfactant effects were excluded as causes of this disturbance. The authors propose the following two hypotheses: 1. storage of perfluorocarbons in mitochondrial membranes, which leads to an increased permeability of these membranes to protons, reduces the electrochemical potential necessary for synthesizing ATP by the proton-transporting ATPase; and 2. formation of free radicals by blood substitutes inhibits electron transport by cytochromes within the respiratory chain and leads to an increase in NADH and lactate despite increased oxygen concentration in the blood.
Index Keywords: Biochemistry--Metabolism; Drug Products--Toxicity; Fluorohydrocarbons--Electrochemistry; Fluorohydrocarbons--Medical Applications; Electrochemical Metabolism; Fluorocarbon-Based Blood Substitutes; Free Radical Formation; Intracellular Energy Generation Inhibitors; Perfluorocarbon Emulsion Toxicity; Biomaterials

Authors: Benson Richard C.
Title: Plate tenting with a one-sided constraint
Affiliations: Univ of Rochester, Rochester, United States
Authors with affiliations: Benson, Richard C., Univ of Rochester, Rochester, United States
Abstract: This paper concerns the loads and deflections of a 'tented' plate. A concentrated load pushes the plate transversely away from a rigid surface. Bending rigidity, inplane tension, foundation stiffness, and weight all act to draw the plate back down to the surface. The deflected region of the tent is assumed to have an ellipsoidal shape, the extent of which is a variable of the problem. Interfacial pressure between the plate and surface is redistributed, after tenting, into a concentrated load at the 'tent pole' and a line load along the contour separating contact and noncontact. The problem is analyzed using energy minimization, and approximate, closed-form expressions are obtained for tent dimensions and interfacial loads. Predictions for the tentpole force are compared to experiment and found to be in good agreement.
Index Keywords: Data Storage, Magnetic - Tape; Mechanics - Mathematical Models; Energy Minimization; Foundation Stiffness; Interfacial Pressure; Plane Tenting; Tentpole Force; Plates

Authors: Murphy J.B., Biscardi R., Bittner J., Blumberg L.N., Bozoki E., Desmond E., Halama H., Heese R., Hsieh H., Keane J., Kramer S., Nawrocky R., Romano T., Rothman J., Schuchman J., Thomas M., Wang J.M., Krishnaswamy J., Louie W., Rose R.
Title: Commissioning of the phase I Superconducting X-ray Lithography Source (SXLS) at BNL
Authors with affiliations: Murphy, J.B.; Biscardi, R.; Bittner, J.; Blumberg, L.N.; Bozoki, E.; Desmond, E.; Halama, H.; Heese, R.; Hsieh, H.; Keane, J.; Kramer, S.; Nawrocky, R.; Romano, T.; Rothman, J.; Schuchman, J.; Thomas, M.; Wang, J.M.; Krishnaswamy, J.; Louie, W.; Rose, R.
Abstract: A report on the performance of Phase I of the Superconducting X-Ray Lithography Source (SXLS) storage ring project at the Brookhaven National Laboratory (BNL) is presented. In Phase I, low field iron dipoles (B = 1.1 T) are being used to study the ring at energies of 200 MeV and below. The basic design parameters of the Phase I SXLS ring are listed and the Twiss parameters are shown. The Phase I ring was commissioned during the fall of 1990 and the design current of 500 ma has been exceeded. The vacuum system and lifetime, the RF system, and the diagnostics are discussed. Ion clearing electrodes have been essential to storing large currents (I > 300 ma) in the ring.
Index Keywords: Electrodes--Applications; Lithography--X-Ray; Radio Transmission--Applications; Superconducting Devices--Applications; Vacuum Technology--Applications; Brookhaven National Laboratory (BNL); Clearing Electrodes; Phase I Superconducting X-Ray Lithography Source (SXLS); Phase I SXLS Ring; Twiss Parameters; Accelerators

Authors: Wang Yu, Singh K.P., Soler A.I., Iulianetti K.
Title: Transient response of large inertia cross flow heat exchangers
Affiliations: Holtec Int, Cherry Hill, United States
Authors with affiliations: Wang, Yu, Holtec Int, Cherry Hill, United States; Singh, K.P., Holtec Int, Cherry Hill, United States; Soler, A.I., Holtec Int, Cherry Hill, United States; Iulianetti, K., Holtec Int, Cherry Hill, United States
Abstract: The 'cross-flow' heat exchanger is a generic term to describe heat exchange equipment wherein the in-tube fluid flows at right angles to the shell side fluid. Cross-flow heat exchangers are commonly used when the fluid medium on the shell side is gaseous, resulting in large volumetric flow rates. The 'sluggish' response problem motivated the authors to develop a methodology to analyze the unsteady state response of outlet temperatures to a ramp variation of input quantities of cross flow recuperators. The concept of the approach is to break the equipment into a number of individual heat transfer units. The governing equation is a set of differential equations which can be easily solved numerically. In this paper, detail mathematical deviations are provided. An illustrative example is given. The numerical difficulties in solving the specific differential equations are also described.
Index Keywords: Compressed Air - Energy Storage; Heat Transfer; Mathematical Techniques - Differential Equations; Compressed Air Energy Storage (CAES); Cross Flow Heat Transfer Unit; Heat Balance Equation; Large Inertia Cross Flow Heat Exchangers; Modified Non-Linear Shape Function; Heat Exchangers

Authors: Rosenberg R.C., McCalla J.
Title: Power to the user in formulating model equations
Source title: American Society of Mechanical Engineers, Dynamic Systems and Control Division (Publication) DSC
Affiliations: Michigan State Univ, East Lansing, United States
Authors with affiliations: Rosenberg, R.C., Michigan State Univ, East Lansing, United States; McCalla, J., Michigan State Univ, East Lansing, United States
Abstract: Engineers increasingly make use of mathematical models when designing and developing new or improved components and systems. For models that are large in dimension or complex in structure assistance is sought from software. Software aides in building models, in formulating equations, and in simulating model behavior. In this paper we focus on lumped-parameter dynamic models governed by ordinary differential equations with time as the independent variable. The particular issue considered is that of models containing algebraically-coupled energy storage effects. Three options are discussed in a bond graph context: solution by a numerical algorithm that expects implicit dynamic equations; augmentation of the energy variable set so as to yield an explicit set of dynamic equations; and reduction of coupled energy effects to an equivalent explicit form locally, also yielding explicit dynamic equations for solution. A software implementation of a reduction procedure for models with a simple class of implicit storage fields is described. An example illustrates the application of the procedure. The engineer's guidance in making selections is preserved as fully as possible.
Index Keywords: Dynamics - Mathematical Models; Mathematical Techniques - Graph Theory; Bond Graphs; Dynamic Equations; Mathematical Models

Authors: Bharadwaj V., Peggs S., Wu G., Saltmarsh C.
Title: Proposed data acquisition system for the Fermilab Booster
Source title: Conference Record of 1991 IEEE Particle Accelerator Conference
Authors with affiliations: Bharadwaj, V.; Peggs, S.; Wu, G.; Saltmarsh, C.
Abstract: The authors propose to design a booster data acquisition system (BDAQ) for the FNAL (Fermi National Accelerator Laboratory) booster. In essence, this system consists of a large number of digitizers with circular memory buffers. After a machine cycle of interest, these buffers are frozen and then read out into a mass storage device. The hardware and software capabilities needed to make such a data acquisition system a powerful tool for doing accelerator physics studies and improving machine performance is discussed.
Index Keywords: Data Processing - Data Acquisition; Particle Accelerators; Physics - High Energy; Accelerator Data Acquisition System; Digitizers; Fermilab Booster; Accelerators

Authors: Zolfaghari A., Demos P.T., Flanz J.B., Jacobs K.
Title: Comparison of SW and TW non-synchronous accelerating cavities as used in electron beam storage rings
Authors with affiliations: Zolfaghari, A.; Demos, P.T.; Flanz, J.B.; Jacobs, K.
Abstract: The authors relate the parameters of detuned standing wave (SW) and non-synchronous beam traveling wave (TW) accelerating cavities of equivalent equilibrium performance when used to compensate for radiation and parasitic energy losses by electrons circulating in a high energy electron storage ring. The relationship is expressed in terms of the coupling parameter and cavity tuning angle of the TW accelerator's equivalent SW system. The basis used for formulating the equivalence of the two systems follows TW cavity non-synchronous beam loading theory developed by G. A. Loew (1960) and SW circuit analysis theory as described by P. B. Wilson (1982).
Index Keywords: Waveguide Components--Applications; Cavity Tuning Angle; Coupling Parameter; Electron Beam Storage Rings; Radiation/Parasitic Energy Losses; SW/TW Non-Synchronous Acceleration Cavities; Accelerators

Authors: Maksimova N.A., Shalyukhin V.G., Leongard E.V., Lyashenko A.I., Petrov B.F., Fasman A.B.
Title: Effect of the storage conditions on the catalytic and physicochemical properties of raney nickel
Affiliations: Acad of Sciences of the Kazakh SSR, Alma-Ata, Russian Federation
Authors with affiliations: Maksimova, N.A., Acad of Sciences of the Kazakh SSR, Alma-Ata, Russian Federation; Shalyukhin, V.G., Acad of Sciences of the Kazakh SSR, Alma-Ata, Russian Federation; Leongard, E.V., Acad of Sciences of the Kazakh SSR, Alma-Ata, Russian Federation; Lyashenko, A.I., Acad of Sciences of the Kazakh SSR, Alma-Ata, Russian Federation; Petrov, B.F., Acad of Sciences of the Kazakh SSR, Alma-Ata, Russian Federation; Fasman, A.B., Acad of Sciences of the Kazakh SSR, Alma-Ata, Russian Federation
Abstract: The effect of the conditions of storage of Raney Ni on its activity and selectivity in hydrogenation of 2-ethylanthraquinone was investigated. It was shown that the distribution of adsorbed hydrogen by energy states changes in an atmosphere of nitrogen, while the degree of filling of the surface of the nickel increases in storage under hydrogen. This is the cause of the difference in the catalytic properties of Raney nickel.
Index Keywords: Catalysts - Surfaces; Hydrogen - Effects; Nickel Aluminum Alloys - Physical Chemistry; Nickel and Alloys - Storage; Organic Compounds - Hydrogenation; Ethylanthraquinone; Raney Nickel; Selective Hydrogenation; Specific Surface Area; Storage Conditions Effects; Catalysts

Authors: Griebenow Bret L., Selleck Colin B., Strope Lowell A., Burke James B.
Title: Imaging, inspection, and characterization systems for underground storage tank remediation
Source title: Conference on Robotics and Remote Systems- Proceedings
Affiliations: Westinghouse Idaho Nuclear Co, Idaho Falls, United States
Authors with affiliations: Griebenow, Bret L., Westinghouse Idaho Nuclear Co, Idaho Falls, United States; Selleck, Colin B., Westinghouse Idaho Nuclear Co, Idaho Falls, United States; Strope, Lowell A., Westinghouse Idaho Nuclear Co, Idaho Falls, United States; Burke, James B., Westinghouse Idaho Nuclear Co, Idaho Falls, United States
Abstract: Underground storage tanks (USTs) containing radioactive and hazardous wastes represent a significant remediation problem for the U.S. Department of Energy (DOE). As part of its Robotic Technology Development Program, the DOE Office of Technology Development is supporting the development, testing, and demonstration of robotic technologies which may be useful in the remediation of these storage tanks. Among the capabilities that will be required before either teleoperated or autonomous robotic operations can be performed in the tanks are remote inspection, imaging, and characterization. For fiscal year 1991, a visual inspection system and two remote imaging systems were demonstrated as part of a multi-laboratory effort.
Index Keywords: Imaging Techniques; Inspection - Robot Applications; Robotics - Applications; Tanks; Remediation; Remote Imaging; Storage Tank Remediation; Underground Storage Tanks; Radioactive Wastes

Authors: Jericha Herbert, Starzer O., Theissing M.
Title: Towards a solar-hydrogen system
Source title: American Society of Mechanical Engineers, International Gas Turbine Institute (Publication) IGTI
Affiliations: Graz Univ of Technology, Graz, Austria
Authors with affiliations: Jericha, Herbert, Graz Univ of Technology, Graz, Austria; Starzer, O., Graz Univ of Technology, Graz, Austria; Theissing, M., Graz Univ of Technology, Graz, Austria
Abstract: An interesting solution for the future power generation are solar systems, either thermal solar or photovoltaic solar systems, which most likely will have to be combined with hydrogen storage, transport and reuse systems. Our institute has contributed projects and feasibility studies to both of these topics. The development of a solar thermal power plant on the basis of a volumetric receiver of new design, with an inverted cycle gas turbine, has proven to be feasible. An attractive solution due to medium range costs of electricity production and additional drinking water supply might be achieved. A thermal plant, using the two components of water as a fuel in an internal combustion cycle, promises efficiencies higher than the combustion of hydrogen in air and avoids totally the generation of nitrogen oxids. In the realisation of such a plant we work on the development of a combustion chamber, burning hydrogen/oxygen in a cooling flow of steam. The hydrogen/oxygen system would be suitable for peaking duties and also for the optimum reuse of hydrogen generated by electrolysis in distant locations.
Index Keywords: NITROGEN OXIDES; Oxygen; Photovoltaic cells; Solar Cells; Solar Energy; STEAM; Steam; Drinking water; Hydrogen Storage; Internal Combustion Cycles; Solar Thermal Power Plants; Solar Power Plants

Authors: Willeke F., Zimmermann F.
Title: The impact of persistent current field errors on the stability of the proton beam in the HERA protorn ring
Source title: Conference Record of 1991 IEEE Particle Accelerator Conference
Authors with affiliations: Willeke, F.; Zimmermann, F.
Abstract: The field error of the HERA magnets are examined with reference to the stability of the proton beam. The dynamics of the proton beam under the influence of the strong persistent field errors and the correction and compensation scheme of HERA is presented and discussed. It is concluded that the field quality of the HERA superconducting magnets is remarkably good. Unavoidable strong systematic persistent current sextupolar, decapolar, and do decapolar field errors have to be compensated for by compensation coils. Differences between the production lines do not cause problems due to ordered sequences of magnet installations. Simulations of single particle stability of a proton beam in HERA at injection energy promise sufficient aperture for stable synchrobetatron oscillations. First results from the commissioning of the HERA proton ring are presented. It has been demonstrated that a proton beam can be stored in HERA at 40 GeV with a reasonable lifetime.
Index Keywords: Accelerators--Storage Rings; Magnetic Fields; Protons; Superconducting Magnets; HERA Proton Ring; Accelerators

Authors: Brefeld W., Gurtler P.
Title: A bypass for synchrotron radiation experiments at the storage ring PETRA II
Source title: Conference Record of 1991 IEEE Particle Accelerator Conference
Authors with affiliations: Brefeld, W.; Gurtler, P.
Abstract: The electron-positron collider PETRA, which is being reconstructed into a 14-GeV electron-proton booster for HERA (Hadron Electron Ring Accelerator), would be an excellent source for next-generation synchrotron radiation experiments. Insertion devices in such a high-energy storage ring would have unique properties in the photon energy range from 20 to 50 keV and open the possibility for experiments above 100 keV. However, all plants have to take into account that PETRA II has primarily to be used as a booster. A bypass at PETRA II seems to be the way to use the ring as a synchrotron radiation source without reducing the qualities of its booster functions. Results of first considerations, which lead to a bypass with two undulator beamlines, are presented.
Index Keywords: Accelerators - Colliding Beam; Accelerators - Storage Rings; Magnets; Electron-Positron Collider PETRA; Electron-Proton Booster; PETRA II-SR-Bypass; Synchrotron Radiation Experiments; Undulator Beamlines; Synchrotron Radiation

Authors: Einfeld D., Richter R.
Title: The ELETTRA linac to storage ring transfer line
Affiliations: Fachhochschule Ostfriesland, Emden, West Germany
Authors with affiliations: Einfeld, D., Fachhochschule Ostfriesland, Emden, West Germany; Richter, R., Fachhochschule Ostfriesland, Emden, West Germany
Abstract: The injection system for the ELETTRA storage ring is a full-energy linear accelerator (linac). It will be located underground outside the storage ring so as not to interfere with the experimental area. It will be constructed and operated in two stages: 1.5 GeV (for initial user operation) and 2 GeV (for final operation), with the option of conversion for positrons in a later stage. To obtain a small beam size as well as to implement many of identical elements, the structure of the transfer line consists of four achromatic arcs, three in the horizontal and one in the vertical direction. The matching between the achromatic arcs is performed with triplet and FODO systems. The longest transfer line (1.5 GeV) with a length of 103 m needs 30 quadrupoles, 7 bending magnets and 34 steerer magnets. The largest beam size obtained throughout the transfer line is ±12 mm for electrons and ±17 mm for positrons. To get 95% of the particles (2 GeV-positrons) through the transfer line and considering misalignment errors, the aperture of the magnetic elements has to be ±25 mm.
Index Keywords: Accelerators - Beam Injection; Accelerators, Linear; Beam Sizes; ELETTRA Linac; Lattice Functions; Storage Ring Transfer Line; Transfer Line Magnetic Structure; Accelerators

Authors: Wait G.D., Barnes M.J., Bishop D., Waters G., Figley C.B.
Title: Prototype studies of a 1 MHz chopper for the kaon factory
Authors with affiliations: Wait, G.D.; Barnes, M.J.; Bishop, D.; Waters, G.; Figley, C.B.
Abstract: The 1.025-MHz beam chopper will create 108-ns gaps in the 1 GeV/c H- beam to allow enough time for the magnetic field to be established in the kicker magnets in each of the 5 accumulator rings of the kaon factory at the Tri-University Meson Facility (TRIUMF). The required deflection of 1 mrad can be achieved with a set of plates 5-cm apart in which the product of voltage difference and plate length is 37.7 kV-m. The kick must have a rise and fall time of less than 39 ns and a flat top of 49 ns, and 92 ns on alternate pulses. The 1-MHz chopper concept involves an energy storage system where the electric pulses are stored in a large-diameter low-loss coaxial cable. Measurements of the performance of a high-voltage prototype are presented. Results show that this novel design can be implemented successfully for the kaon factory.
Index Keywords: Choppers--Applications; Magnets--Applications; 1 MHz Beam Chopper Chopper; Kaon Factory; Kicker Magnets; Tri-University Meson Facility (TRIUMF); Accelerators

Authors: Stephanakis S.J., Cooperstein G., Goodrich P.J., Swanekamp S., Weber B.V.
Title: Experimental study of plasma filled diode operation using flashboard-generated plasmas
Authors with affiliations: Stephanakis, S.J.; Cooperstein, G.; Goodrich, P.J.; Swanekamp, S.; Weber, B.V.
Abstract: The impedance behavior of a 12-cm-diameter plasma-filled, pinch-beam diode was studied on the NRL Gamble II generator. The generator was operated in negative polarity and the plasma was injected through the anode into the anode-cathode region. The plasma was generated on the surface of a capacitor-driven flashboard located downstream of the anode and was injected axially toward the diode. Consideration was given to the case where the plasma was injected through an annular slot in the anode in the vicinity of the anode-cathode gap, as well as to the case where the plasma injection was limited by a 5-cm-diameter hole on the anode at the center of the diode. By varying the relative timings between the capacitor bank firing and the machine pulse arrival, a window was established where the diode impedance started out at 0 Ω for a few tens of nanoseconds (<30 ns) and then increased to the vacuum impedance. Attempts to increase conduction times beyond 30 ns resulted in eventual impedances that were lower than the vacuum impedance.
Index Keywords: Capacitors--Energy Storage; Electrodes; Plasmas--Production; Flashboard Generated Plasmas; NRL Gambel II Generator; Summary Only; Plasma Devices

Authors: Jaquish W.R., Shen E.J., Yount J.A.
Title: Robotics technology demonstration program for underground storage tank remediation
Source title: Conference on Robotics and Remote Systems- Proceedings
Affiliations: Westinghouse Hanford Co, Richland, United States
Authors with affiliations: Jaquish, W.R., Westinghouse Hanford Co, Richland, United States; Shen, E.J., Westinghouse Hanford Co, Richland, United States; Yount, J.A., Westinghouse Hanford Co, Richland, United States
Abstract: To address the technological problems associated with waste retrieval from underground storage tanks, the U.S. Department of Energy Office of Technology Development has created the Robotics Technology Demonstration Program for Underground Storage Tanks. The mission of this program is to develop existing and emerging technologies for possible use in storage tank remediation activities. In 1991, this program has created the Robotics Technology Test Bed at the Hanford Site, Washington. A waste storage tank mockup and multiple robotic manipulators, sensors, and surveillance systems have been installed in this test bed. The test and evaluation activities being performed in the test bed will lead to the development of faster and safer methods for waste retrieval, inspection, and surveillance.
Index Keywords: Industrial Wastes - Hazardous Materials; Storage Tanks; Underground Storage Tanks; Waste Retrieval; Robotics

Authors: Reginato Louis L.
Title: High frequency cascaded resonant transformer rectifier power supply for neutral beam injection
Source title: Conference Record of 1991 IEEE Particle Accelerator Conference
Affiliations: Lawrence Livermore Nat Lab,, Livermore, CA, USA
Authors with affiliations: Reginato, Louis L., Lawrence Livermore Nat Lab,, Livermore, CA, USA
Abstract: Neutral beam injection for fusion requires DC megavolt power sources at several amperes. The conventional methods of using series or shunt fed multipliers cannot provide the current, whereas the 60-Hz coupled transformer method is difficult to modularize because of size and stores excessive amounts of energy. A technique which borrows from several technologies has been investigated and shows promise for a satisfactory solution. This technique uses resonant multistage high frequency (100-kHz) series coupled ferrite transformer with rectifiers to produce megavolts at several amperes of current. Modularity, high efficiency, and low energy storage are desirable features of this power source.
Index Keywords: Accelerators - Beam Injection; Electric Rectifiers; Electric Transformers, High Frequency; Cascaded Resonant Transformer Rectifier; Neutral Beam Injection; Series Coupled Ferrite Transformer; Nuclear Reactors, Fusion

Authors: [No author name available]
Title: Fundamentals of Forced and Mixed Convection and Transport Phenomena
Source title: American Society of Mechanical Engineers, Heat Transfer Division, (Publication) HTD
Abstract: This volume contains 11 papers presented at the Winter Annual Meeting of the ASME, Atlanta, Georgia, December 1-6, 1991, dealing with fundamentals of forced and mixed convection and transport as well as transport phenomena. Individual papers deal with the following topics: thermal energy storage systems with conjugate turbulent forced convection; mixed convection in inclined channels with discrete isothermal heating; mixed convective heat transfer from a cylinder in a porous medium including maximum density effects; heat transfer and convection characteristics of superheated turbulent jet interacting with solid object; a comparison of correlations to describe natural convection heat transfer to a melting ice object; boundary effect on the Benard-Marangoni instability thermal contact conductance of a moist paper handsheet/metal interface; thermocapillary instability of spherical shells; the effect of surface motion on liquid jet impingement heat transfer; heat transfer augmentation and pumping power; heat transfer in a serpentine channel with a series of right angle turns.
Index Keywords: Energy Storage; Flow of Fluids--Jets; Heat Exchangers; Papermaking; Porous Materials; Convective Heat Transfer; EIREV; Melting Ice; Thermal Contact Conductance; Thermal Energy Storage; Turbulent Forced Convection; Heat Transfer

Authors: Zhou P., Rosenzweig J.B.
Title: Ion clearing by cyclotron resonance shaking
Source title: Conference Record of 1991 IEEE Particle Accelerator Conference
Authors with affiliations: Zhou, P.; Rosenzweig, J.B.
Abstract: A new concept in ion clearing for storage rings, that of resonant removal of ions in dipoles by shaking the beam horizontally near the ion cyclotron frequency is discussed. This method of beam shaking is similar to the variations on ion bounce shaking but has advantages in requiring a narrower bandwidth of shaking frequencies and in much higher achievable ion kinetic energies. The results of analytical theory, and computer simulations are discussed.
Index Keywords: Accelerators - Magnets; Ion Beams; Particle Accelerators; Antiproton Accumulators; Cyclotron Shaking; Ion Accumulation; Accelerators

Authors: Wang M.H., Kuo C.C., Hsue C.S.
Title: The booster to storage ring transport line for SRRC
Source title: Conference Record of 1991 IEEE Particle Accelerator Conference
Authors with affiliations: Wang, M.H.; Kuo, C.C.; Hsue, C.S.
Abstract: A 70-m-long booster to storage ring (BTS) transport line has been designed for the SRRC to transport the beam extracted from the booster to the storage ring at 1.3 GeV. The booster is outside the main ring and has a vertical level difference of 4.15 m relative to the ring. The design has been optimized to reach small beam size and to reduce the effects of magnet errors. In total, two families of bending magnets and 17 quadrupoles are used in the BTS line. Diagnostic instruments and correctors are equipped to measure the beam intensity, position, emittance, and energy spread and to steer the beam. A method of injection into the storage ring is also presented.
Index Keywords: Accelerators, Linear; Accelerators, Synchrotron - Storage Rings; Magnets; Bending Magnets; Booster Synchrotron; Quadrupoles; Storage Ring Transport Line; Accelerators, Synchrotron

Authors: Ko In Soo, Yoon M.
Title: Design of beam transfer line and injection system of Pohang Light Source
Source title: Conference Record of 1991 IEEE Particle Accelerator Conference
Authors with affiliations: Ko, In Soo; Yoon, M.
Abstract: The 2-GeV electron (or positron) beam provided by full energy linac is injected into the storage ring after passing about a 100-m-long beam transfer line. Since the linac is located outside and 6 m below the ring, the injecting beam is moved toward the ring in the vertical plane by a Lambertson magnet. Prior to the injection, the orbit of the stored beam is deflected toward the septum by using four bump magnets. The injection rate is 10 Hz.
Index Keywords: Accelerators - Storage Rings; Accelerators, Linear; Electron Beams; Magnets; Beam Transfer Line; Bump Magnets; Lambertson Magnet; Pohang Light Source; Synchrotron Radiation

Authors: Jackson Alan
Title: The Advanced Light Source--Status report
Source title: Conference Record of 1991 IEEE Particle Accelerator Conference
Affiliations: Lawrence Berkeley Lab, Univ of, California, Berkeley, CA, USA
Authors with affiliations: Jackson, Alan, Lawrence Berkeley Lab, Univ of, California, Berkeley, CA, USA
Abstract: The Advanced Light Source (ALS) is a third-generation synchrotron light source designed to produce extremely bright beams of synchrotron radiation in the energy range of from a few electronvolts to 10 KeV. The design is based on a 1-1.9-GeV electron storage ring (optimized at 1.5 GeV), and utilizes special magnets, known as undulators and wigglers (collectively referred to as insertion devices), to generate the radiation. The facility is scheduled to begin operating in April 1993. The authors describe the progress in design, construction, and commissioning of the accelerator systems, insertion devices, and beamlines.
Index Keywords: Accelerators--Magnets; Accelerators--Storage Rings; Light Sources; Advanced Light Source; Undulators; Synchrotron Radiation

Authors: Galiana R., Manglunki D., Mazeline C.
Title: A carbon jet beam profile monitor for LEAR
Authors with affiliations: Galiana, R.; Manglunki, D.; Mazeline, C.
Abstract: CERN's Low Energy Antiproton Ring (LEAR) is now equipped with a non-destructive beam profile monitor. A pulsed carbon jet of 0.8 ms is used to minimize the disruption of the low-energy beam. The jet is produced by a laser beam impinging on a solid carbon target. The atomic jet is collimated to form a thin curtain, which traverses the coasting antiproton beam. The electrons produced by the ionization of the jet are accelerated by electrodes before they hit a phosphorous screen. The image of the profile is acquired by a charge coupled device (CCD) camera and digitized for display on a workstation. The authors describe the techniques used, from generation of the carbon jet, to the analysis of the digitized image. Preliminary results and future improvements are discussed.
Index Keywords: Accelerators--Storage Rings; Cameras; Semiconductor Devices, Charge Coupled; CCD cameras; CERN; LEAR (Low Energy Antiproton Ring); Pulsed carbon jets; Particle Beam Tracking

Authors: Harmon John J., Yu Hsing Chung
Title: Centrifugal chillers and glycol ice thermal storage units
Affiliations: H.C. Yu and Associates, Richmond, United States
Authors with affiliations: Harmon, John J., H.C. Yu and Associates, Richmond, United States; Yu, Hsing Chung, H.C. Yu and Associates, Richmond, United States
Abstract: A well-balanced chiller/ice storage system will use less energy than a conventional system. Engineers have been so comfortable with the performance of centrifugal chillers in large building air-conditioning systems that some may have lost track (or maybe never knew) about the not-so-nice characteristics of these machines. Specifically, centrifugal chillers have a nasty habit of surging if asked to operate at conditions that they do not like. The article addresses this issue and it also discusses successful ice storage installations using centrifugal chillers.
Index Keywords: Buildings--Energy Conservation; Ice--Manufacture; Ice--Storage; Centrifugal Chillers; Glycol Ice Thermal Storage Units; Ice Builders; Off Peak Ice Storage; Buildings

Authors: Lee Chi H.
Title: Generation of high power ultra-wideband electrical impulse by optoelectronic technique
Source title: IEEE MTT-S International Microwave Symposium Digest
Affiliations: Dept of Electr Eng, Univ of, Maryland, College Park, MD, USA
Authors with affiliations: Lee, Chi H., Dept of Electr Eng, Univ of, Maryland, College Park, MD, USA
Abstract: Progress in the application of ultrafast optics and photoconductive switching for the generation of high-power ultrawideband electrical impulses is reviewed. Several techniques are described. Megawatt pulses with picosecond risetimes and falltimes and variable pulse duration have been obtained. Using a photoconductive switch both as a closing and opening switch in an inductive energy storage system, an electrical pulse power enhancement by a factor of 50 has been demonstrated. The unique feature common in all the approaches considered is the jitter-free nature of the picosecond photoconductive switch. Since the switching is jitter-free, the electrical impulses thus generated are in complete time synchronization with the command laser pulse.
Index Keywords: Laser Pulses; Optoelectronic Devices; Photoconducting Devices; Ultrafast optics; Ultrawideband electric impulses; Signal Generators

Authors: Marken K.R.
Title: Superconducting materials and their application: State of the art and prospects for the year 2000
Source title: Proceedings of the Electrical/Electronics Insulation Conference
Affiliations: Battelle, Columbus, OH, USA
Authors with affiliations: Marken, K.R., Battelle, Columbus, OH, USA
Abstract: The state of development of metallic and ceramic superconducting materials is discussed. Both materials properties and processing are considered. Present and future applications are discussed. Emphasis is placed on current-carrying capacity, which is critical for large-scale applications such as high-field magnets, energy storage magnets, power transmission lines, rotating machines, and transportation systems. Additional applications discussed include small-scale devices such as electronic components and sensors.
Index Keywords: Ceramic Materials; Electric Machinery; Electric Power Transmission; Magnets; Metals and Alloys; Ceramic superconductors; High-field magnets; Power lines; Rotating machines; Superconducting Materials

Authors: Fischer W.
Title: Status and prospects of high energy NaS-batteries at ABB
Source title: Mechanical and corrosion properties. Series A, Key engineering materials
Affiliations: ABB Hochenergiebatterie GmbH, Heldelberg, Germany
Authors with affiliations: Fischer, W., ABB Hochenergiebatterie GmbH, Heldelberg, Germany
Abstract: An analytical trend analysis of NaS battery development shows that performance characteristics such as energy density, power density, safety and cycle life of single cells and batteries have been continuously improved and are close to target values. More than 300 batteries have been produced in a pilot plant and have been subjected to laboratory tests, electric vehicle propulsion tests and off-peak electrical energy storage tests. The tests have resulted in statistical knowledge not only on battery performance, but also on performance of systems (such as EV's) containing the battery as an important component. Present and future performance data will be discussed.
Index Keywords: Alumina - Ionic Conduction; Electrolytes, Solid; Beta-Alumina; Beta-Batteries; Sodium-Sulfur Electric Batteries; Electric Batteries

Authors: Srinivasan S., Velev O.A., Parthasarathy A., Manko D.J., Appleby A.J.
Title: High energy efficiency and high power density proton exchange membrane fuel cells - electrode kinetics and mass transport
Affiliations: Center for Electrochemical Systems and Hydrogen Research, Texas Engineering Experiment Station, Texas A and M University System, College Station, TX 77843-3402, United States
Authors with affiliations: Srinivasan, S., Center for Electrochemical Systems and Hydrogen Research, Texas Engineering Experiment Station, Texas A and M University System, College Station, TX 77843-3402, United States; Velev, O.A., Center for Electrochemical Systems and Hydrogen Research, Texas Engineering Experiment Station, Texas A and M University System, College Station, TX 77843-3402, United States; Parthasarathy, A., Center for Electrochemical Systems and Hydrogen Research, Texas Engineering Experiment Station, Texas A and M University System, College Station, TX 77843-3402, United States; Manko, D.J., Center for Electrochemical Systems and Hydrogen Research, Texas Engineering Experiment Station, Texas A and M University System, College Station, TX 77843-3402, United States; Appleby, A.J., Center for Electrochemical Systems and Hydrogen Research, Texas Engineering Experiment Station, Texas A and M University System, College Station, TX 77843-3402, United States
Abstract: The development of proton exchange membrane (PEM) fuel cell power plants with high energy efficiencies and high power densities is gaining momentum because of the vital need of such high levels of performance for extraterrestrial (space, underwater) and terrestrial (power source for electric vehicles) applications. Since 1987, considerable progress has been made in achieving energy efficiencies of about 60% at a current density of 200 mA/cm2 and high power densities (≫ 1 W/cm2) in PEM fuel cells with high (4 mg/cm2) or low (0.4 mg/cm2) platinum loadings in electrodes. This article focuses on: (i) methods to obtain these high levels of performance with low Pt loading electrodes - by proton conductor impregnation into electrodes, localization of Pt near front surface; (ii) a novel microelectrode technique which yields electrode kinetic parameters for oxygen reduction and mass transport parameters; (iii) demonstration of lack of water transport from anode to cathode; (iv) modeling analysis of PEM fuel cell for comparison with experimental results and predicting further improvements in performance; (v) recommendations of needed R&D for achieving the above goals. © 1991.
Index Keywords: Aerospace Engineering--Energy Storage; Membranes--Ion Exchange Membranes; Protons--Ion Exchange; Extraterrestrial Applications; Platinum Electrodes; Proton Exchange Membranes; Fuel Cells

Authors: Brandhorst Jr. Henry W.
Title: Energy requirements for the space frontier
Affiliations: NASA Lewis Research Cent, Cleveland, United States
Authors with affiliations: Brandhorst Jr., Henry W., NASA Lewis Research Cent, Cleveland, United States
Abstract: The future appears rich in missions that will extend the frontlers of knowledge, human presence in space, and opportunities for profitable commerce. Key to success of these ventures is the availability of plentiful, cost effective electric power and assured, low cost access to space. While forecasts of space power needs are problematic, an assessment of future needs based on terrestrial experience has been made. These needs fall into three broad categories survival, self sufficiency and industrialization. The cost of delivering payloads to orbital locations from LEO to Mars has been determined and future launch cost reductions projected. From these factors, then, projections of the performance necessary for future solar and nuclear space power options has been made. These goals are largely dependent upon orbital location and energy storage needs. Finally the cost of present space power systems has been determined and projections made for future systems.
Index Keywords: Electric Power Systems - Space Applications; Satellites - Power Supply; Spacecraft - Power Supply; Technological Forecasting; Space Power Systems; Spacecraft

Authors: Barstow Stephen F., Soroas Per-Erik, Selanger Karl
Title: Wave energy resource mapping for Asia and the Pacific
Authors with affiliations: Barstow, Stephen F.; Soroas, Per-Erik; Selanger, Karl
Abstract: The authors describe a global analysis system for wave energy and one potential application of this system to an accurate global map of available wave energy which would potentially significantly improve knowledge of the available resource on a global basis. A brief description of the SEAWATCH system currently being established in Thailand is presented, which consists of the following modules: data acquisition; data storage, analysis, and presentation; environmental modeling and forecasting; and distribution of data, forecasts, and user-relevant information. Wave measurements are currently being made at five island locations in the South Pacific. The measurements are being made by Waverider buoys moored in deep water fairly close to the various islands. These buoys measure the wave elevation time series, and wave parameters and spectra are computed onboard in real time. This data is subsequently transmitted by the ARGOS satellite system, which also provides buoy location.
Index Keywords: Energy Resources; Oceanography - Measurements; Water Waves - Measurements; Asia Resource Mapping; Global Wave Models; OCEANOR; Pacific Resource Mapping; SEAWATCH System; Wave Energy Resource Mapping; Water Waves

Authors: Gong Z.-X., Zhang Y.-F., Mujumdar A.S.
Title: Cyclic phase change heat conduction in thin composite slabs
Source title: Computational Modelling of Free and Moving Boundary Problems
Affiliations: Tianjin Inst of Light Industry, Tianjin, China
Authors with affiliations: Gong, Z.-X., Tianjin Inst of Light Industry, Tianjin, China; Zhang, Y.-F., Tianjin Inst of Light Industry, Tianjin, China; Mujumdar, A.S., Tianjin Inst of Light Industry, Tianjin, China
Abstract: A one-dimensional conduction-controlled phase change model is derived for composite slabs to simulate the cyclic operation of phase change energy storage systems. A fixed-mesh finite element scheme is adopted to solve the resulting multiple moving boundary problem. Dynamic simulations are carried out. The cumulative energy transferred per cycle, the instantaneous heat flux, the time wise interface locations and the temperature profiles are presented for one mode of operation viz, equal thermal swings with equal melting and freezing periods.
Index Keywords: Energy Storage; HEAT STORAGE; Temperature Distribution; Phase Changes; Thermal Energy Storage; Heat Transfer

Authors: Burkel E., Dorner B., Illini Th., Peisl J.
Title: High-energy resolution in X-ray scattering with the spectrometer INELAX I. The principles and the test instrument
Affiliations: Ludwig-Maximilians-Univ Muenchen, Muenchen, Germany
Authors with affiliations: Burkel, E., Ludwig-Maximilians-Univ Muenchen, Muenchen, Germany; Dorner, B., Ludwig-Maximilians-Univ Muenchen, Muenchen, Germany; Illini, Th., Ludwig-Maximilians-Univ Muenchen, Muenchen, Germany; Peisl, J., Ludwig-Maximilians-Univ Muenchen, Muenchen, Germany
Abstract: Very high-energy resolution measurements using X-rays can be achieved by extreme backreflection (Bragg angle close to 90°) from perfect crystals. This technique, combined with the high intensity of X-rays emitted by synchrotron-radiation sources, allowed the development of the instrument INELAX for inelastic scattering experiments. The principles and test results are discussed.
Index Keywords: Mathematical Models; Spectrometers, X-Ray; X-Rays--Scattering; DORIS Storage Ring; Inelastic X-Ray Scattering; INELAX; Premonochromator; Crystallography

Authors: Aiello G.Roberto, Bossi Maurizio
Title: The ELETTRA gun trigger module
Authors with affiliations: Aiello, G.Roberto; Bossi, Maurizio
Abstract: The ELETTRA injector is a full energy linear accelerator (LINAC). Most of the triggers for the timing system are generated by a module named the gun trigger module. The gun is triggered in synchronism with a reference bucket of the storage ring. It can be programmed with a delay between 2 and 684 ns, a range which covers one revolution period of the storage ring, so that any arbitrary bucket of the ring can be filled. The module also generates the gun trigger for working in FEL (free-electron laser) mode, which needs a repetition of from 30 to 50 ns in a 10-μs window. The jitter of all these triggers is less than 50 ps. The gun trigger module was developed in the VMEbus standard, using transistor-transistor logic and emitter-coupled logic technology. It is remotely programmable through the ELETTRA control system. The general architecture of the ELETTRA timing system is also described.
Index Keywords: Accelerators - Beam Injection; Control Systems; Logic Circuits, Emitter Coupled--Applications; Logic Circuits, Transistor Transistor--Applications; ELETTRA Gun Trigger Module; ELETTRA Injector; Free Electron Laser (FEL) Mode; VMEbus standard; Accelerators, Linear

Authors: Kanari Katsuhiko, Abe Yoshiyuki, Tanaka Kotaro, Takahashi Yoshio, Sakamoto Ryuji, Kamimoto Masayuki, Ozawa Takeo
Title: Heat-transfer characteristics of latent thermal-storage units with sodium hydroxide-based molten salts
Authors with affiliations: Kanari, Katsuhiko; Abe, Yoshiyuki; Tanaka, Kotaro; Takahashi, Yoshio; Sakamoto, Ryuji; Kamimoto, Masayuki; Ozawa, Takeo
Abstract: The present paper describes experimental and computer simulation results for 30 kWh scale horizontal U-tube type latent thermal-energy storage units using a eutectic of sodium hydroxide-sodium nitrate as a phase change material. Through 1000 melting/freezing (charge/discharge) cycle tests on two storage units of bare-tube and finned-tube types, the heat-transfer characteristics were evaluated. Computer simulations on both the storage units were performed with a two-dimensional model. In the case of the finned-tube type, the effect of fins was included in the effective thermal conductivity of molten salt around the tubes. The calculated results were in good agreement with the observed ones. The model was also applied to practical-scale storage units, and the influence of the parameters, such as the ratio of the diameter to the length of the storage vessel, the number of heat-transfer pipes and channel partitions, etc., on the heat-transfer performance was evaluated.
Index Keywords: Heat Transfer - Computer Simulation; Heat Transfer - Fins; Heat Transfer - Tubes; Salts - Molten; Salts - Thermal Conductivity; Bare Tube Thermal Storage Units; Finned Tube Thermal Storage Units; Latent Thermal Storage Units; Sodium Hydroxide Based Molten Salts; Heat Storage

Authors: [No author name available]
Title: 35th Annual Ammonia Symposium
Abstract: This conference proceedings contain 31 papers. Topics covered include all aspects of health environmental, public and equipment safety related to ammonia plants: several major plant equipment and pipeline explosions, rupture fracture etc are described and analysed. Techniques of improving the safety by design one discussed. Inspection and testing procedures are described. Energy efficiency and methods of improvement with regards to heat exchanger design, repair and maintenance are given.

Authors: Hull John R., Schoenung Susan M., Palmer David N., Davis Mark K.
Title: Design and fabrication issues for small-scale SMES
Affiliations: Argonne Natl Lab, Argonne, United States
Authors with affiliations: Hull, John R., Argonne Natl Lab, Argonne, United States; Schoenung, Susan M., Argonne Natl Lab, Argonne, United States; Palmer, David N., Argonne Natl Lab, Argonne, United States; Davis, Mark K., Argonne Natl Lab, Argonne, United States
Abstract: Coil-scaling and structural-force calculations for small-scale solenoidal and toroidal superconducting magnetic energy storage (SMES) systems are presented. The efficiency of the refrigeration system is estimated as a function of mechanical support, insulation, and power-lead thermal losses. Required high-temperature superconductor (HTS) properties are compared to properties of presently available materials or those expected to evolve in the near term. Potential applications are described for small-scale SMES, and these applications will significantly increase when HTSs can be used.
Index Keywords: Applications; Energy storage; Fabrication; High temperature superconductors; Refrigerating machinery; Solenoidal SMES; Superconducting magnetic energy storage (SMES); Toroidal SMES; Superconducting devices

Authors: Kaerner Joachim F., Lorenzen Hans W., Nitsche Andreas
Title: Quench initialization and propagation in Superconducting Magnetic Storage Systems
Affiliations: Technische Universitaet Muenchen, Munich, Germany
Authors with affiliations: Kaerner, Joachim F., Technische Universitaet Muenchen, Munich, Germany; Lorenzen, Hans W., Technische Universitaet Muenchen, Munich, Germany; Nitsche, Andreas, Technische Universitaet Muenchen, Munich, Germany
Abstract: The design of a reliable protection system for Superconducting Magnetic Energy Storage (SMES) plants requires initial investigations on the thermal stability of the field winding. Considering an indirectly cooled superconducting coil (cooling pipes arranged at the inner and outer winding layer only), the superconductor and eddy current losses caused by repeated SMES charging and discharging are calculated. The results are applied to a numerical heat flux simulation program. In this way the stationary temperature distribution of the winding region is obtained for different SMES operation modes. Local exceeding of the superconductor's critical temperature leads to three-dimensional propagation of normal conducting zones (so-called `quench'). Examples are given concerning both normal load operation and forced operation followed by a quench. Conclusions are drawn with regard to cooling system, cycle load efficiency and protective measurements.
Index Keywords: Cooling systems; Electric coils; Electric equipment protection; Electric windings; Energy storage; Heat conduction; Mathematical models; Stability; Quench initialization; Quench propagation; Superconducting magnetic energy storage (SMES) systems; Superconducting magnets

Authors: Meyer Robert, Korinek Kenneth
Title: Alabama electric cooperative compressed air energy storage project
Source title: International Exhibition & Conference for the Power Generation Industries - Power-Gen
Affiliations: Alabama Electric Cooperative, United States
Authors with affiliations: Meyer, Robert, Alabama Electric Cooperative, United States; Korinek, Kenneth, Alabama Electric Cooperative, United States
Abstract: Compressed Air Energy Storage (CAES) is a process that allows storage of energy produced during off-peak periods for use during peak generation periods. Air is compressed and stored at high pressure, and then used in the combustion process of a hot gas expander. Alabama Electric Cooperative (AEC), located in Andalusia, Alabama, now has the first commercial facility in the United States. This paper describes the AEC project and the application of CAES.
Index Keywords: Combustion; Energy storage; Technology; Alabama electric cooperative (AEC) CAES; CAES technology; Compressed air energy storage (CAES); Hot gas expander; Compressed air

Authors: Strater Jay W.
Title: Coding techniques for memory and delay efficient interleaving in slow Rayleigh fading
Affiliations: Mission Research Corp, Santa, Barbara, CA, USA
Authors with affiliations: Strater, Jay W., Mission Research Corp, Santa, Barbara, CA, USA
Abstract: The objective has been to find memory-efficient coding/interleaving techniques and to accurately quantify their memory requirements. Toward this objective, convolutional interleaving, differential phase shift keying (DPSK) modulation, and various convolutional codes, Reed-Solomon codes, and concatenated convolutional and Reed-Solomon codes were evaluated by high-fidelity link simulations. Their interleaving memory requirements were derived as functions of data bit energy relative to channel noise-density for bit-error-rates of 10-5. Interleaving delay requirements were also derived, and code selections with the smallest interleaving memory and delay requirements were identified.
Index Keywords: Codes (symbols); Data storage equipment; Phase shift keying; Telecommunication links; Concatenated codes; Convolutional codes; DPSK; Interleaving; Memory-efficient coding; Rayleigh fading; Reed-Solomon codes; Fading (radio)

Authors: Yotsuya Tsutom, Shibayama Motoaki, Takahata Ryoichi
Title: Characterization of high-temperature superconducting bearing
Affiliations: Osaka Prefectural Industrial, Technology Research Inst, Osaka, Japan
Authors with affiliations: Yotsuya, Tsutom, Osaka Prefectural Industrial, Technology Research Inst, Osaka, Japan; Shibayama, Motoaki, Osaka Prefectural Industrial, Technology Research Inst, Osaka, Japan; Takahata, Ryoichi, Osaka Prefectural Industrial, Technology Research Inst, Osaka, Japan
Abstract: The basic properties of superconducting magnetic bearing (SMB) were examined by using high-Tc superconductor YBa2Cu3OX which had been prepared by MPMG method, and ring-magnets. Rather high loading capacity, low stiffness and extremely low decay torque were confirmed. A disk having a weight of 1 kg and a diameter of 0.01 m supported by the SMB using 16 superconducting pellets rotated at a speed of 5,000 rpm without control. Applicability of SMB to fly-wheel energy storage system was discussed.
Index Keywords: Applications; Characterization; Disks (machine components); Energy storage; Flywheels; High temperature superconductors; Superconducting devices; Yttrium compounds; Flywheel energy storage system; Superconducting magnetic bearing (SMB); Yttrium barium copper oxide; Magnetic bearings

Authors: Jacyno Z.
Title: Control system analysis based on internal energy method
Affiliations: Dept of Phys, Univ of Quebec,, Montreal, Que, Canada
Authors with affiliations: Jacyno, Z., Dept of Phys, Univ of Quebec,, Montreal, Que, Canada
Abstract: In order to gain insight into dynamic and feedback control systems' behavior, the author has introduced a phase space notion, applicable to any linear system. A linear transformation suitably chosen allows for the definition of generalized position and velocity coordinates, and generates the parametric description of dynamic trajectories, which are shown to be energetic levels analogous to the phase plane representation. This parametric representation, given in the form of bilinear and quadratic forms of generalized position and velocity coordinates, defines different energy components of the system, such as kinetic, potential, dissipated or absorbed, exchanged through the control action, or stored within the system. It indicates also which parameters of the system are responsible for different energy components. Thus, parameters responsible for storage and natural frequencies or those involved in the dissipation and establishing damping characteristics are identified.
Index Keywords: Control system synthesis; Dynamics; Linear control systems; Automatic control systems; Dynamic systems; Feedback controls; Mathematical formalisms; Phase space analysis; Control system analysis

Authors: Maegaard Jorn
Title: ISPON isolated power supply networks based on windturbines
Affiliations: Danish Electrical Research Inst, Lyngby, Denmark
Authors with affiliations: Maegaard, Jorn, Danish Electrical Research Inst, Lyngby, Denmark
Abstract: This article describes ISPON, a research project on electricity supplies based on stand-alone windpower systems. The project forwards a possible system solution, and discusses its elements, in particular a short time storage system for the reduction of the fluctuations in the energy production and a load management system. Some of the system elements presented can also be utilised for fuel saving purposes in small communities with diesel-based production of electricity.
Index Keywords: Electric Power Systems; Energy Storage--Equipment; Fuel Saving; ISPON Isolated Power Supply Networks; Short Term Storage System; Wind Turbines; Electricity Generation; Wind Turbines

Authors: Anderson M.A., Bertsch P.M., Feldman S.B., Zelazny L.W.
Title: Interactions of Acidic Metal-Rich Coal Pile Runoff with a Subsoil
Affiliations: Department of Soil and Environmental Sciences, University of California, Riverside, California 92521, United States; Division of Biogeochemistry, University of Georgia, Savannah River Ecology Laboratory, Drawer E, Aiken, South Carolina 29801, United States; Department of Crop and Soil Environmental Sciences, Virginia Polytechnic Institute and State University, Blacksburg, Virginia 24061, United States
Authors with affiliations: Anderson, M.A., Department of Soil and Environmental Sciences, University of California, Riverside, California 92521, United States; Bertsch, P.M., Division of Biogeochemistry, University of Georgia, Savannah River Ecology Laboratory, Drawer E, Aiken, South Carolina 29801, United States; Feldman, S.B., Department of Crop and Soil Environmental Sciences, Virginia Polytechnic Institute and State University, Blacksburg, Virginia 24061, United States; Zelazny, L.W., Department of Crop and Soil Environmental Sciences, Virginia Polytechnic Institute and State University, Blacksburg, Virginia 24061, United States
Abstract: Highly acidic and metal-rich runoff from coal storage facilities can have a dramatic impact on local surface water and groundwater quality. In order to identify important reactions governing metal transport within subsurface environments subject to infiltration of coal pile runoff (CPR), samples of uncontaminated subsoil adjacent to a coal stockpile runoff containment basin at the U.S. Department of Energy’s Savannah River Site were collected and subjected to leaching with acidic, metalliferous CPR. Effluent was collected and multicomponent transport through the subsoil evaluated. Mass balance calculations, a sequential dissolution scheme in which column leaching was terminated and elements were partitioned to water, 1 M NH4Cl, and ammonium oxalate in the dark-extractable phases, and mineralogical and surface chemical analyses were used to identify important chemical processes and mineralogical alterations occurring during leaching. © 1991, American Chemical Society. All rights reserved.

Authors: Johannessen J.N.
Title: Model of chronic neurotoxicity: Long-term retention of the neurotoxin 1- methyl-4-phenylpyridinium (MPP+) within catecholaminergic neurons
Affiliations: FDA, 200 C Street, SW, Washington, DC 20204, United States
Authors with affiliations: Johannessen, J.N., FDA, 200 C Street, SW, Washington, DC 20204, United States
Abstract: The mechanism by which 1-methyl-4-phenyl-1,2,3,6-tetrahydropyridine (MPTP) produces lesions in the nigrostriatal dopamine system has been extensively studied. MPTP, a lipophilic molecule, enters the brain rapidly where it is converted to the pyridinium metabolite 1-methyl-4-phenylpyridinium (MPP+), by a two-step reaction that requires the enzyme monoamine oxidase. Following this conversion, which occurs primarily in astrocytes, MPP+ is sequestered within monoaminergic neurons by the energy-requiring monoaminergic transporters. Inside the neuron, MPP+ is thought to act as a mitochondrial toxin, slowly sapping the neuron of its energy-producing potential by blocking the action of NADH dehydrogenase. Much attention has been focused on cell death after MPTP administration, but little attention has been paid to the effects of small subtoxic doses of MPTP (i.e., doses that do not produce overt neuropathologic changes), which might occur during environmental exposure to a nigrostriatal toxin. Low doses of MPTP (as little as 1/25th of a toxic dose) produce long-term (> 6 weeks) but reversible changes in catecholamine metabolism. These changes are characterized by a decrease in the products of enzymatic oxidative deamination without a concomitant decrease in the amine concentrations (apparent MAO inhibition). Striatal concentrations of MPP+, which is retained in catecholaminergic terminals for similarly long periods, parallel the metabolic changes. Thus, the long-term storage of the MPTP metabolite, MPP+, correlates with altered catecholamine metabolism. The data on the effects of MPTP have been combined into a working model of how MPP+ exerts its effects following subtoxic or toxic doses. The site of this long-term neuronal storage of MPP+ after exposure to subtoxic doses of MPTP is as yet undetermined, but several studies suggest that monoaminergic vesicles may be the primary site, with mitochondria contributing some storage capacity. This vesicular site could represent a potential brain site for the accumulation of toxins during continual or repeated exposure to low levels of MPTP. Induced release from this site might accelerate the toxic interactions with cellular components such as mitochondria.
Author Keywords: Environmental; Monoamine Oxidase; MPP+; MPTP; Parkinsonism; Vesicle
Index Keywords: 1 methyl 4 phenylpyridinium; 1,2,3,6 tetrahydro 1 methyl 4 phenylpyridine; amine oxidase (flavin containing); article; bioaccumulation; catecholamine nerve cell; chronic toxicity; corpus striatum; environmental exposure; neurotoxicity; nonhuman; parkinsonism; priority journal; 1-Methyl-4-phenyl-1,2,3,6-tetrahydropyridine; 1-Methyl-4-phenylpyridinium; Animal; Basal Ganglia Diseases; Catecholamines; Corpus Striatum; Human; Models, Neurological; MPTP Poisoning; Neurons; Time Factors

Authors: Tian G., Smith K.E., Biro G.P., Butler K.W., Haas N., Scott J., Anderson R., Deslauriers R.
Title: A comparison of UW cold storage solution and St. Thomas' solution II: A 31P NMR and functional study of isolated porcine hearts
Source title: Journal of Heart and Lung Transplantation
Affiliations: Institute for Biological Sciences, National Research Council of Canada, Montreal Rd, Bldg. M-40, Ottawa, Ont. K1A 0R6, Canada
Authors with affiliations: Tian, G., Institute for Biological Sciences, National Research Council of Canada, Montreal Rd, Bldg. M-40, Ottawa, Ont. K1A 0R6, Canada; Smith, K.E., Institute for Biological Sciences, National Research Council of Canada, Montreal Rd, Bldg. M-40, Ottawa, Ont. K1A 0R6, Canada; Biro, G.P., Institute for Biological Sciences, National Research Council of Canada, Montreal Rd, Bldg. M-40, Ottawa, Ont. K1A 0R6, Canada; Butler, K.W., Institute for Biological Sciences, National Research Council of Canada, Montreal Rd, Bldg. M-40, Ottawa, Ont. K1A 0R6, Canada; Haas, N., Institute for Biological Sciences, National Research Council of Canada, Montreal Rd, Bldg. M-40, Ottawa, Ont. K1A 0R6, Canada; Scott, J., Institute for Biological Sciences, National Research Council of Canada, Montreal Rd, Bldg. M-40, Ottawa, Ont. K1A 0R6, Canada; Anderson, R., Institute for Biological Sciences, National Research Council of Canada, Montreal Rd, Bldg. M-40, Ottawa, Ont. K1A 0R6, Canada; Deslauriers, R., Institute for Biological Sciences, National Research Council of Canada, Montreal Rd, Bldg. M-40, Ottawa, Ont. K1A 0R6, Canada
Abstract: Although University of Wisconsin cold storage solution provides excellent preservation for the pancreas, the kidney, and the liver after extended cold ischemic storage, its ability to preserve the heart for extended cold storage periods is not yet proved. This study was carried out to evaluate the effect of University of Wisconsin solution on heart preservation and to compare it to modified St. Thomas' solution II with respect to the capacity to preserve high-energy phosphates and contractile function in pig hearts. Hearts were arrested with either University of Wisconsin cold storage solution or St. Thomas' solution II (10 ml/kg) and kept ischemic at 12° C or 4° C for 8 hours. Functional recovery after the preservation period was assessed by means of ventricular function curves of the isovolumically contracting Langendorff model perfused with modified Krebs-Henseleit solution. Phosphorus 31 nuclear magnetic resonance spectroscopy was used to monitor high-energy phosphates and intracellular pH during preservation and reperfusion. At 12° C, hearts arrested and preserved with University of Wisconsin solution showed a rapid decrease in phosphocreatine and adenosine triphosphate. With St. Thomas' solution, phosphocreatine and adenosine triphosphate decreased slowly. Functional recovery was poorer with University of Wisconsin solution than with St. Thomas' solution. Hearts preserved at 4° C with either solution showed no significant differences in high-energy phosphate content and functional recovery. Rigorous control of the low temperature (4° C) is necessary when University of Wisconsin solution is used for heart preservation.

Authors: Marinelli R.A., Penney D.G., Marinelli W.A., Baciewicz Jr. F.A.
Title: Rotary motion in the heart and blood vessels: A review
Affiliations: Department of Physiology, School of Medicine, Wayne State University, 540 E. Canfield, Detroit, MI 48201, United States
Authors with affiliations: Marinelli, R.A., Department of Physiology, School of Medicine, Wayne State University, 540 E. Canfield, Detroit, MI 48201, United States; Penney, D.G., Department of Physiology, School of Medicine, Wayne State University, 540 E. Canfield, Detroit, MI 48201, United States; Marinelli, W.A., Department of Physiology, School of Medicine, Wayne State University, 540 E. Canfield, Detroit, MI 48201, United States; Baciewicz Jr., F.A., Department of Physiology, School of Medicine, Wayne State University, 540 E. Canfield, Detroit, MI 48201, United States
Abstract: The 'wringing,' twisting, or rotary motion of the left ventricle during contraction has been described since early times. Nevertheless, this aspect of heart movement has, and continues to remain, largely unknown to the physician and life scientist. The extent of twisting, the regional variation in this phenomenon, and the effects on it of inotropic state, load conditions, disease state, etc., are just beginning to be understood. New noninvasive methodology, including echocardiography, MR scanning, and ballistocardiography have opened this area to study, allowing the clinical implications of altered heart torsion to be appreciated. Rotary motion of the heart appears to be a function of the opposing spirally oriented muscle layers of the ventricle. It is conjectured that twist induced by contraction of one layer may result in energy storage in another layer, which can be recovered in diastole, recoil operating as in a torsional pendulum. Whether it is a function of ventricular wall morphology, ventricular torsional deformation, or events occurring in the large arteries, rotary blood flow has recently been detected by several noninvasive methods at various sites in the ascending and descending aorta, and in the carotid arteries. It remains unclear, however, whether this pattern of blood flow has functional and clinical implications for vascular health; abnormal blood flow has been implicated in atherosclerosis and thrombosis. Rotary motion could conceivably assist ventricular ejection via momentum imparted from the vortex, contributing to the kinetic energy portion of the total fluid energy of systolic ejection. These and other related questions need to be addressed by experimental studies.
Index Keywords: ascending aorta; biomechanics; blood rheology; cineradiography; diastole; echocardiography; heart left ventricle; heart movement; heart right ventricle; human; normal human; nuclear magnetic resonance imaging; review; systole

Authors: Choong Y.S., Gavin J.B.
Title: Functional recovery of hearts after cardioplegia and storage in University of Wisconsin and in St. Thomas' Hospital solutions
Source title: Journal of Heart and Lung Transplantation
Authors with affiliations: Choong, Y.S.; Gavin, J.B.
Abstract: There are conflicting reports of the beneficial effects of University of Wisconsin (UW) cardioplegic solution used in heart preservation techniques. Therefore we investigated the efficacy of myocardial protection in adult rat hearts subjected to single-dose infusion (3 minutes) of nonoxygenated cardioplegic solutions (UW or St. Thomas' Hospital solution No. 2 [STH]) and stored at 4° C by immersion in the same solution or in saline solution. Isolated working-heart preparations (n = 8 per group) were used to assess the prearrest (20 minutes' normothermic perfusion) and postischemic left ventricular functions. Four groups of hearts underwent 5, 8, 10, and 20 hours of cold ischemia (4° C) in UW solution. Hearts stored for 8 to 20 hours showed no postischemic recovery of cardiac pump function (aortic flow, 0%), had decreased levels of myocardial high-energy phosphates, and were highly edematous (50% to 70% increased). After 5 hours of storage there was also poor recovery of aortic flow, coronary flow, and aortic pressure (55.0% ± 19.4%, 67.1% ± 5.1%, and 58.1% ± 11.7%, respectively) but good recovery of adenosine triphosphate, creatine phosphate, and guanosine triphosphate (18.54 ± 1.42, 29.99 ± 2.05, and 1.64 ± 0.14 μmol/gm dry weight, respectively). In contrast, hearts arrested and stored in STH solution for 5 hours rapidly established normal left ventricular functions (aortic flow, 111.5% ± 2.5%; cardiac output, 99.1% ± 1.2%; coronary flow, 85.0% ± 3.4%; heart rate, 95.8% ± 2.7%; and aortic pressure, 94.6%). A group of hearts arrested with STH solution but stored in saline solution recovered more slowly, had only partial return of function (aortic flow, 73.6% ± 14.8%; p < 0.01 vs STH/STH group), and had significantly greater tissue water content (8.020 ± 0.080 vs 6.870 ± 0.126 ml/gm dry wt; p < 0.01). These results demonstrate the superior preservation of explanted hearts at 4° C obtained by STH cardioplegic solution compared with UW solution under conditions used for transplantation.

Authors: Yen G., Michel A.N.
Title: A learning and forgetting algorithm in associative memories: Results involving pseudo inverses
Source title: Proceedings - IEEE International Symposium on Circuits and Systems
Authors with affiliations: Yen, G.; Michel, A.N.
Abstract: The authors develop a design technique for associative memories with learning and forgetting abilities via artificial feedback neural networks. The proposed method utilizes the theory of large-scale dynamical systems, instead of the usual energy methods. Networks synthesized by this design method are capable of learning new patterns as well as forgetting existing patterns without the necessity of recomputing the entire interconnection weights and external inputs. The method employs the properties of pseudo-inverse matrices to iteratively solve systems of linear equations, and provides significant improvements over the outer product method and the projection learning rule. Several specific examples are given to illustrate the strengths and weaknesses of the methodology.
Index Keywords: Computer Programming--Algorithms; Learning Systems; Mathematical Techniques--Linear Algebra; Neural Networks; Associative Memories; Forgetting Algorithms; Data Storage, Digital

Authors: Amerson R.S., Tyler E.J., Converse J.C.
Title: Infiltration as affected by compaction, fines and contact area of gravel
Affiliations: Univ of Wisconsin-Madison, United States
Authors with affiliations: Amerson, R.S., Univ of Wisconsin-Madison, United States; Tyler, E.J., Univ of Wisconsin-Madison, United States; Converse, J.C., Univ of Wisconsin-Madison, United States
Abstract: Traditional onsite wastewater treatment systems utilize gravel, also referred to as aggregate, to support the sidewalls of the soil excavation preventing its collapse, to dissipate energy from incoming wastewater which might erode the infiltrative surface, to provide storage of peak wastewater flows, to support the distribution pipe, and to provide a media through which the wastewater can flow from the pipe to reach the infiltrative surface (EPA 1980). Some have questioned the effect gravel has upon the infiltration rate of wastewater into soil. The supposed problems caused by gravel include the compaction of the soil infiltrative surface by falling gravel during system construction, the presence of excessive fine earth material, or 'fines,' on the gravel which can wash off and form a restrictive layer on the soil surface, and the 'masking' of a portion of the soil infiltrative surface by contact with the gravel (May 1987). The objective of this study was to evaluate the effect of gravel on soil infiltration rates, and thus on the operation of newly constructed onsite wastewater treatment systems. Specifically, objectives were to evaluate the effect of 1) soil compaction and smearing by falling gravel, 2) the fine earth material carried by gravel, and 3) the masking of the infiltrative surface caused by the contact area between the gravel and the soil.
Index Keywords: Compaction; Gravel; Particle size analysis; Pipe flow; Sewage treatment; Soils; Surfaces; Contact area; Fines; Infiltration rates; Infiltrative surfaces; Onsite wastewater treatment systems; Infiltration

Authors: Lamarre Leslie, Birk James, Pollak Robert, Mehta Ben, Goodson Jim
Title: Alabama cooperative generates from air
Authors with affiliations: Lamarre, Leslie; Birk, James; Pollak, Robert; Mehta, Ben; Goodson, Jim
Abstract: Alabama Electric Cooperative marked a milestone in the history of the electric utility industry with the dedication of the nation's first compressed-air energy storage plant on September 27. Located in McIntosh, Alabama, the 110-MW facility compresses air into a 19-million-cubic-foot underground cavern during periods of low electricity demand. During periods of peak demand, the air can be released, heated, and expanded through a turbine to generate electricity as needed. Overall during the generation period, the plant uses one-third of the fuel required by a conventional combustion turbine power plant and, as a result, releases one-third the emissions. EPRI studies show that 75% of the country's geology has the potential to provide reliable underground air storage. A dozen other utilities are seriously investigating the implementation of this technology.
Index Keywords: Energy resources; Energy storage; Turbomachinery; Air storage; Peak demands; Peak shaving; Underground caverns; Compressed air motors
