Abstract: This Volume 37A contains 93 papers, which are grouped under the following headings: heat and mass transfer in helium II; applications of helium II; heat transfer in cryogenic fluids: heat exchangers and thermoacoustic oscillations; insulation; applications of superconductivity: magnet stability and coil protection; applications of superconductivity: magnets and other devices; applications of superconductivity: cryogenic techniques; refrigeration for electronics; and refrigeration of superconducting systems. Some topics discussed by the papers are cited as examples: a brief history of cryogenics; study of a porous element for a thermomechanical pump in superfluid helium; charaterization of two phase flow in a Fermilab Tevatron satellite refrigerator; design and calibration of a test facility for MLI thermal performance measurements below 80K; influence of disturbance characteristics and copper to superconductor ratio on stability; low operating voltage suerconducting current limiter; SSC 50mm collider dipole cryostat design; a cryogenic system for Josephson computers; and a cryogenic system for the superconducting magnet.
Index Keywords: Electronic equipment; Heat exchangers; Heat transfer; Helium; High temperature superconductors; Hydrogen; Josephson junction devices; Nitrogen; Oxygen; Refrigeration; Superconducting magnets; Thermal insulation; Cryogenic heat exchanger; Darcy goodness factor; EIREV; Helium II; Magnetic energy storage systems; National Aerospace Plane; Superconducting electromagnetic ship thruster; Superconducting Supercollider; Superfluid helium; Thermal acoustic oscillation; Cryogenics

Authors: Lecocq Alfred, Furukawa Kazuo
Title: Hydrogen production for the next century
Source title: International Journal of Global Energy Issues
Affiliations: EURIWA
Authors with affiliations: Lecocq, Alfred, EURIWA; Furukawa, Kazuo, EURIWA
Abstract: The growth of energy consumption at world level should induce, in the next century, a strong supply of all primary energy resources. Nuclear devices, renewable and solar resources, will finally close the fossil era, but the dominant primary fossil energy in the next 100 years will be natural gas. This shift will not prevent the increasing concentration of CO2 in the atmosphere. Nuclear energy is able to alleviate the problem of CO2 emissions through steam reforming of natural gas. With this chemical reaction, carried out in large chemical-nuclear power centres, all the energy of the original methane, plus about 30 per cent deriving from nuclear heat, appears in the form of hydrogen. CO2 gas, produced on an industrial scale, could be easily recovered for injection underground, instead of the usual release into the atmosphere. But nuclear energy has to solve its own problems which are the supply of fissile resources, flexibility versus power size and demand, safety, proliferation and terrorism, waste, economics and public acceptance. All these topics may find a global solution only through a deep change in the philosophical approach to nuclear fission energy. Molten salt mixtures made of beryllium, lithium, thorium and fissile fluorides can be used in a new kind of fission reactor and fissile breeder. These have already been studied and described by laboratories all over the world, and will be the next generation of nuclear power generators.
Index Keywords: Air Pollution - Gaseous Effluents; Environmental Protection; Hydrogen - Storage; Nuclear Energy - Fission Reactions; Nuclear Power Plants; Alternative Fuels; Energy Demand; Steam Reformation; Hydrogen Fuels

Authors: Shikari Yusuf A.
Title: GRI role in gas storage technology research
Source title: Proceedings of the American Gas Association, Operating Section
Affiliations: Gas Research Inst, United States
Authors with affiliations: Shikari, Yusuf A., Gas Research Inst, United States
Abstract: Over the past two decades, the significant growth in gas storage has been one of the most prominent changes in the natural gas industry. Mid-70s saw the beginnings of the regulatory reforms that have, to this date, continued to prompt the local distribution companies, central power producers, and large industrial (and certain commercial) gas customers to participate directly in the purchase and transportation of gas rather than relying on the interstate pipelines. Unbundling of utility services and rates and pricing of energy based on its market value (rather than cost-of- service) are becoming more common. Operating procedures are being revised to improve efficiency and increase throughput. As this restructuring moves the natural gas industry towards a deregulated, competitive environment, gas storage is becoming a vital, strategic component of the energy service market in the United States (U.S.). Recent forecasts of steady growth in gas demand - and prospects for improved gas supplies - will further enhance opportunities for new storage projects in coming years. The Gas Research Institute (GRI), as a research arm of the natural gas industry, has an important role in developing technologies and techniques that increase the value of various gas storage options to its members as well as current and potential gas consumers. In the near term, GRI is focusing its R&D efforts primarily on the development of technologies that would enhance the deliverability of gas from existing underground gas storage facilities. In the long term, GRI's Gas Storage R&D Program will address expanded development of natural gas storage technology to provide new capabilities for storage near demand centers and at powerplant sites. This paper discusses the GRI role in gas storage technology research and highlights key results achieved to-date for selected research projects sponsored under its Gas Storage R&D Program.
Index Keywords: Gas industry; Gases; Research; Storage (materials); Deliverability; Gas research institute; Gas storage; Rock cavern storage; Salt dome storage; Well productivity; Societies and institutions

Authors: Haimson Bezalel C.
Title: Hydraulic fracturing measurements in New York City reaffirm the uniformity of the stress regime in Northeastern United States
Authors with affiliations: Haimson, Bezalel C.
Abstract: It was conducted five hydraulic fracturing stress measurements at depths of 746-800 m, in New York City, as part of a feasibility study toward the constructin of an energy storage cavern in bedrock. The results yield the following stress condition if pore pressure is assumed hydrostatic. This state of stress favoring reverse to strike-slip faulting with NE-ENE maximum compression is very similar to previous hydrofrac results at other northeastern United States locations. Although earlier focal mechanism solutions suggested an apparent diverse stress regime in New England and vicinity, recent reassessments conclude that the high-quality solutions are broadly consistent with the in sity stress measurements and supproted by borehole breakout logging.
Index Keywords: Hydraulic fracturing; Stress analysis; Flowrate-Time digital recording; Hydraulic fracture orientation; Hydraulic fracturing tests; New york city hydraulic fracturing measurements; Northeastern US stress regime; Natural gas wells

Authors: Srinivasan Venugopal, Chia Chen-Siang
Title: Improving bidirectional associative memory performance by unlearning
Authors with affiliations: Srinivasan, Venugopal; Chia, Chen-Siang
Abstract: An encoding strategy for improving the noise tolerance and capacity of Kosko's bidirectional associative memory is proposed. Energy minima corresponding to pattern pairs that are to be stored are enhanced, and, simultaneously, unwanted or spurious states are eliminated. The method is an extension of the multiple training procedure that has been described in the literature for inducing local minima at desired locations. An additional unlearning term in the energy expression is included to eliminate spurious states. Spurious states and parameter values for constructing the network were determined experimentally. Computer simulations showed that unlearning increases the network's storage capacity and its tolerance to noise to a level not achievable by multiple training alone.
Index Keywords: Codes, Symbolic - Encoding; Computer Simulation; Learning Systems; Noise, Spurious Signal; Bidirectional Associative Memories; Noise Tolerance; Storage Capacity; Unlearning; Neural Networks

Authors: Weiberg Carl, Iannucci Joseph, Reading Melissa
Title: Distributed Utility: technology, customer, and public policy changes shaping the electrical utility of tomorrow
Affiliations: Pacific Gas & Electric Co, San Ramon, United States
Authors with affiliations: Weiberg, Carl, Pacific Gas & Electric Co, San Ramon, United States; Iannucci, Joseph, Pacific Gas & Electric Co, San Ramon, United States; Reading, Melissa, Pacific Gas & Electric Co, San Ramon, United States
Abstract: US electric utilities have become highly centralized and vertically integrated companies. They have evolved to provide power with large central station plants tied to customers through complex transmission and distribution (T&D) systems. However, significant changes have taken place in the last twenty years, which well result in a much different utility structure in the future. The major changes include: an exhaustion of economies of scale of central generation, flattening of thermal efficiencies of thermal central station generating plants, an increase in T & D expenditures such that the by 1989 these expenditures equaled generation capital investments in the U.S. utility industry, and declining prices of renewable and other modular technologies. Most of these changes increase the relative advantages of modular renewable technologies, which included substantial localized benefits if placed in the distribution system very close to well-marched loads. This paper is a preliminary assessment in which case studies are evaluated, and the findings suggest that dispersed generation, storage and localized utility demand-side management programs could be a cost effective utility strategy. In a case study , for example the energy and capacity of photovoltaics (PV) were calculated to equal $ 260 per KW-year without regard site. Site-specific benefits , however, could, however increase the total benefits to $ 700 per KW-year. Site specific benefits included lower transmission line losses, kVAR support, reliability enhancements, delayed T&D expenditures , and lower emissions. Utility customers will be beneficiaries of distributed resources, if they realize improved and improved and broader utility services, and lower costs due to more efficient T&D asset utilization. The Distributed Utility has several hurdles to overcome: the technologies themselves must achieve lower costs and broader utility acceptance; the sensors and communications software and hardware must be more highly refined; utility planing models must be adapted to evaluate properly simultaneous integration of projects into the generation, transmission, and distribution system in an integrated cost of service planing method; and regulations should be adopted to provide incentives for utilities top adopt the distributed utility structure when it fits in the least-cost planning. While much quantitative and modelling research remains to be completed before a precise evaluation can be made, it is hypothesized that utilities in the future will evolve into distributed utilities.
Index Keywords: Electric load management; Energy management; Energy policy; Planning; Distributed utilities; United States; Electric utilities

Authors: Minor T., Isselhard W., Kunz G., Saad S.
Title: Involvement of oxygen in harvesting injury of the liver - An experimental study including substrate free organ persufflation to evaluate a specific therapeutic approach
Affiliations: Institut for Experimental Medicine, University of Cologne, Robert-Koch-Strasse 10, Köln 41, W-5000, Germany
Authors with affiliations: Minor, T., Institut for Experimental Medicine, University of Cologne, Robert-Koch-Strasse 10, Köln 41, W-5000, Germany; Isselhard, W., Institut for Experimental Medicine, University of Cologne, Robert-Koch-Strasse 10, Köln 41, W-5000, Germany; Kunz, G., Institut for Experimental Medicine, University of Cologne, Robert-Koch-Strasse 10, Köln 41, W-5000, Germany; Saad, S., Institut for Experimental Medicine, University of Cologne, Robert-Koch-Strasse 10, Köln 41, W-5000, Germany
Abstract: The present study was undertaken to assess the role of oxygen free radicals relating to cell damage upon reoxygenation of the ischemically altered isolated rat liver. Livers were excised and flushed via the portal vein with Ringer's solution and Euro-Collins solution, to which superoxide dismutase (SOD) was added in the experimental group. After warm ischemia at 37°C and cold storage at 4°C, the livers were reperfused via the portal vein with carbogensaturated Krebs-Henseleit solution. Other livers were subjected to a retrograde persufflation via the infrahepatic caval vein with either oxygen or nitrogen and then rinsed with Ringer's solution. During reperfusion, SOD-treated livers showed markedly reduced vascular resistance, lower enzyme release and enhanced VO2 accordingly, energy charge at the end of reperfusion was significantly higher in the treated group. With reference to the tissue content of malondialdehyde, SOD-treated livers showed significantly less damage than the controls. Our experiments with substrate-free persufflation provided sound corroboration for these data. Enzyme activities in the eluate were significantly reduced under anoxic conditions as well as in the presence of SOD. We conclude from these data that oxygen free radicals do exert a detrimental impact on the reoxygenated liver, which could be specifically suppressed by application of exogenous SOD. © 1991 Springer-Verlag.
Author Keywords: Free radicals; Liver; Organ persufflation; Reperfusion damage; SOD
Index Keywords: free radical; malonaldehyde; oxygen; superoxide dismutase; animal tissue; article; cell damage; ischemia; liver cell; male; nonhuman; organ preservation; priority journal; rat; Adenosine Triphosphate; Animal; Energy Metabolism; Free Radicals; In Vitro; Lipid Peroxidation; Liver; Male; Oxygen; Rats; Rats, Inbred Strains; Reperfusion Injury; Superoxide Dismutase

Authors: Schmuser P.
Title: Superconducting magnets for particle accelerators
Affiliations: II. Institut für Experimentalphysik, Universität Hamburg, Luruper Chaussée 149, D-2000 Hamburg 50, Germany
Authors with affiliations: Schmuser, P., II. Institut für Experimentalphysik, Universität Hamburg, Luruper Chaussée 149, D-2000 Hamburg 50, Germany
Abstract: All new large hadron storage rings or colliders are equipped with superconducting magnets, which allow significantly higher particle energies to be achieved at much reduced operational costs. The basis properties and design criteria of superconducting accelerator magnets are reviewed with special emphasis on the following topics: field calculation and multipole expansion; layout of coils; influence of iron yoke; mechanical tolerances; magnetic forces and stresses in the coils; persistent currents in the superconductor filaments and resulting field distortions; stability of the magnets; quench origins, quench protection; performance of practical magnets; prospects for future applications.

Authors: Eggert F., Maneck M., Scholze F., Krumrey M., Tegeler E.
Title: Calibration of a Si(Li) detector system with different radiation entrance windows
Affiliations: ZWG-RönTec, Schnellerstrasse 138, O-1190 Berlin, Germany; Physikalisch-Technische Bundesanstalt (PTB), Institut Berlin, Abbestrasse 2-12, W-1000 Berlin 10, Germany
Authors with affiliations: Eggert, F., ZWG-RönTec, Schnellerstrasse 138, O-1190 Berlin, Germany; Maneck, M., ZWG-RönTec, Schnellerstrasse 138, O-1190 Berlin, Germany; Scholze, F., ZWG-RönTec, Schnellerstrasse 138, O-1190 Berlin, Germany; Krumrey, M., Physikalisch-Technische Bundesanstalt (PTB), Institut Berlin, Abbestrasse 2-12, W-1000 Berlin 10, Germany; Tegeler, E., Physikalisch-Technische Bundesanstalt (PTB), Institut Berlin, Abbestrasse 2-12, W-1000 Berlin 10, Germany
Abstract: The spectral quantum detection efficiency of a Si(Li) detector was determined using the electron storage ring BESSY as a standard source of calculable spectral photon flux. The calibrations were performed for the same detector system with a Be window, an ultrathin silicon-based window and without window for photon energies above 300 eV. For comparison the transmission of the windows was measured in monochromatic radiation from 350-2000 eV with high spectral resolution.

Authors: Havaux M., Greppin H., Strasser R.J.
Title: Functioning of photosystems I and II in pea leaves exposed to heat stress in the presence or absence of light - Analysis using in-vivo fluorescence, absorbance, oxygen and photoacoustic measurements
Affiliations: Laboratoire de Bioénergétique, Université de Genève, Station de Botanique, Lullier-Genève, CH-1254, Switzerland; Laboratoire de Biochimie et physiologie végétales, Université de Genève, 3 place de l'Université, Genève 4, CH-1211, Switzerland
Authors with affiliations: Havaux, M., Laboratoire de Bioénergétique, Université de Genève, Station de Botanique, Lullier-Genève, CH-1254, Switzerland; Greppin, H., Laboratoire de Biochimie et physiologie végétales, Université de Genève, 3 place de l'Université, Genève 4, CH-1211, Switzerland; Strasser, R.J., Laboratoire de Bioénergétique, Université de Genève, Station de Botanique, Lullier-Genève, CH-1254, Switzerland
Abstract: Fluorimetric, photoacoustic, polarographic and absorbance techniques were used to measure in situ various functional aspects of the photochemical apparatus of photosynthesis in intact pea leaves (Pisum sativum L.) after short exposures to a high temperature of 40 ° C. The results indicated (i) that the in-vivo responses of the two photosystems to high-temperature pretreatments were markedly different and in some respects opposite, with photosystem (PS) II activity being inhibited (or down-regulated) and PSI function being stimulated; and (ii) that light strongly interacts with the response of the photosystems, acting as an efficient protector of the photochemical activity against its inactivation by heat. When imposed in the dark, heat provoked a drastic inhibition of photosynthetic oxygen evolution and photochemical energy storage, correlated with a marked loss of variable PSII-chlorophyll fluorescence emission. None of the above changes were observed in leaves which were illuminated during heating. This photoprotection was saturated at rather low light fluence rates (around 10 W · m-2). Heat stress in darkness appeared to increase the capacity for cyclic electron flow around PSI, as indicated by the enhanced photochemical energy storage in far-red light and the faster decay of P700+(oxidized reaction center of PSI) monitored upon sudded interruption of the far-red light. The presence of light during heat stress reduced somewhat this PSI-driven cyclic electron transport. It was also observed that heat stress in darkness resulted in the progressive closure of the PSI reaction centers in leaves under steady illumination whereas PSII traps remained largely open, possibly reflecting the adjustment of the photochemical efficiency of undamaged PSI to the reduced rate of photochemistry in PSII. © 1991 Springer-Verlag.
Author Keywords: Chlorophyll fluorescence; Heat stress; Leaf (light absorbance); Photoprotection; Photosystem I, II; Pisum (photosynthesis)

Authors: Gräf D., Grundner M., Mühlhoff L., Dellith M.
Title: Influence of Cu on the native oxide growth of Si
Affiliations: Wacker-Chemitronic GmbH, Research Center, Postfach 1140, D-8263 Burghausen, Germany; Siemens AG, Department HL TB 34, Otto-Hahn-Ring 6, D-8000 München 83, Germany
Authors with affiliations: Gräf, D., Wacker-Chemitronic GmbH, Research Center, Postfach 1140, D-8263 Burghausen, Germany; Grundner, M., Wacker-Chemitronic GmbH, Research Center, Postfach 1140, D-8263 Burghausen, Germany; Mühlhoff, L., Siemens AG, Department HL TB 34, Otto-Hahn-Ring 6, D-8000 München 83, Germany; Dellith, M., Siemens AG, Department HL TB 34, Otto-Hahn-Ring 6, D-8000 München 83, Germany
Abstract: The influence of Cu on the native oxide growth on Si wafers was investigated by means of x-ray photoelectron spectroscopy and high-resolution electron energy loss spectroscopy (HREELS). The Cu coverage on the Si wafers was varied from 1012 cm-2 to about half a monolayer by adding Cu to aqueous HF in the ppm range. Immediately after the HF treatment no SiO2-x component (chemical shift ≳3.4 eV) can be measured by XPS. The chemical surface composition as characterized by HREELS is practically the same as for noncontaminated HF. A short additional water rinse of 2 min changes the chemical surface state of the Si wafers significantly. For Cu coverages more than about 1% of a monolayer, a pronounced initial oxide growth was noticed already after a 2-min water rinse with the oxide thickness depending on the amount of Cu coverage present on the Si surface. The oxide growth kinetics after storage of Cu-contaminated Si surfaces in air was studied for storage times up to 1 year. With almost no change in the chemical surface state visible directly after the HF treatment, however, an enhanced roughness of the Si wafer was noticed. The copper-induced enhancement of the oxidation of the silicon surface in combination with the oxide removal of the HF leads to an etching of the Si wafer.

Authors: Veeranjaneyulu K., Charland M., Charlebois D., Leblanc R.M.
Title: Photosynthetic energy storage of Photosystems I and II in the spectral range of photosynthetically active radiation in intact sugar maple leaves
Affiliations: Centre de recherche en photobiophysique, Université du Québec à Trois-Rivières, 3351, boul. des Forges, Trois-Rivières, G9A 5H7, Québec, Canada
Authors with affiliations: Veeranjaneyulu, K., Centre de recherche en photobiophysique, Université du Québec à Trois-Rivières, 3351, boul. des Forges, Trois-Rivières, G9A 5H7, Québec, Canada; Charland, M., Centre de recherche en photobiophysique, Université du Québec à Trois-Rivières, 3351, boul. des Forges, Trois-Rivières, G9A 5H7, Québec, Canada; Charlebois, D., Centre de recherche en photobiophysique, Université du Québec à Trois-Rivières, 3351, boul. des Forges, Trois-Rivières, G9A 5H7, Québec, Canada; Leblanc, R.M., Centre de recherche en photobiophysique, Université du Québec à Trois-Rivières, 3351, boul. des Forges, Trois-Rivières, G9A 5H7, Québec, Canada
Abstract: The relative activity of Photosystems (PS) I and II in the spectral range between 400 and 720 nm was studied by measuring photosynthetic energy storage (ES) of an intact sugar maple leaf using photoacoustic spectroscopy. ES, determined with a modulated (80 Hz) monochromatic light beam in the presence of saturating intensity of background non-modulated white light, indicated the total energy stored by both photosystems (EST). Using background far-red light, ES of PS I (ESPS I) was quantified. ESPS II was derived from EST-ESPS I. EST dependence on intensity and wavelength of modulated light was studied at 470, 560, 640 and 680 nm. EST was maximum in red light and minimum in blue light. It decreased with an increase in modulated light intensity. The ratio ESPS II/ESPS I, measured at 640 nm, remained nearly constant with an increase in modulated light intensity. The relative quantum yield of EST spectrum showed two peaks around 610 and 660 nm, and declined sharply after 680 nm, revealing a clear red drop. ESPS I spectrum presented peaks around 610 and 670 nm, and a minimum between 440 and 470 nm. ESPS I was observed beyond 700 nm up to 720 nm, indicating the energy stored by cyclic electron transport. ESPS II spectrum showed broad peaks, around 460, 490, 600 and 660 nm, and a shoulder between 530 and 560 nm. ESPS II was always higher than ESPS I between 400 and 690 nm and reached zero around 700 nm. © 1991 Kluwer Academic Publishers.
Author Keywords: action spectrum; light distribution; photoacoustic spectroscopy

Authors: Sato E., Shikoda A., Kimura S., Sagae M., Isobe H., Takahashi K., Tamakawa Y., Yanagisawa T., Honda K., Yokota Y.
Title: Kilohertz-range flash x-ray generator utilizing a triode in conjunction with an extremely hot cathode
Affiliations: Department of Physics, School of General Education, Iwate Medical University, Morioka 020, Japan; Computer Research Center, School of Medicine, Iwate Medical University, Morioka 020, Japan; Department of Radiology, School of Medicine, Iwate Medical University, Morioka 020, Japan; X-Ray Tube Division, Hitachi Medical Inc., Mobara 297, Japan
Authors with affiliations: Sato, E., Department of Physics, School of General Education, Iwate Medical University, Morioka 020, Japan; Shikoda, A., Department of Physics, School of General Education, Iwate Medical University, Morioka 020, Japan; Kimura, S., Department of Physics, School of General Education, Iwate Medical University, Morioka 020, Japan; Sagae, M., Department of Physics, School of General Education, Iwate Medical University, Morioka 020, Japan; Isobe, H., Department of Physics, School of General Education, Iwate Medical University, Morioka 020, Japan; Takahashi, K., Computer Research Center, School of Medicine, Iwate Medical University, Morioka 020, Japan; Tamakawa, Y., Department of Radiology, School of Medicine, Iwate Medical University, Morioka 020, Japan; Yanagisawa, T., Department of Radiology, School of Medicine, Iwate Medical University, Morioka 020, Japan; Honda, K., X-Ray Tube Division, Hitachi Medical Inc., Mobara 297, Japan; Yokota, Y., X-Ray Tube Division, Hitachi Medical Inc., Mobara 297, Japan
Abstract: The construction and the fundamental studies of a kilohertz-range flash x-ray generator having a triode in conjunction with an extremely hot cathode are described. This generator consisted of the following components: a constant-high voltage power supply, an energy storage condenser of 100 nF, a constant high-voltage power supply for regulating an initial grid voltage of -1.6 kV, a grid pulser, and an x-ray tube. The x-ray tube was of an enclosed-triode type and consisted of the following major parts: an anode rod made of copper, a plane anode tip (target) made of tungsten, a focusing electrode made of iron, a hot cathode (filament) made of tungsten, a grid made from tungsten wire, and a glass tube body. The energy storage condenser was charged from 50 to 70 kV, and the electric charges in the condenser were discharged repetitively to the x-ray tube by the grid electrode driven by the grid pulser. The temperature of the filament was about 2000 K, and the cathode current was primarily controlled by the grid voltage and its value was less than 1.2 A. The pulse widths were about 1 μs and the maximum repetitive frequency was about 2.0 kHz. The x-ray intensity was 19.7 nC/kg at 0.5 m per pulse with a peak grid voltage of 1.0 kV and a condenser charged voltage of 70 kV.

Authors: Yoneta M., Kamiura Y., Hashimoto F.
Title: Chemical etching-induced defects in phosphorus-doped silicon
Affiliations: Faculty of Engineering, Okayama University, Okayama 700, Japan
Authors with affiliations: Yoneta, M., Faculty of Engineering, Okayama University, Okayama 700, Japan; Kamiura, Y., Faculty of Engineering, Okayama University, Okayama 700, Japan; Hashimoto, F., Faculty of Engineering, Okayama University, Okayama 700, Japan
Abstract: We have found with deep-level transient spectroscopy that chemical etching introduced three electron traps, E1(0.11), E2(0.13), and E3(0.15), in the near-surface region of phosphorus-doped crystalline silicon. The results on depth profiles of these traps and carriers suggested the donor character of the traps, but they hardly exhibited the Poole-Frenkel effect. From their correlations with carbon and oxygen, we propose a tentative identification that E1 and E2 traps arise from two kinds of hydrogen-oxygen-carbon complexes and the E3 trap arises from a hydrogen-carbon complex. Hydrogen is assumed to be adsorbed on the silicon surface during chemical etching and diffuse into the interior of the crystal during the subsequent evaporation and sample storage processes to be trapped at two kinds of oxygen-carbon complexes and substitutional carbon to form the traps. The annealing behavior of E2 and E3 traps in the dark were studied in detail. Their densities were increased at temperatures of 70-90 °C and subsequently were decreased at higher temperatures obeying first-order kinetics. The increase in trap densities is interpreted to be due to the further formation of the traps by capturing mobile hydrogen by oxygen-carbon complexes and substitutional carbon. This hydrogen is assumed to be released at temperatures of 70-90 °C by the dissociation of the hydrogen-phosphorus complex that was also formed by in-diffusing hydrogen during the evaporation and sample storage processes. The subsequent decrease in trap densities is attributed to the thermal dissociation of the traps at higher annealing temperatures and the subsequent loss of hydrogen at sinks. The illumination of band-gap light above 230 K annihilated the traps. The annihilation of the traps occurred only outside the depletion region of the Schottky structure. This effect is ascribed to the recombination-enhanced reaction, in which the electronic energy released by the electron-hole recombination at a trap level is converted into local vibrational energy to induce the thermal dissociation of the traps.

Authors: Di L.M., Bakker H.
Title: Mechanically induced phase transformation in the Nb3Au intermetallic compound
Affiliations: Van der Waals-Zeeman Lab., Amsterdam Univ., Netherlands
Authors with affiliations: Di, L.M., Van der Waals-Zeeman Lab., Amsterdam Univ., Netherlands; Bakker, H., Van der Waals-Zeeman Lab., Amsterdam Univ., Netherlands
Abstract: The A15 intermetallic compound Nb3Au was subjected to grinding in a high-energy ball mill. A phase transformation from the A15 phase to the high-temperature BCC solid solution of gold in niobium was observed after milling. Differential scanning calorimetry revealed an exothermic peak with a heat content of 4.6 kJ mol-1. The activation energy was 435 kJ mol-1. The present result is very similar to the previous results on the V3Ga compound. The energies involved in the order-disorder reactions for these two compounds scale very well. These results, together with similar results obtained by other authors, strongly support the concept of energy storage by ball milling mainly in the form of atomic disorder.

Authors: Kaplan C.R., Oran E.S.
Title: Mechanisms of Ignition and Detonation Formation in Propane-Air Mixtures
Affiliations: Navy Technology Center for Safety and Survivability, Naval Research Laboratory, Washington, D.C. 20375, United States; Laboratory for Computational Physics, Fluid Dynamics Naval Research Laboratory, Washington, D.C. 20375, United States
Authors with affiliations: Kaplan, C.R., Navy Technology Center for Safety and Survivability, Naval Research Laboratory, Washington, D.C. 20375, United States; Oran, E.S., Laboratory for Computational Physics, Fluid Dynamics Naval Research Laboratory, Washington, D.C. 20375, United States
Abstract: Numerical simulations of the spontaneous ignition and subsequent detonation of propane-air mixtures caused by a weak shock in a partially confined volume containing an obstacle are performed to study potential hazards from a leaking storage container. The numerical model combines a solution of the compressible equations of fluid dynamics with a phenomenological chemical induction model for species conversion and energy release. The purpose of the simulations is to study the mechanism of the ignition and detonation processes due to shock reflections from the wall boundaries. Nonreactive simulations show how the obstacle partially blocks the flow such that one portion of the shock front reflects off of the obstacle and another portion is transmitted. Reactive-flow simulations of stoichiometric propane-air show spontaneous ignition behind the shock reflected from the obstacle and later transition to detonation in the direction of the transmitted wave. A series of computations performed to study the effect of obstacle height show the various mechanisms responsible for the transition to detonation for the different obstacle sizes considered. Simulations in a mixture with variable stoichiometry around the obstacle, a more realistic picture of the physical scenario, show decay of the transmitted shock and then re-ignition as the shock reaches the stoichiometric region. Two separate areas of ignition eventually combine and transition to detonation. As this detonation propagates into the lean region far from the obstacle, it decays into a shock wave followed by a decaying flame front. © 1991, Taylor & Francis Group, LLC. All rights reserved.
Author Keywords: Reactive-flow simulations; spontaneous ignition; transition to detonation

Authors: Li-Jun Lu, Jin-Yong Chen
Title: Discussion and improvement of the SX-700 beamline
Source title: Nuclear Inst. and Methods in Physics Research, A
Affiliations: Hefei National Synchrotron Radiation Laboratory, University of Science and Technology of China, Hefei, Anhui 230026, China; Changchun Institute of Fine Mechanics and Optics of Academia Sinica, Changchun, Jielin, 130022, People's Republic of China
Authors with affiliations: Li-Jun Lu, Hefei National Synchrotron Radiation Laboratory, University of Science and Technology of China, Hefei, Anhui 230026, China; Jin-Yong Chen, Changchun Institute of Fine Mechanics and Optics of Academia Sinica, Changchun, Jielin, 130022, People's Republic of China
Abstract: We analyze and compare the existing designs of SX-700 beamline in this article and describe a new version of the SX-700 beamline in which we make some improvements on SX-700 designs mentioned before [1-4]. The new design uses a plane elliptical pre-mirror which deflects the SR beam vertically to compress the SR source onto the entrance slit and uses an ellipsoidal mirror to focus the monochromatized light. By proper selection of design parameters, the beamline produces non-astigmatic and nearly aberration free images like the improved SX-700 beamline by Nyholm et al. [4]. But our design has the following advantages: (1) our plane elliptical pre-mirror is much smaller, (2) an entrance slit is put in the beamline, and (3) the beamline is suitable to be installed at high energy electron storage rings. © 1991.

Authors: Moses K., Manore M.M.
Title: Development and testing of a carbohydrate monitoring tool for athletes
Source title: Journal of the American Dietetic Association
Affiliations: Department of Family Resources, Arizona State University, Tempe, AZ 85287-2502, United States
Authors with affiliations: Moses, K., Department of Family Resources, Arizona State University, Tempe, AZ 85287-2502, United States; Manore, M.M., Department of Family Resources, Arizona State University, Tempe, AZ 85287-2502, United States
Abstract: Improving carbohydrate intake in athletes will increase muscle glycogen storage. This in turn can improve exercise time and performance by delaying fatigue. However, planning and consuming a diet that contains 60% to 70% carbohydrate is difficult for most athletes. To develop a simple carbohydrate monitoring tool for athletes, we analyzed three sets of 3-day diet records from 17 male endurance runners over a 10-week competitive period and 9 female endurance runners over a 9-week training period. We then developed a simple carbohydrate monitoring tool. To validate the instrument, we compared each athlete's carbohydrate intake as estimated using the instrument with the athlete's actual carbohydrate intake from the 3-day diet records. Mean estimated percents of energy from carbohydrate using the carbohydrate monitoring tool were not significantly different from the actual mean carbohydrate intakes. Examination of individual diets showed that the estimated carbohydrate was always within 2% of the actual carbohydrate. Therefore, the instrument did a good job of estimating the percent of energy from carbohydrate in the diets of endurance runners. This instrument will provide a quick method by which the athlete can assess and improve carbohydrate intake on a daily basis without the use of daily diet records.
Index Keywords: carbohydrate; adult; article; athlete; female; food intake; human; male; monitoring; normal human; priority journal; Diet; Diet Surveys; Dietary Carbohydrates; Energy Intake; Female; Health Education; Human; Male; Running; Elagatis

Abstract: We have used laser-induced optoacoustic spectroscopy to investigate photosynthetic energy storage during the first 1.4 μs after a laser excitation flash in cells of the cyanobacterium Synechococcus 6301 adapted to light-states 1 and 2. Abstract: Data are reported for stored energy release from Bi4Ge3O12 after He+ ion implantation and/or gamma ray irradiation. Authors: Blanchard M.B., Dobson D.C., Voegele M.D., Younker J.L.
Title: Licensing a geologic repository: Types of uncertainties
Affiliations: U.S. Department of Energy, P.O. Box 98518, Las Vegas, 89193-8518, Nevada, United States; Science Applications International Corporation, 101 Convention Center Dr., Las Vegas, 89109, Nevada, United States
Authors with affiliations: Blanchard, M.B., U.S. Department of Energy, P.O. Box 98518, Las Vegas, 89193-8518, Nevada, United States; Dobson, D.C., U.S. Department of Energy, P.O. Box 98518, Las Vegas, 89193-8518, Nevada, United States; Voegele, M.D., Science Applications International Corporation, 101 Convention Center Dr., Las Vegas, 89109, Nevada, United States; Younker, J.L., Science Applications International Corporation, 101 Convention Center Dr., Las Vegas, 89109, Nevada, United States
Abstract: This paper provides a summary of the regulatory background for the U.S. geologic repository program, describing the history of the congressional actions that established the program and the allocation of responsibilities within the program. The current status of actions by the U.S. Department of Energy (DOE) to investigate a potential repository site, located at Yucca Mountain in Nye County, Nevada, is then reviewed. The U.S. Nuclear Regulatory Commission has provided guidance to the DOE for characterizing potential repository sites, and the DOE's approach to implementing that guidance is described. One of the purposes of intensive characterization of a potential repository site is to reduce uncertainties about key aspects of the site that are relevant to protection of public health and safety. However, the link between measurable site characteristics and demonstrations of compliance with regulatory criteria promulgated by the responsible federal agencies are often complex. A discussion of types of uncertainties points out that the potential licensee (DOE) and the regulator (NRC) may have differing views of the nature and importance of uncertainties. © 1991 Springer-Verlag New York Inc.

Authors: Stein D.G., Permut L.C., Drinkwater Jr. D.C., Bhuta S., Chang P., Wu A., Laks H.
Title: Complete functional recovery after 24-hour heart preservation with University of Wisconsin solution and modified reperfusion.
Affiliations: Division of Cardiothoracic Surgery, UCLA Medical Center 90024.
Authors with affiliations: Stein, D.G., Division of Cardiothoracic Surgery, UCLA Medical Center 90024.; Permut, L.C., Division of Cardiothoracic Surgery, UCLA Medical Center 90024.; Drinkwater Jr., D.C., Division of Cardiothoracic Surgery, UCLA Medical Center 90024.; Bhuta, S., Division of Cardiothoracic Surgery, UCLA Medical Center 90024.; Chang, P., Division of Cardiothoracic Surgery, UCLA Medical Center 90024.; Wu, A., Division of Cardiothoracic Surgery, UCLA Medical Center 90024.; Laks, H., Division of Cardiothoracic Surgery, UCLA Medical Center 90024.
Abstract: Successful long-term myocardial preservation is dependent on optimizing conditions during arrest, storage, and reperfusion. Neonatal piglet hearts were arrested and stored in University of Wisconsin solution (UW) at 4 degrees C for 24 hours and reperfused on a blood-perfused, adult animal-supported isolated circuit. Results were compared with nonischemic continuously perfused control hearts (group 1, n = 5). The initial 10 minutes of reperfusion in groups 2-4 was modified by aspartate/glutamate-enriched leukocyte-depleted blood cardioplegia (group 2, n = 7), leukocyte depletion alone (group 3, n = 9), and aspartate/glutamate-enriched blood cardioplegia alone (group 4, n = 6). After 10 minutes, perfusion was continued with unmodified whole blood. In group 5 (n = 9), unmodified whole blood was used for initial reperfusion as well as subsequent perfusion. The stroke work index was determined 60 minutes after reperfusion. Biopsies for high-energy phosphates, myocardial water content, and electron microscopy were obtained after functional assessment. The stroke work index at left ventricular end-diastolic pressure of 9 mm Hg did not differ between groups 1 and 2 (19.0 +/- 1.4 x 10(3) and 19.0 +/- 1.5 x 10(3) [mean +/- SEM] erg/g, respectively). These were both different from group 5 (13.3 +/- 0.8 x 10(3) erg/g, p less than 0.05). Group 3 showed improved function (15.7 +/- 0.7 x 10(3) erg/g), but this did not reach statistical significance when compared with group 5. No difference was found between groups 4 and 5. Myocardial water content, high-energy phosphate levels, and ultrastructure were similar in all groups.(ABSTRACT TRUNCATED AT 250 WORDS)

Authors: Bolstad James J., Miles Ronald C.
Title: Development testing of zinc/bromine batteries
Source title: Proceedings of the International Power Sources Symposium
Affiliations: Johnson Controls, Inc, Milwaukee,, WI, USA
Authors with affiliations: Bolstad, James J., Johnson Controls, Inc, Milwaukee,, WI, USA; Miles, Ronald C., Johnson Controls, Inc, Milwaukee,, WI, USA
Abstract: The zinc/bromine battery is a relatively high energy density system with the potential for bulk energy storage at a low cost. A new design that uses a thermal welding technique to achieve a hermetically sealed battery stack is described. Electrodes in the design are based on polyethylene, instead of polypropylene, since the latter was more susceptible to expansion and warpage in the presence of bromine. Embedded glass fibers are also used to increase the tensile modulus of the electrodes in the new design. Improved separators and improved electrolyte flow distribution within the battery stack have reduced the amount of self-discharge compared to earlier batteries. Specific properties of the batteries were measured by different kinds of tests in the laboratory. The initial test given to each battery was a set of constant current cycles to determine the fundamental operating characteristics. These test results served as a baseline for comparison after other tests were completed. The other tests included a high rate peak power discharge, an SFUDS-type discharge, and a Ragone power curve. The results of these tests are given.
Index Keywords: Bromine; Electrodes; ELECTROLYTES; Polyethylenes; Polypropylenes; SEPARATORS; Zinc and Alloys; Embedded Glass Fibers; Hermetically Sealed Battery Stacks; Thermal Welding; Zinc/Bromine Batteries; Electric Batteries

Abstract: The University of Wisconsin's experience as a superconductivity engineering research center since the invention of the superconductive magnetic energy storage (SMES) system is described. The SMES used today consists of a superconductive storage coil charged and discharged by a Graetz bridge. The topics discussed are the following: the electrical use of SMES; configurations; structure and conductor requirements; the status of present SMES design; rippled design; non-rippled design; the conductor and stability; SMES coil protection systems; and the use of high-temperature superconductors in SMES systems.

Abstract: The authors describe high voltage energy discharge capacitor technology and research and development issues, approaches and methodology. Results of some past development projects are presented. Film capacitors can deliver very high peak power pulses and high average power pulse trains. Energy density of film capacitors has historically been comparatively low, but recent developments have increased their energy density by an order of magnitude, and further advances are anticipated in the early 1990s. These advances will be based largely on new dielectric materials and dielectric systems. The availability of these high energy density pulse capacitors is contributing to the introduction of new military, industrial and commercial systems never before feasible.

Abstract: The authors briefly review past efforts to develop superconducting opening switches, and report on the initial phase of an analytical and experimental program designed to assess the potential of the high-transition temperature (Tc) materials as opening switches. Abstract: This review addresses fundamentals of dielectric capacitor technology and multifactor stress aging of all classes of insulating media that form elements of this technology. It is directed towards the delineation of failure processes in highly stressed, compact capacitors. Factors affecting the complex aging processes such as thermal, electromechanical, and partial discharges are discussed. Diagnostic measurement techniques available and those being developed to determine material degradation affecting available life and failure probability of capacitors are presented.

Authors with affiliations: Levy, Samuel C., Sandia Nat Lab, Albuquerque, NM, USA; Bouchard, Darryl A., Sandia Nat Lab, Albuquerque, NM, USA
Abstract: Storage and discharge tests and chemical analyses were conducted on Li/SO2 cells from two manufacturers. Cells from five lots and five storage temperatures, ranging from one year to seven years in age, were studied. An Arrhenius plot was constructed from the storage and discharge data and an activation energy of 10.26 kcal/mol was calculated for the self-discharge process. Hydrogen gas is generated during storage, resulting in a slight increase in internal pressure of the cells. This was not found to affect their performance or safety.

Source title: Proceedings of the International Power Sources Symposium
Affiliations: US Army Electron Technol &, Devices Lab, Fort Monmouth, NJ, USA
Authors with affiliations: Slane, S., US Army Electron Technol &, Devices Lab, Fort Monmouth, NJ, USA; Plichta, E., US Army Electron Technol &, Devices Lab, Fort Monmouth, NJ, USA; Salomon, M., US Army Electron Technol &, Devices Lab, Fort Monmouth, NJ, USA
Abstract: Electrolyte improvements made in laboratory half cells have enabled the practical development of the rechargeable Li/LiCoO2 system into sealed 70-mAh button cells. High-rate capabilities of greater than 6 mA/cm2 have been demonstrated in button cells cycled between 4.3 and 3.0 V at 25°C. Energy densities for a discharge rate of 2.7 mA/cm2 at 25°C, -10°C, and -40°C were 102, 89, and 81 Wh/kg, respectively. Higher-rate charging up to 1.25 mA/cm2 has been demonstrated. In addition, the effect of storage on the open circuit voltage of charged cells has been investigated.

Authors: Conway B.E.
Title: Transition from 'supercapacitor' to 'battery' behavior in electrochemical energy storage
Source title: Proceedings of the International Power Sources Symposium
Affiliations: Chem Dept, Univ of Ottawa, Ont,, Canada
Authors with affiliations: Conway, B.E., Chem Dept, Univ of Ottawa, Ont,, Canada
Abstract: The storage of electrochemical energy in battery, supercapacitor, and double-layer capacitor devices is considered. Supercapacitor systems based on 2-dimensional underpotential deposition reactions are highly reversible and their behavior arises from the pseudocapacitance associated with potential-dependence of 2-dimensional coverage of electroactive adatoms on an electrode substrate surface. Such capacitance can be 10 to 100 times the double-layer capacitance of the same electrode area. An essential fundamental difference from battery behavior arises because, in such systems, the chemical and associated electrode potentials are a continuous function of degree of charge, unlike the thermodynamic behavior of single-phase battery reactants. Quasi-2-dimensional systems, such as hyper-extended hydrous RuO2, also exhibit large pseudocapacitance. Other examples are the conducting polymer electrodes and Li intercalate systems. The impedance behavior of an RuO2 supercapacitor is illustrated but is far from that expected for an electrostatic capacitor.
Index Keywords: Capacitors, Electrolytic; Electrochemistry; Energy Storage; Double Layer Capacitor Devices; Electrochemical Energy Storage; Electrostatic Energy Storage; Pseudocapacitance; Supercapacitor Devices; Two-dimensional Underpotential Deposition Reactions; Electric Batteries

Authors: Palmer David N., Hull John R., Kuzay Tuncer M., Schoenung Susan M.
Title: Use of high-temperature superconductors in superconducting magnetic energy power sources
Source title: Proceedings of the International Power Sources Symposium
Affiliations: ABB-Combustion Engineering, Windsor,, CT, USA
Authors with affiliations: Palmer, David N., ABB-Combustion Engineering, Windsor,, CT, USA; Hull, John R., ABB-Combustion Engineering, Windsor,, CT, USA; Kuzay, Tuncer M., ABB-Combustion Engineering, Windsor,, CT, USA; Schoenung, Susan M., ABB-Combustion Engineering, Windsor,, CT, USA
Abstract: The concept of mobile superconducting magnetic energy power sources (SMEPSs) is introduced and scrutinized. The use of high-temperature superconductors (HTSs) in mobile SMEPS systems is discussed. Coil scaling and structural force calculations for small solenoidal and toroidal coil systems are presented. Estimates of system refrigeration efficiency are made as a function of mechanical support, insulation, and power lead thermal losses. Required HTS properties, derived from considerations presently developed, are compared to properties of currently available materials or those expected to evolve in the near term. The analysis verifies the applicability of SMEPS for military and nonmilitary mobile energy storage and power backup applications. The results show that the evolution of SMEPS systems will be stimulated by the development of higher-strength, tougher HTSs that can operate at current densities greater than 104 A/cm2 in magnetic fields of 4 to 6 T and at temperatures of 77 K or higher.
Index Keywords: Electric Coils; Energy Storage; HIGH TEMPERATURE SUPERCONDUCTORS; Refrigeration; Superconducting Magnets--Energy Storage; Superconducting Magnetic Energy Power Sources; Superconducting Devices

Authors: Fadaghi Abdollah
Title: Feasibility study of utilising modular ice storage system
Source title: Australian refrigeration, Air conditioning and heating
Affiliations: Trane Co of Australia Pty Ltd
Authors with affiliations: Fadaghi, Abdollah, Trane Co of Australia Pty Ltd
Abstract: The installation of ice storage systems in commercial buildings is a growing trend. The interest in this system is based on the potential to reduce cooling energy costs by shifting some of the building power consumption to the off-peak period. The concept of thermal ice storage systems appears to be very simple, but unlike the concept, the design and evaluation of the system is complex. The complexities are in two areas, firstly in obtaining the components' optimum balance point and secondly proving the economic viability of the designed system. The system components' optimum balance point is obtained normally by trial and error from the performance characteristics of the four basic components of an ice storage system which are, load, chiller, ice tank and glycol loop. The economic viability of the system mainly depends on the comparison of the initial and operating cost of different alternatives. Both the above, obtaining the equipment balance point and proving the economic viability, involves a lengthy calculation which can be performed accurately and quickly by a computer programme.
Index Keywords: Buildings - Energy Storage; Cooling; Ice Storage Systems; Energy Storage

Authors: Schönfeld C.L., Trendelenburg U.
Title: The sensitivity of adrenergic varicosities to the 3H-noradrenaline-releasing effect of potassium
Affiliations: Institut für Pharmakologie und Toxikologie, Universität Würzburg, Versbacher Strasse 9, Würzburg, W-8700, Germany
Authors with affiliations: Schönfeld, C.L., Institut für Pharmakologie und Toxikologie, Universität Würzburg, Versbacher Strasse 9, Würzburg, W-8700, Germany; Trendelenburg, U., Institut für Pharmakologie und Toxikologie, Universität Würzburg, Versbacher Strasse 9, Würzburg, W-8700, Germany
Abstract: After the loading of incubated, homogeneously innervated tissues with 3H-noradrenaline (monoamine oxidase and catechol-O-methyl transferase inhibited, calcium-containing solution) high K+ released the 3H-amine from adrenergic varicosities. In paired experiments the sensitivity of rat atria to high K+ exceeded that of vasa deferentia. In the rat vas deferens the releasing effect of high K+ was enhanced by drugs or procedures which induce a carrier-mediated outward transport of 3H-noradrenaline, i.e., by ouabain, by glucose deprivation and by hypoxia. - In the presence of extracellular calcium desipramine failed to affect the releasing effect of high K+ (except in the absence of glucose or during hypox1a), but in the absence of calcium desipramine reduced it. Apparently, whenever the axoplasmic levels of 3H-noradrenaline are increased, high K+ is able to induce some carrier-mediated outward transport of the 3H-amine. It is suggested that "organ differences" with respect to the sensitivity to high K+ may well be due to hypoxia (plus some lack of glucose) of those varicosities that had been loaded with 3H-noradrenaline. The risk of storage of 3H-noradrenaline in hypoxic varicosities appears to be greater in incubated than in perfused organs, and in the former it is greater in sparsely than in densely innervated tissues. © 1991 Springer-Verlag.
Author Keywords: Energy requirements; Noradrenaline release by K+; Rat atria; Rat vas deferens

Abstract: Polyvinyl acetate was evaluated for food packaging by studying interactions with food nutrients like ascorbic acid, niacin, phenylalanine and caffeine. The polymer was immobilized on silica support and food based solvent like water used as a mobile phase. Thermodynamic parameters such as enthalpy of sorption, Gibb's free energy and activity coefficient data were used to determine mechanism, magnitude and kind (weak or strong) of interactions. Authors: Griesser H.J., Youxian D., Hughes A.E., Gengenbach T.R., Mau A.W.H.
Title: Shallow Reorientation in the Surface Dynamics of Plasma-Treated Fluorinated Ethylene Propylene Polymer
Affiliations: Division of Chemicals and Polymers, CSIRO, Private Bag 10, Clayton, Victoria 3168, Australia; Institute of Chemistry, Academia Sinica, Beijing, China; Division of Materials Science and Technology, CSIRO, layton, Victoria 3168, Australia
Authors with affiliations: Griesser, H.J., Division of Chemicals and Polymers, CSIRO, Private Bag 10, Clayton, Victoria 3168, Australia; Youxian, D., Division of Chemicals and Polymers, CSIRO, Private Bag 10, Clayton, Victoria 3168, Australia, Institute of Chemistry, Academia Sinica, Beijing, China; Hughes, A.E., Division of Materials Science and Technology, CSIRO, layton, Victoria 3168, Australia; Gengenbach, T.R., Division of Chemicals and Polymers, CSIRO, Private Bag 10, Clayton, Victoria 3168, Australia; Mau, A.W.H., Division of Chemicals and Polymers, CSIRO, Private Bag 10, Clayton, Victoria 3168, Australia
Abstract: Samples of fluorinated ethylene propylene (FEP) copolymer have been treated in plasma atmospheres that induce oxidative modification of the surface. Contact angles changed markedly within short plasma treatment times, and XPS demonstrated the incorporation of oxygen-containing chemical groups on the FEP surface. The contact angles, measured after various storage times in air to assess the long-term stability of the modified surfaces, increased markedly within a 3-week period whereas the changes in XPS were considerably less pronounced. Surface recontamination appeared unlikely on the basis of XPS analysis and the surface reversal was attributed to FEP chain dynamics, which causes rearrangement toward a lower energy surface. The surface reorientation of plasma-treated FEP samples did not proceed to completion; some of the polar groups are believed to be attached to immobile sites on the surface. The observation that the surface energy decreases while the oxygen content as measured by XPS increases on storage is proposed to be related to two factors. First, the driving force for reorientational movement of treated polymer chains in FEP acts over a depth smaller than the XPS signal depth; the mobile oxygen-containing groups thus move away from the immediate surface but stay within the XPS analysis depth. Second, oxidative reactions are believed to continue for extended periods of time following plasma treatment; these reactions, which originate from radicals, cause uptake of oxygen over entended periods of time. © Copyright 1991 American Chemical Society. © 1991, American Chemical Society. All rights reserved.

Authors: Mills D.R., Monger A.G., Morrison G.L.
Title: Comparison of asymmetrical and symmetrical non-imaging reflectors for east-west circular cylindrical solar receivers
Source title: Proceedings of SPIE - The International Society for Optical Engineering
Affiliations: Department of Applied Physics, University of SydneyNSW  2006, Australia; School of Mechanical Engineering, University of New South WalesNSW  2033, Australia
Authors with affiliations: Mills, D.R., Department of Applied Physics, University of SydneyNSW  2006, Australia; Monger, A.G., Department of Applied Physics, University of SydneyNSW  2006, Australia; Morrison, G.L., School of Mechanical Engineering, University of New South WalesNSW  2033, Australia
Abstract: A computer simulation of the relative performance of certain truncated symmetrical and asymmetrical fixed reflector designs for solar energy collection was performed. The major results were as follows: 1)Annual solar fractions in excess of 90% seems to be feasible with a fixed load matching collector, in a climate where 70% of hot water requirements is the norm from flat plate collectors. Consumer interaction could either improve or lower this figure depending upon circumstances. 2)Symmetrical CPC reflectors always gave the best annual output performance per unit of mirror area, and allowed the lowest receiver area for situations of constant annual load. 3)Asymmetrical fixed concentrators are most cost-effective for seasonally asymmetrical load patterns. 4)Fixed parabolic systems were not competitive. 5)The concentration levels utilizable in fixed systems are much higher than previously supposed, with approximately 3.1:1 in an asymmetrical reflector being optimal for the domestic load pattern used. 6)With seasonal load matching, the storage required to achieve solar fractions above 90% appears to be approximately one day of typical load. © 1991 SPIE. All rights reserved.
Author Keywords: Asymmetrical reflectors; CPC; Fixed reflectors; Non-imaging concentrators; Non-imaging concentrators; Stationary solar concentrators
Index Keywords: Cost effectiveness; Light; Solar concentrators; Solar energy; Concentration levels; Consumer interaction; Flat-plate collector; Non-imaging; Parabolic system; Reflector design; Relative performance; Solar energy collections; Reflection

Authors: Kreile J., Kurland H.-D., Seibel W., Schweig A.
Title: A new angle-resolving photoelectron spectrometer for photoionisation studies of free atoms and molecules using synchrotron radiation
Source title: Nuclear Inst. and Methods in Physics Research, A
Affiliations: Fachbereich Physikalische Chemie, Philipps-Universität Marburg, Hans-Meerwein-Strasse, D-3550 Marburg, Germany
Authors with affiliations: Kreile, J., Fachbereich Physikalische Chemie, Philipps-Universität Marburg, Hans-Meerwein-Strasse, D-3550 Marburg, Germany; Kurland, H.-D., Fachbereich Physikalische Chemie, Philipps-Universität Marburg, Hans-Meerwein-Strasse, D-3550 Marburg, Germany; Seibel, W., Fachbereich Physikalische Chemie, Philipps-Universität Marburg, Hans-Meerwein-Strasse, D-3550 Marburg, Germany; Schweig, A., Fachbereich Physikalische Chemie, Philipps-Universität Marburg, Hans-Meerwein-Strasse, D-3550 Marburg, Germany
Abstract: A newly constructed angle-resolving photoelectron spectrometer and an appropriate computer-based spectrometer control and data-acquisition system, both specifically designed for photoionisation studies of free atoms and molecules using monochromatised synchrotron radiation from the electron storage ring BESSY, are described. Details of an experimental procedure for the determination of high-precision photoelectron angular-distribution parameters β are specified. To illustrate the performance of the described apparatus and procedure, β values for the Kr+ (4p)-1 spin-orbit components 2P3 2 and 2P1 2, measured using synchrotron radiation in the photon energy range 15-24.8 eV, are presented and compared with available experimental and theoretical literature data. The uncertainties of the reported angular-distribution parameters are considerably smaller than those of earlier data. Hence the angular-distribution parameters of the present study can be very useful for future accurate polarisation determinations of monochromatised synchrotron radiation and for calibration procedures of other angle-resolving photoelectron spectrometers. © 1991.

Authors: Veshcherevich V.G., Vobly P.D., Kulipanov G.N., Mezentsev N.A., Morgunov L.G., Ovchinnikov A.A., Ponedelko V.N.
Title: Compact superconducting storage ring with azimuthal symmetry - SR source for technological purposes
Source title: Nuclear Inst. and Methods in Physics Research, A
Affiliations: Institute of Nuclear Physics, 630090 Novosibirsk, Russian Federation
Authors with affiliations: Veshcherevich, V.G., Institute of Nuclear Physics, 630090 Novosibirsk, Russian Federation; Vobly, P.D., Institute of Nuclear Physics, 630090 Novosibirsk, Russian Federation; Kulipanov, G.N., Institute of Nuclear Physics, 630090 Novosibirsk, Russian Federation; Mezentsev, N.A., Institute of Nuclear Physics, 630090 Novosibirsk, Russian Federation; Morgunov, L.G., Institute of Nuclear Physics, 630090 Novosibirsk, Russian Federation; Ovchinnikov, A.A., Institute of Nuclear Physics, 630090 Novosibirsk, Russian Federation; Ponedelko, V.N., Institute of Nuclear Physics, 630090 Novosibirsk, Russian Federation
Abstract: The project for a compact storage ring SIBERIA-AS - a synchrotron radiation (SR) source for X-ray lithography with an electron energy of 600 MeV and an orbit circumference of about 3 m - is considered. The major component of the storage ring is a 3.8 T azimuthally symmetrical magnet consisting of annular superconducting coils without utilization of ferromagnetic material. The suggested design has enabled the effect of iron yoke saturation on the magnetic field distribution to be eliminated, and both the weight (about 8 tons) and the overall dimensions (a cylinder of 2 m in diameter and 2 m in height) to be considerably reduced. The basic systems of the storage ring are described and its parameters are reported. © 1991.

Authors: Dolbnya I.P., Gavrilov G.N., Mezentsev N.A., Pindyurin V.F., Sheromov M.A.
Title: X-ray focusing monochromator for an X-ray scanning microscopy and microtomography station
Source title: Nuclear Inst. and Methods in Physics Research, A
Affiliations: Institute of Nuclear Physics, 630090 Novosibirsk, Russian Federation
Authors with affiliations: Dolbnya, I.P., Institute of Nuclear Physics, 630090 Novosibirsk, Russian Federation; Gavrilov, G.N., Institute of Nuclear Physics, 630090 Novosibirsk, Russian Federation; Mezentsev, N.A., Institute of Nuclear Physics, 630090 Novosibirsk, Russian Federation; Pindyurin, V.F., Institute of Nuclear Physics, 630090 Novosibirsk, Russian Federation; Sheromov, M.A., Institute of Nuclear Physics, 630090 Novosibirsk, Russian Federation
Abstract: The first results concerning an X-ray focusing monochromator in the energy range 5-35 keV for an X-ray scanning microscopy and microtomography station at the VEPP-3 storage ring are presented. Sagittal focusing with the use of Si(111) crystal in the Von Hamos scheme is investigated and discussed. © 1991.

Authors: Artemiev A.N., Avaev A.V., Sinyansky O.V.
Title: Distributed SR receiver for the strong-field superconducting wavelength shifter of the SIBERIA-2 storage ring
Source title: Nuclear Inst. and Methods in Physics Research, A
Affiliations: I.V. Kurchatov Institute of Atomic Energy, Moscow, 123182, Russian Federation
Authors with affiliations: Artemiev, A.N., I.V. Kurchatov Institute of Atomic Energy, Moscow, 123182, Russian Federation; Avaev, A.V., I.V. Kurchatov Institute of Atomic Energy, Moscow, 123182, Russian Federation; Sinyansky, O.V., I.V. Kurchatov Institute of Atomic Energy, Moscow, 123182, Russian Federation
Abstract: The design peculiarities of the SIBERIA-2 storage ring - a dedicated synchrotron radiation source - and its strong-field superconducting wavelength shifter determine the density of X-ray power incident on the surface of the SR receivers: with an electron energy of Ee = 2.5 GeV and electron current Ie = 300 mA, the incident power density is 100 W/mm2. In order to minimize the thermal load a distributed SR receiver has been designed, which will provide a temperature on the surface receiving X-rays of less then 250° C. © 1991.

Authors: Tomimasu T.
Title: Development of five compact storage rings, TERAS and NIJI-I-IV, at ETL
Source title: Nuclear Inst. and Methods in Physics Research, A
Affiliations: Electrotechnical Laboratory, Umezono, Tsukuba, Ibaraki, 305, Japan
Authors with affiliations: Tomimasu, T., Electrotechnical Laboratory, Umezono, Tsukuba, Ibaraki, 305, Japan
Abstract: At the Electrotechnical Laboratory (ETL) four compact storage rings, TERAS and NIJI-I-III, have been constructed and a compact storage ring, NIJI-IV, with 7.2 m long straight sections for a free electron laser (FEL) experiment will be completed in November 1990. TERAS is a 0.8 GeV storage ring and has been operated since October 1981 for research into radiometric standards, dissociative photoionization, SR lithography, generation of gamma-rays and FEL experiments using a transverse optical klystron (TOK). A 10 T three-pole wiggler will be installed in 1991 at the straight section where the TOK is installed. NIJI-I is a 0.27 GeV compact ring. It was operated from February 1986 to March 1989 for machine study of beam storage higher than 0.5 A at low energies below 0.15 GeV. NIJI-II is a 0.6 GeV conventional-type compact ring operated in August 1989 for SR lithography, chemical vapor deposition (CVD) and polarized SR experiments. NIJI-III is a 0.62 GeV superconducting-type ring for SR lithography operated in June 1990. Key technologies needed to realize compact SR facilities, such as the electron undulating method and high-current storage, are briefly reviewed. © 1991.

Authors: Barkov A.V., Dudarev A.V., Egorov V.V., Keilin V.E., Pavlov O.V., Stepanenko A.V.
Title: A 10 T superconducting shifter for the "SIBERIA-2" storage ring
Source title: Nuclear Inst. and Methods in Physics Research, A
Affiliations: Kurchatov Institute of Atomic Energy, Moscow, 123182, Russian Federation
Authors with affiliations: Barkov, A.V., Kurchatov Institute of Atomic Energy, Moscow, 123182, Russian Federation; Dudarev, A.V., Kurchatov Institute of Atomic Energy, Moscow, 123182, Russian Federation; Egorov, V.V., Kurchatov Institute of Atomic Energy, Moscow, 123182, Russian Federation; Keilin, V.E., Kurchatov Institute of Atomic Energy, Moscow, 123182, Russian Federation; Pavlov, O.V., Kurchatov Institute of Atomic Energy, Moscow, 123182, Russian Federation; Stepanenko, A.V., Kurchatov Institute of Atomic Energy, Moscow, 123182, Russian Federation
Abstract: The problems of constructing a high-field shifter for the "SIBERIA-2" specialized storage ring are discussed. The design of a 10 T shifter to generate synchrotron radiation with a characteristic energy of about 42 keV is described. © 1991.

Authors: Dolbnya I.P., Knyazev B.A., Simonov V.P., Feldman G.G.
Title: Measuring the absolute sensitivity of an X-ray electron-optical image converter in the range 7-20 keV
Source title: Nuclear Inst. and Methods in Physics Research, A
Affiliations: Institute of Nuclear Physics, 630090 Novosibirsk, Russian Federation
Authors with affiliations: Dolbnya, I.P., Institute of Nuclear Physics, 630090 Novosibirsk, Russian Federation; Knyazev, B.A., Institute of Nuclear Physics, 630090 Novosibirsk, Russian Federation; Simonov, V.P., Institute of Nuclear Physics, 630090 Novosibirsk, Russian Federation; Feldman, G.G., Institute of Nuclear Physics, 630090 Novosibirsk, Russian Federation
Abstract: The absolute sensitivity of an X-ray electron-optical image converter with a MCP used as both photocathode and amplifier has been investigated using synchrotron radiation from the VEPP-3 storage ring (INP, Novosibirsk) in the energy range of 7 to 20 keV. In this spectral range the response of the converter increases from 1200 to 2200 blue photons at the output per one incident X-ray quantum. The distribution of the sensitivity along the image field has been also studied. © 1991.

Authors: Barsukov V.P., Dolbnya I.P., Kolokolnikov Yu.M., Kurylo S.G., Mezentsev N.A., Pindyurin V.F., Sheromov M.A.
Title: X-ray monochromator for digital subtraction angiography using synchrotron radiation
Source title: Nuclear Inst. and Methods in Physics Research, A
Affiliations: Institute of Nuclear Physics, 630090 Novosibirsk, Russian Federation
Authors with affiliations: Barsukov, V.P., Institute of Nuclear Physics, 630090 Novosibirsk, Russian Federation; Dolbnya, I.P., Institute of Nuclear Physics, 630090 Novosibirsk, Russian Federation; Kolokolnikov, Yu.M., Institute of Nuclear Physics, 630090 Novosibirsk, Russian Federation; Kurylo, S.G., Institute of Nuclear Physics, 630090 Novosibirsk, Russian Federation; Mezentsev, N.A., Institute of Nuclear Physics, 630090 Novosibirsk, Russian Federation; Pindyurin, V.F., Institute of Nuclear Physics, 630090 Novosibirsk, Russian Federation; Sheromov, M.A., Institute of Nuclear Physics, 630090 Novosibirsk, Russian Federation
Abstract: The design of an X-ray double beam monochromator for digital subtraction angiography using synchrotron radiation is described. The monochromator provides two line-like monochromatic beams with a quanta energy just above and below the K-absorption edge of iodine. The monochromatization is performed by two flat silicon crystals in Laue diffraction on the (111) plane. The experimental results of testing the monochromator using synchrotron radiation from the VEPP-3 storage ring are also presented. © 1991.

Authors: Artemiev A.N., Barkov A.V., Chechin A.I., Dudarev A.V., Krylov Yu.V., Smolyakov N.V.
Title: The multipole superconducting wiggler for the SIBERIA-2 storage ring
Source title: Nuclear Inst. and Methods in Physics Research, A
Affiliations: I.V. Kurchatov Institute of Atomic Energy, 123182 Moscow, Russian Federation
Authors with affiliations: Artemiev, A.N., I.V. Kurchatov Institute of Atomic Energy, 123182 Moscow, Russian Federation; Barkov, A.V., I.V. Kurchatov Institute of Atomic Energy, 123182 Moscow, Russian Federation; Chechin, A.I., I.V. Kurchatov Institute of Atomic Energy, 123182 Moscow, Russian Federation; Dudarev, A.V., I.V. Kurchatov Institute of Atomic Energy, 123182 Moscow, Russian Federation; Krylov, Yu.V., I.V. Kurchatov Institute of Atomic Energy, 123182 Moscow, Russian Federation; Smolyakov, N.V., I.V. Kurchatov Institute of Atomic Energy, 123182 Moscow, Russian Federation
Abstract: The project of the multipole superconducting wiggler for the SIBERIA-2 storage ring is discussed. The wiggler will be used for the generation of high-intensity synchrotron radiation (SR) beams in the X-ray energy region of 5-25 keV and will allow the SR beam intensity to be increased by a factor of 30-100. A SR beam driver system is also proposed, which would increase the number of independently operating stations on the SR wiggler beam lines. © 1991.

Authors: Artemiev A.N., Akhmedzhanov S.M., Vasilyev A.A., Gritsuk G.M., Dozorov A.V., Doronkin Yu.V., Zabelin A.V., Klimenko M.N., Kotov S.A., Krylov Yu.V., Lebedev V.A., Lipilin A.V., Nagornyh I.M., Nikulin O.N., Odintsov D.G., Pashkov S.D., Pesterev S.G., Prosvetov V.K., Rybakov V.N., Samorukov M.M., Treshchin V.A., Ushkov V.L., Tsup A.R., Chaikin E.M., Yupinov Yu.L.
Title: The SIBERIA dedicated synchrotron radiation source: status report on the storage rings complex at the Kurchatov Institute for Atomic Energy
Source title: Nuclear Inst. and Methods in Physics Research, A
Affiliations: Kurchatov Institute for Atomic Energy, Moscow, Russian Federation
Authors with affiliations: Artemiev, A.N., Kurchatov Institute for Atomic Energy, Moscow, Russian Federation; Akhmedzhanov, S.M., Kurchatov Institute for Atomic Energy, Moscow, Russian Federation; Vasilyev, A.A., Kurchatov Institute for Atomic Energy, Moscow, Russian Federation;
