Authors: Mayer R.
Title: Direct imaging of x rays with a CCD using hardware processing
Affiliations: National Institute of Standards and Technology, Gaithersburg, Maryland 20899, United States
Authors with affiliations: Mayer, R., National Institute of Standards and Technology, Gaithersburg, Maryland 20899, United States
Abstract: This study investigated the direct imaging of low intensity x-rays by a room-temperature charge coupled device (CCD). Commercial CCD evaluation kits read out the information and provided initial processing of the data. The extraction of the signal from noise was achieved using NIM modules rather than by storing and numerically analyzing the data. Due to the fast processing at standard TV rates, the storage of the data required conversion of the signal from a timing to a pulse height analysis (PHA) spectrum. The tested CCDs were found to have lower efficiency relative to the proportional counter for the range of photon energies (1.5–8.0 keV) studied but had higher spatial resolution than gas-filled position-sensitive detectors. Application of CCDs for x-ray energy dispersive detectors is described. © 1991, American Institute of Physics. All rights reserved.
Author Keywords: CHARGE−COUPLED DEVICES; IMAGE FORMING; NOISE; POSITION SENSITIVE DETECTORS; PULSE HEIGHT ANALYSIS; RADIATION DETECTORS; READOUT SYSTEMS; SIGNAL PROCESSING; X RADIATION

Authors: Currin C., Mitchell T., Morris M., Ylvisaker D.
Title: Bayesian prediction of deterministic functions, with applications to the design and analysis of computer experiments
Source title: Journal of the American Statistical Association
Affiliations: Department of Psychology, Ohio State University, Columbus, OH, 43210, United States; Mathematical Sciences Section, Engineering Physics and Mathematics Division, Oak Ridge National Laboratory, Oak Ridge, TN, 37831, United States; Department of Mathematics, University of California, Los Angeles, CA, 90024, United States
Authors with affiliations: Currin, C., Department of Psychology, Ohio State University, Columbus, OH, 43210, United States; Mitchell, T., Mathematical Sciences Section, Engineering Physics and Mathematics Division, Oak Ridge National Laboratory, Oak Ridge, TN, 37831, United States; Morris, M., Mathematical Sciences Section, Engineering Physics and Mathematics Division, Oak Ridge National Laboratory, Oak Ridge, TN, 37831, United States; Ylvisaker, D., Department of Mathematics, University of California, Los Angeles, CA, 90024, United States
Abstract: This article is concerned with prediction of a function y(t) over a (multidimensional) domain T, given the function values at a set of “sites” (t(1), t(2), …, t(n)) in T, and with the design, that is, with the selection of those sites. The motivating application is the design and analysis of computer experiments, where t determines the input to a computer model of a physical or behavioral system, and y(t) is a response that is part of the output or is calculated from it. Following a Bayesian formulation, prior uncertainty about the function y is expressed by means of a random function Y, which is taken here to be a Gaussian stochastic process. The mean of the posterior process can be used as the prediction function ŷ(t), and the variance can be used as a measure of uncertainty. This kind of approach has been used previously in Bayesian interpolation and is strongly related to the kriging methods used in geostatistics. Here emphasis is placed on product linear and product cubic correlation functions, which yield prediction functions that are, respectively, linear or cubic splines in every dimension. A posterior entropy criterion is adopted for design; this minimizes the expected uncertainty about the posterior process, as measured by the entropy. A computational algorithm for finding entropy-optimal designs on multidimensional grids is described. Several examples are presented, including a two-dimensional experiment on a computer model of a thermal energy storage device and a six-dimensional experiment on an integrated circuit simulator. Predictions are made using several different families of correlation functions, with parameters chosen to maximize the likelihood. For comparison, predictions are also made via least squares fitting of various polynomial and spline models. The Bayesian design/prediction methods, which do not require any modeling of y, produce comparatively good predictions. For some correlation functions, however, the 95% posterior probability intervals do not give adequate coverage of the true values of y at selected test sites. These methods are fairly simple and offer considerable potential for virtually automatic implementation, although further development is needed before they can be applied routinely in practice. © 1991 Taylor & Francis Group, LLC.
Author Keywords: Computer models; Correlation function; Cross-validation; Entropy; Experimental design; Interpolation; Kriging; Optimal design; Spline fitting; Stochastic processes

Authors: Kress M.E., Fishman J.
Title: Applications of the laws of thermodynamics for decision making in the use of alternative energy sources
Source title: International Journal of Mathematical Education in Science and Technology
Affiliations: Department of Computer Science, College of Staten Island, City University of New York, 130 Stuyvesant Place, Staten Island, NY, 10301, United States
Authors with affiliations: Kress, M.E., Department of Computer Science, College of Staten Island, City University of New York, 130 Stuyvesant Place, Staten Island, NY, 10301, United States; Fishman, J., Department of Computer Science, College of Staten Island, City University of New York, 130 Stuyvesant Place, Staten Island, NY, 10301, United States
Abstract: The laws of thermodynamics are applied to assess real costs in the use of alternative energy sources in the United States—in this case, liquefied natural gas (LNG) in place of natural gas. It is clear that LNG has a higher market price than natural gas. What has not been included in this price differential is the ultimate cost of reducing the total global supplies because of the lower energy efficiency in the use of LNG. The laws of thermodynamics also show there is a limit to the increased efficiency gained by technological improvements in the liquefaction process. Sharp increases in the price of imported LNG and a glut of domestic natural gas lead to a sharp reduction in the imports of LNG. Opposition to at least one import terminal because of concern with the possible danger in the shipping and storage of LNG contributed to its shut-down. The early consideration of the hidden costs of LNG might have saved this nation billions of dollars invested in import terminals now standing largely unused. The assumption here is that students should be aware of how mathematics and science can play important roles in supporting different views in often heated debates. © 1991 Taylor and Francis Group, LLC.

Authors: Miyatake O., Yamada A., Arimatsu Y.
Title: Fundamental Study of Characteristics of Flash Evaporation in a Steam Accumulator
Affiliations: Dept. of Chem. Eng., Kyushu Univ., Fukuoka 812, Japan
Authors with affiliations: Miyatake, O., Dept. of Chem. Eng., Kyushu Univ., Fukuoka 812, Japan; Yamada, A., Dept. of Chem. Eng., Kyushu Univ., Fukuoka 812, Japan; Arimatsu, Y., Dept. of Chem. Eng., Kyushu Univ., Fukuoka 812, Japan
Abstract: An experimental study is carried out with a quantity of warm pool water exposed to a sudden pressure drop, to determine the performance characteristics of a steam accumulator. Ranges of experimental variables include: initial liquid temperatures of 40, 60 and 80 °C, liquid levels of 0.30 and 0.60 m, and superheats between 2 and 13K. From the experimental results, it is found that the nonequilibrium phenomenon of pool water is induced mainly by the boiling point elevation due to liquid level and, consequently, the amount of evaporation per unit mass of liquid decreases as the liquid level increases and as the liquid temperature decreases. It is also found that the evaporation efficiency based on the local superheat in liquid phase depends practically on the dimensionless depth of superheated zone, and an empirical equation is deduced for predicting the mass of evaporated liquid. © 1991, The Society of Chemical Engineers, Japan. All rights reserved.
Author Keywords: Energy Storage; Evaporation; Flash Evaporation; Nonequilibrium Phenomenon; Steam Accumulator; Superheated Liquid

Authors: Miyatake O., Fujita K., Kibashi K.
Title: Effect of the Installation of a Baffle Plate Near the Inlet on the Thermal Storage Performance of a Cylindrical Water Tank
Affiliations: Dept. of Chem. Eng., Kyusyu Univ., Fukuoka 812, Japan; Takasago Thermal Eng. Co., Ltd., Japan; Toshiba Corp., Japan
Authors with affiliations: Miyatake, O., Dept. of Chem. Eng., Kyusyu Univ., Fukuoka 812, Japan; Fujita, K., Takasago Thermal Eng. Co., Ltd., Japan; Kibashi, K., Toshiba Corp., Japan
Abstract: An experimental study was carried out to investigate the effect of the installation of a horizontal circular baffle plate near the inlet on the thermal storage performance of a cylindrical water tank, by measuring transient water temperature responses for the case in which hot water was charged through a vertical inlet tube into the upper part of a tank filled with cold water. Experimental parameters included the diameter of inlet tube, the diameter of baffle plate, the position of baffle plate, the hot-cold water temperature difference, the flow rate, and the water level. From the experimental results and theoretical considerations, dimensionless semi-empirical equations suitable for predicting the amount of cold water mixed into the hot water region and the thermal storage efficiency of the cylindrical water tank were deduced as a function of the Archimedes number based on inflow conditions, the Peclet number, and three dimensionless geometric parameters. The general conclusion reached was that, for relatively low Archimedes numbers, the installation of a baffle plate improved the thermal storage efficiency appreciably due to the prevention of mixing of hot and cold water. © 1991, The Society of Chemical Engineers, Japan. All rights reserved.
Author Keywords: Baffle Plate; Empirical Equation; Energy; Temperature Stratification; Thermal Storage Efficiency; Thermal Storage Tank
Index Keywords: Tanks (containers); Temperature; Water; Water levels; Water tanks; Baffle plate; Empirical equations; Energy; Temperature stratification; Thermal storage; Heat storage

Authors: Deufel T., Gerbitz K.-D.
Title: Biochemistry and Molecular Genetics of Muscle Diseases
Affiliations: Abt. für Klin. Chemie und Biochemie im Dr. von Haunerschen Kinderspital der Universität, Germany; Institute für Klinische Chemie und für Diabetesforschung am Städt. Authors with affiliations: Deufel, T., Abt. für Klin. Chemie und Biochemie im Dr. von Haunerschen Kinderspital der Universität, Germany, Arzt für Laboratoriumsmedizin, Abt. für Klin. Chemie und Biochemie, Kinderklinik der Universität im Dr. von Haunerschen Kinderspital, Lindwurmstraße 4, D-8000 München 2, Germany; Gerbitz, K.-D., Institute für Klinische Chemie und für Diabetesforschung am Städt. Krankenhaus Schwabing, Munich, Germany
Abstract: The inherited skeletal muscle diseases form a highly heterogeneous group of disorders covering single enzyme defects, complex metabolic disorders, storage diseases, dystrophies and malignant hyperthermia. Whereas these myopathies may be caused by a large number of different biochemical and genetic defects their clinical presentation by contrast is relatively monotonous, with only a few specific findings pointing to a particular molecular defect. This review of the biochemical and molecular genetic basis of these diseases concentrates on 1) disorders in fuel utilization and energy production, 2) disorders in structural integrity or mechanical function, and 3) disorders in contractility and electrophysiological properties of the muscle cell. The authors address the questions of organ-specificity and of a possible relationship between clinical, biochemical, and genetic heterogeneity of metabolic defects, and also try to present the current state of chromosome mapping for such disorders. © 1991 Walter de Gruyter & Co.

Authors: Cook G.M., Spindler W.C., Grefe G.
Title: Overview of Battery Power Regulation and Storage
Affiliations: Electric Power Research Institute, Palo Alto, CA, United States; Batteries Included, Riverside, CA, United States; Public Service Electric and Gas, Newark, NJ, United States
Authors with affiliations: Cook, G.M., Electric Power Research Institute, Palo Alto, CA, United States; Spindler, W.C., Batteries Included, Riverside, CA, United States; Grefe, G., Public Service Electric and Gas, Newark, NJ, United States
Abstract: Battery energy systems are new electric utility technology whose applications are not yet fully demonstrated. This paper describes not only the applications and benefits achieved by existing and planned facilities but also those that are possible. The performance of existing facilities and the benefits predicted by models show that battery energy systems can be an economically attractive addition to the equipment now used to generate and transmit electric power. © 1991 IEEE. All rights reserved.

Authors: Rustan P.L., Jr., Verga R.L., Straw D.C.
Title: SDIO Pulsed Power R & D Requirements
Affiliations: Strategic Defense Initiative Orgaization, Office of the Secretary of Defense, Washington, DC, 20301–7100, United States; Associates. Inc., Arlington, VA, United States
Authors with affiliations: Rustan, P.L., Jr., Strategic Defense Initiative Orgaization, Office of the Secretary of Defense, Washington, DC, 20301–7100, United States, Associates. Inc., Arlington, VA, United States; Straw, D.C., Associates. Inc., Arlington, VA, United States
Abstract: The Strategic Defense Initiative Organization (SDIO) per- forms pulse power research and technology base development to satisfy the requirements of six major systems: Neutral Particle Beams (NPB‘s), Space-Based Free Electron Lasers (SBFEL‘s), Ground-Based Lasers (GBL‘s), Electromagnetic Launchers (EML‘s), Laser Radars (LR‘s), and High Power Microwaves (HPM‘s). The research is focused on component development with mass, volume, and efficiency being the key technology drivers. Order of magnitude improvements are in many cases required in order to meet the specific requirement. These development efforts include those power conditioning devices and components needed to match the electrical characteristics of the power source with those required by the load. Technology areas include energy storage, switching, and power conversion. This paper will detail the specific component requirements and two space experiments integrating developmental components. © 1991 IEEE

Authors: Veeranjaneyulu K., N'soukpoé-Kossi C.N., Leblanc R.M.
Title: Spectral Efficiency of in vivo Photochemical Energy Storage in SO2 Fumigated Sugar Maple Leaves
Affiliations: Centre de recherche en photobiophysique, Université du Québec à Trois-Rivières, 3351, boul. des Forges,  C.P. 500, Trois-Rivières, Québec, G9A 5H7, Canada
Authors with affiliations: Veeranjaneyulu, K., Centre de recherche en photobiophysique, Université du Québec à Trois-Rivières, 3351, boul. des Forges,  C.P. 500, Trois-Rivières, Québec, G9A 5H7, Canada; N'soukpoé-Kossi, C.N., Centre de recherche en photobiophysique, Université du Québec à Trois-Rivières, 3351, boul. des Forges,  C.P. 500, Trois-Rivières, Québec, G9A 5H7, Canada; Leblanc, R.M., Centre de recherche en photobiophysique, Université du Québec à Trois-Rivières, 3351, boul. des Forges,  C.P. 500, Trois-Rivières, Québec, G9A 5H7, Canada
Abstract: Photosynthetic action spectrum and quantum yield of photochemical energy storage were determined by recording photoacoustic spectra of sugar maple (Acer saccharum Marsh.) leaves at a modulation frequency of 80 Hz. At this low frequency, the difference between the intensity of spectra in the presence and in the absence of a non-modulated background light indicated the relative magnitude of the photochemical energy storage, which is generally measured at high frequencies. The amount of energy stored per unit absorbed light energy is low in blue, intermediate in green and high in red regions of the spectrum, indicating the excitation energy transfer efficiency of photosynthetic pigments. Similarly, the relative quantum yield of energy storage was low in blue and high in red regions showing the red-drop phenomenon. The energy storage spectrum per unit incident energy showed a similar profile except for a decline between 520 and 570 nm. In 2 µL L-1 SO2 fumigated leaves, the photochemical activity decreased relative to the control, confirming the SO2 inhibitory site on the electron transport chain. © 1991, Gustav Fischer Verlag, Stuttgart. All rights reserved.
Author Keywords: Acer saccharum; action spectra; PAS; PES; photoacoustic spectroscopy; photoacoustic spectroscopy; photochemical energy storage; photochemical energy storage; photosynthesis; SO2

Title: Proceedings of the ASME Turbo Expo

Abstract: The proceedings contain 5 papers. The topics discussed include: analysis of integrated coal gasification system/compressed-air energy storage power plant concepts; application of air saturation to integrated coal gasification/CAES power plants; use of circulating fluidized bed combustors in compressed air energy storage systems; assessment of refrigeration-type cooling of inlet air for Essex unit no. 9; and repowering of a combined cycle plant.

Authors: Brandhorst H.W., Cataldo R.L.
Title: SEI needs for space nuclear power
Source title: AIAA/NASA/OAI Conference on Advanced SEI Technologies, 1991
Affiliations: NASA Lewis Research Center, 21000 Brookpark Rd, Cleveland, OH  44135, United States
Authors with affiliations: Brandhorst, H.W., NASA Lewis Research Center, 21000 Brookpark Rd, Cleveland, OH  44135, United States; Cataldo, R.L., NASA Lewis Research Center, 21000 Brookpark Rd, Cleveland, OH  44135, United States
Abstract: On the 20th anniversary of the first human landing of the Moon, President Bush proclaimed that “the time has come to commit ourselves to the permanent settlement of space.” Three steps or gateways toward that goal were outlined: build a space station, establish a permanent lunar base and undertake the human exploration of Mars. In order to respond to President Bush’s mandate, it is expected that the peculiar demands of the lunar base and Mars missions will require 1he use of nuclear energy. For example, the demands of permanent human presence on the Moon with its 354 hour night puts extreme demands for energy storage on solar based power systems. Because energy storage is bulky and massive, it is likely that a practical cost effective upper limit on the amount of solar based power will be reached before the demands of permanent human habitation will have been satisfied. To put this into perspective, the cost of transporting both 100 kWe solar and nuclear power systems to the Moon and Mars will be presented. Various technological options will be presented for each of the scenarios. These results demonstrate a clear advantage for nuclear power systems on the Moon and a lesser advantage on Mars. © 1991 by American Institute of Aeronautics and Astronautics, Inc.
Index Keywords: Cost effectiveness; Energy storage; Lunar landing; Lunar missions; Martian surface analysis; Moon; Moon bases; Nuclear energy; Seebeck effect; Space stations; Cost effective; Human exploration; Human habitation; Human landing; Mars missions; Permanent settlements; Space nuclear power; Upper limits; Nuclear fuels

Authors: Havaux M., Eyletters M.
Title: Is the in vivo Photosystem I Function Resistant to Photoinhibition? An Answer from Photoacoustic and Far-Red Absorbance Measurements in Intact Leaves
Source title: Zeitschrift fur Naturforschung - Section C Journal of Biosciences
Affiliations: Universitè de Genève, Laboratoire de Bioènergètique, Station de Botanique, CH-1254 Lullier-Genève, Switzerland; Universitè Libre de Bruxelles, Laboratoire de Physiologie Vègètale, 28 avenue P. Heger, B-1050 Bruxelles, Belgium
Authors with affiliations: Havaux, M., Universitè de Genève, Laboratoire de Bioènergètique, Station de Botanique, CH-1254 Lullier-Genève, Switzerland; Eyletters, M., Universitè Libre de Bruxelles, Laboratoire de Physiologie Vègètale, 28 avenue P. Heger, B-1050 Bruxelles, Belgium
Abstract: Preillumination of intact pea leaves with a strong blue-green light of 400 W m-2 markedly inhibited both photoacoustically monitored O2-evolution activity and PS II photochemistry as estimated from chlorophyll fluorescence measurements. The aim of the present work was to examine, with the help of the photoacoustic technique, whether this high-light treatment deteriorated the in vivo PS I function too. High-frequency photoacoustic measurements indicated that photochemical conversion of far-red light energy in PS I was preserved (and even transiently stimulated) whereas photochemical energy storage monitored in light exciting both PS I and PS II was markedly diminished. Low-frequency photoacoustic measurements of the Emerson enhancement showed a spectacular change in the PS II/PS I activity balance in favor of PS I. It was also observed that the linear portion of the saturation curve of the far-red light effect in the Emerson enhancement was not changed by the light treatment. Those results lead to the conclusion that, in contrast to PS II, the in vivo PS I photofunctioning was resistant to strong light stress, thus confirming previous suggestions derived from in vitro studies. Estimation of the redox state of the PS I reaction center by leaf absorbance measurements at ca. 820 nm suggested that, under steady illumination, a considerably larger fraction of PS I centers were in the closed state in high-light pretreated leaves as compared to control leaves, presumably allowing passive adjustment of the macroscopic quantum yield of PS I photochemistry to the strongly reduced photochemical efficiency of photoinhibited PS II. © 1991, Verlag der Zeitschrift für Naturforschung. All rights reserved.
Author Keywords: Photoacoustics; Photoinhibition; Photosystem I

Authors: Hohlberg A., Aguilera J.M., Diaz R.
Title: Economic evaluation of postharvest losses and utilization of hard-to-cook beans: A case study in chile
Affiliations: Departamento de Ingenieria Quimica Escuela de Ingenieria and Departamento de Economia Agraria Escuela de Agronomia Universidad Catolica de Chile, Casilla 6177, Santiago, Chile
Authors with affiliations: Hohlberg, A., Departamento de Ingenieria Quimica Escuela de Ingenieria and Departamento de Economia Agraria Escuela de Agronomia Universidad Catolica de Chile, Casilla 6177, Santiago, Chile; Aguilera, J.M., Departamento de Ingenieria Quimica Escuela de Ingenieria and Departamento de Economia Agraria Escuela de Agronomia Universidad Catolica de Chile, Casilla 6177, Santiago, Chile; Diaz, R., Departamento de Ingenieria Quimica Escuela de Ingenieria and Departamento de Economia Agraria Escuela de Agronomia Universidad Catolica de Chile, Casilla 6177, Santiago, Chile
Abstract: A methodology was developed to quantify postharvest economic losses due to bean hardening, and was used to predict losses in the main variety of beans consumed in Chile. Losses caused by bean hardening during storage in Chile were determined from a survey and a model of the post-production trade system. The survey involved nine farmers and four wholesalers in the bean growing area. After one year of storage, losses due to hardening were significant at both ends of the commercialization chain. The model used dynamic simulation of the post-harvest trade chain of beans in Chile to predict the losses. The overall economical loss due to this defect in tortola beans only, was estimated at almost US$4 million per annum. Of this loss, 34% was attributable to physical losses, 41% to nutritional losses and 24% to extra energy required to cook beans. Alternatives to reduce energy consumption were evaluated. © 1991, Taylor & Francis Group, LLC. All rights reserved.
Author Keywords: cooking; economic evaluation; hardening model; market chain; Postharvest losses; pretreatments; tortola beans

Authors: Xie S.M., Wei D.Y., Bao C.L., Aoki T.
Title: The mechanism of explosive cyclogenesis over the sea east of china and japan
Affiliations: National Research Center for Marine Environmental Forecasts, 8 Da Hui Si, Hai Dian Division, Beijing 100081, China; Meteorological Agency, 1–3-4 Ote-machi, Chiyoda-ku Tokyo 100, Japan
Authors with affiliations: Xie, S.M., National Research Center for Marine Environmental Forecasts, 8 Da Hui Si, Hai Dian Division, Beijing 100081, China, Meteorological Agency, 1–3-4 Ote-machi, Chiyoda-ku Tokyo 100, Japan; Wei, D.Y., National Research Center for Marine Environmental Forecasts, 8 Da Hui Si, Hai Dian Division, Beijing 100081, China, Meteorological Agency, 1–3-4 Ote-machi, Chiyoda-ku Tokyo 100, Japan; Bao, C.L., National Research Center for Marine Environmental Forecasts, 8 Da Hui Si, Hai Dian Division, Beijing 100081, China, Meteorological Agency, 1–3-4 Ote-machi, Chiyoda-ku Tokyo 100, Japan; Aoki, T., National Research Center for Marine Environmental Forecasts, 8 Da Hui Si, Hai Dian Division, Beijing 100081, China, Meteorological Agency, 1–3-4 Ote-machi, Chiyoda-ku Tokyo 100, Japan
Abstract: By using 10-level data on a 2.5° latitude-longitude grid of March 14–15, 1988, a diagnostic analysis is made of the explosive intensification of a cyclone (pressure drop of 24hPa/24h) over the Kuroshio region. The cyclone experienced three development stages: energy storage stage, explosive development stage and continuous development stage. The explosive in tensification of the cyclone is caused mainly by the heat transport from the Kuroshio in to the cyclone, baroclinicity of the SST frontal zone and cumulus convection in the warm sector of the cyclone. The continuous explosive development is caused by a change in the atmospheric dynamic condition resulting from the development in the earlier stages and the release of baroclinic energy from the oceanic and atmospheric frontal zones. © 1991, Elsevier B.V. All rights reserved.

Authors: Brindley D.N.
Title: Chapter 6 Metabolism of triacylglycerols
Affiliations: Department of Biochemistry, Lipid and Lipoprotein Research Group, 328 Heritage Medical Research Centre, University of Alberta, Edmonton, Alta., Canada
Authors with affiliations: Brindley, D.N., Department of Biochemistry, Lipid and Lipoprotein Research Group, 328 Heritage Medical Research Centre, University of Alberta, Edmonton, Alta., Canada
Abstract: Triacylglycerols play a major role in energy storage in animals, where they are deposited in adipose tissue. This chapter describes the biosynthesis of triacylglycerols, digestion, absorption, and transport of lipids, control of triacylglycerol synthesis, metabolism of triacylglycerols when the action of insulin is high, and metabolism of triacylglycerols when the action of insulin is high. Most of the triacylglycerols in animals are stored in adipose tissue. However, triacylglycerols can be deposited in liver, heart, and skeletal muscle under several conditions of metabolic stress when the supply of fatty acids from adipose tissue exceeds the need or capacity of the cells to oxidize them. Although, the increased use of tissue- and cell-culture techniques means that the specific effects of hormones and metabolites on triacylglycerol metabolism can be investigated, one of the biggest problems in lipid metabolism is to isolate, characterize, purify, and raise antibodies against the enzymes, which are often tightly associated with membranes. The regulation of triacylglycerol metabolism is an important part of intermediary metabolism. A greater appreciation of this regulation would help to alleviate or prevent several clinical conditions, including fatty liver, diabetes, obesity, hyperlipidemias, and atherosclerosis. © 1991, Elsevier B.V. All rights reserved.

Authors: Kanari K., Abe Y., Tanaka K., Takahashi Y., Sakamoto R., Kamimoto M., Ozawa T.
Title: Heat Transfer Characteristics of Latent Thermal Storage Units with Sodium Hydroxide-Based Molten Salts
Affiliations: Electrotechnical Laboratory, Tsukuba 305, Japan; Daicel Chemical Industries, Ltd., Japan
Authors with affiliations: Kanari, K., Electrotechnical Laboratory, Tsukuba 305, Japan; Abe, Y., Electrotechnical Laboratory, Tsukuba 305, Japan; Tanaka, K., Electrotechnical Laboratory, Tsukuba 305, Japan; Takahashi, Y., Electrotechnical Laboratory, Tsukuba 305, Japan; Sakamoto, R., Electrotechnical Laboratory, Tsukuba 305, Japan; Kamimoto, M., Electrotechnical Laboratory, Tsukuba 305, Japan; Ozawa, T., Daicel Chemical Industries, Ltd., Japan
Abstract: The present paper describes experimental and computer simulation results for horizontal U-tube latent thermal storage units with a eutectic of sodium hydroxide-sodium nitrate. Through 1000 melting-freezing (charge-discharge) cycle tests on two 30 kWh scale storage units of bare-tube and finned-tube stypes, the heat transfer characteristics were evaluated. Computer simulations of both types of storage units were performed with a two dimensional model. For the finned-tube type, the effect of fin was included in the effective thermal conductivity of molten salt around the tubes. The calculated results were in good agreement with experimental ones. The heat transfer characteristics were evaluated for various storage units with different parameters such as number of passes, and number of heat transfer pipes. © 1991, The Society of Chemical Engineers, Japan. All rights reserved.
Author Keywords: Computer Simulation; Energy; Heat Transfer; High Temperature; Latent Heat; Molten Salt; Sodium Hydroxide; Thermal Storage
Index Keywords: Caustic soda; Computer simulation; Fins (heat exchange); Fused salts; Heat storage; Latent heat; Thermal conductivity; Tubes (components); Energy; High temperature; Molten salt; Sodium hydroxides; Thermal storage; Heat transfer

Authors: Kaushik S.C., Rao S.K., Kumari R.
Title: Dynamic simulation of an aqua-ammonia absorption cooling system with refrigerant storage
Affiliations: Centre of Energy Studies, Indian Institute of Technology, Hauz Khas, New Delhi, 110 016, India
Authors with affiliations: Kaushik, S.C., Centre of Energy Studies, Indian Institute of Technology, Hauz Khas, New Delhi, 110 016, India; Rao, S.K., Centre of Energy Studies, Indian Institute of Technology, Hauz Khas, New Delhi, 110 016, India; Kumari, R., Centre of Energy Studies, Indian Institute of Technology, Hauz Khas, New Delhi, 110 016, India
Abstract: A dynamic computer simulation model of a solar powered aqua-ammonia absorption cooling system with refrigerant storage is presented. The model requires a known solution flow-rate as well as average hourly weather data and the cooling load pattern as input parameters and is capable of predicting various heat flows, temperatures, concentrations, mass flows and mass stored in the absorber/condenser stores. The design parameters of the system components are evaluated at rated conditions using the steady state model. Test simulation of the dynamic model is carried out with the cooling load corresponding to a typical cold storage house on a hot summer day. It is found that the refrigerant stored during excess generation hours may not be sufficient to meet the cooling load during off-generation hours, and hence, provision to evaluate the auxiliary refrigerant mass required and the fraction of the load met by solar energy is included in the simulation model. Thus, the concept of refrigerant storage within the cycle is feasible, but it has to be integrated with other storage options for absorption cooling systems. © 1991.
Author Keywords: Absorption cooling; Aqua-ammonia; Continuous space conditioning; Dynamic simulation; Refrigerant storage

Authors: Baixeras C., Domingo C., Fernández F.
Title: Ultra heavy ion studies with plastic nuclear track detectors. Application to cosmic rays
Source title: International Journal of Radiation Applications and Instrumentation. Part
Affiliations: Física de les Radiacions. Departament, Física. Universitat Autònoma de Barcelona. E-08193 Bellaterra Barcelona. Spain, Spain
Authors with affiliations: Baixeras, C., Física de les Radiacions. Departament, Física. Universitat Autònoma de Barcelona. E-08193 Bellaterra Barcelona. Spain, Spain; Domingo, C., Física de les Radiacions. Departament, Física. Universitat Autònoma de Barcelona. E-08193 Bellaterra Barcelona. Spain, Spain; Fernández, F., Física de les Radiacions. Departament, Física. Universitat Autònoma de Barcelona. E-08193 Bellaterra Barcelona. Spain, Spain
Abstract: In order to investigate plastic track detectors similar to those used in the UHCRE, our group has participated in several accelerator experiments in the past few years. The goal of these experiments was to determine the detector response to ultra heavy ions and to study the parameters which could affect this response. We have found that a corrected Bethe-Bloch formula should be used to obtain the ultra heavy ion energy losses and ranges in plastic detectors. The intrinsic charge uncertainty for polycarbonate associated to the experimental method used is σZ = (1.05 ± 0.16) charge units for Z > 60 ions. By reproducing the UHCRE exposure and storage conditions a charge uncertainty of σZ = (1.70 ± 0.19) charge units is obtained. This charge uncertainty still allows the separation of the Lead and Platinum charge groups of cosmic radiation. © 1991.
Author Keywords: charge identification; cosmic radiation; energy loss; latent track evolution; Plastic track detectors; Ultra Heavy elements

Authors: Csige I., Hunyadi I., Charvát J.
Title: Environmental effects on induction time and sensitivity of different types of CR-39
Source title: International Journal of Radiation Applications and Instrumentation. Part
Affiliations: Institute of Nuclear Research, Debrecen, 4001, Hungary; Institute of Radiation Dosimetry, Prague, 18086, Czech Republic
Authors with affiliations: Csige, I., Institute of Nuclear Research, Debrecen, 4001, Hungary; Hunyadi, I., Institute of Nuclear Research, Debrecen, 4001, Hungary; Charvát, J., Institute of Radiation Dosimetry, Prague, 18086, Czech Republic
Abstract: The track registration properties of different types of CR-39 solid state nuclear track detectors (MA-ND, Pershore, Tastrak) were studied in vacuum for alpha particles with different energies. The alpha particle response is characterized by the etch induction time and the etch rate ratio. It is found that the etch induction time increases and the etch rate ratio decreases in vacuum and different types of CR-39 show different behavior. The role of the pre outgassing time and post storage time in vacuum in the latent track formation is discussed. The effect of storage time in normal air at different temperatures was also studied in a three year period. A slow but definite decrease of sensitivity was observed, which was negligible at lower temperature. © 1991.
Author Keywords: CR-39 nuclear track detectors; etch induction time; etch rate ratio; latent track formation; long term ageing effect; vacuum effect

Authors: Kevan L.
Title: Electron spin echo modulation analysis of photoproduced radical cation locations in micelles and vesicles
Source title: International Journal of Radiation Applications and Instrumentation. Part
Affiliations: Department of Chemistry, University of Houston, Houston, TX 77204, United States
Authors with affiliations: Kevan, L., Department of Chemistry, University of Houston, Houston, TX 77204, United States
Abstract: The electron spin echo modulation method provides a technique to measure very weak dipolar hyperfine interactions between a paramagnetic species and surrounding magnetic nuclei about 0.25-0.6 nm distant from the paramagnetic center. This technique is used to measure the surroundings of the photoproduced paramagnetic radical cations in micellar and vesicular structures in order to determine the structural constraints that optimize and control the charge separation process of molecules embedded in such organized molecular media. This control can then be related to methods for potential storage of light energy. © 1991.

Authors: Maschke B.
Title: Geometrical formulation of bond graph dynamics with application to mechanisms
Affiliations: Boursier CIRCEA-Cisi-Ingéniérie, DPT, UGRA/SERA Bât. 38/1, BP 6, 92 265 Fontenay-aux-Roses Cedex, France
Authors with affiliations: Maschke, B., Boursier CIRCEA-Cisi-Ingéniérie, DPT, UGRA/SERA Bât. 38/1, BP 6, 92 265 Fontenay-aux-Roses Cedex, France
Abstract: A differential-geometric formulation of the dynamics associated with a bond graph model of energy-conserving physical systems is presented. Based on the generalized bond graph notation and the symplectic gyrator element, the causal procedure of constructing the bond graph dynamics is shown to fit with the symplectic formalism of classical mechanics. A simple mechanical example illustrates the geometric-differential formulation of its dynamics and the question of its order with respect to reduction procedures. For bond graphs containing dependent energy-storage fields, the multiple causality assignments are interpreted in differential-geometric terms as a set of coordinate charts of the constrained state-space. Finally, the bond graph dynamics of models of mechanisms is formulated, where the energy variables, the momenta, belong now to a certain cotangent bundle over the inertial positions associated with the bodies of the mechanism. © 1991.

Authors: Koelle H.H.
Title: A model for a regional transportation system within the geostationary space complex
Affiliations: Techn.Univ. Berlin, Aerospace Institute, Salzufer 17-19, D-1000 Berlin 10, Germany
Authors with affiliations: Koelle, H.H., Techn.Univ. Berlin, Aerospace Institute, Salzufer 17-19, D-1000 Berlin 10, Germany
Abstract: The geostationary orbit about the Earth is presently used by a great number of communication and observation satellites. These nearly one hundred satellites have a limited lifetime and are expected to be replaced in due time by unmanned platforms of increasing size. Maintenance, repair and removal of these platforms by unmanned and manned space vehicles is one of the options discussed with increasing frequency. Another space system envisioned for the geostationary orbit are space solar power plants (SSPS). They have been investigated during the last two decades to find out whether there are any technical or financial problems which have to be overcome before a SSPS can materialize sometime in the next century. So far, none have been discovered, but proof is lacking that a SSPS is technically feasible and competitive if compared with other options to solve the energy problem on this planet in the next century. A partial problem for the acquisition and operation of a system of space power satellites is their assembly, maintenance and repair. Most of it must be done automatically but a sizable crew would probably have to be in GEO for quick action. Such a crew requires not only habitats, storages and a local energy supply, but also a regional space transportation system to transport spares, tools and people between the individual power plants and the other elements of the geostationary infrastructure. Such a regional transportation system for local transportation in the geostationary orbit (GRET) was recently studied at the Aerospace Institute of the Technical University of Berlin. It envisions a fleet of small space vehicles for interorbital transfer requiring modest velocity changes and flight times. The fleet comprises taxis for passenger transport, tugs for cargo transport and several unmanned and manned services vehicles of different sizes. These vehicles are housed in a special GEO space facility connected directly to the GEO spaceport. A SSPS driven market model assumes the initial operational capability for the year 2004. The GEO crew might have two hundred people by 2010 and several thousand tons of construction materials and spares would have to be transported by that time. The regional transportation system including GEO facilities and space vehicles will require approximately 1000 tons within the first decade of operation, not counting the propellants. The results of a preliminary cost model indicate acquisition cost in the order of 28 × 109 dollars. If the acquisition and operating costs of a commercial entity of this kind are to be covered by the services rendered to the company operating the SSPS, then transportation prices of 15,000 $/trip and 50,000 $/metric ton moved between the GEO facilities would have to be charged. This system model might not be the best way for solving the local transportation problem in GEO, but this kind of overhead cost must be included in any future system analysis of the SSPS. © 1991.

Authors: Hénoux J.C.
Title: The energy budget in active regions and flares
Affiliations: Observatoire de Paris, DASOP, URA326, 92195 Meudon, France
Authors with affiliations: Hénoux, J.C., Observatoire de Paris, DASOP, URA326, 92195 Meudon, France
Abstract: Information on the energetic balance in active regions derived from space observations is reviewed. It suggests both a global balance with some lag between sunspot darkening and plage brightening and the existence of a solar-cycle modulation. Some recent models are quoted. Recent works on the role of the global magnetic field topology and on flare energy storage are briefly discussed. The role of large scale structures is emphasized. Progress on the understanding of the energy transport mechanisms in solar flares is reviewed. It includes new observational indications of the existence of low energy protons and confirmation of the significance of the coupling between modes to the transport of energy. The role of the radiative transport mechanism is underlined. Observations support for the model of chromospheric evaporation derived from multiwavelength observations is presented. Other possible interpretations are briefly discussed. © 1991.

Authors: kachru R.P.
Title: A pneumatic emptying device for a flat-bottomed grain storage bin
Affiliations: All India Coordinated Research Project on Post Harvest Technology, Central Institute of Agricultural Engineering, Nabi Bagh, Berasia Road, Bhopal-462 018 (MP)
Authors with affiliations: kachru, R.P., All India Coordinated Research Project on Post Harvest Technology, Central Institute of Agricultural Engineering, Nabi Bagh, Berasia Road, Bhopal-462 018 (MP)
Abstract: An air sweep, self emptying device for a grain bin (capacity of 500 kg wheat) was developed by designing a perforated flat bottom with raised apertures arranged in a particular pattern to allow complete unloading of the grain from the bin (used for drying, aeration and/or storage purpose). The dimensions of the apertures, which were in the form of a segment of a circle, (elevation view) were 12.0 mm chord length by 2.5 mm arc height. Their spacing and number were dictated by the grain size and minimum opening area needed for grain flow. Without using a blower, the time taken for partial unloading of grain by gravity alone from the bin varied from 57 s for chickpea to 100 s for wheat. However, the amount of grain left in the bin was a maximum for pigeon pea of 258 kg/m2 and minimum for soybean at 193 kg/m2 of bin bottom area. With the blower, the bin was completely emptied. The minimum time required for unloading wheat, soybean and pigeon pea was found to be 202 s, 366 s and 295 s, respectively at an air flow rate of 55.2m3/min per m2 of bin bottom area using electric energy of 720 kJ. For chickpea, the time taken was 398 s at an air flow rate of 59.8 m3/min per m2 of bottom area using electrical energy of 1800 kJ. © 1991 The British Society for Research in Agricultural Engineering.

Authors: Schmieder B., van Driel-Gesztelyi L., Hénoux J.C., Simnett G.
Title: Flares and filament formation due to the interaction between two active regions
Affiliations: Observatoire de Paris, Section d'Astrophysique, 92195 Meudon, France; Sterrenkundig Instituut, Postbus 80.000, 3508 TA Utrecht, Netherlands; Heliophysical Observatory, P.O. Box 30, H-4010 Debrecen, Hungary; Department of Physics and Space Research, University of Birmingham, Birmingham, B15 2TT, United Kingdom
Authors with affiliations: Schmieder, B., Observatoire de Paris, Section d'Astrophysique, 92195 Meudon, France; van Driel-Gesztelyi, L., Sterrenkundig Instituut, Postbus 80.000, 3508 TA Utrecht, Netherlands, Heliophysical Observatory, P.O. Box 30, H-4010 Debrecen, Hungary; Hénoux, J.C., Observatoire de Paris, Section d'Astrophysique, 92195 Meudon, France; Simnett, G., Department of Physics and Space Research, University of Birmingham, Birmingham, B15 2TT, United Kingdom
Abstract: We follow the evolution (flare activity, filament formation) of two interacting active regions of different ages over three days, through observations at white-light, Hα, UV, and X-ray wavelengths. We show that the observed photospheric motions could generate DC electric currents and that they could lead to free energy storage. Flares were observed more-or-less simultaneously in remote locations of the sunspot group. This suggests that the same perturbation affected an ensemble of lines of force. Filament formation took place due to DC current generation by photospheric shearing motions with a velocity up to 350 m s-1. © 1991.

Authors: Zer-Zion D., Seidman A., Koetz U.
Title: Degradation of CMOS-integrated electronics under ionizing irradiation
Affiliations: DESY, 2 Hamburg 52, F.R.Germany; Tel-Aviv University, 69978 Tel-Aviv, Israel
Authors with affiliations: Zer-Zion, D., DESY, 2 Hamburg 52, F.R.Germany, Tel-Aviv University, 69978 Tel-Aviv, Israel; Seidman, A., DESY, 2 Hamburg 52, F.R.Germany, Tel-Aviv University, 69978 Tel-Aviv, Israel; Koetz, U., Tel-Aviv University, 69978 Tel-Aviv, Israel
Abstract: In high energy physics collider experiments, particles interact with semiconductor structures of integrated circuits, causing degradation of the physical and electronic characteristics. At the calorimeter of the HERA-experiment ZEUS, at DESY, a fast analog storage device, realized by CMOS integrated electronics was investigated under irradiation conditions higher than those expected in the experiment. Various parameters showed continuous degradation with irradiation. Also ways of correcting for the effect of the degradation on the calorimeter resolution, up to high doses, are shown. © 1991.

Authors: Mishra R.S.
Title: Techno-economic evaluation of hybrid thermosyphonic solar water heating systems
Affiliations: Mechanical Engineering Department, Panjab Agricultural University, Ludhiana (Panjab)-, 141 004, India
Authors with affiliations: Mishra, R.S., Mechanical Engineering Department, Panjab Agricultural University, Ludhiana (Panjab)-, 141 004, India
Abstract: The problem inhibiting the popular use of solar water heating systems is the cost of the delivered useful energy which has to be estimated with proper techno-economics. The numerical calculations are made for Indian market conditions and Delhi (India) climate for open loop water heating systems and closed loop water heating systems, with a heat exchanger in the collector loop. The basic problem which deserves to be considered for all types of solar water heating systems is the optimization of the collector with respect to the cost of useful delivered energy for various storage capacities. It was observed from computation that the cost of solar energy comes out to be more than for electrical energy which has been highly subsidized in the alternative systems. The cost of useful delivered energy comes out around the cost of electrical energy without a subsidy and 10% less with a subsidy. The optimized collector area for 70°C desired temperature for 200 l. of daily hot water demand comes out to be 2.5 m2 for 801. of tank capacity and 2 m2 with a heat exchanger in the collector loop. The cost of the useful delivered energy will be more if an auxiliary heating system is provided inside the storage tank instead of at load. For a forced flow system, the cost of the delivered useful energy comes out 15% higher. © 1991.

Authors: [No author name available]
Title: Guidelines on the electrostatic hazards during pneumatic conveying and storage of flammable powders
Source title: Journal of Loss Prevention in the Process Industries
Abstract: A purpose-built industrial-sized metal silo facility was used to assess the electrostatic hazards that may arise during the pneumatic conveyance of a range of powdered products. This range embraced the insulating powders, high density polyethylene (HDPE) and phenol formaldehyde (resistivity > 1013 Ωm); the moderately conducting products, starch and sugar (resistivity 109 Ωm); and relatively conductive wheat (resistivity 107 Ωm). Pneumatic transport tests were conducted and triboelectric charging was monitored. The incendivity of electrostatic discharges in the receiving silo was assessed by using an earthed probe shrouded in a propaneair environment. Numerous non-incendive discharges were promoted by the probe. By increasing the product charge levels artificially by using a charge-injection device to simulate the levels of triboelectric charging that might arise in some industrial circumstances, it was possible to promote two propaneair ignitions at the probe, one from bulk HDPE and one from the starch dust cloud. It was concluded that the risk of discharges from bulked powder igniting the dust cloud depends on product resistivity. For relatively conducting products of resistivity < 109 Ωm no ignition risk was identified. For more insulating products when resistivity > 109 Ωm no risk was identified if minimum ignition energy > 10 mJ. For discharges from the product dust cloud there is no evidence from the silo project to contradict the guidance in BS 5958. © 1991.
Author Keywords: electrostatc; hazard; powders

Authors: Wiesmann P.G.
Title: Linac ring collider
Affiliations: CERN, 1211 Geneva 23, Switzerland
Authors with affiliations: Wiesmann, P.G., CERN, 1211 Geneva 23, Switzerland
Abstract: The collision of a linear accelerator electron beam with a particle beam stored in a ring allows center of mass energies and luminosities beyond those achievable in pure storage ring colliders. The constraints of such a collider scheme and the unusual beam-beam interaction scenario with a highly disrupted electron beam are discussed. Machine parameters for a high luminosity B factory are given. The possibilities to use the LEP type superconducting acceleration cavities for the linac and a low emittance and high current positron ring analog to advanced synchrotron light sources are outlined. The option for a parallel useability of the electron beam for linac-ring collisions and fixed target operation is mentioned. © 1991.

Authors: Scott A.C.
Title: Davydov's soliton revisited
Affiliations: Laboratory of Applied Mathematical Physics, Technical University of Denmark, DK-2800 Lyngby, Denmark; Department of Mathematics, University of Arizona, Tuczon, AZ 85721, United States
Authors with affiliations: Scott, A.C., Laboratory of Applied Mathematical Physics, Technical University of Denmark, DK-2800 Lyngby, Denmark, Department of Mathematics, University of Arizona, Tuczon, AZ 85721, United States
Abstract: Following a brief survey of past research on Davydov's soliton mechanism for the storage and transport of vibrational energy in protein, the present status of the theory is evaluated. Although much remains to be done before the soliton stability at physiological temperature (310 K) is well understood, currently available numerical results on a simplified model of alpha-helix indicate useful lifetimes. Finally, some suggestions for future research are presented. © 1991.

Authors: Hasse R.W.
Title: Excess energy of cylindrical coulomb crystals
Affiliations: ESR Division, Gesellschaft für Schwerionenforschung (GSI), D-6100 Darmstadt, Germany
Authors with affiliations: Hasse, R.W., ESR Division, Gesellschaft für Schwerionenforschung (GSI), D-6100 Darmstadt, Germany
Abstract: Excess energies are calculated for cylindrical Coulomb crystals at very low temperature and various densities as an approximation of a cooled ion beam in a storage ring or of cold trapped ions. Even for the large six-shell structures it is found that the plane hexagonal lattice on the surface is still dominating with an excess (Madelung) energy of -0.892 28 over the expected infinite bcc structure. The results of molecular-dynamics computer simulations are compared with results of a classical shell model which takes into account the constant intershell distances and hexagonal surface occupation. © 1991 The American Physical Society.

Authors: Akerib D.S., Barish B., Cowen D.F., Eigen G., Stroynowski R., Urheim J., Weinstein A.J., Morrison R., Schmidt D., Procario M., Johnson D.R., Lingel K., Rankin P., Smith J.G., Alexander J., Bebek C., Berkelman K., Besson D., Browder T.E., Cassel D.G., Cheu E., Coffman D.M., Drell P.S., Ehrlich R., Galik R.S., Garcia-Sciveres M., Geiser B., Gittelman B., Gray S.W., Hartill D.L., Heltsley B.K., Honscheid K., Kandaswamy J., Katayama N., Kreinick D.L., Lewis J.D., Ludwig G.S., Masui J., Mevissen J., Mistry N.B., Nandi S., Ng C.R., Nordberg E., Ogrady C., Patterson J.R., Peterson D., Pisharody M., Riley D., Sapper M., Selen M., Worden H., Worris M., Avery P., Freyberger A., Rodriguez J., Yelton J., Kinoshita K., Pipkin F., Wilson R., Wolinski J., Xiao D., Sadoff A.J., Ammar R., Baringer P., Coppage D., Davis R., Haas P., Kelly M., Kwak N., Lam H., Ro S., Kubota Y., Nelson J.K., Perticone D., Poling R., Schrenk S., Alam M.S., Kim I.J., Nemati B., Romero V., Sun C.R., Wang P.-N., Zoeller M.M., Crawford G., Fulton R., Gan K.K., Jensen T., Kagan H., Kass R., Malchow R., Morrow F., Whitmore J., Wilson P., Butler F., Fu X., Kalbfleisch G., Lambrecht M., Skubic P., Snow J., Wang P.-L., Bortoletto D., Brown D.N., Dominick J., Mcilwain R.L., Miller D.H., Modesitt M., Shibata E.I., Schaffner S.F., Shipsey I.P.J., Battle M., Kroha H., Sparks K., Thorndike E.H., Wang C.-H., Artuso M., Goldberg M., Haupt T., Horwitz N., Jain V., Kennett R., Moneti G.C., Rozen Y., Rubin P., Skwarnicki T., Stone S., Thusalidas M., Yao W.-M., Zhu G., Barnes A.V., Bartelt J., Csorna S.E., Letson T., Mestayer M.D.

Abstract: Using the CLEO II detector at the Cornell Electron Storage Ring, we have determined the inclusive B* cross section above the (4S) resonance in the energy range from 10.61 to 10.70 GeV. We also report a new measurement of the energy of the B*B transition photon of 46.20.30.8 MeV. © 1991 The American Physical Society.

Authors: Konishi S., Inoue M., Hayashi T., O'Hira S., Watanabe T., Okuno K., Naruse Y., Barnes J.W., Bartlit J.R., Anderson J.L.
Title: Early experiments of JAERI fuel cleanup system at the tritium systems test assembly
Affiliations: Japan Atomic Energy Research Institute, Tokai, Ibaraki, 319-11, Japan; Los Alamos National Laboratory, Los Alamos, NM 87545, United States
Authors with affiliations: Konishi, S., Japan Atomic Energy Research Institute, Tokai, Ibaraki, 319-11, Japan; Inoue, M., Japan Atomic Energy Research Institute, Tokai, Ibaraki, 319-11, Japan; Hayashi, T., Japan Atomic Energy Research Institute, Tokai, Ibaraki, 319-11, Japan; O'Hira, S., Japan Atomic Energy Research Institute, Tokai, Ibaraki, 319-11, Japan; Watanabe, T., Japan Atomic Energy Research Institute, Tokai, Ibaraki, 319-11, Japan; Okuno, K., Japan Atomic Energy Research Institute, Tokai, Ibaraki, 319-11, Japan; Naruse, Y., Japan Atomic Energy Research Institute, Tokai, Ibaraki, 319-11, Japan; Barnes, J.W., Los Alamos National Laboratory, Los Alamos, NM 87545, United States; Bartlit, J.R., Los Alamos National Laboratory, Los Alamos, NM 87545, United States; Anderson, J.L., Los Alamos National Laboratory, Los Alamos, NM 87545, United States
Abstract: The Tritium Process Laboratory (TPL) at the Japan Atomic Energy Research Institute (JAERI) has developed a Fuel Cleanup System (FCU) which accepts simulated fusion reactor exhaust and produces pure hydrogen isotopes and tritium-free waste. Under the collaboration program of USDOE and JAERI, an integrated process, the "JAERI Fuel Cleanup System" (JFCU) was designed and fabricated for testing at the Tritium Systems Test Assembly (TSTA) as a major subsystem of the simulated fusion fuel cycle. The JFCU has the capability to continuously process a mixture of hydrogen isotopes and impurities of 15 mol/h. The major components are: a palladium diffuser for hydrogen isotopes purification, a catalytic reactor for oxidation of tritium in impurities, cold traps for separation of tritiated water to produce exhaust containing a very low level of tritium, a ceramic electrolysis cell for decomposition of tritiated water, and zirconium-cobalt beds for hydrogen isotopes storage. In early 1990, the JFCU was installed in the TSTA and preliminary testing without tritium was initiated. Components such as the palladium diffuser, cold traps, catalytic reactor, scroll pump and electrolysis cell were tested independently as well as in the integrated process tests. © 1991.

Authors: Carlson T.N., Lynn B.
Title: The effects of plant water storage on transpiration and radiometric surface temperature
Affiliations: Department of Meteorology, The Pennsylvania State University, University Park, PA 16802, United States
Authors with affiliations: Carlson, T.N., Department of Meteorology, The Pennsylvania State University, University Park, PA 16802, United States; Lynn, B., Department of Meteorology, The Pennsylvania State University, University Park, PA 16802, United States
Abstract: The storage of water in plants (a capacitor) is incorporated into the plant component of a boundary layer model. The capacitance, storage resistance, and storage water potential are related directly to the volume of water stored. We show how an initial volume of stored water affects the surface transpiration flux, canopy radiometric temperature and stomatal resistance. The magnitude of the capacitance effect in large plants did not exceed 20-50 W m-2 in transpiration (per unit leaf area) and 1 °C in surface radiometric temperature. Storage in small plants seem to play virtually no role in the surface energy budget or have any significant effect on surface radiometric temperature. © 1991.

Authors: Al-Karaghouli A., Abood I., Al-Hamdani N.I.
Title: The solar energy research center building thermal performance evaluation during the summer season
Affiliations: Engineering and Industrial Applications Department, Solar Energy Research Center, P.O. Box 13020, Baghdad, Iraq
Authors with affiliations: Al-Karaghouli, A., Engineering and Industrial Applications Department, Solar Energy Research Center, P.O. Box 13020, Baghdad, Iraq; Abood, I., Engineering and Industrial Applications Department, Solar Energy Research Center, P.O. Box 13020, Baghdad, Iraq; Al-Hamdani, N.I., Engineering and Industrial Applications Department, Solar Energy Research Center, P.O. Box 13020, Baghdad, Iraq
Abstract: In this paper, the thermal performance of the Solar Energy Research Center Building during the summer season was analyzed. The building is considered as one of the world's largest to be cooled by solar energy. The front surface of the building is inclined at 45° and oriented 22° east of south. It is constructed on a ground area of 3300m 2 and consists of five floors with a total area of 6331 m2 and an air-conditioned area of 3351 m2. The cooling system comprises mainly of 1577 evacuated tube solar collectors, two thermal storage tanks of 15 m3, two chilled water storage tanks of 150 m3 each, two absorption chillers of 60 tons each, two heat pump chillers of 40 tons each, two heat exchangers, two auxiliary boilers, five cooling towers, four air-handling units and associated pumps and control equipment. The results show that the daily average solar collection efficiency is 49%, the chiller COP is 0.618, and the solar fraction to the load is 0.604. © 1991.

Authors: Rose M.F., Merryman S.A., Johnson C.R.
Title: Comparative Analysis of Energy Storage Media and Techniques
Source title: IEEE Aerospace and Electronic Systems Magazine
Affiliations: Space Power Institute, Auburn University, AL, 36849, United States
Authors with affiliations: Rose, M.F., Space Power Institute, Auburn University, AL, 36849, United States; Merryman, S.A., Space Power Institute, Auburn University, AL, 36849, United States; Johnson, C.R., Space Power Institute, Auburn University, AL, 36849, United States
Abstract: Since energy can neither be created nor destroyed—only changed from one form to another, the subject of energy storage and conversion is critical to advanced power technology. In this paper we will examine techniques for storing and converting energy from one form to another. The parameters of interest are storage density (in terms of both energy and power) conversion efficiency, and number of steps in the conversion process. The techniques compared are electrostatic, magnetic, inertial, chemical, thermal, and nuclear. Each technique for storage is discussed in terms of the ease with which the energy can be converted to electricity for powering lightweight compact power systems for a variety of uses. The storage density associated with the various mechanisms spans an enormous range (~ 0.5 MJ/kg to ~ 105 MJ/kg). The impact upon time-to-refuel within the context of mobile tactical army applications is discussed. © 1991, IEEE.

Authors: Widom A., Vittoria C.
Title: Quantum-mechanical phase locking in weak-link arrays
Affiliations: Physics Department, Northeastern University, Boston, MA 02115, United States; Department of Electrical Engineering, Northeastern University, Boston, MA 02115, United States
Authors with affiliations: Widom, A., Physics Department, Northeastern University, Boston, MA 02115, United States; Vittoria, C., Department of Electrical Engineering, Northeastern University, Boston, MA 02115, United States
Abstract: Quantum-mechanical descriptions of arrays of Josephson weak links often invoke electric-field-energy storage in the weak-link capacitors. However, such quantum-electrodynamic mechanism is by no means a requirement for the notion of macroscopic quantum-mechanical wave functions for the array as a whole. These statements are illustrated for the phenomena of quantum-mechanical phase locking in one- and two-dimensional arrays in electromagnetic fields. © 1991 The American Physical Society.

Authors: Weislogel M.M., Chung J.N.
Title: Experimental investigation of condensation heat transfer in small arrays of PCM-filled spheres
Source title: International Journal of Heat and Mass Transfer
Affiliations: Department of Mechanical and Materials Engineering, Washington State University, Pullman, WA 99164-2920, United States
Authors with affiliations: Weislogel, M.M., Department of Mechanical and Materials Engineering, Washington State University, Pullman, WA 99164-2920, United States; Chung, J.N., Department of Mechanical and Materials Engineering, Washington State University, Pullman, WA 99164-2920, United States
Abstract: Experimental investigations on the condensation heat and mass transfer between flowing steam and a small regularly packed bed of encapsulated spheres filled with PCM (phase-change material) are performed. The objectives of the research are to obtain transient transport characteristics of the dual-latent heat thermal storage system during the charging process. A special device is used to instrument the inside of the sphere. This device retards the sinking of the unmelted solid PCM toward the bottom of the spherical shell, thus reducing the strong dependence of the heat flux on tangential angle location. Instantaneous heat transfer rates are obtained for spheres of three different sizes (with single sphere and small packed bed arrangements). Tests performed to note Reynolds number and Stefan number dependencies of the two phase transfer and energy storage are also carried out. The device worked well, particularly for the larger spheres (6.35 and 7.62 cm diameter), which allowed the normalized thermal energy stored to be correlated by a single dimensionless time scale for all of the tests performed. © 1991.

Authors: Abdel-Kader A., Farag H.I., Tolba A.R.
Title: Thermoluminescence and storage stability of TLD-100 dosimeter irradiated with 60Co-gamma rays
Affiliations: Physics Department, Faculty of Science, Menoufia University, Menoufia, Egypt; Radiotherapy Department, Radiation Physics Unit, National Cancer Institute, Cairo University, Cairo, Egypt
Authors with affiliations: Abdel-Kader, A., Physics Department, Faculty of Science, Menoufia University, Menoufia, Egypt; Farag, H.I., Radiotherapy Department, Radiation Physics Unit, National Cancer Institute, Cairo University, Cairo, Egypt; Tolba, A.R., Radiotherapy Department, Radiation Physics Unit, National Cancer Institute, Cairo University, Cairo, Egypt
Abstract: Thermoluminescence glow curves of TLD-100 revealed three peaks at 373, 460 and 518 K for all samples irradiated with gamma ray doses of 0.5 to 700 Gy. The total thermoluminescence response and the height of the main peak at 460 K showed similar characteristics to radiation dose. On the other hand, the total area under the glow curve increases continuously with radiation dose up to 1000 Gy. All irradiated samples investigated showed no significant fading over 28 d. Activation energy, E, and escape frequency factor, s, for the main glow peak were calculated by the modified empirical equation, as well as by methods depending on the shape of the glow peak. It was found that E has a value of 1.33 to 1.83 eV and s falls between 5.8×1013 and 3.06×1019 sec-1, depending on the method used. © 1991 Chapman and Hall Ltd.

Authors: Vogel I., Möbius A.
Title: On some problems of the zinc-bromine system as an electric energy storage system of higher efficiency-I. Kinetics of the bromine electrode
Affiliations: Dresden University of Technology, Department of Chemistry, Mommsenstraß 13, Dresden, 8027, Germany; G.D.R. Academy of Sciences, Rudower Chaussee 5, Berlin, 1199, Germany
Authors with affiliations: Vogel, I., Dresden University of Technology, Department of Chemistry, Mommsenstraß 13, Dresden, 8027, Germany; Möbius, A., G.D.R. Academy of Sciences, Rudower Chaussee 5, Berlin, 1199, Germany
Abstract: The addition of bromine to different quarternary ammonium compounds which are important for working of the zinc/bromine battery and the interaction of the polybromides with the electrolyte and electrode material were investigated. Using cyclovoltammetry and the method of rotating disc electrode the kinetics of the bromine/polybromide electrode were studied in different aqueous salt solutions, differing from each other by their intensity of interaction with the bromine molecule. The bond strength of the bromine to the cation increases in the order NaBr, ZnBr2, NH4Br. The peak potential differences are enhanced with increasing interaction between bromine and cation, whereas exchange current densities decrease to the same extent. The rate constant of the heterogeneous charge transfer determined from rd-measurements also indicates an inhibition of the charge transfer in the anodic process when NH4Br is used. © 1991.
Author Keywords: -measurements.; bromine polybromide electrode; cv-rd; electrochemical kinetics; heterogeneous charge transfer; zinc/bromine battery

Authors: Yamamoto K., Kameyama H.
Title: Proposal of an Air Conditioner with an Ice-Storage Apparatus Utilizing an Organic Polymer Gel and a Vacuum Pump
Affiliations: Div. of Chem. & Biol. Sci. and Tech., Tokyo Univ. of Agri. and Tech., Tokyo 186, Japan
Authors with affiliations: Yamamoto, K., Div. of Chem. & Biol. Sci. and Tech., Tokyo Univ. of Agri. and Tech., Tokyo 186, Japan; Kameyama, H., Div. of Chem. & Biol. Sci. and Tech., Tokyo Univ. of Agri. and Tech., Tokyo 186, Japan
Abstract: A low-temperature-heat storage apparatus that stores the heat of water evaporation in the form of ice produced in a kind of organic polymer gel (WAPG) was proposed. An air conditioner with the above heat storage apparatus was also proposed (Fig. 5). The surface area of water can be spread by the use of WAPG in a thin sheet type. Part of the water contained in WAPG is vaporized at 0.2 to 0.6 kPa to change the remaining part of the water into ice. It was shown that the water vapor pressure above the polymer gel was the same as that above pure water. The heat stored in a liter of WAPG was around 222 kJ. From calculation, the coefficient of performance of heat storage (COPC) was 5 to 10, depending on the temperatures of vaporization and condensation (Fig. 7). The coefficient of performance of the air conditioner (COPA) was calculated for various operating parameters such as COPC temperature and vapor pressure changes of the air-conditioned room, work of the blower and total energy loss. The proposed air conditioner can be operated at a COPA of 2 to 4 (Figs. 10, 11, 12). © 1991, The Society of Chemical Engineers, Japan. All rights reserved.
Author Keywords: Air Conditioning; Coefficient of Performance; Energy; Heat Storage; Ice; Organic Polymer Gel; Water Vapor Compression
Index Keywords: Domestic appliances; Energy dissipation; Heat storage; Hydrostatic pressure; Ice; Organic polymers; Temperature; Water vapor; Coefficient of Performance; Energy; Low temperatures; Operating parameters; Pressure change; Total energy loss; Vapor compression; Water evaporation; Air conditioning

Authors: Yamamoto K., Kameyama H.
Title: Study of Energy Storage with Ice Forming by Direct Water Evaporation from Surface of Polymer Gel by Evacuation
Affiliations: Div. of Material and Biol. Science and Tech., Tokyo Univ. of Agr. and Tech., Tokyo 186, Japan
Authors with affiliations: Yamamoto, K., Div. of Material and Biol. Science and Tech., Tokyo Univ. of Agr. and Tech., Tokyo 186, Japan; Kameyama, H., Div. of Material and Biol. Science and Tech., Tokyo Univ. of Agr. and Tech., Tokyo 186, Japan
Abstract: Kinetic studies of energy storage by ice production in polymer gel were made to show the practicality of the preriously proposed ice storage system. The rates of water evaporation from several kinds of gel were the same as that from pure water. The rate of water evaporation was linearly proportional to the difference between the water vapor pressure and the evacuation pressure, and inversely proportional to the square root of the evaporation temperature (Eq. (2)). The experiments were conducted under a rather high evacuation pressure of 98 to 99% of the vapor pressure at the vaporization temperature. The vaporization rate constant k3 was 1g-Pa-1.K0,5. min-1.m-2, and by use of a gel layer with the thickness of around 6 cm the rate was large enough to produce ice required for energy storage during 10 hr evacuation at night. The procedure of ice formation within the gel was studied by calculating the energy balance of the experimental system. The simulation was proved to be a useful method of elucidating the amount of ice produced in a gel when no other direct method can show the rate of frozen water to total water in the frozen gel. © 1991, The Society of Chemical Engineers, Japan. All rights reserved.
Author Keywords: Energy Storage; Ice Production; Kinetics; Polymer Gel; Water Evaporation; Without Freons
Index Keywords: Copolymers; Energy storage; Enzyme kinetics; Evaporation; Hydrostatic pressure; Polymers; Rate constants; Vaporization; Evaporation temperature; Experimental system; Ice production; Ice-storage system; Linearly proportional; Polymer gels; Vaporization temperature; Water evaporation; Ice

Authors: Ennis C.D., Chen A.
Title: Cognitive style differences within an analytical curriculum: Examples of success and nonsuccess
Affiliations: University of Maryland, United States; University of Northern Colorado, United States
Authors with affiliations: Ennis, C.D., University of Maryland, United States, University of Northern Colorado, United States; Chen, A., University of Maryland, United States
Abstract: This research was conducted to examine field dependence/independence cognitive style differences exhibited by young children in analytically-oriented movement education curricula. It was hypothesized that an analytical focus demands mental energy, memory storage/retrieval capacity, and cognitive flexibility that are especially challenging for field-dependent children. The behaviors of field-dependent (FD) and field independent (Fl) children were videotaped within the natural school context. Examples of success and nonsuccess were examined using the critical incident technique to compare the teacher's directions and comments with FD or Fl students’ performances. Results suggested that Fl children experienced success 76.6% of the time, while FD children were successful 46.6%. Teachers permitted Fl children to respond to questions and take part in demonstrations more frequently that FD children. FD Children's behavioral responses to complex problem solving situations are discussed. © 1991, Taylor & Francis Group, LLC. All rights reserved.
