Authors: Schwarz J., Keller C., Soltes J.
Title: Adsorption cycles with the working fluid zeolite/water
Affiliations: Zeo-Tech GmbH, Munich, Germany
Authors with affiliations: Schwarz, J., Zeo-Tech GmbH, Munich, Germany; Keller, C., Zeo-Tech GmbH, Munich, Germany; Soltes, J., Zeo-Tech GmbH, Munich, Germany
Abstract: Sorption technology that converts thermal energy is receiving renewed attention due to environmental concerns. A new class of materials, zeolites, is gaining importance. Zeolites can be combined with water for use in sorption cycles. Sorption machines can store energy for any desired period of time without thermal insulation. The stored energy can then be used to produce either heating or cooling power in an environmentally safe way. For example, a sorption-based thermal storage device working at ambient pressure can store and later transfer internally stored energy at approximately 125 Btu per pound of zeolite (80 Wh/kg) at a short-term sorption efficiency of 4.30 Btu/s per pound of zeolite (10 kW/kg zeolite). If the sorption process works in a vacuum, the number of applications can be extended. A sorption device with a cooling coefficient of performance (COP) of 0.35 and a heating COP of 1.35 can be used as a heat pump, a hot-water storage system, an exhaust-driven automotive air conditioner, a freeze boiler, or an icemaker.
Index Keywords: Air - Drying; Water - Adsorption; Zeolites - Surface Properties; Desiccants; Thermal Energy Conversion; Air Conditioning

Authors: Ahn S.J., Kim G.H., Choi G.W.
Title: Tributary pollutant effects in the urban stream network
Affiliations: Chung Buk Natl Univ, Cheong Ju, South Korea
Authors with affiliations: Ahn, S.J., Chung Buk Natl Univ, Cheong Ju, South Korea; Kim, G.H., Chung Buk Natl Univ, Cheong Ju, South Korea; Choi, G.W., Chung Buk Natl Univ, Cheong Ju, South Korea
Abstract: With considering unsteady flow and backwater effects, a linear water quality model is developed based on the finite difference approximation. The model is composed to two components which are hydraulic and mass transport components. The hydraulic component in the model consists of two partial differential equations describing the conservations of mass and momentum in the interior channel cross section and two equations describing the conservations of mass and energy at channel junctions. The mass transport component in the model is composed of two mass transport equations which are applied in the interior channel cross section and channel junctions. This model uses a simultaneous solution algorithm for stream network. This algorithm takes advantage of the banded matrix features to compute the coefficient matrix. This algorithm has the advantages of significantly reduced computer storage requirement and computational time requirement. To show tributary pollutant effects a hypothetical stream network having mild channel bed slopes was applied to the model. The simulation results show that simultaneous water quality model can predict more reliable results rather than the sequential models.
Index Keywords: Mathematical Models; Mathematical Techniques - Finite Difference Method; Stream Flow; Water Supply - Water Quality; Linear Water Quality Models; Stream Networks; Tributary Pollutant Effects; Urban Stream Networks; Water Pollution

Authors: Pang D., Kirk J.A., Anand D.K., Huang C.
Title: Design optimization for magnetic bearing
Source title: Proceedings of the Intersociety Energy Conversion Engineering Conference
Affiliations: Univ of Maryland, College Park, United States
Authors with affiliations: Pang, D., Univ of Maryland, College Park, United States; Kirk, J.A., Univ of Maryland, College Park, United States; Anand, D.K., Univ of Maryland, College Park, United States; Huang, C., Univ of Maryland, College Park, United States
Abstract: This paper proposes an optimization design methodology for the PM/EM radially active magnetic bearing developed at the Advanced Design and Manufacturing Laboratory of the University of Maryland. The bearing is used in the flywheel energy storage system to magnetically suspend the rotating flywheel without friction loss. The optimization model is based on the stiffness and permeance models of the magnetic bearing. The objective of the optimization design is to maximize the stable displacement range, which directly affects the stiffness, load capacity and operating range of the bearing. The constraints include the bearing load, the magnetic flux density, the axial load and stiffness, the geometric limitation, and the power amplifier and the control system. There are a total of 12 design variables, 11 inequality constraints and 6 equality constraints. The problem is solved by three different optimization methods: the monotonicity analysis, the generalized reduced gradient method and the augmented Lagrange multiplier method. The design methodology not only can help to achieve the design goals and better performance but specify the important dimensions and design variables of the bearing. A case study of the magnetic bearing flywheel system design is demonstrated. These three methods yield results with less than 1% error.
Index Keywords: Control Systems; Energy Storage; Flywheels; Friction; Optimization; Flywheel Systems; Magnetic Bearings; Bearings

Authors: Waldron R.D., Criswell D.R.
Title: System requirements/constraints and design options for a global lunar power system
Source title: Proceedings of the Intersociety Energy Conversion Engineering Conference
Authors with affiliations: Waldron, R.D.; Criswell, D.R.
Abstract: A conceptual system for collecting and converting solar radiation to electric power on the lunar surface and transmitting beamed electro-magnetic power to multiple earth stations has been described. A minimum or core system requires 6 classes of elements: 1) solar collection/conversion fields, 2) RF or optical electromagnetic wave generators, 3) lunar transmitting aperture(s) and structural elements, 4) terrestrial receiving apertures and structures (including rectification), and 5,6) transmission/distribution systems for moon and earth. The system requirements are constrained by: 1) true and projected dimensions of transmitting and receiving apertures on the moon and earth, 2) beam cross-sectional shaping and azimuthal variations due to combined earth and moon motions, 3) permissible main beam and side lobe power densities, and 4) time constraints for illumination of solar receiver plots and line-of-sight transmission to specific earth bases. The effects of lunar libration and earth rotation are discussed. The characteristics of beam power propagation of convergent electromagnetic waves in the radiative near field region are described including deliberate defocusing to produce intensity leveling in the receiver plane. System options for solar collector fields, reflector structures for transmitting and receiving arrays and non-core elements such as energy storage and orbital reflectors are presented.
Index Keywords: Energy Conversion; Moon; Solar Radiation--Collectors; Space Stations; Spacecraft; Global Lunar Power Systems; Wave Generators; Electric Power Systems

Authors: Hockney Richard L., Goldie James H., Kirtley James L.
Title: Flywheel energy storage for electromechanical actuation systems
Source title: Proceedings of the Intersociety Energy Conversion Engineering Conference
Affiliations: SatCon Technology Corp, Cambridge, United States
Authors with affiliations: Hockney, Richard L., SatCon Technology Corp, Cambridge, United States; Goldie, James H., SatCon Technology Corp, Cambridge, United States; Kirtley, James L., SatCon Technology Corp, Cambridge, United States
Abstract: This paper describes a flywheel energy storage system designed specifically to provide load-leveling for a Thrust Vector Control (TVC) system employing Electromechanical Actuators (EMA). One of the major advantages of an EMA system implementation as compared to a hydraulic system is the significant reduction in total energy consumed during the launch profile. Realization of this energy reduction will, however, require localized energy storage capable of delivering the peak power required by the EMAs. A combined flywheel-motor/generator unit which interfaces directly to the 20 kHz power bus represents an ideal candidate for this load-leveling. The overall objective of this research is the definition of a flywheel energy storage system for this application. This paper discusses progress on four specific technical objectives: 1) Definition of the specifications for the flywheel-motor/generator system including system-level trade-off analysis; 2) Design of the flywheel rotor; 3) Design of the motor/generator; and 4) Determination of the configuration for the power management system.
Index Keywords: Actuators; Electric Motor Generator Sets; Energy Storage; Electromechanical Actuation Systems; Flywheel Energy Storage; Flywheels

Authors: Oberly C.E., Kozlowski G., Gooden C.E., Lenard R.X., Sarkar A.K., Maartense I., Ho J.C.
Title: Principles of application of high temperature superconductors to electromagnetic launch technology
Affiliations: WRDC/POOX-3, Wright-Patterson AFB OH 45433, United States; AFATL/SAH, Eglin AFB, FL 32548, United States; SDI/TNS, Pentagon, Washington, D.C. 20301, United States; University of Dayton Research Institute, Dayton, Ohio 45469, United States; Dept. of Physics and Chemistry, Institute for Aviation Research, Wichita State University, Wichita, KS 67208, United States

Abstract: Many recent advances in the performance of bulk high temperature superconductors (HTSC) now permit conductor and magnet development at practical magnetic fields to be pursued for high current applications such as electromagnetic launchers (EML). While early hopes for a superconductor critical temperature (Tc) approaching room temperature have not been fulfilled, numerous HTSC with Tc between 60K and 125K exist which can be successfully processed. Some of these HTSC are well enough understood that small conductors and coils may be fabricated for operation near 20K. Numerous physics, magnetic flux mechanics, materials processing and structural support issues remain for resolution before large scale coils made of HTSC can be operated at high energy storage density at temperatures well above 20K. This paper describes our recent results on properties and materials processing of HTSC and their relation to EML applications technology. © 1991 IEEE
Index Keywords: Electric Coils; Electromagnetic Launchers; Magnetic Fields; Large-Scale Coils; Magnetic Flux; High Temperature Superconductors

Authors: Gully J.H.

Abstract: Power supply technology for electric guns continues to mature at a rapid pace. Batteries, flywheels, capacitors, pulsed alternators, homopolar generators, inductors and high power switches are all viable components for electric gun systems. An assessment of the state-of-the-art technology for these components and potential for near-term and long-term growth is presented. Pulse power requirements for coilguns, electrothermal guns, and railguns are addressed, as well as energy storage techniques for multishot performance. © 1991 IEEE

Authors: Sato Y., Aikawa T.
Title: Adenosine deaminase in the adductor muscle of the scallop, Patinopecten yessoensis
Source title: Comparative Biochemistry and Physiology -- Part B: Biochemistry and
Affiliations: Department of Biology, Faculty of Science, College of General Education, Niigata 950-21, Japan, Japan; Department of Biology, College of General Education, Niigata University, Niigata 950-21, Japan, Japan

Abstract: 1. 1. The scallop enzyme was separated by DE52 ion-exchange chromatography into two forms with the same mol. wt of 38,000 and similar characteristics. 2. 2. The enzyme was inactivated in the absence of dithiothreitol and complete reactivation was achieved by adding the agent within a critical storage period. 3. 3. The apparent values of pKm and Vmax sensitively increased as ionic strength was raised to 250 mM and phosphate and sodium ions elevated the former value with a further increase of the ionic strength. 4. 4. The apparent activation energies for the α (Vmax/Km and β (Vmax) parameters of both the forms were approximately 5 and 8 kcal/mol, respectively. 5. 5. The enzyme deaminated 2′-, 3′-deoxyadenosine and 2′,3′-isopropylidene adenosine but did not deaminate 5′-deoxyadenosine, α-adenosine and adenine nucleotides. 6. 6. The affinity for inosine was much lowered with a high Ki value. Adenine and purine riboside inhibited the enzyme competitively, and coformycin was a tight, slow binding inhibitor. © 1991.

Authors: Wells C.M.M., Pearson D.W., De Luca P.M., Wells G.M., Cerrina F., Kennan W.S., Gould M.N.
Title: Synchrotron-produced ultrasoft x-rays: A tool for testing biophysical models of radiation action
Affiliations: Department of Medical Physics, University of Wisconsin-Madison, Madison, WI, 53706, United States; Department of Electrical and Computer Engineering, University of Wisconsin-Madison, Madison, WI, 53706, United States; Department of Human Oncology, University of Wisconsin-Madison, Madison, WI, 53792, United States
Authors with affiliations: Wells, C.M.M., Department of Medical Physics, University of Wisconsin-Madison, Madison, WI, 53706, United States; Pearson, D.W., Department of Electrical and Computer Engineering, University of Wisconsin-Madison, Madison, WI, 53706, United States; De Luca, P.M., Department of Human Oncology, University of Wisconsin-Madison, Madison, WI, 53792, United States; Wells, G.M., Department of Medical Physics, University of Wisconsin-Madison, Madison, WI, 53706, United States; Cerrina, F., Department of Medical Physics, University of Wisconsin-Madison, Madison, WI, 53706, United States; Kennan, W.S., Department of Medical Physics, University of Wisconsin-Madison, Madison, WI, 53706, United States; Gould, M.N., Department of Medical Physics, University of Wisconsin-Madison, Madison, WI, 53706, United States
Abstract: Ultrasoft X-rays are useful for mechanistic studies of ionizing radiation damage in living cells due to the localized nature of their energy depositions. To date radiobiology experiments in this energy region have relied on characteristic X-rays (mainly Alk and Ck) from X-ray tubes. However, limitations in the photon intensity and the available energies from X-ray tube sources prevent a definitive characterization of the relationship between photon energy and biological damage. Synchrotron radiation has the potential to avoid these limitations, since it produces X-rays with high intensity over a continuous spectrum. We have established a synchrotron-based system for radiation biology studies using the ES-0 exposure station of the Center for X-ray Lithography at the University of Wisconsin Synchrotron Radiation Center storage ring, Aladdin. A characterization of the system including spectral and intensity properties of the photon beam is presented. The first mammalian cell survival curve for synchrotron-produced ultrasoft X-rays was generated and is presented. Cell survival curves of C3H/10T1/2 cells using synchrotron radiation of 1.48 keV agree with previous data using Alk X-rays (1.49 keV). An RBE of 1.47 ± 0.30 at the 10% survival level was measured with reference to 250 kVp X-rays. © 1991 Informa UK Ltd All rights reserved: reproduction in whole or part not permitted.

Authors: Kapoor Kamlesh, Jaluria Yogesh
Title: Mixed convection flow due to a buoyant wall jet turning downward at a corner
Source title: American Society of Mechanical Engineers, Heat Transfer Division, (Publication) HTD
Affiliations: Rutgers, State Univ of New Jersey, New Brunswick, United States
Authors with affiliations: Kapoor, Kamlesh, Rutgers, State Univ of New Jersey, New Brunswick, United States; Jaluria, Yogesh, Rutgers, State Univ of New Jersey, New Brunswick, United States
Abstract: A detailed experimental investigation has been carried out on the flow characteristics of a horizontal buoyant ceiling jet which turns downward at a corner to yield a vertical negatively buoyant wall flow. Such mixed convection flows are frequently encountered in thermal energy storage problems in electonic systems and in room fires. However, not much work has been done to understand the basic fluid flow mechanisms of such flows, particularly the flow near the corner. In this study, a two-dimensional horizontal jet of heated air is discharged adjacent to the lower surface of an isothermal horizontal plate. An isothermal vertical plate is attached at the other end of the horizontal surface, making a right angle corner. The vertical penetration distance of the resulting downward flow is measured and is related to the inflow conditions, particularly, the temperature and velocity at the jet discharge. The penetration distance was also found to increase as the distance between the discharge location and the corner was reduced. Extensive velocity and temperature measurements were carried out over the flow region, particularly near the surfaces and the corner. These measurements indicate that the ceiling flow separates from the horizontal surface just before reaching the corner and then reattaches itself to the vertical wall at a finite distance vertically below the corner. The local surface heat flux measurements show a minimum in the heat transfer rate before the corner and a maximum just after the turn, indicating a recovery in the heat transfer rate at the corner. All these results confirm the existence of a small recirculation zone near the corner. The net mass flow entrainment into the ceiling jet was also measured and correlated with the jet discharge conditions.
Index Keywords: Energy Storage; Fires; Flow of Fluids--Jets; Heat Transfer--Measurements; Mechanical Variables Measurement--Velocity; Buoyant Jets; Ceiling Jets; Flow Characteristics; Mixed Convection; Recirculation Zones; Heat Transfer

Authors: Zhao J., Yang M., Shen Z.
Title: High photosensitivity in cis-poly(phenylacetylene) films irradiated by electron beams
Affiliations: Chemistry Department, Zhejiang University, Hangzhou, 310027, China; Guangzhou Institute of Chemistry, Guangzhou, 510650, China
Authors with affiliations: Zhao, J., Chemistry Department, Zhejiang University, Hangzhou, 310027, China, Guangzhou Institute of Chemistry, Guangzhou, 510650, China; Yang, M., Chemistry Department, Zhejiang University, Hangzhou, 310027, China; Shen, Z., Chemistry Department, Zhejiang University, Hangzhou, 310027, China
Abstract: Photosensitivity in cis-poly(phenylacetylene) (cis-PPA) films prepared with rare-earth coordination catalysts can be greatly improved by the irradiation with electron beams. Irradiation energy is a key factor for obtaining high photosensitivity. The potential discharge rate and difference between the initial and residual potential under an IR-lamp exposure increase with increasing energy from 1.3 to 1.8 MeV. Photosensitivity in cis-PPA remains almost constant if the irradiation flux is more than the critical flux (1×10 e cm-1). The irradiation effect for electron beams is strongly dependent on the microstructure of PPA and irradiation atmosphere. The dependence of the photosensitivity of the irradiated cis-PPA films on their storage time and temperature has been investigated. The characterization results of the irradiated cis-PPA have been described. A mechanism by which electron beams induce high photosensitivity in cis-PPA is proposed. © 1991, The Society of Polymer Science, Japan. All rights reserved.
Author Keywords: Cis-Polyphenylacetylene films; Electron beam irradiation; Photosensitivity

Authors: Brown Daryl R.
Title: Site-specific investigations of aquifer thermal energy storage for space and process cooling
Source title: Proceedings of the Intersociety Energy Conversion Engineering Conference
Affiliations: Pacific Northwest Lab, Richland, United States
Authors with affiliations: Brown, Daryl R., Pacific Northwest Lab, Richland, United States
Abstract: The Pacific Northwest Laboratory (PNL) has completed three preliminary site-specific feasibility studies that investigated aquifer thermal energy storage (ATES) for reducing space and process cooling costs. Chilled water stored in an ATES system could be used to meet all or part of the process and/or space cooling loads at the three facilities investigated. Seasonal or diurnal chill ATES systems could be significantly less expensive than a conventional electrically-driven, load-following chiller system at one of the three sites, depending on the cooling water loop return temperature and presumed future electricity escalation rate. For the other two sites investigated, a chill ATES system would be economically competitive with conventional chillers if onsite aquifer characteristics were improved. Well flow rates at one of the sites were adequate, but the expected thermal recovery efficiency was too low. The reverse of this situation was found at the other site, where the thermal recovery efficiency was expected to be adequate, but well flow rates were too low.
Index Keywords: Air Conditioning; Energy Storage; Heating--Heat Storage; Refrigeration; Aquifer Thermal Energy Storage; Chillers; Process Cooling; Space Cooling; Thermal Recovery Efficiency; Aquifers

Authors: Higgins M.A., Plant D.P., Ries D.M., Kirk J.A., Anand D.K.
Title: Flywheel energy storage for electric utility load leveling
Source title: Proceedings of the Intersociety Energy Conversion Engineering Conference
Affiliations: FARE Inc, College Park, United States
Authors with affiliations: Higgins, M.A., FARE Inc, College Park, United States; Plant, D.P., FARE Inc, College Park, United States; Ries, D.M., FARE Inc, College Park, United States; Kirk, J.A., FARE Inc, College Park, United States; Anand, D.K., FARE Inc, College Park, United States
Abstract: The purpose of a magnetically suspended flywheel energy storage system for electric utility load leveling is to provide a means to store energy during times when energy is inexpensive to produce and then return it to the customer during times of peak power demand when generated energy is most expensive. The design of a 20 kWh flywheel energy storage system for electric utility load leveling applications involves the successful integration of a number of advanced technologies so as to minimize the size and cost of the system without affecting its efficiency and reliability. The flywheel energy storage system uses a carbon-epoxy flywheel, two specially designed low loss magnetic bearings, a high efficiency motor/generator, and a 60 cycle AC power converter all integrated through a microprocessor controller. This paper will discuss in detail the basic design of each of the components that is utilized in the energy storage design.

Authors: Frate David T.
Title: Nickel-hydrogen cell low-earth-orbit life test update
Source title: Proceedings of the Intersociety Energy Conversion Engineering Conference
Affiliations: Natl Aeronautics and Space, Administration, Cleveland, United States
Authors with affiliations: Frate, David T., Natl Aeronautics and Space, Administration, Cleveland, United States
Abstract: When individual pressure vessel (IPV) nickel-hydrogen (Ni/H2) cells were selected as the energy storage system for Space Station Freedom in March of 1986, a limited database existed on life and performance characteristics of these cells in a low-earth-orbit (LEO) regime. Therefore, NASA LeRC initiated a Ni/H2 cell test program with the primary objectives of building a test facility, procuring cells from existing NASA contracts, and screening several cell designs by life testing in a LEO 35% depth-of-discharge (DOD) scenario. A total of 40 cells incorporating 13 designs were purchased from Yardney, Hughes, and Eagle-Picher. Thirty-two of the cells purchased were 65 Ampere-hour (A-hr) nameplate capacity and eight cells were 50 A-hr. Yardney and Eagle-Picher cells were built with both the Air Force recirculating and the advanced back-to-back electrode stack configurations and incorporated 31 and 26% potassium hydroxide (KOH) electrolyte. Hughes cells were built with the back-to-back design and with both 31 and 26% KOH. Acceptance testing of the first delivered cells began in March of 1988, with life testing following in September of that year. Performance comparisons of these cells are made here while specifically addressing life test data relative to the design differences.
Index Keywords: Electric Batteries - Space Applications; Energy Storage; Nickel Compounds - Applications; Pressure Vessels; Eagle-Picher Cells; Hughes Cells; Individual Pressure Vessel (IPV) Cells; Low-Earth-Orbit Regime; Nickel-Hydrogen Cell Low-Earth Orbit Life Tests; Potassium Hydroxide (KOH) Electrolyte; Space Stations

Authors: Bodet Jean-Marie, Labat Jean, Goualard Jacques
Title: Study of rechargeable lithium cells for space applications
Source title: Proceedings of the Intersociety Energy Conversion Engineering Conference
Affiliations: Saft Space Dep, Romainville, France
Authors with affiliations: Bodet, Jean-Marie, Saft Space Dep, Romainville, France; Labat, Jean, Saft Space Dep, Romainville, France; Goualard, Jacques, Saft Space Dep, Romainville, France
Abstract: SAFT research on lithium rechargeable cells investigated Li/Lix V205 couple with organic electrolyte. It led to prototype cells exhibiting specific energy from 100 to 140 Wh/kg and cycle life up to 120 cycles. SAFT is involved in a CNES (Centre National des Etudes Spatiales, Toulouse; France) sponsored research program to demonstrate the feasibility of ambient temperature secondary lithium batteries for geosynchronous space applications. We report here results of recent studies on cycling ability of cells. Laboratory prototypes have been designed with variable lithium/electrolyte relative weight and distribution. Cycling test in 2.8-3.8V and 2.0-3.8V ranges with 100% or 50% depth of discharge demonstrates up to 500 cycles. In order to simulate space applications, intermittent cycling storage test has been achieved with two storage modes: open circuit and trickle-charge. The test will run for several years, and we report herein the results available to date.
Index Keywords: Electric Batteries - Charging; Electric Batteries - Space Applications; Lithium and Alloys - Applications; Lithium Rechargeable Cells; Open Circuit Voltage; Space Cell Technology; Space Mission Batteries; Trickle-Charge Storage; Spacecraft

Authors: Strasser K.
Title: PEM fuel cells for energy storage systems
Source title: Proceedings of the Intersociety Energy Conversion Engineering Conference
Affiliations: Siemens AG, Erlangen, Germany
Authors with affiliations: Strasser, K., Siemens AG, Erlangen, Germany
Abstract: For many years, Siemens has been involved in the development of low-temperature fuel cells, with special concentration on alkaline H2/O2 fuel cells with mobile electrolyte. After acquisition of the basic PEM know-how, Siemens began the development of a 34 kW PEM fuel cell module for an air-independent propulsion system in 1984. The PEM fuel cell was selected as an H2/O2 cell because of its high overload capacity, its excellent long-term behavior, the absence of corrosive liquid electrolyte and the high energy density of the system. Due to its modular design, the system can readily be adapted to special requirements. Functionability of the system has already been demonstrated using a 20 kW module. Due to the fact that PEM fuel cells can also be operated with CO2-containing reactants and because of their considerable potential for increasing power, it is possible to construct H2/air storage systems which can be used in electrically driven vehicles or as long-term storage facilities for regenerative energy systems. Depending on the storage capacity required, it is possible to obtain energy densities which clearly surpass those of Na/S batteries.
Index Keywords: Electrolytes; Energy Storage; Air-Independent Propulsion System; Energy Storage Systems; Fuel Cell Stacks; Low-Temperature Fuel Cells; PEM Cell Design; Proton Exchange Membrane (PEM) Fuel Cells; Fuel Cells

Authors: Freilich J., Gordon J.M.
Title: Case study of a central-station grid-intertie photovoltaic system with V-trough concentration
Affiliations: Applied Solar Calculations Unit, Jacob Blaustein Institute for Desert Research Ben-Gurion University of the Negev, Sede Boqer Campus, 84993, Israel; The Pearlstone Center for Aeronautical Engineering Studies, Department of Mechanical Engineering, Ben-Gurion University of the Negev, Beersheva, Israel
Authors with affiliations: Freilich, J., Applied Solar Calculations Unit, Jacob Blaustein Institute for Desert Research Ben-Gurion University of the Negev, Sede Boqer Campus, 84993, Israel, The Pearlstone Center for Aeronautical Engineering Studies, Department of Mechanical Engineering, Ben-Gurion University of the Negev, Beersheva, Israel; Gordon, J.M., Applied Solar Calculations Unit, Jacob Blaustein Institute for Desert Research Ben-Gurion University of the Negev, Sede Boqer Campus, 84993, Israel, The Pearlstone Center for Aeronautical Engineering Studies, Department of Mechanical Engineering, Ben-Gurion University of the Negev, Beersheva, Israel
Abstract: Our presentation is a case study of an installed, central-station (no storage), utility-intertie photovoltaic (PV) system in Sede Boqer, Israel (latitude 30.9°N). The nominally 12 kW peak PV system is comprised of 189 polycrystalline silicon modules mounted on inexpensive, one-axis north-south horizontal trackers with V-trough mirrors for optical boost. The power conditioning unit operates at a fixed voltage rather than at maximum power point (MPP). The primary task in analyzing the installed system was to investigate the cause of measured power output significantly below the design predictions of the installers, and to recommend system design modifications. Subsequent tasks included the quantitative assessment of fixed-voltage operation and of the energetic value of V-trough concentration and one-axis tracking for this system. Sample results show: (i) fixed-voltage operation at the best fixed voltage (BFV) can achieve around 96% of the yearly energy of MPP operation; (ii) the sensitivity of the yearly energy delivery to the selection of fixed voltage and its marked asymmetry about the BFV; (iii) the influences of inverter current constraints on yearly energy delivery and BFV; and (iv) how the separate effects of tracking and optical concentration increase yearly energy delivery. © 1991.
Index Keywords: Electric Inverters - Applications; Mirrors - Applications; Photovoltaic Cells - Applications; Best Fixed Voltage (BFV); Central-Station Grid-Intertie Photovoltaic System; Maximum Power Point (MPP); Power Conditioning Unit; V-Trough Concentrators; Electric Power Systems

Authors: Witherspoon F.D., Burton R.L., Goldstein S.A.
Title: A second generation emet railgun for secondary arc studies
Affiliations: GT-Devices, Inc., 5705A General Washington Dr., Alexandria, VA, 22312, Egypt
Authors with affiliations: Witherspoon, F.D., GT-Devices, Inc., 5705A General Washington Dr., Alexandria, VA, 22312, Egypt; Burton, R.L., GT-Devices, Inc., 5705A General Washington Dr., Alexandria, VA, 22312, Egypt; Goldstein, S.A., GT-Devices, Inc., 5705A General Washington Dr., Alexandria, VA, 22312, Egypt
Abstract: Since 1985 GT-Devices has been operating a pair of railguns with lengths of 0.9m and 3.6m respectively. Although velocities up to 5.65 km/s have been obtained with “clean” plasma armature structures devoid of secondary arcs, performance on most shots is degraded to one degree or another by the formation of parasitic secondary arcs. These experimental results, however, have not been very reproducible, making controlled studies of these secondary arcs difficult. A new second generation railgun is now being constructed to improve straightness, stiffness, sealing, and diagnostic access. The basic design consists of a steel tube with a thin lengthwise slit forming two halves in cross section with bolt preloading. The internal structure consists of split tubular G-10 compression blocks with Glidcop AL-15 rails and polycarbonate insulators formed from 90 degree tube sections. Machining tolerance mismatch is adjusted with compliant layers as required. An adjustable diameter, helical diamond lap is used to produce a finished round bore of nominally 1 cm diameter in the assembled launcher and for bore refurbishment between shots. This approach is expected to provide well defined and reproducible bore initial conditions. A fully functional 12” long test barrel has been constructed allowing verification of assembly techniques, current feed connections, diagnostics, machining tolerance checks, and initial tests of high risk rail and insulator materials. A new 0.9 m launcher of the same design is now under construction, with a 3.6 m version to follow thereafter. An upgraded electrothermal injector has been developed using modified Armature Injection Module (AIM) hardware. Injection velocities of 2500 mls have been attained with 1.1 gram polycarbonate projectiles for stored bank energies of 65 kJ. Injection velocities of 3000 m/s may be possible. The paper will discuss the design details of the new railgun, injector, and diagnostics and present some initial experimental results. © 1991 IEEE
Index Keywords: Ballistics - Projectiles; Electric Arcs; Energy Storage; Plasma Devices; Second-Generation Railguns; Electromagnetic Launchers

Authors: Johnson D.E., Clements N.D.
Title: Lightweight high-efficiency energy-storage transformers
Affiliations: IAP Research. Inc., 2763 Culver Avenue, Dayton, OH, 45429-3723, United States
Authors with affiliations: Johnson, D.E., IAP Research. Inc., 2763 Culver Avenue, Dayton, OH, 45429-3723, United States; Clements, N.D., IAP Research. Inc., 2763 Culver Avenue, Dayton, OH, 45429-3723, United States
Abstract: Lightweight high-efficiency energy-storage transformers require stiff external structures. The conductors used to minimize resistive losses have an inherently low modulus of elasticity and are therefore useless as a structure. This generalization includes new “hyperconductors” such as high-purity aluminum in an aluminum-iron-cerium matrix. Although the aluminum material has high yield strength, the useful strength is limited by the strain induced in the pure aluminum filaments during magnetic loading. To maintain low resistivity at 20 K (boiling hydrogen), filament strain must not exceed 0.2%. All aluminum alloys at all temperatures have essentially the same elastic modulus, 70 GPa. The useful strength is thus limited to 140 MPa. Self-supporting transformers or inductors operating at this stress store only about 15 kJ/kg. Improving the specific energy requires adding a lightweight stiff structure. Boron or graphite might be used to make such a structure. We estimate that transformers or inductors can store energy at 50 to 100 kJ/kg using a boron structure and hyperconducting windings. In this paper we describe the scaling relationships for energy-storage transformers and how external structures improve specific energy. We compare transformer mass and efficiency to several transformer designs, each storing 5 MJ at I MA. © 1991 IEEE
Index Keywords: Electric Conductors; Electric Inductors; Hyperconducting Aluminum; Electric Transformers

Authors: Serfass J.A., Nahmias D., Appleby A.J.
Title: A practical hydrogen development strategy
Affiliations: National Hydrogen Association, 1101 Connecticut Ave., NW, #910, Washington, DC 20036, United States; Govt. Systems, Air Products and Chemicals, Inc., 7201 Hamilton Blvd, Allentown, PA 18195, United States; Director, CESHR, 238 Wisenbaker ERC, Texas A and M University, College Station, TX 77843-3577, U.S.A.
Authors with affiliations: Serfass, J.A., National Hydrogen Association, 1101 Connecticut Ave., NW, #910, Washington, DC 20036, United States; Nahmias, D., Govt. Systems, Air Products and Chemicals, Inc., 7201 Hamilton Blvd, Allentown, PA 18195, United States; Appleby, A.J., Director, CESHR, 238 Wisenbaker ERC, Texas A and M University, College Station, TX 77843-3577, U.S.A.
Abstract: The National Hydrogen Association's mission is to foster the development of hydrogen technologies and their utilization in industrial and commercial applications and promote the transition role of hydrogen in the energy field. Hydrogen's transitional role requires that it be part of a National Energy Strategy that utilizes the experience of private industry, academia, research organizations and government to address opportunities for environmentally compatible production and greater utilization of hydrogen as a fuel in the long-term energy mix of the U.S. and the world. The transition strategy must address the economics of hydrogen production, storage and transport; the need for environmentally acceptable production technologies; development of application technologies and markets; and the development of safety guidelines and information that will allow hydrogen to be used in a manner the public perceives as safe. © 1991.
Index Keywords: Energy Policy - United States; Energy Resources - United States; Societies and Institutions - United States; National Energy Strategy; National Hydrogen Association; Hydrogen Fuels

Authors: Davidson J.H., Walker H.A.
Title: Design optimization of a two-phase solar water heater using R-123
Affiliations: Colorado State Univ, Fort Collins, United States
Authors with affiliations: Davidson, J.H., Colorado State Univ, Fort Collins, United States; Walker, H.A., Colorado State Univ, Fort Collins, United States
Abstract: Design of a vapor transport solar water heater using R-123, an environmentally safe alternative to R-11, is optimized to maximize thermal performance and minimize life cycle cost. Optimal systems for one- and two-story homes are identified in a parametric study of collector area, condenser heat transfer area, water storage tank volume and circulating refrigerant volume for the Solar Rating and Certification Corporation rating procedure. Selection of collector and heat exchanger areas is critical to performance. With warm and cloudless ambient conditions, the most economic system is a large collector area, low efficiency system capable of meeting nearly 100% of the load. Under more realistic operating conditions, the best design will place more emphasis on efficiency. The condenser should have sufficient surface area to avoid significant increases in collector operating temperatures. Thermal performance is relatively insensitive to either refrigerant or water storage volume.
Index Keywords: Heat Transfer; Solar Energy; Water Tanks and Towers; Water--Storage; Solar rating; Two-phase solar water heaters; Water Heaters

Authors: Xia Zhongfu, Jiang Jian
Title: Corona-charged Aclar PCTFE film electrets
Affiliations: Tongji Univ, Shanghai, China
Authors with affiliations: Xia, Zhongfu, Tongji Univ, Shanghai, China; Jiang, Jian, Tongji Univ, Shanghai, China
Abstract: In this paper, the electric properties of negative and positive charging at room and elevated temperature in polychlorotrifluoroethylene (Aclar PCTFE) were studied by means of corona charging, electron-beam bombardment and thermally-stimulated discharge (TSD). After corona charging, the shift of the mean charge depth with delay during ageing at 150°C after corona charging at room temperature was investigated. Activation energies were obtained from the initial rise and peak cleaning technique, and the attempt-to-escape frequencies were estimated. The transport model of detrapped charge in an Aclar PCTFE sample was discussed by means of the Laser Induced Pressure Pulse (LIPP) method. The geometric distribution of traps with different activation energies along thickness was studied by means of electron-beam discharge and TSD currents in combination with the heat pulse method. Comparison of charge storage ability was made for positive and negative corona charge samples.
Index Keywords: Electrets - Thin Films; Electric corona; Plastics Films - Electric Properties; Aclar Thin Films; Polychlorotrifluoroethylenes; Fluorine containing polymers

Authors: Zangrando F.
Title: On the hydrodynamics of salt-gradient solar ponds
Affiliations: Solar Energy Research Institute (SERI), Golden, CO 80401, United States
Authors with affiliations: Zangrando, F., Solar Energy Research Institute (SERI), Golden, CO 80401, United States
Abstract: The objective of this paper is to discuss those hydrodynamical issues that affect the performance of the solar pond as an energy collector and storage system, e.g., mass and energy balance; formation, stability, and maintenance of the gradient layer; energy extraction from the bottom mixed layer; stability of stratified fluids to shearing flows; interface dynamics; and wall effects. Many of these topics are not fully understood and the discussion focuses on the present state of knowledge, some of the engineering correlations available at this time, and the research that is still required to resolve the relevant issues. © 1991.

Authors: Hayes R.J., Zowarka R.C., Jr.
Title: Experimental results from CEM-UT‘s single shot 9 MJ railgun
Affiliations: Center for Electromechanics, The University of Texas at Austin, 10100 Burnet Rd. Bldg. 133, Austin, 78758–4497, United States
Authors with affiliations: Hayes, R.J., Center for Electromechanics, The University of Texas at Austin, 10100 Burnet Rd. Bldg. 133, Austin, 78758–4497, United States; Zowarka, R.C., Jr., Center for Electromechanics, The University of Texas at Austin, 10100 Burnet Rd. Bldg. 133, Austin, 78758–4497, United States
Abstract: The Center for Electromechanics at the University of Texas at Austin (CEM-UT) has designed and fabricated a 10-m long 90 mm bore railgun. During the test program, a number of solid armatures and projectile packages have been tested in a 50 m deep vertical test range. The experiments are powered by six homopolar generator (HPG) charged inductive stores, sequentially staged to provide the desired acceleration profile. Prior to testing, computer simulations are run to determine the preferred current profile and predict system performance. During projectile flight, high speed films, x-rays, muzzle volts, and velocity/acceleration profiles are recorded along with power supply operating parameters. Postshot diagnostics include bore wear analysis and armature and target recovery. Comparisons of predicted and recorded shot performance are also made. On selected tests, an energy balance is performed to determine efficiencies of the various system components. A summary of all 90 mm gun shots is presented along with critical data collected from selected tests. © 1991 IEEE
Index Keywords: Ballistics - Projectiles; Electric Generators, DC; Energy Storage; Homopolar Generators; Electromagnetic Launchers

Authors: Richardson John A., Hull Todd R., Borchardt David E.
Title: Preliminary feasibility assessment of several spent fuel transfer/storage options suitable for early deployment at an MRS
Affiliations: United Engineers and Constructors, Inc, Washington, United States
Authors with affiliations: Richardson, John A., United Engineers and Constructors, Inc, Washington, United States; Hull, Todd R., United Engineers and Constructors, Inc, Washington, United States; Borchardt, David E., United Engineers and Constructors, Inc, Washington, United States
Abstract: This paper provides (a) an overview of the range of feasible Monitored Retrievable Storage (MRS) facility transfer and storage configurations that are available to the U.S. Department of Energy (DOE), Office of Civilian Radioactive Waste Management (OCRWM), and (b) a preliminary qualitative assessment of alternative configurations that identifies those proven or reasonably available technologies that appear to best meet the anticipated mission and functional requirements of the MRS. Twenty four spent fuel transfer options are discussed each of which can be configured with one or more of the 5 individual dry storage modes included in the assessment. A summary is provided of the recent work that has been performed on the MRS facility design program by OCRWM in preparation for the start of Title I - Preliminary Design, slated for October, 1991.

Authors: Blazek Mary Lou, Franco Janet E., Robison Robert W., Sanderson William J., Stewart-Smith David A., Binney Stephen E., Dodd Brian
Title: Oregon experiment. Public information and involvement
Affiliations: Oregon Dept of Energy, Salem, United States
Authors with affiliations: Blazek, Mary Lou, Oregon Dept of Energy, Salem, United States; Franco, Janet E., Oregon Dept of Energy, Salem, United States; Robison, Robert W., Oregon Dept of Energy, Salem, United States; Sanderson, William J., Oregon Dept of Energy, Salem, United States; Stewart-Smith, David A., Oregon Dept of Energy, Salem, United States; Binney, Stephen E., Oregon Dept of Energy, Salem, United States; Dodd, Brian, Oregon Dept of Energy, Salem, United States
Abstract: Oregon is neighbor to the Hanford Nuclear Site that now has the nation's largest store of radioactive waste. Oregon supports Hanford cleanup, which will require waste transport through Oregon. The Oregon Department of Energy, aided by Oregon State University, designed a means to measure how information affects public opinion, if at all, about nuclear weapons waste transport. The project has four components: 1) two formal organizations at state policy and citizen advisory levels, 2) a transport safety program, 3) formal professional public opinion surveys, and 4) a comprehensive public information strategy. The two organizations developed transport safety recommendations, most of which were adopted by USDOE. Early survey results are being analyzed and interpreted.

Source title: Proceedings of the American Power Conference
Affiliations: Energy Storage and Power Consultants, Inc, Mountainside, United States
Authors with affiliations: Nakhamkin, Michael, Energy Storage and Power Consultants, Inc, Mountainside, United States; Andersson, Lars, Energy Storage and Power Consultants, Inc, Mountainside, United States; Swensen, Eric, Energy Storage and Power Consultants, Inc, Mountainside, United States; Howard, John, Energy Storage and Power Consultants, Inc, Mountainside, United States; Meyer, Robert, Energy Storage and Power Consultants, Inc, Mountainside, United States; Schainker, Robert, Energy Storage and Power Consultants, Inc, Mountainside, United States; Pollak, Robert, Energy Storage and Power Consultants, Inc, Mountainside, United States; Mehta, Ben, Energy Storage and Power Consultants, Inc, Mountainside, United States
Abstract: The 110 MW Compressed Air Energy Storage (CAES) plant being built by the Alabama Electric Cooperative, Inc. (AEC) in McIntosh Alabama, is currently in the final construction and plant testing phase and is scheduled for commercial operation by June 1991. The contract to build the plant was signed in August, 1988. Throughout the engineering and construction phases of the project, various problems surfaced due to the plant being the first of its kind in the United States. As a result of these problems, valuable lessons have been learned which can be applied generically to the conceptual design, detailed engineering, schedule and construction of future CAES plants. The objective of this paper is to describe major problems and their solutions and to provide current information regarding the overall status of the ongoing project. After a brief description of the plant and its mode of operation, the paper is divided into sections describing engineering problems, shop testing, and construction status including recent photographs taken in January 1991.

Authors: Minten J., Segel L.D., Van Belle H., Wynants J., Flameng W.
Title: Differences in high-energy phosphate catabolism between the rat and the dog in a heart preservation model
Source title: Journal of Heart and Lung Transplantation
Affiliations: Laboratory of Experimental Cardiac Surgery, Catholic University of Leuven, Minderbroedersstraat 17, B-3000 Leuven, Belgium
Authors with affiliations: Minten, J., Laboratory of Experimental Cardiac Surgery, Catholic University of Leuven, Minderbroedersstraat 17, B-3000 Leuven, Belgium; Segel, L.D., Laboratory of Experimental Cardiac Surgery, Catholic University of Leuven, Minderbroedersstraat 17, B-3000 Leuven, Belgium; Van Belle, H., Laboratory of Experimental Cardiac Surgery, Catholic University of Leuven, Minderbroedersstraat 17, B-3000 Leuven, Belgium; Wynants, J., Laboratory of Experimental Cardiac Surgery, Catholic University of Leuven, Minderbroedersstraat 17, B-3000 Leuven, Belgium; Flameng, W., Laboratory of Experimental Cardiac Surgery, Catholic University of Leuven, Minderbroedersstraat 17, B-3000 Leuven, Belgium
Abstract: Concentrations of ATP and creatine phosphate were measured in rat and dog hearts preserved either by cold storage (procedure A) or by continuous hypothermic perfusion (procedure B). In procedure A (3 dogs, 4 rats) the hearts were normothermically excised without cardioplegia and were stored in 0.9% NaCl at 0.5°C; in procedure B (6 dogs, 21 rats) hypothermic cardioplegic arrest was performed, and then the hearts were retrogradely perfused through the aorta for 24 hours with use of an oxygenated Bretschneider cardioplegic solution at 2° to 4°C. Whole rat hearts were frozen using Wollenberger clamps at desired times during the preservation period; transmural needle biopsy specimens were sampled from dog hearts. In control nonpreserved hearts, the ATP and creatine phosphate were as follows (mean ± SD): 26.7 ± 4.1 and 27.1 ± 10.3 μmol/gm dry weight, respectively (dog hearts), and 23.1 ± 2.1 and 34.2 ± 12.1 μmol/gm dry weight, respectively (rat hearts). With procedure A, ATP decreased by 36% in dog hearts and by 64% in rat hearts during the first hour of storage. By 24 hours, only 6% of the ATP remained in the dog hearts and 1% in the rat hearts. Creatine phosphate decreased by 85% (dog hearts) and by 93% (rat hearts) during the first hour of storage. The ATP and creatine phosphate values observed in rat hearts after 1 hour of procedure A preservation were significantly lower than in dog hearts (p<0.05). With procedure B, cardioplegic arrrest by itself did not alter high-energy phosphate concentrations in dog or rat hearts. After 24 hours of perfusion preservation, no changes in high-energy phosphate levels were observed in the dog hearts. In the rat hearts, however, by the 6-hour point, high-energy phosphate concentrations were significantly lower than control values and significantly lower than in the dog hearts (p<0.05). By 24 hours, the difference between the two species had increased, such that only 40% of the ATP and 20% of the creatine phosphate remained in the rat heart at that point. These data indicate that the preservation of high-energy phosphate levels by continuous hypothermic perfusion of the heart with a Bretschneider cardioplegic solution was superior to that attained by simple storage in cold saline solution. In addition, the effect of this protection varied with the species tested.

Authors: Saitoh Takeo
Title: Reduction of air pollution by changing the pollutant emission from the vehicles
Source title: Proceedings of the Intersociety Energy Conversion Engineering Conference
Affiliations: Tohoku Univ, Sendai, Japan
Authors with affiliations: Saitoh, Takeo, Tohoku Univ, Sendai, Japan
Abstract: The present paper reports the results of the numerical prediction for urban environment by reducing air pollutant flux from the vehicles. One idea to reduce the pollutant flux in the urban area is introduction of the electric vehicle, hydrogen fueled vehicle and other vehicles which emit less pollutant gases including alcohol fueled vehicles. This paper also reports the results of the numerical prediction of the anthropogenic energy consumption on the urban atmosphere. A three-dimensional simulation was carried out by a Supercomputer SX-2 at Tohoku University. The governing equations for continuity, energy, momentum, and species conservation were solved numerically. The effects of the energy consumption rate, pollutant emission flux from the vehicles including NO2, CO2, CO, and NOx on heat island intensity and concentration distributions were clarified in detail. It is shown that the introduction of hybrid vehicles combining electric power and fossil fueled engine gives most significant results to reduce the pollutant concentration in the urban atmosphere. The present results will contribute the preservation of the urban environment as well as the earth's environment.
Index Keywords: Automobile Engines - Exhaust Gases; Environmental Protection; Mathematical Models; Storage Battery Vehicles; Supercomputers; Automobiles

Authors: Sawase Kazuhisa, Kurosaki Yasuo, Isshiki Naotsugu, Shimizu Takashi

Source title: Proceedings of the Intersociety Energy Conversion Engineering Conference
Affiliations: Railway Technical Research Inst, Tokyo, Japan
Authors with affiliations: Sawase, Kazuhisa, Railway Technical Research Inst, Tokyo, Japan; Kurosaki, Yasuo, Railway Technical Research Inst, Tokyo, Japan; Isshiki, Naotsugu, Railway Technical Research Inst, Tokyo, Japan; Shimizu, Takashi, Railway Technical Research Inst, Tokyo, Japan
Abstract: A roof snow melting system has a heat exchanger to extract the thermal energy from the well water pumped up from the aquifer. Heat retrieved from a cooling tower for the air-conditioning of the station building during summer is stored in the aquifer. The field experiments carried out at Nagaoka station of Joetsu Shinkansen (Super-Express Railway) with a water heat source heatpump, a thermal storage tank and a conventional water heater indicated that a heat reclamation in the aquifer thermal energy storage was 40% and that the coefficient of performance of the water heat source heatpump was 7.5. The system utilizing the natural energy for the snow-melting on the roof is quite promising because of its high energy saving performance up to 26%.

Title: Operation of a 500kW/4,000kWh Na/S battery energy storage plant
Source title: Proceedings of the Intersociety Energy Conversion Engineering Conference

Abstract: The Yuasa Battery Company, in collaboration with the NGK Spark Plug Company and under the sponsorship and direction of the New Energy and Industrial Technology Development Organization, is now manufacturing a 1MW/8MWh Na/S battery for a utility load leveling system. So far, a half of the battery has been manufactured and is now under testing, while the remainder of the battery is being manufactured. The half battery rated at 500kW/4,000kWh was found to show an energy efficiency of approximately 87% on the battery basis, 86% on the DC/DC basis including the auxiliary power consumption, and 76% on the AC/AC basis in a charge/discharge cycle at 8HR. Up until now, the battery has been cycled up to approximately 70 cycles in half a year, demonstrating its compatibility with the utility grid. The manufacturing of the full battery rated at 1MW/8MWh will be completed by the summer, 1991, when the battery will be put into a test as a whole system.

Authors: Fischer Wilfried
Title: Status and prospects of NaS energy batteries
Source title: Proceedings of the Intersociety Energy Conversion Engineering Conference
Affiliations: ABB Hochenergiebatterie GmbH, Heidelberg, Germany
Authors with affiliations: Fischer, Wilfried, ABB Hochenergiebatterie GmbH, Heidelberg, Germany
Abstract: The performance characteristiques of NaS batteries such as energy density, power density, safety and cycle life have been continuously improved over the years. Energy and power density are close to target values. Safety is sufficient for EV propulsion on public streets. More than 350 batteries have been produced in a pilot plant and have been subjected to laboratory tests, electric vehicle propulsion tests and off-peak electrical energy storage tests. The tests have resulted in statistical knowledge not only on battery performance, but also on performance of NaS battery containing systems such as EV's. A trend analysis shows that all performance characteristiques including life will be sufficiently high when EV-volume production begins.

Authors: Saman N., Fazzolari R.

Abstract: A procedure for predicting the preconditioning and storage loads resulting from shutting a heating, ventilating, and air-conditioning (HVAC) system down is presented. The DOE-2 building energy analysis program is used for the calculations. After startup, the extra load resulting from shutting down the HVAC system is calculated for a zone with given ambient conditions. General graphs for predicting the design requirements for a specific location are generated.

Abstract: This article describes a comparison and evaluation of the Solar One and CESA-I receiver and thermal storage systems. The evaluation is based on operating data from Solar One, the 10 MWc experimental solar central receiver plant located near Barstow, California, U.S.A., and CESA-I, the 1.2 MWc experimental solar central receiver plant located near Almeria, Spain. This study was sponsored by the U.S.-Spain Joint Committee for Scientific and Technological Cooperation. Significant differences exist in the design and operation of the receiver and thermal storage systems for the two experimental plants. An evaluation of their performance has increased our understanding of the plant design variables and provides useful information to improve the designs of future central receiver plants. © 1991.

Authors: Baixeras C., Domingo C., Fernandez F.
Title: Ultra heavy ion studies with plastic nuclear track detectors. Application to cosmic rays
Affiliations: Univ Autonoma de Barcelona, Barcelona, Spain
Authors with affiliations: Baixeras, C., Univ Autonoma de Barcelona, Barcelona, Spain; Domingo, C., Univ Autonoma de Barcelona, Barcelona, Spain; Fernandez, F., Univ Autonoma de Barcelona, Barcelona, Spain
Abstract: In order to investigate plastic track detectors similar to those used in the UHCRE, our group has participated in several accelerator experiments in the past few years. The goal of these experiments was to determine the detector response to ultra heavy ions and to study the parameters which could affect this response. We have found that a corrected Bethe-Bloch formula should be used to obtain the ultra heavy ion energy losses and ranges in plastic detectors. The intrinsic charge uncertainty for polycarbonate associated to the experimental method used is σZ = (1.05 ± 0.16) charge units for Z > 60 ions. By reproducing the UHCRE exposure and storage conditions a charge uncertainty of σZ = (1.70 ± 0.19) charge units is obtained. This charge uncertainty still allows the separation of the Lead and Platinum charge groups of cosmic radiation.

Authors: Akiyama T., Ashizawa Y., Yagi J.-I.
Title: Storage and Release of Heat in a Single Spherical Capsule Containing Phase Change Material of High Melting Point
Source title: Transactions of the Japan Society of Mechanical Engineers Series B
Authors with affiliations: Akiyama, T.; Ashizawa, Y.; Yagi, J.-I.
Abstract: A latent heat thermal storage system using a packed bed is one of the most attractive recovery methods of periodically generated waste heat in industrial processes. The thermal performance of the system depends largely on that of a single spherical capsule containing phase change material (PCM). In this study, PCMs were investigated as materials to recover and store heat for the temperature range between 500 and 1100K. Some inorganic salts and metals were selected from the point of view of higher latent heat, chemical stability, nontoxicity, inexpensiveness. Heat storage and release experiments of single capsules under the condition of predominant convective heat transfer were carried out. The results were favorably simulated by a mathematical model derived from enthalpy balance. For obtaining constant-temperature gas. metallic PCMs were more advantageous than inorganic salts because of higher thermal conductivity. © 1991, The Japan Society of Mechanical Engineers. All rights reserved.

Authors: Franssila-Kallunki A., Rissanen A., Ekstrand A., Eriksson J., Saloranta C., Widén E., Schalin-Jäntti C., Groop L.
Title: Fuel metabolism in anorexia nervosa and simple obesity
Affiliations: Fourth Department of Medicine, Helsinki University Hospital, Helsinki, Finland
Authors with affiliations: Franssila-Kallunki, A., Fourth Department of Medicine, Helsinki University Hospital, Helsinki, Finland; Rissanen, A., Fourth Department of Medicine, Helsinki University Hospital, Helsinki, Finland; Ekstrand, A., Fourth Department of Medicine, Helsinki University Hospital, Helsinki, Finland; Eriksson, J., Fourth Department of Medicine, Helsinki University Hospital, Helsinki, Finland; Saloranta, C., Fourth Department of Medicine, Helsinki University Hospital, Helsinki, Finland; Widén, E., Fourth Department of Medicine, Helsinki University Hospital, Helsinki, Finland; Schalin-Jäntti, C., Fourth Department of Medicine, Helsinki University Hospital, Helsinki, Finland; Groop, L., Fourth Department of Medicine, Helsinki University Hospital, Helsinki, Finland
Abstract: To examine insulin sensitivity and the relative contribution of different fuels to energy metabolism in anorexia nervosa and obesity, we measured oxidation (indirect calorimetry) of glucose, lipids, and proteins in the basal state and during an insulin clamp (+45 mU/m2 · min) in 11 women with anorexia nervosa (age, 25 ± 3 years; body mass index [BMI], 13.6 ± 0.4 kg/m2; fat mass, 15.7% ± 1.6%), eight obese women (age, 31 ± 3; BMI 36.0 ± 1.5; fat mass, 47.1% ± 1.9%), and eight controls (age, 26 ± 3; BMI, 21.8 ± 0.9; fat mass, 25.7% ± 3.6%). Expressed per lean body mass, (LBM), glucose disposal was equally reduced in anorectics (7.53 ± 0.62 mg/kg LBM · min) and obese (6.80 ± 1.07 mg/kg LBM · min) compared with controls (10.64 ± 0.69 mg/kg LBM · min; P < .01). The reduction in glucose disposal in anorectics was primarily due to a significant (P < .01) reduction in glucose storage, while glucose oxidation was normal. In obese women, both storage and oxidation of glucose were reduced compared with controls (P < .01). Basal energy expenditure was similar in anorectic, obese, and control subjects (20.6 ± 1.00, 23.7 ± 0.56, 23.2 ± 1.36 cal/kg LBM · min, respectively). However, the contribution of glucose, lipids, and proteins to basal energy expenditure differed between anorectic (62%, 16%, 22%), obese (26%, 58%, 16%), and control (30%, 54%, 16%) subjects (P < .05 v all). In conclusion, in anorexia nervosa, insulin stimulates glucose oxidation more than storage. In obesity, both components of insulin-stimulated glucose metabolism are impaired. Anorexia nervosa can thus be considered as an insulin-resistant state in terms of the effect of insulin on glucose storage. © 1991.
Index Keywords: insulin; neutral insulin; adult; anorexia nervosa; article; clinical article; controlled study; energy metabolism; female; human; insulin resistance; obesity; priority journal; Adult; Anorexia Nervosa; Energy Metabolism; Female; Glucose; Human; Insulin; Liver; Obesity; Oxidation-Reduction; Support, Non-U.S. Gov't

Authors: Vitousek P.M.
Title: Can planted forests counteract increasing atmospheric carbon dioxide?
Affiliations: Dep. of Biology, Stanford Univ., Stanford, CA 94305, United States
Authors with affiliations: Vitousek, P.M., Dep. of Biology, Stanford Univ., Stanford, CA 94305, United States
Abstract: Establishing new forests has been widely suggested as a means to prevent, reduce, or delay fossil fuel-driven increases in CO2 concentrations in the atmosphere. This analysis examines the potential magnitude of C storage in biomass, emphasizing the amount of land area that could be planted to trees, the rates of C storage in developing forest plantations, and the fate of material harvested from forests. I conclude that while converting old-growth forests to plantations is a losing proposition, there may be sufficient formerly forested land and the possibility of sufficiently high rates of C storage in young tree plantations that reforestation could remove substantial quantities of C from the atmosphere (≥~1 Pg yr-1). However, rapid net C storage is a short-lived phenomenon, and it is unlikely that a substantial fraction of material harvested from plantations can go into long-term storage on land. Therefore, new tree plantations designed to store C can at best cause a brief delay in the accumulation of CO2 in the atmosphere. Forest plantations designed to produce energy from biomass would represent a longer-term contribution to reducing rates of CO2 accumulation - as long as they replaced fossil fuel-derived energy.
Index Keywords: carbon dioxide; fossil fuel; methane; nitrogen oxide; air quality control; climate; forest; nonhuman; review; tree

Authors: Hasan M., Mujumdar A.S., Weber M.E.
Title: Cyclic melting and freezing
Affiliations: Department of Chemical Engineering, McGill University, 3480 University Street, Montreal, H3A 2A7, Canada
Authors with affiliations: Hasan, M., Department of Chemical Engineering, McGill University, 3480 University Street, Montreal, H3A 2A7, Canada; Mujumdar, A.S., Department of Chemical Engineering, McGill University, 3480 University Street, Montreal, H3A 2A7, Canada; Weber, M.E., Department of Chemical Engineering, McGill University, 3480 University Street, Montreal, H3A 2A7, Canada
Abstract: This paper reports the results of a numerical and experimental investigation of one-dimensional conduction-controlled cyclic melting and freezing. The phase change material (PCM) was a plane slab, one surface of which was subjected to alternating periods of constant temperature above and below the fusion temperature while the other surface was insulated. Due to the cyclic change of temperature, multiple solid and liquid regions develop within the material. A front-tracking, self-starting finite-difference scheme was used to solve the resulting multiple moving boundary problem. Numerical computations were carried out from a uniform initial condition until a periodic steady state was attained. In this periodic steady state all temperatures and solid/liquid interface movements were identical from one cycle to the next. Experiments were performed on n-octadecane in a thin horizontal cell with heat transfer from above. The numerical results were in good agreement with these conduction-controlled experiments. © 1991.
Index Keywords: Energy Storage; Heat Transfer--Conduction; Heating--Heat Storage; Mathematical Techniques--Numerical Methods; Solar Energy--Storage; Cyclic Freezing; Cyclic Melting; Octadecane; Phase Change Material; Heat Transfer

Authors: Nudd Greg, Koughan Jim, Cranor Matt
Title: Design and performance of the 'Texas Native Sun'
Affiliations: Univ of Texas at Austin, Austin, United States
Authors with affiliations: Nudd, Greg, Univ of Texas at Austin, Austin, United States; Koughan, Jim, Univ of Texas at Austin, Austin, United States; Cranor, Matt, Univ of Texas at Austin, Austin, United States
Abstract: A team of student engineers at the University of Texas at Austin designed, built and raced the solar powered vehicle, 'Texas Native Sun', in GM Sunrayce U.S.A. The single-seat vehicle uses conventional photovoltaic solar cells to produce electricity for propulsion. The vehicle features graphite/epoxy composite monocoque construction, a high power-density permanent magnet electric motor, a continuously variable transmission, nickel-hydrogen satellite batteries, and a composite leaf spring suspension. The race revealed several problems with the team's design and strategy, providing an opportunity for them to see how practice differs from theory. Much of the technology employed in the vehicle may one day become an ordinary part of future transportation systems which seek greater energy efficiency and less damage to the environment.
Index Keywords: Photovoltaic Cells; Solar Cells; Solar Energy--Applications; Storage Battery Vehicles; Solar powered vehicles; Automobiles

Authors: Ito Sadasuke, Miura Naokatsu
Title: Heat transfer enhancement by fins in latent heat thermal energy storage devices
Affiliations: Kanagawa Inst of Technology, Kanagawa, Japan
Authors with affiliations: Ito, Sadasuke, Kanagawa Inst of Technology, Kanagawa, Japan; Miura, Naokatsu, Kanagawa Inst of Technology, Kanagawa, Japan
Abstract: An approximate numerical solution is proposed to the freezing process of a phase change material on a finned flat wall of a rectangular latent heat thermal energy storage device. The flat wall has thin fins fixed on it in parallel with each other. The tips of the fins are not in contact with a wall. The numerical analysis was made under the assumption of quasi-steady state. Experiments were also performed in which the ratio of the pitch to the hight of the fins was 0.2 or 0.4. A paraffin, 99% pure n-octadecane, with a freezing temperature of 28.0°C was cooled from the end wall and the photographs of the shapes of the freezing front on the wall and fins were taken from the side wall of the energy storage device. The temperature distribution on a fin was also measured. The experimental results agreed well with those obtained by the analysis. Finally, the effect of the pitch and conduction through the fins on the speed of solidification is studied.
Index Keywords: Heat Transfer--Fins; Heat transfer enhancement; Latent heat; Thermal energy storage; Thin fins; Heat Storage

Authors: Tracey Tom
Title: Improvements in the cost effectiveness and reliability of central receiver solar power systems
Authors with affiliations: Tracey, Tom
Abstract: The basic objective of this paper is to suggest specific design changes that will improve the cost effectiveness and reliability of solar central receiver power plants. The improvements are considered technically feasible now. Department of Energy studies estimated the cost of electricity at 8.5 cents/kWeh for 200-MWe solar systems using advanced stretched membrane heliostats and 9.5 cents/kWeh using the well proven glass/metal heliostats. The design changes suggested here could reduce the cost by at least 25 percent, which would make these central receiver systems competitive. System improvements suggested include the following: (1) the use of statistical analysis to determine the plant output; (2) major reductions in system parasitics and salt pressure levels; (3) elimination of system-related hardware including most electrical trace heating, many pipe expansion joints, and salt attemperation in the steam generator evaporator; and (4) reduction of losses due to receiver start-up transients. Receiver subsystem improvements include the following: (1) optimization of fluid/hydraulics to reduce the pressure drop; (2) use of variable speed pumps instead of control valves; (3) elimination of the purge valves; and (4) integrating the receiver/tower structure. Storage subsystem improvements include: (1) elimination of air treatment for the tanks; (2) deletion of the salt heater and tank preheater; and (3) use of low-cost nitrate salts from Chile.
Index Keywords: Salts; Solar Radiation; Central receivers; Nitrate salts; Solar receivers; Solar Power Plants

Authors: Umeda M.
Title: Stability design for conductor motions of the high current density magnet
Source title: Denshi Gijutsu Sogo Kenkyusho Iho/Bulletin of the Electrotechnical Laboratory
Authors with affiliations: Umeda, M.
Abstract: Disturbance energies due to frictional motions of conductors on a pancake coil type superconducting magnet have been detected. On the other hand, the stability margins of a magnet using Nb3Sn superconductors have been designed to overcome these disturbances at the design point of 2KA and 10T. The magnet has been operated successfully until the design point without quenching. The magnet current density obtained was 74A/mm2, and the stored energy was 16MJ including that of the back-up magnet.

Authors: Sagara K., Nakahara N.
Title: Thermal performance and pressure drop of rock beds with large storage materials
Affiliations: Department of Architecture, Mie University, Kamihama-cho, Tsu, 514, Japan; Department of Architecture, Nagoya University, Furo-cho, Chikusa-ku, Nagoya, 464, Japan
Authors with affiliations: Sagara, K., Department of Architecture, Mie University, Kamihama-cho, Tsu, 514, Japan; Nakahara, N., Department of Architecture, Nagoya University, Furo-cho, Chikusa-ku, Nagoya, 464, Japan
Abstract: In air-based solar heating systems, the fan power needed to overcome friction loss in rock beds can reduce the benefit of the system. The system performance of rock beds with large-sized storage materials that have comparably low friction loss is studied. A theoretical model of the heat transfer process within the rock bed is developed for large storage materials. In this model, the temperature within the materials is assumed to be distributed quadratically and symmetrically at their center. The relationship between the model parameter and the air flow rate was derived from experimental measurements for some large materials as well as the pressure drop through the bed. The energy performance of heat pump solar systems with rock beds of various storage materials are studied by the computer simulation under Japanese winter weather conditions. It is concluded that the possibility exists for some large-sized storage materials to have almost the same performance as small-sized materials for heat pump solar systems. © 1991.
Index Keywords: Computer Simulation--Applications; Heat Pump Systems--Performance; Heat Transfer; Air Flow Rate; Japanese Winter Weather Conditions; Model Parameters; Rock Beds; Thermal Performance; Heating

Authors: Pathare V.M., Klemptner L.J., Parish M.V., Park H.D., Chandler D.B., Neal M.J., Halloran J.W., Hodge J.D., Bakis G.
Title: Fabrication of high Jc YBa2Cu3O7-δ wires by a ceramic fiber process
Affiliations: CPS Superconductor Corp, Milford, United States
Authors with affiliations: Pathare, V.M., CPS Superconductor Corp, Milford, United States; Klemptner, L.J., CPS Superconductor Corp, Milford, United States; Parish, M.V., CPS Superconductor Corp, Milford, United States; Park, H.D., CPS Superconductor Corp, Milford, United States; Chandler, D.B., CPS Superconductor Corp, Milford, United States; Neal, M.J., CPS Superconductor Corp, Milford, United States; Halloran, J.W., CPS Superconductor Corp, Milford, United States; Hodge, J.D., CPS Superconductor Corp, Milford, United States; Bakis, G., CPS Superconductor Corp, Milford, United States
Abstract: Recent progress in the field of High Temperature Superconductors (HTSC) brings the hope for commercial utilization of these materials closer to reality. One of the main goals of any bulk superconductor program is the development of HTSC wire suitable for use in magnets, motors, generators, energy storage systems and transmission lines at 77K. The ceramic fiber process developed at CPS Superconductor represents an important step towards the realization of that goal. This process has been demonstrated to be continuous and robust and would therefore be suitable for use in an industrial environment. This paper describes each step of the process currently used to continuously manufacture sintered polycrystalline YBa2Cu3O7-δ wire. Additionally a description of the melt-texturing process being developed to continuously produce high current carrying (high Jc) HTSC wire is given. Transport electrical properties of various wire samples are presented.

Abstract: A portable data acquisition system, using a laptop computer, was developed to monitor performance of soil-engaging implements during field operation. Authors: Ulrich Nathan, Kumar Vijay
Title: Passive mechanical gravity compensation for robot manipulators
Source title: Proceedings - IEEE International Conference on Robotics and Automation
Affiliations: Dept of Appl Ocean Phys & Eng,, Woods Hole Oceanographic Inst, Woods, Hole, MA, USA
Authors with affiliations: Ulrich, Nathan, Dept of Appl Ocean Phys & Eng,, Woods Hole Oceanographic Inst, Woods, Hole, MA, USA; Kumar, Vijay, Dept of Appl Ocean Phys & Eng,, Woods Hole Oceanographic Inst, Woods, Hole, MA, USA
Abstract: A simple mechanical method for passively compensating for gravitationally induced joint torques is presented. This energy-conservative gravity-compensation method is suitable for a variety of manipulator designs. With cables and appropriate pulley profiles, changes in potential energy associated with link motion through a gravity field can be mapped to changes in strain energy storage in spring elements. The resulting system requires significant energy input only for acceleration and deceleration or to resist external forces. A testbed with both single- and double-link configurations has demonstrated the efficiency and accuracy of this gravity compensation method, as well as its robustness under dynamic loading conditions.
