Authors: Landis Geoffrey A.
Title: Space power by ground-based laser illumination
Source title: Proceedings of the Intersociety Energy Conversion Engineering Conference
Affiliations: Sverdrup Technology, Inc, Cleveland, United States
Authors with affiliations: Landis, Geoffrey A., Sverdrup Technology, Inc, Cleveland, United States
Abstract: Energy storage comprises a significant portion of the mass of space power systems. Requirements for storage can be reduced if the photovoltaic arrays can be illuminated by a remotely located laser system. It is proposed to locate large lasers on cloud-free sites at one or more ground locations, and use large lenses or mirrors with adaptive optical correction to reduce the beam spread due to diffraction or atmospheric turbulance. During the eclipse periods or lunar night, the lasers illuminate the solar arrays to a level sufficient to provide operating power. Two applications are discussed: illumination of geosynchronous orbit satellites and illumination of a moonbase power system.
Index Keywords: Energy Storage; Laser Beams--Applications; Photovoltaic Cells; Satellites--Geostationary; Moonbase Power Systems; Satellites

Authors: Kelly John H., Shoup III Milton J., Skeldon Mark D., Bui Snow T.
Title: Design and energy characteristics of a multisegment glass-disk amplifier
Source title: Proceedings of SPIE - The International Society for Optical Engineering
Affiliations: Univ. of Rochester, Rochester, NY,, USA
Authors with affiliations: Kelly, John H., Univ. of Rochester, Rochester, NY,, USA; Shoup III, Milton J., Univ. of Rochester, Rochester, NY,, USA; Skeldon, Mark D., Univ. of Rochester, Rochester, NY,, USA; Bui, Snow T., Univ. of Rochester, Rochester, NY,, USA
Abstract: Multi-segment disk amplifiers (MSA) are of particular interest in fusion laser systems because of the improved efficiency and compactness they offer compared with conventional disk amplifiers. A multisegment amplifier consists of two or more conventional disk amplifiers which share one or more common flash-lamp arrays. Each 'segment' amplifies one 'beamlet.' A 2 x 2 MSA can therefore amplify four beamlets. The shared flash-lamp arrays, lacking large reflectors, pump the disks more efficiently because of reduced lamp self-absorption. Furthermore, the reduction of reflector surface area per unit disk area reduces absorptive losses of pump light. The authors have constructed a 2 x 2 MSA with individual beamlet apertures of 24 cm. Each aperture contains five phosphate glass disks. This device is designed to be angularly double-passed by a 20-cm beam. Design details and rationale are presented. The energy transport performance of the amplifier was measured in both small- and large-signal regimes. A nominal small-signal gain of 11.8 was measured. The storage efficiency exceeded 3.5% at the nominal operating point. The amplifier was deployed as a booster for one beamline of the OMEGA laser system at the University of Rochester. In that configuration, 950 J of focusable energy was obtained from a single segment in a 800-ps pulse at 130-J drive. Details of these measurements are presented.
Index Keywords: Glass; Plasmas--Confinement; Multisegment Disc Amplifiers; OMEGA Laser; Lasers, Solid state

Authors: Moroto M., Hiro N., Akashi K., Nasako K., Yonesaki T., Osumi M.
Title: Development of a refrigeration system using hydrogen absorbing alloys
Affiliations: Control and Systems Research Cent, Osaka, Japan
Authors with affiliations: Moroto, M., Control and Systems Research Cent, Osaka, Japan; Hiro, N., Control and Systems Research Cent, Osaka, Japan; Akashi, K., Control and Systems Research Cent, Osaka, Japan; Nasako, K., Control and Systems Research Cent, Osaka, Japan; Yonesaki, T., Control and Systems Research Cent, Osaka, Japan; Osumi, M., Control and Systems Research Cent, Osaka, Japan
Abstract: Using hydrogen absorbing alloys, various heat utilization systems such as heat transportation systems and heat storage systems were developed for the effective use of heat at our research center. Utilizing these technologies, a prototype refrigeration system using hydrogen absorbing alloys was developed which is able to obtain temperatures below 10°C with a refrigerator driven by thermal energy. This prototype refrigeration system is able to obtain a heat medium temperature of -15°C and maintains -10°C conditions in the icebox (200ℓ) by using a heat source(150°C) and cooling water(20°C). The performance of this prototype refrigeration system could be achieved 1) by the development of a new heat exchanger that quickly and efficiently conducts the alloy reaction heat through heat transfer fins made of aluminium plates (fin pich: 1mm), 2) by adaptation of vacuum insulation technology for a hydrogen absorbing alloy vessel that radically reduces heat loss, and 3) by the development of a high-efficiency operation control method.
Index Keywords: Heat Exchangers; Heat Transfer; Hydrogen; Metals and Alloys; Hydrogen absorbing alloys; Refrigeration

Authors: De Steese John G., Kreid Dennis K., Haner John M., Myers Walter E.
Title: Assessment of SMES benefits in electric utility applications
Source title: Proceedings of the American Power Conference
Affiliations: Pacific Northwest Lab, Richland, United States
Authors with affiliations: De Steese, John G., Pacific Northwest Lab, Richland, United States; Kreid, Dennis K., Pacific Northwest Lab, Richland, United States; Haner, John M., Pacific Northwest Lab, Richland, United States; Myers, Walter E., Pacific Northwest Lab, Richland, United States
Abstract: A scoping study was performed by Pacific Northwest Laboratory, in collaboration with Bonneville Power Administration (BPA), to evaluate the multiple benefits electric utilities might realize from superconducting magnetic energy storage (SMES). Benefits and costs were compared on a levelized annual basis to indicate the general viability of system-specific SMES applications. A principal purpose was to provide information that could help increase utility interest in SMES and, thereby, assist the rapid development and deployment of the technology. This paper reviews eight SMES application scenarios and their estimated benefit/cost ratios under the operational conditions of specific utility systems. Most of the SMES scenarios show levelized benefit/cost ratios greater than unity. However, the value of a single benefit was seldom found to exceed the unit's levelized cost. This suggests, as a general principle, that the total value of multiple benefits should be considered to fully establish the cost effectiveness of SMES in many utility applications. These results should encourage utilities to conduct more detailed analyses of SMES benefits to identify the applications cost beneficial to individual systems.
Index Keywords: Electric Power Systems - Energy Storage; Cost Benefit Study; Superconducting Magnetic Energy Storage; Energy Storage

Authors: Ammar A.S.A., Ghoneim A.A.
Title: Optimization of a sensible heat storage unit packed with spheres of a local material
Affiliations: Department of Engineering, Mathematics and Physics, Faculty of Engineering, University of Alexandria, Alexandria, Egypt
Authors with affiliations: Ammar, A.S.A., Department of Engineering, Mathematics and Physics, Faculty of Engineering, University of Alexandria, Alexandria, Egypt; Ghoneim, A.A., Department of Engineering, Mathematics and Physics, Faculty of Engineering, University of Alexandria, Alexandria, Egypt
Abstract: A sensible heat storage unit in the form of a bed, randomly packed with spheres manufactured from a local material (an Egyptian clay), is the subject of the present work. The bed is subjected to explicit and implicit constraints. Explicit constraints are imposed on the bed length, the sphere diameter, and the mass flow rate while implicit constraint is imposed on the pressure drop across the bed. Optimization of the bed parameters, to enable getting maximum ratio of the storing to pumping energy, is achieved by the aid of a computer program which is developed based on the direct search method. The optimum bed parameters are found. to be: 2.1 m for bed length, 0.019 m for particle diameter, and 900 kg/h for mass flow rate. © 1991.

Authors: Karpiscak M.M., Brittain R.G., Gerba C.P., Foster K.E.
Title: Demonstrating residential water conservation and reuse in the Sonoran desert: Casa del Agua and Desert House
Affiliations: Office of Arid Lands Studies, University of Arizona, Tucson, AZ 85719, United States

Abstract: Single-family homes are being used to demonstrate and research water conserving and reuse techniques and technologies. These facilities can provide real-world data as well as public information and educational programs. The installation of water-conserving fixtures, rainwater harvesting, and graywater reuse systems and storage can reduce the requirements for potable water by 50 percent. Authors: Smithrick John J., Hall Stephen W.
Title: Effect of KOH concentration on leo cycle life of IPV nickel-hydrogen flight cells-an update
Source title: Proceedings of the Intersociety Energy Conversion Engineering Conference
Affiliations: Natl Aeronautics and Space, Administration, Cleveland, United States
Authors with affiliations: Smithrick, John J., Natl Aeronautics and Space, Administration, Cleveland, United States; Hall, Stephen W., Natl Aeronautics and Space, Administration, Cleveland, United States
Abstract: An update of validation test results confirming the breakthrough in LEO cycle life of nickel-hydrogen cells containing 26 percent KOH electrolyte is presented. A breakthrough in the low-earth-orbit (LEO) cycle life of individual pressure vessel (IPV) nickel-hydrogen cells was reported. The cycle life of boiler plate cells containing 26 percent potassium hydroxide (KOH) electrolyte was about 40 000 LEO cycles compared to 3500 cycles for cells containing 31 percent KOH. This test was conducted at Hughes under a NASA Lewis contract. The purpose for the contract was to investigate effect of KOH concentration on cycle life. The cycle regime was a stressful accelerated LEO, which consisted of a 27.5 min charge followed by a 17.5 min discharge (2x normal rate). The depth of discharge (DOD) was 80 percent. The cell temperature was maintained at 23°C. The boiler plate test results are in the proces of being validated using flight hardware and real time LEO test at the Naval Weapons Support Center (NWSC), Crane, Indiana under a NASA Lewis Contract. Six 48 Ah Hughes recirculation design IPV nickel-hydrogen flight battery cells are being evaluated. Three of the cells contain 26 percent KOH (test cells), and three contain 31 percent KOH (control cells). They are undergoing real time LEO cycle life testing. The cycle regime is a 90-min LEO orbit consisting of a 54-min charge followed by a 36-min discharge. The depth-of-discharge is 80 percent. The cell temperature is maintained at 10°C. The 26 percent KOH cells have been cycled for over 14 000 cycles with no cell failure in the continuing test. However, all three 31 percent KOH cells failed (cycles 3 729, 4 165 and 11 355).
Index Keywords: Energy Storage; Nickel Compounds - Applications; Potassium Compounds - Applications; Cell Description; Hughes Flight Cells; Low-Earth-Orbit Cycle Life; Nickel Hydrogen Battery Storage Test; Nickel Hydrogen Flight Cells; Storage Test; Electric Batteries

Authors: Fathalah K., Aly S.E.
Title: Theoretical study of a solar powered absorption/MED combined system
Source title: Institution of Chemical Engineers Symposium Series
Affiliations: King Abdulaziz Univ, Jeddah, Saudi Arabia
Authors with affiliations: Fathalah, K., King Abdulaziz Univ, Jeddah, Saudi Arabia; Aly, S.E., King Abdulaziz Univ, Jeddah, Saudi Arabia
Abstract: A theoretical study is presented for a solar powered combined system comprising a LiBr-H2O absorption cooling machine and a multi effect distillator (MED). The MED has 8 VTE of the falling film type and it replaces the condenser in conventional absorption machines. The MED is powered by the waste heat of the absorption machine which improves the overall gain and the thermodynamic characteristics significantly. Governing equations for the combined system are given and are numerically solved. Medium parabolic concentrators are used to power the system and a transient simulation for the combined arrangement is presented. Results are given for a typical design summer day in Jeddah Saudi Arabia for a range of firing temperature 150-190°C with a storage temperature amplitude of 10-20°C over a daily working period of 12 hours.
Index Keywords: Desalination; Solar Energy - Applications; Solar Radiation - Concentrators; Abstract Form Only; Multi-Effect Distillation (MED); Parabolic Concentrators; Solar Powered Absorption/MED Combined System; Water Treatment

Authors: Looper Robert
Title: Development of the collett reservoir addition to the Muck Valley Hydroelectric Project
Source title: Waterpower '91: A New View of Hydro Resources
Affiliations: Malacha Hydro Ltd Partnership, Redding, United States
Authors with affiliations: Looper, Robert, Malacha Hydro Ltd Partnership, Redding, United States
Abstract: The existing 26 MW Muck Valley Hydroelectric Project is located on the Pit River, 90 miles east of Redding in Northastern California. The Project was licensed by the Federal Energy Regulatory Commission (FERC) as Project No. 8296 in December 1986 and was placed in service in December 1988. In January 1989, a FERC license Amendment to the Project was filed for the Collett Addition, a 7800 acre-ft off-stream storage reservoir to enhance summer peak generation. The FERC Amendment was issued on June 7, 1990 and the Project was placed in service in December 21, 1990. This paper presents a discussion in the use of off-stream storage to enhance run-of-river hydroelectric facilities. The Collett Reservoir Addition is utilized as a case example.
Index Keywords: Reservoirs; Collett Reservoir; Muck Valley Hydro Project; Pit River; Hydroelectric Power Plants

Authors: Mote R., Probert S.D., Nevrala D.
Title: Free-convective flows within a hot-water store, induced by a submerged, relatively cold heat exchanger
Affiliations: Department of Applied Energy, Cranfield Institute of Technology, Bedford, MK43 0AL, United Kingdom; Watson House, British Gas plc, Peterborough Road, Fulham, London, SW6 3HN, United Kingdom
Authors with affiliations: Mote, R., Department of Applied Energy, Cranfield Institute of Technology, Bedford, MK43 0AL, United Kingdom; Probert, S.D., Department of Applied Energy, Cranfield Institute of Technology, Bedford, MK43 0AL, United Kingdom; Nevrala, D., Watson House, British Gas plc, Peterborough Road, Fulham, London, SW6 3HN, United Kingdom
Abstract: A coiled finned-pipe heat exchanger was employed to extract heat rapidly, at temperatures in excess of 30° C, from a 90-litre hot-water charged tank; the water being initially at a temperature of approximately 80° C. Free-convective buoyancy movements of the water around the outside of this coiled pipe (immersed in the store) occur as a result of initially-cold water (at ∼ 20° C) being forced internally through the heat exchanger's pipe. For the most rapid rate of heat extraction, the axis of the heat exchanger coil should be oriented horizontally, and the heat exchanger's inlet arranged to be at the lowest level. Increasing the rate of water being passed through the heat exchanger's pipe resulted in a reduction of the heat exchanger's quality effectiveness, but a rise in the thermal store's recuperation effectiveness. The latter was due to the reduced level of mixing between the ascending warm streams and the descending colder streams. The development of the thermal boundary layer adjacent to the tank's wall was beneficial in deflecting the centrally descending stream of relatively colder water (which comes off the heat exchanger's pipe) to drive the ascending warmer water onto the heat exchanger, which is located near the surface of the water in the tank. © 1991.
Index Keywords: Energy Storage; Flow of Fluids; Heat Exchangers - Heat Transfer; Heat Transfer - Mathematical Models; Hot Water Supply Systems - Heat Exchangers; Free Convection; Hot Water Store; Submerged Heat Exchangers; Heating

Authors: Barnea G., Navon E., Ginzburg A., Politch J.
Title: Use of storage phosphor imaging plates in portal imaging and high-energy radiography: The intensifying effect of metallic screens on the sensitivity
Affiliations: Rafael, P.O.B. 2250, Haifa, Israel; Department of Radiology and Optical Sciences Center, University of Arizona, Tucson, Arizona 85721, United States; Center for Radiation Research, National Institute of Standards and Technology, Gaithersburg, Maryland 20899, United States
Authors with affiliations: Barnea, G., Rafael, P.O.B. 2250, Haifa, Israel, Department of Radiology and Optical Sciences Center, University of Arizona, Tucson, Arizona 85721, United States, Center for Radiation Research, National Institute of Standards and Technology, Gaithersburg, Maryland 20899, United States; Navon, E., Rafael, P.O.B. 2250, Haifa, Israel, Center for Radiation Research, National Institute of Standards and Technology, Gaithersburg, Maryland 20899, United States; Ginzburg, A., Rafael, P.O.B. 2250, Haifa, Israel; Politch, J., Rafael, P.O.B. 2250, Haifa, Israel
Abstract: The sensitivity of storage phosphor imaging plates (SPIP) at megavolt photon energies (60Co, 6-, 10-, and 18-MV radiotherapy beams) is studied both experimentally and by Monte Carlo radiation transport calculations. In addition, the same techniques are used to investigate the intensifying effect of metal screens on the sensitivity of the SPIP. The results provide evidence that the sensitivity of the SPIPs is proportional to the absorbed energy in the phosphor layer per cGy. The spectral sensitivity is calculated for photon energies between 10 keV and 20 MeV for various SPIP-screen combinations. © 1991, American Association of Physicists in Medicine. All rights reserved.
Author Keywords: absorbed dose; energies; megavolt photon; metal screens; Monte Carlo; sensitivity; storage phosphor imaging plates
Index Keywords: article; controlled study; digital radiography; instrumentation; megavoltage radiotherapy; priority journal; radiation response; treatment planning; Aluminum; Copper; Human; Lead; Luminescence; Tantalum; X-Ray Intensifying Screens

Authors: Nelms R.M., Schatz J.E., Pollard Barry
Title: Comparison of converter topologies for charging capacitors used in pulsed load applications
Source title: Proceedings of the Intersociety Energy Conversion Engineering Conference
Affiliations: Auburn Univ, United States
Authors with affiliations: Nelms, R.M., Auburn Univ, United States; Schatz, J.E., Auburn Univ, United States; Pollard, Barry, Auburn Univ, United States
Abstract: Flashlamps, pulsed lasers, and other pulsed loads require short but intense bursts of energy which may be derived by rapidly discharging a capacitor. This capacitor is then rechraged to a target voltage using a capacitor charging power supply. The operating characteristics of a power supply utilized in capacitor charging applications is discussed. A qualitative comparison of different converter topologies which may be used in this application is presented.
Index Keywords: Capacitors--Energy Storage; Electronic Circuits, Power Supply; Laser Pulses; Capacitor Charging; Electric Converters, Power Type

Authors: Amir E.J., Grandegger K., Esper A., Sumarsono M., Djaya C., Mühlbauer W.
Title: Development of a multi-purpose solar tunnel dryer for use in humid tropics
Affiliations: Research Institute for Estate Corps, Bogor, Indonesia; Institute for Agricultural Engineering, Hohenheim University, Garbenstraße 9, 7000 Stuttgart 70, Germany; Agency for the Development and Application of Technology, Jakarta, Indonesia
Authors with affiliations: Amir, E.J., Research Institute for Estate Corps, Bogor, Indonesia; Grandegger, K., Institute for Agricultural Engineering, Hohenheim University, Garbenstraße 9, 7000 Stuttgart 70, Germany; Esper, A., Institute for Agricultural Engineering, Hohenheim University, Garbenstraße 9, 7000 Stuttgart 70, Germany; Sumarsono, M., Agency for the Development and Application of Technology, Jakarta, Indonesia; Djaya, C., Research Institute for Estate Corps, Bogor, Indonesia; Mühlbauer, W., Institute for Agricultural Engineering, Hohenheim University, Garbenstraße 9, 7000 Stuttgart 70, Germany
Abstract: Particularly in tropical countries, a high percentage of crops are spoiled during the drying period due to permanently high relative humidity and sudden rainfalls. Open air sun drying and smoke drying, which are traditional drying methods in these regions, lead to insufficient product quality. In order to be marketable, the produce meant for sale on the world market has to meet high quality standards. Otherwise the price will decline resulting in low profits for the exporting country and the producing farmer. To produce high quality products for the world market as well as to reduce losses, the development of suitable dryers for tropical regions is urgently needed. A multi-purpose solar tunnel dryer, orginally developed for the use in arid zones, was modified to enable operation under tropical weather conditions. This type of dryer consists of a small centrifugal blower, a collector and a tunnel drying chamber. To prevent penetration of water into the construction and subsequent flooding, the solar dryer was installed on a wooden substructure. To heat the drying air during cloudy and rainy days, particularly in the rainy season, a biomass furnace with heat exchanger was integrated into the solar drying system. The construction consists exclusively of materials available in Java. Only low energy requirements are necessary to run the blower. Results showed that compared to natural sun drying, the drying time of cocoa, coffee and coconut could be reduced up to 40%. Solar drying improves the quality of the products in terms of colour, flavour and appearance, reduces the risk of microorganism growth, prevents insect infestation and contamination by foreign matters and mycotoxins. The products dried with the solar drying system meet the national and ingternational market standards. Investigations further showed that even during the rainy season it was possible to dry the products to the final moisture content which is needed for storage and marketing. The modular system allows adaptation to different farm sizes as well as cooperative use. © 1991.
Index Keywords: Food Products - Drying; Solar Energy - Applications; Cocoa Drying; Coffee Drying; Solar Drying; Solar Tunnel Dryer; Tropical Climates; Dryers

Authors: Sato Eiichi, Kimura Shingo, Isobe Hiroshi, Takahaski Kei, Tamakawa Yoshiharu, Yanagisawa Toru
Title: Disk-cathode flash x-ray tube driven by a repetitive-type of Blumlein pulser
Source title: Proceedings of SPIE - The International Society for Optical Engineering
Affiliations: Iwate Medical Univ, Morioka, Japan
Authors with affiliations: Sato, Eiichi, Iwate Medical Univ, Morioka, Japan; Kimura, Shingo, Iwate Medical Univ, Morioka, Japan; Isobe, Hiroshi, Iwate Medical Univ, Morioka, Japan; Takahaski, Kei, Iwate Medical Univ, Morioka, Japan; Tamakawa, Yoshiharu, Iwate Medical Univ, Morioka, Japan; Yanagisawa, Toru, Iwate Medical Univ, Morioka, Japan
Abstract: A repetitive flash x-ray generator utilizing a disk-cathode radiation tube is described. This generator consisted of the following essential components: a high-voltage power supply, an energy storage condenser, a repetitive type of modified Blumlein pulser, a turbo molecular pump, and a flash x-ray tube. This high-voltage pulser consisted of the following major devices: two ceramic condensers with capacities of 850pF, a gas gap switch driven by electric field distortion, and a coil. The two condensers were charged from -50 to -70kV, and the total capacity during main discharge was 425pF. The peak voltages of the pulser output were about -1.4 times the condenser charged voltage. The flash x-ray tube consisted of the following major devices: a rod-shaped anode tip made of tungsten, a disk cathode made of graphite, a spattering shield, and a tube body made of acrylate resin. The anode-cathode (A-C) space was regulated from the outside of the x-ray tube by rotating the anode rod. The maximum values of the tube voltage and the current were about 80kV and 1.2kA, respectively. The maximum pulse width was about 100ns, and the x-ray intensity was less than lμC/kg at 0.3m per pulse. The repetition frequency was less than 50Hz, and the maximum focal spot size was equivalent to the anode diameter of 3.0mm.
Index Keywords: Mathematical Models; Pulse Generators; Radiography - X-Ray; X-Ray Tubes; Blumlein Pulser; Disk-Cathode Radiation Tube; Repetitive Flash X-Ray Generator; Turbo Molecular Pump; X-Ray Apparatus

Authors: Lund Kurt O.
Title: Heat rejection in thermal energy storage experiments for solar-dynamic space power development
Authors with affiliations: Lund, Kurt O.
Abstract: Methods of heat rejection in planned thermal energy storage experiments are analyzed using approximate numerical and analytical techniques. The experiments will be performed on a space-shuttle flight, as well as in preliminary ground tests, and it is important that sufficient energy can be radiated to space to solidify the phase-change material (PCM), and that the phase-change occurs in a regular, verifiable manner. In this work two arrangements are considered for heat rejection from the molten LiF salt: One where the heat is rejected by conduction from the canister containing salt and then radiated to space, and the other where heat is first radiated from the canister to a conductor-rod and then radiated to space. Results show that by using high-emissivity textured surfaces for the canister and conductor-rod, sufficient heat can be rejected in the radiation-gap arrangement and that axial temperature gradients are minimized. Large gradients in the direct conduction arrangement could not be eliminated.
Index Keywords: Heat Transfer--Space Applications; Solar Energy; Solar Power Plants; Solar Radiation; Space Shuttles; Heat rejection; Thermal energy storage; Heating

Authors: Brennan W.J., Feast W.J., Munro H.S., Walker S.A.
Title: Investigation of the ageing of plasma oxidized PEEK
Affiliations: Wilton Materials Research Centre, ICI plc, Wilton, Middlesbrough, United Kingdom; Department of Chemistry, University of Durham, South Road, Durham, United Kingdom
Authors with affiliations: Brennan, W.J., Wilton Materials Research Centre, ICI plc, Wilton, Middlesbrough, United Kingdom; Feast, W.J., Department of Chemistry, University of Durham, South Road, Durham, United Kingdom; Munro, H.S., Department of Chemistry, University of Durham, South Road, Durham, United Kingdom; Walker, S.A., Department of Chemistry, University of Durham, South Road, Durham, United Kingdom
Abstract: Oxygen plasma treatment can be used for increasing the hydrophilicity of polymer surfaces, however, it is widely known that this effect decays significantly with time. This ageing phenomenon is thought to be caused by both migration of low molecular weight fragments and reorientation of modified polymer chains. It has recently been shown that the aged surface becomes transiently hydrophilic before attaining a final surface energy significantly lower than the initially treated surface. X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) and contact angle measurements were used to monitor the changes in surface chemistry of plasma oxidized poly(ether ether ketone) (PEEK) during post treatment storage. The decay and transient increase in hydrophilicity were found to be dependent upon crystallinity and storage temperature. © 1991.
Author Keywords: ageing; PEEK; X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy
Index Keywords: Chemical Reactions - Plasma Applications; Polymers - Aging; Plasma Oxidation; Polyether Ether Ketones; X-Ray Photoelectron Spectroscopy; Polyethers

Authors: Bernier H., Raghavan G.S.V., Paris J.
Title: Evaluation of a soil heat exchanger-storage system for a greenhouse. Part I. System performance
Affiliations: Inst de Technologie Agro-Alimentaire, La Pocatiere, Canada
Authors with affiliations: Bernier, H., Inst de Technologie Agro-Alimentaire, La Pocatiere, Canada; Raghavan, G.S.V., Inst de Technologie Agro-Alimentaire, La Pocatiere, Canada; Paris, J., Inst de Technologie Agro-Alimentaire, La Pocatiere, Canada
Abstract: A soil heat exchanger-storage system was installed in a commercial-type greenhouse. A heat exchanger-storage system, made of 26 non-perforated, corrugated plastic drainage pipes, 102 mm in diameter, was buried in the soil. Two rows of 13 pipes, 12 m long, were buried at 450 mm and 750 mm depths, respectively. The pipes were parallel to the longitudinal axis of the greenhouse and were spaced 450 mm apart. A 0.75 kW blower circulated hot air collected in the greenhouse through the pipes at a flowrate of 0.91 m3/s. The heat stored was recovered both by convection at the soil surface and by forced circulation through the exchanger pipes. A minimum temperature differential of 2°C between the air and the soil appears suitable for efficient operation. Results indicate that an average coefficient of performance (COP) of 4.6 was obtained during the test period.
Index Keywords: Greenhouses - Heat Exchangers; Heat Exchangers - Testing; Soils - Energy Storage; Coefficient of Performance; Soil Heat Exchangers; Soils

Authors: Chmielewski Art B., Pyle Jon S.
Title: NASA's Office of Aeronautics and Exploration Technology space power flight projects
Source title: Proceedings of the Intersociety Energy Conversion Engineering Conference
Affiliations: California Inst of Technology, Pasadena, United States
Authors with affiliations: Chmielewski, Art B., California Inst of Technology, Pasadena, United States; Pyle, Jon S., California Inst of Technology, Pasadena, United States
Abstract: NASA's Office of Aeronautics and Exploration Technology (OAET) created a program called In-STEP (In-Space Technology Experiments Program) to give the aerospace community an opportunity to validate advanced technologies in space. Power technology is only one of many technologies supported by In-STEP. In-STEP supports all technology areas that are important to OAET: propulsion, space environmental effects on materials, fluid and thermal management, space structures, sensors, communications and others. In-STEP has funded feasibility studies for the following experiments in the power technology arena: Microsphere Insulation Investigation, Unitized Regenerative Fuel Cell, Inflatable Solar Collector, Moving Belt Radiator, and Liquid Drop Radiator. The following experiments are currently in the experiment definition phase: Integrated Two-Phase Thermal Experiment, Electrolysis Performance Experiment and Sodium Sulfur Battery. Three In-STEP experiments are entering hardware fabrication phase: Thermal Energy Storage Technology, Solar Array Module Plasma Interaction Experiment and Heat Pipe Performance. This paper describes each one of these experiments with an emphasis placed on the benefits of technology validation.
Index Keywords: Aerospace Engineering; Space Research; In Space Technology Experiments Program; In STEP Program; Office Of Aeronautics and Exploration Technology; Technology Validation; Electric Power Systems

Authors: Kapoor Kamlesh, Jaluria Yogesh
Title: Mixed convective heat transfer characteristics of a downward turning buoyant ceiling jet
Source title: American Society of Mechanical Engineers, Heat Transfer Division, (Publication) HTD
Affiliations: Rutgers, State Univ of New Jersey, New Brunswick, United States
Authors with affiliations: Kapoor, Kamlesh, Rutgers, State Univ of New Jersey, New Brunswick, United States; Jaluria, Yogesh, Rutgers, State Univ of New Jersey, New Brunswick, United States
Abstract: An experimental investigation has been carried out on the mixed convective heat transfer characteristics of a buoyant ceiling jet turning downward at a corner. Such flows are frequently encountered in buoyancy driven transport in enclosed regions, such as those associated with thermal energy storage problems and enclosure fires. However, very little work has been done on the basic heat transfer mechanisms in such flows, particularly on the local heat flux distributions over the ceiling and the vertical wall near the corner. In this study, a two-dimensional horizontal jet of heated air is discharged adjacent to the underside of an isothermal horizontal plate whose other end is attached to an isothermal vertical plate, making a right angle corner with it. The distance between the jet discharge and the corner could be varied. Extensive heat flux measurements were carried out for different inflow conditions of the jet. The variation of the local heat transfer rate along the ceiling and the vertical wall shows a minimum followed by a recovery, as the flow turns at the corner. The average Nusselt numbers for the horizontal surface and the vertical walls are obtained as functions of the mixed convection parameter Gr/Re2 which is also known as the Richardson number Ri of the discharged ceiling jet. The total heat transfer rate to the isothermal ceiling and the vertical wall by the jet flow is also obtained. The study brings out several basic considerations in the thermal transport from a buoyant jet to the isothermal surface over which it flows, including the effects of opposing buoyancy for the vertical wall.
Index Keywords: Air; Flow of Fluids--Jets; Plates; Buoyant Ceiling Jets; Heat Flux Distributions; Heat Transfer Rates; Inflow Conditions; Mixed Convection; Heat Transfer

Authors: Park Dong C., Mohammed Osama, Oh S., Chung Suk Y., Marks II R.J.
Title: A correlation based associative memory
Affiliations: Dept of Electr & Comput Eng,, Florida Int Univ, Miami, FL, USA
Authors with affiliations: Park, Dong C., Dept of Electr & Comput Eng,, Florida Int Univ, Miami, FL, USA; Mohammed, Osama, Dept of Electr & Comput Eng,, Florida Int Univ, Miami, FL, USA; Oh, S., Dept of Electr & Comput Eng,, Florida Int Univ, Miami, FL, USA; Chung, Suk Y., Dept of Electr & Comput Eng,, Florida Int Univ, Miami, FL, USA; Marks II, R.J., Dept of Electr & Comput Eng,, Florida Int Univ, Miami, FL, USA
Abstract: An associative memory based on minimization of a free energy function determined by the library vectors to be stored is proposed. When the library vectors are bipolar, the energy function contains minima at the library vector location. The minima can be sought by search techniques such as gradient descent. Significantly, if the correlation nonlinearity is chosen to be sufficiently strong, then convergence occurs in a single step.
Index Keywords: Computer Architecture; Probability; Bipolar Library; Correlation-Based Associative Memory; Free Energy Function; Library Vectors; Data Storage, Digital

Authors: Conniff J.P.
Title: Strategies for reducing peak air-conditioning loads by using heat storage in the building structure
Affiliations: Ross & Baruzzini Inc, St. Louis, United States
Authors with affiliations: Conniff, J.P., Ross & Baruzzini Inc, St. Louis, United States
Abstract: This paper looks at operating and control procedures that shift the heat storage in the building elements to times of day when the building's air-conditioning load peaks and procedures that increase the heat stored to reduce the peak load. The reduction of peak load will decrease system size and peak electrical load. Operating and control procedures have been evaluated using weighting factors. Theoretical results are compared with test results, and good agreement is shown. The results and discussion are based on an interior room with no occupants. The only load is lighting. This paper also looks at the length of the pulldown cycle required to remove stored heat from the structure, the effect of switching return air from ceiling plenum return to ducted return, direct cooling of the return air plenum for part of the occupied period, temperature drift resulting from limited cooling capacity, and the time shift obtained by precooling the room. Air-conditioning load reductions of as much as 25% of the lighting power (CLF of .75) are demonstrated using these techniques. Since lighting may represent as much as 20% of the total cooling load, this can reduce the building's air-conditioning system load by 5%.
Index Keywords: Air Conditioning - Optimization; Buildings - Air Conditioning; Energy Storage; HEAT STORAGE; Air Conditioning Load Peaks; Air Conditioning

Authors: Anand D.K., Kirk J.A., Zmood R.B., Pang D., Lashley C.
Title: Final prototype of magnetically suspended flywheel energy storage system
Source title: Proceedings of the Intersociety Energy Conversion Engineering Conference
Affiliations: Univ of Maryland, College Park, United States
Authors with affiliations: Anand, D.K., Univ of Maryland, College Park, United States; Kirk, J.A., Univ of Maryland, College Park, United States; Zmood, R.B., Univ of Maryland, College Park, United States; Pang, D., Univ of Maryland, College Park, United States; Lashley, C., Univ of Maryland, College Park, United States
Abstract: A prototype of a 500 WH magnetically suspended flywheel energy storage system was designed, built and tested at the University of Maryland. The system design utilized new innovations of composite materials, magnetic suspension, and permanent magnet brushless motor/generator technology. A design goal of the system is to maximize the specific energy density (SED) to exceed a value of 20 WH/Kg for spacecraft applications. This paper presents the work done and includes the following: (1) a final design of magnetic bearing, control system, and motor/generator, (2) construction of prototype system consisting of the magnetic bearing stack, flywheel, motor, container, and display module, (3) experimental results of the magnetic bearings, motor and the entire system. The successful completion of the prototype system has achieved: (1) manufacture of tight tolerance bearings, (2) stability and spin above the first critical frequency, (3) use of inside sensors to eliminate runout problems, (4) integration of the motor and magnetic bearings.
Index Keywords: Bearings--Magnetic; Containers; Electric Generators; Electric Motors; Flywheels; SPACECRAFT; Brushless Motors; Magnetic Bearings; Magnetic Suspension; Permanent Magnets; Specific Energy Density; Energy Storage

Authors: Franz Alan, Szczepanski Jeffrey, Nye Alan
Title: Spirit. Solar powered innovations at the Rochester Institute of Technology
Affiliations: Rochester Inst of Technology, Rochester, United States
Authors with affiliations: Franz, Alan, Rochester Inst of Technology, Rochester, United States; Szczepanski, Jeffrey, Rochester Inst of Technology, Rochester, United States; Nye, Alan, Rochester Inst of Technology, Rochester, United States
Abstract: Through the cumulative effort of about 25 students, the SPIRIT team designed, constructed and raced a vehicle which competed in the l990 GM Sunrayce, USA. A finite number of race rules allowed for an infinite number of solutions to race a solar powered vehicle from Florida to Michigan. The solution to this competition differed from many other teams. The shell was designed and constructed to be lighter than any other. The electric systems were one of the most advanced. This paper reports the solutions which RIT students representing engineering, industrial design, and business, used to produce a competitive solar powered race vehicle.
Index Keywords: Energy Resources; Solar Cells; Solar Energy; Storage Battery Vehicles; Automobile races; Race vehicles; Solar powered vehicles; Automobiles

Authors: Gilmore Steven P.
Title: Development of the world's largest crawler dragline
Source title: Session Papers - American Mining Congress Coal Convention
Affiliations: Dresser-Marion, Marion, United States
Authors with affiliations: Gilmore, Steven P., Dresser-Marion, Marion, United States
Abstract: The special needs of an eastern Australia coal mining company has resulted in the development of the world's largest crawler mounted dragline. It has a working weight of 2.5 million pounds and a rated load of 100,000# with its longest boom length of 255 feet-0. When equipped with its 195 feet-0 boom the rated load increases to 120,000#. This paper describes how the independent dual motor planetary drive crawler technology of Dresser-Marion's new series of mining shovels was combined with the features of the 8000 series walking draglines to produce a crawler dragline 50 percent larger than existing models.
Index Keywords: Coal Mines and Mining--Australia; Crawler Dragline; Energy Storage Flywheel System; Mining Shovels; Walking Draglines; Mining Machinery

Authors: Marshall R.A., Barber J.P.
Title: The 10 km/s 10 kg railgun
Affiliations: WBM Stalker Pty. Ltd., 99 Leichhardt st., Brisbane, Qld, Australia; IAP Research, Inc., 2763 Culver Ave., Dayton, OH, 45429, United States
Authors with affiliations: Marshall, R.A., WBM Stalker Pty. Ltd., 99 Leichhardt st., Brisbane, Qld, Australia; Barber, J.P., IAP Research, Inc., 2763 Culver Ave., Dayton, OH, 45429, United States
Abstract: The system design for a railgun powered by capacitor-based energy stores distributed along its length is presented. It is assumed that it is required to accelerate a mass of l0kg to a velocity of 10km/s. Parameters for the railgun and its energy stores are derived and the performance of the system is computed with particular attention being paid to the efficiency with which store energy is converted to launch package kinetic energy. It is shown that efficiencies of 90 percent can be expected from a properly designed system. © 1991 IEEE
Index Keywords: Capacitors; Energy Storage; Capacitor-Based Energy Stores; Electromagnetic Launchers

Authors: Mckee R.W., Johnson K.I., Huber H.D., Bierschbacn M.C.
Title: Effects of spent fuel aging on repository disposal requirements
Affiliations: Pacific Northwest Lab, Richland, United States
Authors with affiliations: Mckee, R.W., Pacific Northwest Lab, Richland, United States; Johnson, K.I., Pacific Northwest Lab, Richland, United States; Huber, H.D., Pacific Northwest Lab, Richland, United States; Bierschbacn, M.C., Pacific Northwest Lab, Richland, United States
Abstract: A study has been carried out to analyze the effects of extended spent fuel aging on spent fuel disposal requirements. The analysis considers additional spent fuel aging up to a maximum of 50 years relative to the currently planned 2010 repository startup. As part of the analysis, an equal energy deposition (EED) methodology was developed for determining allowable waste emplacement densities in a tuff geologic repository as a function of spent fuel age and exposure. The method yields virtually identical results to those obtained by a more indirect method referred to as the 'equivalent peak temperature rise concept' that has been used by the Yucca Mountain Project. This study demonstrates how this methodology can be used to design both the waste package and the waste emplacement layout to meet more than one thermal goal simultaneously. The analysis also demonstrated the feasibility of delivering an energy levelized mix of spent fuel to the repository each year either directly from the reactors or from a Monitored Retrievable Storage (MRS) facility and the feasibility of representing the complex spent fuel mixture received by the repository by simply the average age and exposure. Results of this analysis indicate that substantial benefits of spent fuel aging will already have been achieved by a repository startup in 2010 (when the average spent fuel age will be 28 years). Even so, further significant aging benefits in terms of reduced emplacement areas and mining requirements and reduced number of waste containers, will continue to accrue if the repository startup is delayed for at least another 50 years, when the average spent fuel age would be 78 years.
Index Keywords: Nuclear Reactors--Spent Fuels; Equal Energy Deposition Methodology; Monitored Retrievable Storage (MRS) Facility; Radwaste Emplacement Layout; Spent Fuel Aging; Yucca Mountain Geological Repository; Radioactive Wastes

Authors: Gallagher M.W.
Title: Integrated thermal storage/life safety systems in tall buildings
Affiliations: Southern California Air Conditioning, Distributors, La Puente, United States
Authors with affiliations: Gallagher, M.W., Southern California Air Conditioning, Distributors, La Puente, United States
Abstract: The City of Los Angeles has enacted laws that mandate fire safety systems with auxiliary storage tanks. The electrical rates in Los Angeles favor thermal storage. An opportunity has arisen to combine the two concepts. An integrated thermal storage/life safety system, using the same storage tanks and fluid, helps solve storage space problems and produces two payback changes. First, it permits the sprinkler system to be part of a system that enhances cash flow. Second, the incremental extra cost of the thermal storage system is reduced since the storage tanks already had to be provided for the sprinkler system. A comprehensive feasibility study will include an examination of the integrated thermal storage/life safety application. Closer cooperation between design disciplines is required. This paper presents an explanation of the concept and an overview of the design and financial impacts.
Index Keywords: Air Conditioning - Energy Conservation; Energy Storage - Economics; Fire Protection - Sprinkler Systems; Life Safety Systems; Thermal Storage; Buildings

Authors: Tsuang Ben J., Dracup John A.
Title: Effect of global warming on Sierra Nevada mountain snow storage
Source title: Proceedings of The Western Snow Conference
Affiliations: Univ of California, Los Angeles, United States
Authors with affiliations: Tsuang, Ben J., Univ of California, Los Angeles, United States; Dracup, John A., Univ of California, Los Angeles, United States
Abstract: In most prior studies of the hydrologic consequences of climatic change, snowmelt runoff is considered to be either a function of temperature or a function of precipitation (Gleick 1987; Lettenmaier and Gan 1990). Nonetheless, the greenhouse effect is expected to be accompanied by changes not only in temperature and precipitation, but also in radiation, wind, humidity, and the snow/rain ratio (Ramanathan 1981; Washington and Meehl 1983; Manabe and Wetherald 1975; Manabe et al. 1981; Schlesinger 1984; Wilson and Mitchell 1987; Schlesinger and Mitchell 1987). This study evaluates the impacts of all of the aforementioned changes. In order to evaluate all these impacts, traditionally used air-temperature-index-based snowmelt runoff models, such as used by Gleick (1989) and Lettenmaier and Gan (1990), cannot be used. This snowmelt runoff model has five major characteristics that together are structurally unique: 1) a two-layer snowmelt runoff algorithm is developed; 2) the variations in the snow albedo are determined as a function of the snow grain size and the impurities in snow composition; 3) the flux of water in the snow pack is determined by Darcy's law; 4) the snow metamorphism of the snowpack is determined; and 5) the model is structured to be readily used in the analysis of the effects of greenhouse warming on snowmelt runoff.
Index Keywords: Energy Resources--Calculations; Greenhouse Effect; Meteorology--Climatology; Global Warming; Sierra Nevada; Snowmelt Runoff; Snow and Snowfall

Authors: Tsilingiris P.T.
Title: Large scale solar cooling design using salt gradient solar ponds
Affiliations: Council of Technological Research, Commercial Bank of Greece, 81 Eolou Street, 105 51 Athens, Greece, Greece
Authors with affiliations: Tsilingiris, P.T., Council of Technological Research, Commercial Bank of Greece, 81 Eolou Street, 105 51 Athens, Greece, Greece
Abstract: The future of large scale cooling is closely linked to the long term economically viable component development for collection and storage of solar energy at relatively high temperatures. As such, solar ponds at the present state of their development are undoubtedly considered as the only promising large scale solar collection and heat storage device for such applications. The present analysis, based on numerical calculations, allows a parametric investigation of solar pond design and operational characteristics to the capacity of a conventionally designed, commercially available, absorption chiller. The results can prove very useful for the rough design and pond size selection for operation of chillers of a substantial capacity, directly from solar ponds. © 1991.
Index Keywords: Solar Energy; Absorption Chiller; Condenser Heat Rejection; Large Scale Solar Cooling Design; Salt Gradient Solar Ponds; Solar Radiation

Authors: Kim A., Zeto R., Youmans R., Kondek C., Weiner M.
Title: High power, high PRF pulse generation using a laser diode activated photoconductive GaAs switch
Source title: Proceedings of SPIE - The International Society for Optical Engineering
Affiliations: U.S. Army LABCOM, Fort Monmouth, United States
Authors with affiliations: Kim, A., U.S. Army LABCOM, Fort Monmouth, United States; Zeto, R., U.S. Army LABCOM, Fort Monmouth, United States; Youmans, R., U.S. Army LABCOM, Fort Monmouth, United States; Kondek, C., U.S. Army LABCOM, Fort Monmouth, United States; Weiner, M., U.S. Army LABCOM, Fort Monmouth, United States
Abstract: The generation of sub-nanosecond risetime pulses with 2 MW peak power, at 1 kHz PRF, has been achieved by triggering a hybrid pulser with a laser diode array. The hybrid pulser combines an optical switch centered in a metallized teflon disk that serves as an energy storage medium as well as a radial transmission line. Nearly 90% of the bias voltage (10 kV) was delivered to a 50 ohm load impedance as a result of the variation of impedance of the radial line. Avalanche switching yielded 4 nanoseconds pulses with a risetime of less than 500 picoseconds.
Index Keywords: Photoconducting Devices - Switching; Semiconducting Gallium Arsenide - Applications; Avalanche Switching; Optical Pulsers; Optical Switches; Triggering; Pulse Generators

Authors: Abbott David G., Nolan Don J., Yoshimura H.Richard
Title: Certifying the TN-BRP and TN-REG transportable storage demonstration casks
Affiliations: EG&G Idaho Inc, Idaho Falls, United States
Authors with affiliations: Abbott, David G., EG&G Idaho Inc, Idaho Falls, United States; Nolan, Don J., EG&G Idaho Inc, Idaho Falls, United States; Yoshimura, H.Richard, EG&G Idaho Inc, Idaho Falls, United States
Abstract: The U.S. Department of Energy (DOE) has obtained U.S. Nuclear Regulatory Commission (NRC) certification to transport two transportable storage casks for a demonstration project. Because the casks had been built before the decision was made to obtain NRC certification, only limited modifications could be made to the casks. NRC's review resulted in several technical concerns that were subsequently resolved by design modifications, testing, and further analysis. Certification activities included qualifying the ferritic steel body material, modifying the borated stainless steel basket design, and extensive impact limiter testing. Recommendations for certifying future casks are presented based on experience with these casks.
Index Keywords: Containers--Steel; Nuclear Reactors--Spent Fuels; Structural Analysis; Nuclear Cask Structural Analysis; Shippable Storage Cask Demonstration Project; Transportable Storage Demonstration Casks; US Nuclear Regulatory Commission; Radioactive Wastes

Authors: Strumpf Hal J., Avanessian Vahe, Ghafourian Reza
Title: Design analysis and life prediction for the brayton engine solar receiver for the Space Station Freedom solar dynamic option
Source title: Proceedings of the Intersociety Energy Conversion Engineering Conference
Affiliations: Allied-Signal Aerospace Co, Torrance, United States
Authors with affiliations: Strumpf, Hal J., Allied-Signal Aerospace Co, Torrance, United States; Avanessian, Vahe, Allied-Signal Aerospace Co, Torrance, United States; Ghafourian, Reza, Allied-Signal Aerospace Co, Torrance, United States
Abstract: A study has been conducted on the design and development of a solar receiver to be used for electrical power production for the solar dynamic option on Space Station Freedom. The receiver incorporates integral thermal storage, using a eutectic mixture of LiF and CaF2 as a solid-to-liquid phase change material (PCM). The design comprises a cylindrical receiver cavity. The walls of the cavity are lined with a series of working fluid tubes running the length of the cavity. The PCM is enclosed in individual, sealed metallic containment canisters which are stacked and brazed to the tubes. The compartmentalization of the PCM localizes void formation upon freezing. An additional attribute of compartmentalization is that a containment canister failure affects only that one canister; the receiver continues to operate with only a minute loss of capacity. Nevertheless, a considerable effort has been expended to ensure that the containment canisters will survive the entire 30-year lifetime required for Freedom. A detailed analytical procedure was developed to evaluate the canister creep strain accumulated in 30 years. This accumulated creep strain, which is in the range of 0.03 to 0.79 percent, compares favorably with the preliminary value of 4 percent for the canister material allowable 30-year creep rupture ductility.
Index Keywords: Calcium Compounds; Lithium Compounds; Spacecraft--Power Supply; Thermodynamics--Brayton Cycle; Phase Change Materials; Solar Dynamic Systems; Space Station Freedom; Solar Energy

Authors: Sedgwick L.M., Kaufmann K.J., McLallin K.L., Kerslake T.W.
Title: Full-size solar dynamic heat receiver thermal-vacuum tests
Source title: Proceedings of the Intersociety Energy Conversion Engineering Conference
Affiliations: Boeing Aerospace & Electronics, Seattle, United States
Authors with affiliations: Sedgwick, L.M., Boeing Aerospace & Electronics, Seattle, United States; Kaufmann, K.J., Boeing Aerospace & Electronics, Seattle, United States; McLallin, K.L., Boeing Aerospace & Electronics, Seattle, United States; Kerslake, T.W., Boeing Aerospace & Electronics, Seattle, United States
Abstract: The first ever testing of a full-size, 102 kWt, solar dynamic heat receiver utilizing high-temperature thermal energy storage has been completed. The purpose of the test program was to quantify receiver thermodynamic performance, operating temperatures, and thermal response to changes in environmental and power module interface boundary conditions. The heat receiver was tested in a vacuum chamber with liquid nitrogen cold shrouds and an aperture cold plate to partially simulate a low-Earth-orbit environment. The cavity of the receiver was heated by an infrared quartz lamp heater with 30 independently controllable zones to allow axially and circumferentially varied flux distributions. A closed-Brayton cycle engine simulator conditioned a helium-xenon gas mixture to specific interface conditions to simulate the various operational modes of the solar dynamic power module on the Space Station Freedom. Inlet gas temperature, pressure, and flow rate were independently varied. A total of 58 simulated orbital cycles, each 94 minutes in duration, was completed during the test conduct period.
Index Keywords: Heating--Heat Storage; Solar Energy; Thermodynamics--Brayton Cycle; Solar Dynamic Systems; Space Station Freedom; Thermal Energy Storage; Space Stations

Authors: Berglund L.G.
Title: Comfort benefits for summer air conditioning with ice storage
Affiliations: John B. Pierce Lab, New Haven, United States
Authors with affiliations: Berglund, L.G., John B. Pierce Lab, New Haven, United States
Abstract: Air-conditioning systems with ice storage have a greater potential for dehumidifying the air than conventional chilled-water systems. At a given temperature, reduced humidity results in occupants feeling cooler, drier, and more comfortable; further, the air is perceived to be fresher, less stale, and more acceptable. These conclusions were derived from the subjective responses of 20 subjects studied at three temperatures, three humidities, and three activities.
Index Keywords: Air Conditioning - Human Factors; Buildings - Climate Control; Energy Storage; Ice - Storage; Dehumidifiers; Summer Air Conditioning; Air Conditioning

Authors: Catanese D.L.
Title: Energy analysis of low-temperature air distribution systems and reduced economizer-cycle cooling
Affiliations: Pennsylvania Electric Co, Johnstown, United States
Authors with affiliations: Catanese, D.L., Pennsylvania Electric Co, Johnstown, United States
Abstract: Low-temperature supply air systems are often used with an ice storage system to take advantage of the 34°F to 38°F chilled water available. By using a low-temperature air distribution system to provide primary air for space conditioning or process cooling, distribution equipment can be downsized to offer significant savings in first costs and often lower energy costs. However, some of the benefits of the natural cooling normally available in a conventional (55°F) supply air system will be lost in a low-temperature supply air system. This is generally experienced in climates where a significant portion of the operating hours between 45°F and 60°F allow the use of the economizer cycle in a conventional system and otherwise require mechanical cooling in a low-temperature air distribution system. By using an hourly building energy analysis program to compare the energy use associated with a conventional (55°F) supply air system with the energy use of a low-temperature supply air system, this paper quantifies the energy penalty associated with reduced economizer-cycle cooling in a low-temperature air system at various locations throughout the United States and also shows that this energy penalty can be overcome by the savings in fan horsepower energy associated with the low-temperature supply air system.
Index Keywords: Buildings - Energy Utilization; Energy Storage; Energy Utilization - Computer Aided Analysis; Fans - Energy Conservation; Ice - Manufacture; Economizer Cycle Cooling; Ice Storage Systems; Low-Temperature Air Distribution; Air Conditioning

Authors: Fath H.E.S.
Title: Heat exchanger performance for latent heat thermal energy storage system
Affiliations: Mechanical Engineering Department, Faculty of Engineering, Alexandria University, Alexandria, Egypt
Authors with affiliations: Fath, H.E.S., Mechanical Engineering Department, Faculty of Engineering, Alexandria University, Alexandria, Egypt
Abstract: An experimental and theoretical study was carried out to investigate the heat transfer in a component of a low temperature thermal energy storage (TES) system using the latent heat of fusion of a phase change material (PCM). The heat storage container is a double pipe heat exchanger where the energy source fluid (hot water) flows through the inner tube, while the heat sink (storage PCM) fills the annulus gap. The tested phase change material is the paraffin wax of melting temperature of 50°C. Measurements were made of the temperature change of the hot water as well as of the paraffin wax. The heat transfer rate and the accumulative energy stored as a function of time is presented for different hot water flow rates and inlet temperatures. An analytical model is developed for the prediction of the storage heat transfer rate and accumulative energy. The predictions of the model are compared with experimental results and show good agreement. The developed model is also used to study the effect of convertion in the molten zone, initial PCM subcooling, and heat exchanger dimensions on heat transfer rate and accumulative energy. © 1991.
Index Keywords: Energy Storage; Phase Change Materials; Thermal Energy Storage; Heat Exchangers

Authors: Carotenuto A., Fucci F., La Fianza G., Reale F.
Title: Physical model and demonstration of an aquifer thermal energy store
Affiliations: DETEC, University of Napoli, Federico II, P. le Tecchio, 80125 Napoli, Italy
Authors with affiliations: Carotenuto, A., DETEC, University of Napoli, Federico II, P. le Tecchio, 80125 Napoli, Italy; Fucci, F., DETEC, University of Napoli, Federico II, P. le Tecchio, 80125 Napoli, Italy; La Fianza, G., DETEC, University of Napoli, Federico II, P. le Tecchio, 80125 Napoli, Italy; Reale, F., DETEC, University of Napoli, Federico II, P. le Tecchio, 80125 Napoli, Italy
Abstract: An experimental loop has been set up to demonstrate the technical feasibility of a hot water aquifer store and to validate an original physical model and code as well as the engineering based on it. The model applies to a "reference aquifer" and an appropriate exploitation system, as defined in the text. Experiments have been carried out for a period of 37 days, 15 days for injection of hot water at 40°C, 7 days of storage at rest, 15 days for pumping out stored hot water. The system has worked perfectly at the specified performance. Measured temperatures show a very good accordance with temperatures predicted by the numerical model. The rated 52% efficiency has been confirmed. Although more extended experiments shall be performed, one can conclude that the engineering of the system is appropriate and the physical model and numerical code developed by the authors are satisfactory. © 1991.
Index Keywords: Geology; Temperature Distribution; Hydrogeology; Thermal Energy Storage; Aquifers

Authors: Evans S.D., Sharma R., Ulman A.
Title: Contact Angle Stability: Reorganization of Monolayer Surfaces?
Affiliations: Corporate Research Laboratories, Manufacturing Research and Engineering Organization, Eastman Kodak Company, Rochester, New York 14659-2109, United States
Authors with affiliations: Evans, S.D., Corporate Research Laboratories, Manufacturing Research and Engineering Organization, Eastman Kodak Company, Rochester, New York 14659-2109, United States; Sharma, R., Corporate Research Laboratories, Manufacturing Research and Engineering Organization, Eastman Kodak Company, Rochester, New York 14659-2109, United States; Ulman, A., Corporate Research Laboratories, Manufacturing Research and Engineering Organization, Eastman Kodak Company, Rochester, New York 14659-2109, United States
Abstract: Contact angle variation was studied on self-assembled alkanethiol monolayers containing mixtures of OH and CH3 groups at their air/monolayer interface. It was found that these high free energy organic surfaces yielded contact angles which were not stable over long periods of time. The extent of the variation was found to be related to the surface free energy (percent OH). The effect of different storage environments and temperature on the changing contact angles is discussed. We propose that monolayer surfaces containing high concentrations of OH groups on mobile organic chains are not stable. Such monolayer surfaces may stabilize, over a time dependent on the chain length, by surface reorganization and the adsorption of contaminants. © 1991, American Chemical Society. All rights reserved.
Index Keywords: Films - Surface Properties; Liquids - Surface Tension; Surface Phenomena - Thermodynamics; Alkanethiols; Contact Angle; Organic Compounds

Authors: Cnare E.C., Widner M.M., Duggin B.W.
Title: A 10-stage reconnection demonstration launcher
Affiliations: Electromagnetic Launcher Division 1221, Sandia National Laboratories, Albuquerque, New Mexico, 87185, United States

Abstract: A small-scale, 10-stage cylindrical reconnection launcher has been designed, fabricated, and tested. Ten-gram projectiles are accelerated from rest to 317 ms through the 0.44 m launcher assembly with a projectile kinetic energy to capacitor stored energy efficiency of 9%. Comparison of test results and computer code predictions will be presented. Results of these studies have substantiated launcher scaling at small size and have provided a useful test bed for launcher components and diagnostics. © 1991 IEEE
Index Keywords: Accelerators; Capacitors - Energy Storage; Reconnection Launchers; Ballistics

Authors: Johnson P.E., Wankerl M.W., Joy D.S.
Title: Transportation capabilities of the existing cask fleet
Affiliations: Oak Ridge Natl Lab, Oak Ridge, United States
Authors with affiliations: Johnson, P.E., Oak Ridge Natl Lab, Oak Ridge, United States; Wankerl, M.W., Oak Ridge Natl Lab, Oak Ridge, United States; Joy, D.S., Oak Ridge Natl Lab, Oak Ridge, United States
Abstract: This paper describes a number of scenarios estimating the amount of spent nuclear fuel that could be transported to a Monitored Retrievable Storage (MRS) Facility by various combinations of existing cask fleets. To develop the scenarios, the data provided by the Transportation System Data Base (TSDB) were modified to reflect the additional time for cask turnaround resulting from various startup and transportation issues. With these more realistic speed and cask-handling assumptions, the annual transportation capability of a fleet consisting of all of the existing casks is approximately 465 metric tons of uranium (MTU). The most likely fleet of existing casks that would be made available to the Department of Energy (DOE) consists of two rail, three overweight truck, and six legal weight truck casks. Under the same transportation assumptions, this cask fleet is capable of approximately transporting 270 MTU/year. These ranges of capability is a result of the assumptions pertaining to the number of casks assumed to be available. It should be noted that this assessment assumes additional casks based on existing certifications are not fabricated.
Index Keywords: Database Systems--Applications; Radioactive Materials--Transportation; Monitored Retrievable Storage (MRS) Facility; Radwaste Cask Fleet; Spent Fuel Legal-Weight Shipments; Transportation System Data Base; Nuclear Reactors

Authors: Jourda P., Probert S.D.
Title: Heat-transfer considerations for large liquefied-natural-gas storage tanks
Affiliations: Department of Applied Energy, Cranfield Institute of Technology, Bedford, MK43 0AL, United Kingdom
Authors with affiliations: Jourda, P., Department of Applied Energy, Cranfield Institute of Technology, Bedford, MK43 0AL, United Kingdom; Probert, S.D., Department of Applied Energy, Cranfield Institute of Technology, Bedford, MK43 0AL, United Kingdom
Abstract: Natural gas is used worldwide as a practical energy source. In order to have a concentrated form of energy, natural gas is liquefied and stored under a pressure slightly above atmospheric and at a corresponding temperature just above its normal boiling point (112 K). This investigation presents a general steady-state study of the heat transfers into such a storage tank. Two mathematical models are proposed in order to help improve the thermal design process for such a tank. It is concluded that the aspect ratio (i.e. height-to-radius) of such a tank for the minimum rate of heat gains should be approximately unity. This value differs from the economically most favourable aspect ratio, i.e. that leading to the least total financial expenditure over the lifetime of the tank. However, the two models allow a complete simulation of the thermal costs. As the unit cost of fuel rises relative to other costs (e.g. for the construction of the tank), the overall most economic tank design approaches that of the optimal thermal design of tank as deduced in this investigation. © 1991.
Index Keywords: Economics; Mathematical Models; Tanks--Heat Transfer; Aspect Ratio; Heat Gains; LNG Storage Tank; Thermal Design; Natural Gas, Liquefied

Authors: Sequeira C.A.C., Freitas A.M.G., Araujo L.P.S.
Title: Candidate materials for electric vehicle propulsion batteries
Source title: International Journal of Global Energy Issues
Affiliations: Inst Tecnologico para a Europa, Comunitaria, Lisboa, Portugal
Authors with affiliations: Sequeira, C.A.C., Inst Tecnologico para a Europa, Comunitaria, Lisboa, Portugal; Freitas, A.M.G., Inst Tecnologico para a Europa, Comunitaria, Lisboa, Portugal; Araujo, L.P.S., Inst Tecnologico para a Europa, Comunitaria, Lisboa, Portugal
Abstract: The general overview of various types of electrodes and electrolytes used in advanced high-power battery systems are presented with sources for details related to various specific applications, namely electric-vehicle propulsion. A typical cell comprises a metal sulfide cathode such as FeS or FeS2, a separator of BN or MgO powder with molten salt electrolyte, and LiAl or LiAl/LiSi anode. Typical molten salts are the LiCl-KCl and the LiCl-KBr eutectics. The very high melting points of these electrolytes necessitate operation of batteries in the 400 to 500°C range. At these temperatures, they exhibit very high-power densities, adequate for electric vehicle propulsion. Cells having 100 to 175 Wh/kg specific energy, >200 W/kg powder density, and a cycle life of over 400 cycles have been developed. Considerable work must, however, be done to establish the feasibility of scaled-up high temperature molten salt batteries.
Index Keywords: Automobiles - Electric; Electrodes, Electrochemical; Electrolytes; Energy Resources; Propulsion - Electric Energy; Electric Vehicle Propulsion; Energy Demands; High Energy Battery Systems; Molten Salts; Storage Battery Vehicles

Authors: Tappy L., Felber J.P., Jéquier E.
Title: Energy and substrate metabolism in obesity and postobese state
Affiliations: Institute of Physiology, Faculty of Medicine, University of Lausanne, Lausanne, Switzerland; Institut de Physiologie, 7, rue du Bugnon, 1005 Lausanne, Switzerland
Authors with affiliations: Tappy, L., Institute of Physiology, Faculty of Medicine, University of Lausanne, Lausanne, Switzerland; Felber, J.P., Institute of Physiology, Faculty of Medicine, University of Lausanne, Lausanne, Switzerland; Jéquier, E., Institute of Physiology, Faculty of Medicine, University of Lausanne, Lausanne, Switzerland, Institut de Physiologie, 7, rue du Bugnon, 1005 Lausanne, Switzerland
Abstract: The total energy expenditure (EE) of human beings is represented by basal metabolic rate (which corresponds to 60-70% of EE), dietary-induced thermogenesis (10% of EE), and the energy expended in physical activity (20-30% of EE). Obese individuals have an increased total EE compared with lean subjects; this increase is essentially due to an increased lean body mass concomitant with obesity, and is completely reverted after weight loss. Glucose-induced thermogenesis (GIT), measured during an oral glucose tolerance test (OGTT) or hyperinsulinemic-euglycemic clamps, has been found to be decreased in obese individuals, although some discrepancy exists between studies. The observed decreases in GIT show a gradation, increasing progressively from obese patients with normal glucose tolerance to obese patients with impaired glucose tolerance (IGT) to obese patients with non-insulin-dependent diabetes mellitus (NIDDM) and an increased insulin response after OGTT to obese patients with NIDDM and a hypoinsulinemic response after OGTT. The defect in GIT appears to be related to impairment in nonoxidative glucose storage and with the degree of insulin resistance. Obese patients after weight loss show a further decrease in GIT after OGTT or during a euglycemic clamp, which remains unclear. Obese patients have an increased basal lipid oxidation and a decreased suppression of lipid oxidation after OGTT or during a euglycemic clamp. Glucose oxidation and storage are both markedly decreased during a euglycemic clamp. In contrast, the defect in glucose storage is less apparent after OGTT, due to the compensatory effect of hyperglycemia and hyperinsulinemia. Infusion of triglycerides in lean nondiabetic individuals increases plasma free-fatty acid concentration and lipid oxidation and decreases insulin-mediated glucose oxidation and storage during a euglycemic clamp. Hyperglycemia under these conditions restored both glucose oxidation and storage to their initial values, Thus, an increase in lipid oxidation produces in lean individuals the metabolic alterations observed in obese patients.
Index Keywords: glucose; triacylglycerol; adult; controlled study; energy metabolism; human; impaired glucose tolerance; non insulin dependent diabetes mellitus; obesity; priority journal; review; Aging; Body Temperature Regulation; Diabetes Mellitus, Non-Insulin-Dependent; Energy Metabolism; Fatty Acids, Nonesterified; Glucose Tolerance Test; Human; Insulin Resistance; Obesity; Obesity in Diabetes; Weight Loss

Authors: Salas J., Girardet J.P., De Potter S., Martí-Henneberg C., Goulet O., Ricour C.
Title: Glucose versus glucose-fat mixture in the course of total parenteral nutrition: effects on substrate utilisation and energy metabolism in malnourished children
Affiliations: Service de Gastroenterologie et Nutrition, Département de Pédiatrie, Hôpital Necker, 149 rue de Sevres, Paris Cedex 15, France; Department of Medicine and Surgery, Research Unit on Human Nutrition and Growth, VII Division, c/ Sant Llorenç 21, 43201 Reus, Spain
Authors with affiliations: Salas, J., Department of Medicine and Surgery, Research Unit on Human Nutrition and Growth, VII Division, c/ Sant Llorenç 21, 43201 Reus, Spain; Girardet, J.P., Service de Gastroenterologie et Nutrition, Département de Pédiatrie, Hôpital Necker, 149 rue de Sevres, Paris Cedex 15, France; De Potter, S., Service de Gastroenterologie et Nutrition, Département de Pédiatrie, Hôpital Necker, 149 rue de Sevres, Paris Cedex 15, France; Martí-Henneberg, C., Department of Medicine and Surgery, Research Unit on Human Nutrition and Growth, VII Division, c/ Sant Llorenç 21, 43201 Reus, Spain; Goulet, O., Service de Gastroenterologie et Nutrition, Département de Pédiatrie, Hôpital Necker, 149 rue de Sevres, Paris Cedex 15, France; Ricour, C., Service de Gastroenterologie et Nutrition, Département de Pédiatrie, Hôpital Necker, 149 rue de Sevres, Paris Cedex 15, France
Abstract: Energy substrate utilisation was evaluated over 21 days in two groups of malnourished children on total parenteral nutrition (TPN). Non-protein energy was infused as glucose (Group A; n = 7) or as a glucose/fat (1:1 v/v) mixture (Group B; n = 10). Results indicated that: 1) net glucose oxidation was related to glucose intake; 2) glucose storage was elevated in group A; 3) net fat synthesis occurred earlier in group B together with constant net fat oxidation which was inversely related to glucose intake (r = -0.89, p < 0.001); 4) lipogenesis from glucose occurred only when glucose intake exceeded 19.3g/kg/d; 5) energy expenditure increased by 36% (group A) and 18% (group B) during renutrition; 6) 73% and 82% of the energy administered in excess of energy required was stored in group A and B respectively. Hence, glucose/fat infusion appears to be more energy-efficient than glucose-alone in TPN of malnourished children. © 1991.
