Authors: Bjorntorp P.
Title: Importance of fat as a support nutrient for energy: Metabolism of athletes
Affiliations: Department of Medicine I, Sahlgren’s Hospital, University of Goteborg, Sweden
Authors with affiliations: Bjorntorp, P., Department of Medicine I, Sahlgren’s Hospital, University of Goteborg, Sweden
Abstract: The two main fuels for muscle metabolism are carbohydrate and fat. There is a limited store of carbohydrate in the body but this is not the case with fat. The average lean man has about 15% of his body weight as fat, whereas the average lean women has about 25% of her body weight as fat. Male and female endurance athletes have only about 7-10% of their body weights as fat. Sedentary people consume diets which contain about 35-40% of their energy intake as fat. The recommended intake of fat in the diet of active and sedentary people is less than that percentage. Although there is a need to increase carbohydrate intake as part of the preparation for heavy training and competition there is no need to supplement the normal diet with additional fat. Fat is mobilized from adipose tissue in response to stimulation of an intracellular lipase by the catecholamines. The products of the hydrolysis of triglycerides, the storage form of fat, are fatty acids and glycerol. The ‘free’ fatty acids are transported to muscle in loose combination with plasma albumin where they are released and taken up and oxidized. Glycerol is not used directly as a substrate but undergoes gluconeogenesis in the liver. This process helps restock liver glycogen stores which, in turn, provides glucose as a fuel for the central nervous system and for muscle metabolism. Training increases the capacity of skeletal muscles to use fat as an energy source. An increase in fat metabolism during prolonged exercise has a glycogen sparing effect and as such improves endurance capacity. Fat cells increase their sensitivity to hormonal stimulation after training and, as a result, mobilization of fatty acid more closely matches utilization. © Taylor & Francis Group, LLC.
Author Keywords: Body fat; Diet; Energy metabolism; Exercise; Fatty acids; Gluconeogenesis; Glycerol; Muscle
Index Keywords: fat; fatty acid; glycerol; athlete; body fat; conference paper; diet; endurance; energy metabolism; gluconeogenesis; muscle metabolism; nutrition; sport; training; Adaptation, Physiological; Dietary Carbohydrates; Dietary Fats; Energy Metabolism; Exercise; Female; Human; Male; Physical Endurance; Sports

Authors: Schrage Dean S.
Title: Thermal modeling of nickel-hydrogen battery cells operating under transient orbital conditions
Source title: Proceedings of the Intersociety Energy Conversion Engineering Conference
Affiliations: Sverdrup Technology Inc, Brook Park, United States
Authors with affiliations: Schrage, Dean S., Sverdrup Technology Inc, Brook Park, United States
Abstract: The nickel-hydrogen (Ni-H2) battery cell is a key component in the electrical power generating system for Space Station Freedom. Although noted for marked improvements in reliability, energy density and charge retention over conventional energy storage technologies, the failure modes of the nickel-hydrogen battery cell are intimately coupled to their ability to dissipate waste heat while operating in a thermally obtrusive environment. Designs must abide by constraints in the cell stack (intracell) and cell-to-cell (intercell) temperature extremes and gradients, necessitating detailed thermal analysis at the component- and systems-level. In the present study, combined finite-element and finite-difference techniques are employed to arrive at a computationally efficient composite thermal model representing a series-cell arrangement operating in conjunction with a radiately coupled baseplate and coldplate thermal bus. An aggressive, low-mass design approach indicates that thermal considerations can and should direct the design of the thermal bus arrangement.
Index Keywords: Electric Batteries - Space Applications; Electric Batteries - Thermal Effects; Mathematical Techniques - Finite Difference Method; Mathematical Techniques - Finite Element Method; Nickel Compounds - Applications; Nickel Hydrogen Battery Cells; Nickel Hydrogen Battery Thermal Modeling; Space Station Freedom; Space Stations

Authors: Bossone C.A., Hannon J.P.
Title: Metabolic actions of morphine in conscious chronically instrumented pigs
Source title: American Journal of Physiology - Regulatory Integrative and Comparative Physiology
Affiliations: Div. of Military Trauma Rsrch., Letterman Army Inst. of Rsrch., Presidio San Fran., CA 94129, United States
Authors with affiliations: Bossone, C.A., Div. of Military Trauma Rsrch., Letterman Army Inst. of Rsrch., Presidio San Fran., CA 94129, United States; Hannon, J.P., Div. of Military Trauma Rsrch., Letterman Army Inst. of Rsrch., Presidio San Fran., CA 94129, United States
Abstract: Effects of a modest dose of morphine sulfate (1 mg/kg) on total body energy metabolism, body thermal status, and the plasma concentrations of certain electrolytes and metabolites were investigated in conscious chronically instrumented pigs (n = 8). Control pigs (n = 8) received an equivalent volume of normal saline. Intravenous morphine injection led to an excitatory state associated with significant (P ≤ 0.05) immediate increases in O2 consumption, CO2 production, respiratory exchange ratio, and plasma concentrations of lactate, glucose, potassium, phosphate, epinephrine, and norepinephrine. Significant more gradual increases were observed in rectal and skin temperatures, body heat content, and the plasma concentrations of adrenocorticotropic hormone, cortisol, and phosphate. The hypermetabolic state persisted for ~1 h. Thereafter, most functional variables regressed toward, but did not reach, control levels. Increased muscle activity appeared to be the major factor underlying the rise in energy metabolism. Body heat storage after morphine injection appeared to be attributable to increased heat production coupled with an inadequate rise in heat loss.
Author Keywords: Body heat content; Conscious swine; Heat balance; Metabolic rate; Morphine hyperthermia; Pituitary-adrenal axis
Index Keywords: adrenalin; corticotropin; morphine; noradrenalin; animal experiment; article; controlled study; hypophysis adrenal system; intravenous drug administration; metabolism; nonhuman; priority journal; swine; thermoregulation

Authors: Nixon P., Price J., Jago J., Davis R.
Title: The Stability of Thiamine and Thiamine Tetrahydrofurfuryl Disulfide Added to Table Wines
Source title: Journal of Nutritional Science and Vitaminology

Abstract: Both thiamine hydrochloride and thiamine tetrahydrofurfuryl disulfide were added separately to table wines at concentrations equivalent to 0.3 and 1.5 ßg of free thiamine per kJ of caloric energy. The resultant mean increments in thiamine activity, measured by Lactobacillus fermenti microbiological assay after 21 months of storage, were in the range 55 to 103% of the added vitamin, indicative of high bioavailability of thiamine from this source. © 1991, Center for Academic Publications Japan. All rights reserved.

Authors: Perez-Davis Marla E., Gaier James R., Petrefski Chris
Title: Sensible heat receiver for solar dynamic space power system
Source title: Proceedings of the Intersociety Energy Conversion Engineering Conference
Affiliations: NASA Lewis Research Cent, Cleveland, United States
Authors with affiliations: Perez-Davis, Marla E., NASA Lewis Research Cent, Cleveland, United States; Gaier, James R., NASA Lewis Research Cent, Cleveland, United States; Petrefski, Chris, NASA Lewis Research Cent, Cleveland, United States
Abstract: The growth of electrical power requirements for space missions has stimulated the development of power system concepts that are more efficient and lighter than the state-of-the-art technology. Solar dynamic power systems are being studied for such high power space missions. A sensible heat receiver considered in this study uses a vapor grown carbon fiber-carbon (VGCF/C) composite as the thermal storage media and was designed for a 7 kW Brayton engine. The proposed heat receiver stores the required energy to power the system during eclipse in the VGCF/C composite. The heat receiver thermal analysis was conducted through the Systems Improved Numerical Differencing Analyzer and Fluid Integrator (SINDA) software package. The sensible heat receiver compares well with other latent and advanced sensible heat receivers analyzed in other studies while avoiding the problems associated with latent heat storage salts and liquid metal heat pipes. The concept also satisfies the design requirements for a 7 kW Brayton engine system. The weight and size of the system can be optimized by changes in geometry and technology advances for this new material.
Index Keywords: Computer Programming; Electric Power Systems; Heating--Heat Storage; Mathematical Techniques--Numerical Analysis; Thermodynamics--Brayton Cycle; Heat Receivers; Solar Energy

Authors: Aspden Harold
Title: Principles underlying regenerative free energy technology
Source title: Proceedings of the Intersociety Energy Conversion Engineering Conference
Affiliations: Univ of Southampton, Southampton, United Kingdom
Authors with affiliations: Aspden, Harold, Univ of Southampton, Southampton, United Kingdom
Abstract: The conversion of environmental energy, whether stored as heat in a familiar form or stored in movement and electrical displacement of something wholly unfamiliar that constitutes the vacuum field, to produce useful electric output is discussed. There are several routes to this objective, but the physical principles underlying the three ways in which this author is particularly interested will be presented. The object is not to disclose specific structures which warrant research and development and which are deemed of a proprietory nature at this time, but rather to share an insight into the basic factors involved, so that the 'free energy' challenge to win through and revolutionize the energy scene can involve more people with design skills and resources.
Index Keywords: Energy Conversion; Energy Storage; Environmental Engineering; HEAT STORAGE; Environmental Energy; Regenerative Free Energy Technology; Energy Resources

Authors: Sun Yang, Li Chengfu, Deng He, Gan Fuxi
Title: Laser-induced phase transition in InSb films
Affiliations: Acad Sinica, Shanghai, China
Authors with affiliations: Sun, Yang, Acad Sinica, Shanghai, China; Li, Chengfu, Acad Sinica, Shanghai, China; Deng, He, Acad Sinica, Shanghai, China; Gan, Fuxi, Acad Sinica, Shanghai, China
Abstract: The phase transitions induced by laser irradiation on thin films and surfaces of bulk materials have been widely investigated. Because these phase transitions often result in changes in optical, thermal as well as electrical and magnetic properties, the phase change materials can be widely used in many fields, such as optical storage. Meanwhile the study on laser induced phase change is also attributable to understanding the mechanism of the interaction between laser beam and materials. In this work we have observed the temporal reflectivity changes in InSb films after pulsed Nd:glass laser irradiation and analysed the dynamic processes of phase transitions. The results show that the speed of phase transition strongly depends on the thermal conductivity and temperature gradient of the film, and that the speeds of melting and solidification vary greatly when deposited energy changes. Phase transition can also occur at non-irradiated areas near irradiated spots, which indicates that the phase transition is finally induced by thermal absorption.
Index Keywords: Intermetallics - Phase Transitions; Laser Beams - Effects; Semiconducting Films - Radiation Effects; Indium Antimonide; Laser Irradiation; Semiconducting intermetallics

Authors: Hanafi Abdalla
Title: Design and performance of solar MSF desalination systems
Source title: Institution of Chemical Engineers Symposium Series
Affiliations: Cairo Univ, Cairo, Egypt
Authors with affiliations: Hanafi, Abdalla, Cairo Univ, Cairo, Egypt
Abstract: Solar desalination systems using flat plate or concentrating collectors are still in the development stage. Two main stages in the advancement of any solar desalination systems, namely design and performance are analyzed in the present work. In the design stage, the solar system together with the MSF chamber parameters are selected and analyzed to attain at the proper system configurations and operating conditions. Solar systems including flat plate and concentrating collectors with different collector fluids are investigated. The solar data are calculated for clear sky and corrected according to measurements. As a result the interaction of the design configurations and the thermal operating conditions are analyzed. A stage - to - stage design of the MSF chamber and the system transient performance are carried out. According to the selected solar system and MSF parameters, the transient performance analysis is obtained by modelling the system thermal performance through a small interval of time.
Index Keywords: Solar Energy - Applications; Solar Radiation - Collectors; Water Treatment Plants - Design; Fresh Water Production; Multi-Stage Flash System; Solar Multi-Stage Flash Desalination Plants; Thermal Storage; Desalination

Authors: Gadalla M.A.
Title: Second law analysis of cooling thermal energy storage system
Source title: Proceedings of the Intersociety Energy Conversion Engineering Conference
Affiliations: Univ of Alabama, Tuscaloosa, United States
Authors with affiliations: Gadalla, M.A., Univ of Alabama, Tuscaloosa, United States
Abstract: Due to the worldwide effort on solving energy crises, utilities are turning to energy conservation load management techniques to improve the load factor and better utilize the existing generating capacity. A latent heat thermal energy storage (LHTES) cooling system which utilizes a refrigerant gas hydrate as well as ice as storage media has been experimentally tested and theoretically analyzed. In this paper a brief overview of second law analysis that provides a useful measure of the energy utilization is discussed for short-term cooling loads storage systems. This analysis has been used to evaluate the performance of the energy storage systems that utilize direct contact heat transfer model between the cyclic fluid and the storage media in a closed loop latent heat thermal energy storage unit. This heat transfer model reduces the thermal resistance between the tank components and in turn increases the system performance. The main purpose of this paper is to provide clear physical insights to the second law analysis and present thermal design parameters that describe the optimal performance and operation of thermal energy storage systems.
Index Keywords: Energy Storage; Heat Transfer; Thermodynamics; Cooling Thermal Energy Storage; Latent Heat Thermal Energy Storage; Heating

Abstract: The present paper reports the current progress of advanced solar dynamic receiver the authors have conducted at Electrotechnical Laboratory. The first part of the paper describes component test of receiver tube with LiF in metallic containers, which was performed in a closed high temperature He-Xe loop. The second part gives the details of the development of composite phase change materials, such as ceramics/molten salts or carbon/molten salts for advanced receiver concepts. As for SiC/LiF composite, the performance test of receiver component will soon be ready for the initiation.

Authors: van den Berg A.C., van Wingerden C.J.M., The H.G.
Title: Vapor cloud explosion blast modelling. Experimental investigation of the key parameters and blast modelling
Source title: Institution of Chemical Engineers Symposium Series

Abstract: The Multi-Energy method for vapor cloud explosion blast modeling is presented and demonstrated in a case study. The Multi-Energy method constitutes an alternative for conventional TNT-equivalency methods which are unsatisfactory in several aspects. The Multi-Energy concept as it is, however, is only a framework which has to be completed with additional data. These data can be generated in various ways dependent on the available time and budget. In particular, the use of computational fluid dynamics within the Multi-Energy framework enables an increasingly sophisticated approach in vapor cloud explosion hazard analysis.

Authors: Brogan John J.
Title: Overview of the U.S. Department of Energy's Electric Vehicle Program
Affiliations: U.S. Dept of Energy, Washington, United States
Authors with affiliations: Brogan, John J., U.S. Dept of Energy, Washington, United States
Abstract: The need for pollution-free motor vehicles has been demonstrated many times. Leading candidate powerplants to meet this requirement are the electric battery and/or fuel cell systems. This paper summarizes the organization of the Government's activities, accomplishments, and ongoing research and development of these powerplants. The Department of Energy's (DOE) electric propulsion systems program is organized into three areas: advanced battery systems, fuel cell systems, and advanced technology development. Each area is described.

Authors: Mollhoff T., Sukehiro S., Hendrickx M., Van Belle H., Flameng W.
Title: Effects of hypothermic ischemia on purine catabolism in canine, primate, and human myocardium
Affiliations: Klinik und Poliklinik fur, Anasthesiologie und, Operative Intensivmedizin, Albert-Schweitzer-Strasse 33, W-4400 Munster, Belgium
Authors with affiliations: Mollhoff, T., Klinik und Poliklinik fur, Anasthesiologie und, Operative Intensivmedizin, Albert-Schweitzer-Strasse 33, W-4400 Munster, Belgium; Sukehiro, S., Klinik und Poliklinik fur, Anasthesiologie und, Operative Intensivmedizin, Albert-Schweitzer-Strasse 33, W-4400 Munster, Belgium; Hendrickx, M., Klinik und Poliklinik fur, Anasthesiologie und, Operative Intensivmedizin, Albert-Schweitzer-Strasse 33, W-4400 Munster, Belgium; Van Belle, H., Klinik und Poliklinik fur, Anasthesiologie und, Operative Intensivmedizin, Albert-Schweitzer-Strasse 33, W-4400 Munster, Belgium; Flameng, W., Klinik und Poliklinik fur, Anasthesiologie und, Operative Intensivmedizin, Albert-Schweitzer-Strasse 33, W-4400 Munster, Belgium
Abstract: After hypothermic cardiac arrest, creatine phosphate (CrP) and adenine nucleotide catabolism was compared in myocardium from dogs (n = 7), baboons (n = 5), and man (n = 7; patients undergoing cardiac transplantation) during cold (0.5 °C) storage for up to 24 hours. Although hypothermia delayed the catabolism in dog myocardium it still remained very extensive. CrP dropped to virtually nil and ATP fell to below 15% of the total purines within 6 hours. The majority of the adenine nucleotides was broken down to adenosine (ADO; 32% of total purines) and inosine (INO; 21%). Apart from the delay (7 to 9-fold), hypothermia also reversed the ratio between ADO and INO when compared to normothermia, suggesting a profound effect of temperature on the nucleoside transporter. In human myocardium even after 12 hours of hypothermia ATP still contributed more than 60% to the total purines. Concomitantly, nucleoside formation proceeded slowly with almost no intermediate ADO. Under similar conditions, the catabolism of ATP in baboon myocardium occurred at a higher rate than in man but still far below canine metabolism. Irrespective of the relatively higher fall in ATP, ADP and AMP accumulated more in baboon myocardium indicating a limited dephosphorylation of the nucleotides. Only in the baboon myocardium did inosine monophosphate increase above the detection limits. In none of the species did purine catabolism proceed beyond hypoxanthine and even this could hardly be detected in the primates. It is concluded that considerable species differences do exist in the rate as well as in the pattern of nucleotide catabolism even during storage of the myocardium at low temperature.
Author Keywords: baboons; dogs; donor heart storage; high-energy phosphate level; hypothermic preservation; man
Index Keywords: endogenous compound; article; baboon; dog; heart muscle ischemia; heart preservation; heart transplantation; high energy phosphate; human; hypothermia; nonhuman; priority journal

Authors: Dou S.X., Liu H.K., Wang J., Apperley M.H., Sorrell C.C.
Title: Critical current density at 77K in magnetic field in silver-clad superconducting Bi-Pb-Sr-Ca-Cu-O
Affiliations: Univ of New South Wales, Sydney
Authors with affiliations: Dou, S.X., Univ of New South Wales, Sydney; Liu, H.K., Univ of New South Wales, Sydney; Wang, J., Univ of New South Wales, Sydney; Apperley, M.H., Univ of New South Wales, Sydney; Sorrell, C.C., Univ of New South Wales, Sydney
Abstract: Weak flux pinning strength and concomitant low current density of Bi-based high-Tc superconductors, especially for bulk materials, have been obstacles to large-scale applications in power engineering, electronics, and energy storage. These problems have been attempted to be overcome by methods such as grain alignment, and introduction of impurity precipitates and defects. The Jc of metal-clad Bi-based tapes has been reported to be as high as 10000 A/cm2 at 77K and zero field. The high Jc was ascribed to a combination of elimination of the poisoning effect of Ag on the superconductor, grain alignment through cold rolling, enhancement of flux pinning through chemical doping, and fast formation of the 110K (Bi, Pb) SrCaCuO (2223) phase through powder processing by freeze drying. The present work describes some of the processing parameters of Bi-Pb-Sr-Ca-Cu-O that were used to increase Jc under magnetic field, the resultant microstructures, and potential pinning through the anisotropy of materials.
Index Keywords: Ceramic Materials--Superconductivity; Copper Oxides--Processing; Electric Measurements--Current Distribution; Magnetic Field Effects; Bismuth Lead Strontium Calcium Copper Oxides; Critical Current Density; Flux Pinning Strength; Silver Clad Superconductor; Silver Effects; High Temperature Superconductors

Authors: Quigley Jr. Richard E., Massie Lowell D.
Title: Future trends in space power technology
Source title: Proceedings of the Intersociety Energy Conversion Engineering Conference
Affiliations: Aero Propulsion and Power, Directorate
Authors with affiliations: Quigley Jr., Richard E., Aero Propulsion and Power, Directorate; Massie, Lowell D., Aero Propulsion and Power, Directorate
Abstract: This paper summarizes the status of the Air Force Space Power Research and Development Program and describes the current generic issues and requirements affecting the Strategic Planning of Space Power advancements for the duration of the millennium and beyond. The paper highlights the major thrusts of the Air Force part of the Strategic Defense Initiative Office (SDIO) Space Power Program with emphasis on the on-going advanced component technology development program. The current status of these component technologies in the areas of (a) Power Sources (b) Energy Storage (c) Power Management and Distribution and (d) Thermal Management are described. Technology projections for the full range of envisioned technology options for the disciplines defined in (a) through (d) above are used as the basis for a series of point designs to derive the subsystem and system level benefits of the various technologies. The primary focus of the paper is on baseload (CW) power systems operating in the range from 100 Watts ('Small-Sats'/'Light-Sats') to 50 Kilowatts for potential large surveillance satellites of the future. The secondary focus is on large, multi-megawatt pulsed power systems and related components for potential future applications such as directed energy. The time frame from 1991 (present) through the year 2010 has been selected for illustrating the component and subsystem/system technologies of interest. Major drivers such as performance, reliability, durability, practicality, survivability and affordability issues are considered as appropriate. Finally, potential 'Trump Card' technologies related to energy conversion, storage, power electronics and thermal management are identified for the relative near-term (CY 1993) to far-term (Post-CY2000) time frame.
Index Keywords: Electric Batteries - Space Applications; Electric Inverters - Space Applications; Electric Power Systems; Photovoltaic Cells; Array Concepts; Hydrogen Cooled Generators; Space Power Technology; Thermal Management; Thermionic Energy Conversion; Spacecraft

Authors: Webb P.R.
Title: Remote area power supplies, 'The Hybrid System'
Source title: National Conference Publication - Institution of Engineers, Australia
Authors with affiliations: Webb, P.R.
Abstract: The Diesel Hybrid System uses an intermittently operated, automatically controlled diesel generator to charge energy storage cells. This is combined with an inverter to provide 24 hour AC power supply. The diesel is operated at full power typically only 6 hours per day. As a result the power generated per litre of fuel is much higher than in conventional systems where much time is spent at very low loads. Total running hours are reduced, maintenance costs are reduced and high peak load capacities can be provided. Power supplied is standard 50Hz sine wave AC as in conventional power networks. All standard appliances can be operated without modification. The Standard Diesel Hybrid System comprises of an AC power source, typically a diesel, an AC DC converter, a bank of storage cells, a solid state inverter, optionally a DC DC regulator with a rotary converter and related monitoring and control electronics. Auxiliary energy sources which produce either DC or AC (such as solar or wind generation) can be incorporated. A Diesel Hybrid system can be integrated into any existing generating system from 2-500kW and upwards which has significant differences between peak and average demands and achieve significant fuel savings. Systems have been installed and operational in the Northern Territory for several years.
Index Keywords: Diesel Electric Power Plants; Electric Batteries; Electric Converters, Static; Electric Generators, Synchronous; Electric Inverters; AC-DC Converter; DC-AC Rotary Converter; Diesel Hybrid System; Dual Inverter Dual Battery System; Solid State Static Inverters; Stand Alone Diesel System; Electric Power Systems

Authors: Hafen Douglas
Title: Comparison of Nickel-Hydrogen and Nickel-Cadmium reliability
Source title: Proceedings of the Intersociety Energy Conversion Engineering Conference
Affiliations: Lockheed Missiles and Space Co., Inc, Sunnyvale, United States
Authors with affiliations: Hafen, Douglas, Lockheed Missiles and Space Co., Inc, Sunnyvale, United States
Abstract: Nickel-Hydrogen (NiH2) realtime and accelerated low-earth-orbit (LEO) cycle test data at 10°C have been used to generate a model of reliability as a function of depth-of-discharge (DOD). A cycle life prediction has also been derived from the reliability equation and has been compared to a prediction generated for Nickel-Cadmium (NiCd) hardware. The comparison clearly shows the superiority of NiH2 in LEO. At each DOD for which test data existed in the 5°C to 10°C range, the real time and accelerated LEO life cycle test data were best-fit to a Weibull distribution by a method that accounts for cells removed from test without a failure. The analysis was performed for the 40%, 60% and 80% DOD test conditions for NiH2, and at DOD's ranging from 15% to 50% for NiCd. The end result of the cell reliability analysis is a plot of cell probability of success (PS) versus cycle time. The PS graph may be converted to a graph of expected cycle life for the case of a battery, given number of cells per battery and a value for required battery reliability. Low earth orbit life test data at 10°C shows that NiH2 has a superior cycle life to the established NiCd system. In conjunction with the energy density advantage, NiH2 is clearly the system of choice for both GEO and LEO missions requiring high reliability and longer life.
Index Keywords: Energy Storage - Space Applications; Nickel Cadmium Alloys; Accelerated Low-Earth -Orbit (LEO) Cycle Test; Geosynchronous (GEO) Energy Storage; Low Earth Orbit Life Test Data; Martin-Marietta Nickel-Hydrogen Tests; Nickel Cadmium Analysis; Nickel Hydrogen Analysis; Electric Batteries

Authors: Wild Urs P., Renn Alois
Title: Molecular computing. A review. I. Data and image storage
Affiliations: Swiss Federal Inst of Technology, Zurich, Switzerland
Authors with affiliations: Wild, Urs P., Swiss Federal Inst of Technology, Zurich, Switzerland; Renn, Alois, Swiss Federal Inst of Technology, Zurich, Switzerland
Abstract: A review is presented of the method of spectral hole-burning and its application to data and image storage. This spectroscopic method promises extremely high data storage capacities through its wavelength multiplexing property. Fundamentals such as supramolecular photochemistry, inhomogeneous line broading, energy selection and holography are outlined. The inclusion of the electric field dimension leads to a four-dimensional data and image storage device. Two-dimensional data arrays or images are stored at given values of the optical frequency and of an externally applied electric field. In storage devices with extremely large capacity, transportation of the information becomes the real bottleneck, and parallel access and processing become essential. Molecular computing opens a way to perform parallel logical operations between stored data arrays. The feasibility of such a device has recently been demonstrated in the laboratory.
Index Keywords: Image Storage; Molecular Computing; Molecular Data Storage; Molecular Image Storage; Spectral Hole Burning; Wavelength Multiplexing; Chemical Reactions - Photochemical Reactions; Electric Field Effects; Holography; Molecules; Multiplexing; Data Storage, Optical

Authors: Isobe Hiroshi, Sato Eiichi, Kimura Shingo, Tamakawa Yoshiharu, Yanagisawa Toru, Honda Keiji, Yokota Yoshiharu
Title: Repetitive flash x-ray generator utilizing an enclosed-type diode with a ring-shaped graphite cathode
Source title: Proceedings of SPIE - The International Society for Optical Engineering
Affiliations: Iwate Medical Univ, Morioka, Japan
Authors with affiliations: Isobe, Hiroshi, Iwate Medical Univ, Morioka, Japan; Sato, Eiichi, Iwate Medical Univ, Morioka, Japan; Kimura, Shingo, Iwate Medical Univ, Morioka, Japan; Tamakawa, Yoshiharu, Iwate Medical Univ, Morioka, Japan; Yanagisawa, Toru, Iwate Medical Univ, Morioka, Japan; Honda, Keiji, Iwate Medical Univ, Morioka, Japan; Yokota, Yoshiharu, Iwate Medical Univ, Morioka, Japan
Abstract: The fundamental studies of the repetitive type of flash x-ray generator utilizing an enclosed-type diode with a ring-shaped graphite cathode for soft radiography are described. This generator consisted of the following essential components: a constant high-voltage power supply, an energy storage condenser of 100nF, a high-voltage pulser, a repetitive impulse switching system, and a flash x-ray tube. The pulser employed a modified two-stage Marx circuit with a capacity during main discharge of 425pF. The x-ray tube was of the enclosed-diode type and consisted of the following major devices: a rod-shaped anode tip made of tungsten, a ring cathode made of graphite, an x-ray window made of beryllium, a spattering shield made of stainless steel, and a tube body made of glass. Two condensers in the pulser were charged from 50 to 70kV, and the output voltage was about 1.6 times the charged voltage. Both the peak tube voltage and the peak tube current increased according to increases in the charged voltage, and the maximum values of the voltage and the current were about 90kV and 0.5kA, respectively. The pulse width was about 100ns, and the x-ray intensity was less than 2.0μC/kg at 0.5m per pulse. The repetition frequency was less than 50Hz, and the maximum size of the effective focal spot was nearly equivalent to the anode diameter of 3.0mm.
Index Keywords: Cathodes; Electron Tubes, Diode; Pulse Generators; Radiography; Flash X-Rays; Focal Spot; Ring-Shaped Graphite Cathode; Soft Radiography; X-Ray Generator; X-Ray Apparatus

Authors: Muller M.J., Fenk A., Lautz H.U., Selberg O., Canzler H., Balks H.J., Von Zur Muhlen A., Schmidt E., Schmidt F.W.
Title: Energy expenditure and substrate metabolism in ethanol-induced liver cirrhosis
Source title: American Journal of Physiology - Endocrinology and Metabolism
Affiliations: Medizinische Hochschule Hann., Dept. Innere Medizin/Dermato., Abt. Gastroenterologie, Konstanty-Gutschow-Str. 8, D-3000 Hannover 61, Germany

Gastroenterologie, Konstanty-Gutschow-Str. 8, D-3000 Hannover 61, Germany; Canzler, H., Medizinische Hochschule Hann., Dept. Innere Medizin/Dermato., Abt. Gastroenterologie, Konstanty-Gutschow-Str. 8, D-3000 Hannover 61, Germany; Balks, H.J., Medizinische Hochschule Hann., Dept. Innere Medizin/Dermato., Abt. Gastroenterologie, Konstanty-Gutschow-Str. 8, D-3000 Hannover 61, Germany; Von Zur Muhlen, A., Medizinische Hochschule Hann., Dept. Innere Medizin/Dermato., Abt. Gastroenterologie, Konstanty-Gutschow-Str. 8, D-3000 Hannover 61, Germany; Schmidt, E., Medizinische Hochschule Hann., Dept. Innere Medizin/Dermato., Abt. Gastroenterologie, Konstanty-Gutschow-Str. 8, D-3000 Hannover 61, Germany; Schmidt, F.W., Medizinische Hochschule Hann., Dept. Innere Medizin/Dermato., Abt. Gastroenterologie, Konstanty-Gutschow-Str. 8, D-3000 Hannover 61, Germany
Abstract: Energy expenditure and substrate metabolism were investigated in 10 patients with alcoholic liver cirrhosis (EtOH-Ci) and 10 healthy controls (C). Resting metabolic rate (RMR) varied from 1,269 to 2,467 kcal/day in C and from 1,228 to 2,098 kcal/day in EtOH-Ci. RMR was significantly related to fat-free mass (FFM) in both groups, but EtOH-Ci decreased FFM and increased RMR when expressed per kilogram FFM (+33%). Glucose intolerance, hyperinsulinemia, and a decreased C-peptide-to-insulin ratio were observed in EtOH-Ci after a test meal. Concomitantly, nonoxidative glucose metabolism was reduced in association with normal increases in glucose oxidation. EtOH-Ci reduced insulin sensitivity (-59%) and maximal insulin-dependent glucose disposal (-40%) during a sequential two-step glucose clamp protocol (phase 1: 1 mU·kg body wt-1·min-1 insulin infusion rate + euglycemia; phase 2: 4 mU·kg body wt-1·min-1 insulin infusion rate + 165 mg/dl plasma glucose concentration). This was explained by reduced glucose storage (-99%, -51%) in association with normal responses in glucose oxidation rate, plasma lactate concentration, lipid oxidation rate, and rate of lipogenesis. Defective glucose storage was independent of reduced FFM. EtOH-Ci increased glucose-induced thermogenesis by 57%. We conclude that increased resting metabolic rate, enhanced thermogenesis, defective glucose storage, and normal glucose oxidation together result in increased energy needs and favor negative energy balance in patients with alcoholic cirrhosis.
Author Keywords: Glucose metabolism; Insulin resistance; Thermogenesis

Authors: Bosch Jr. Robert J., Carter Chris C.
Title: Early deployment of the MRS the Modular Vault Dry Store
Affiliations: Foster Wheeler Energy Corp, Livingston, United States
Authors with affiliations: Bosch Jr., Robert J., Foster Wheeler Energy Corp, Livingston, United States; Carter, Chris C., Foster Wheeler Energy Corp, Livingston, United States
Abstract: The Nuclear Waste Policy Amendments Act of 1987 (NWPAA) authorized the Department of Energy to site, construct, and operate Monitored Retrievable Storage. The Modular Vault Dry Store is a technology which has been in commercial operation in the United Kingdom for 20 years. Recently, this technology has been adapted to the requirements of Light Water Reactor Spent Fuel. This technology is ideally suited for use in the United States Department of Energy's Monitored Retrievable Storage (MRS) Program. It is available now for deployment, meeting all the requirements of a MRS.
Index Keywords: Nuclear Industry--Legislation; Nuclear Reactors, Light Water--Spent Fuels; Modular Vault Dry Store; Monitored Retrievable Storage Facility; Nuclear Spent Fuel Storage; Nuclear Waste Policy Amendments Act 1987; Radioactive Wastes

Authors: Parrish Clyde F., Scaringe Robert P., Pratt David M.
Title: Development of an innovative spacecraft thermal storage device
Source title: Proceedings of the Intersociety Energy Conversion Engineering Conference
Affiliations: Mainstream Engineering Corp, Rockledge, United States
Authors with affiliations: Parrish, Clyde F., Mainstream Engineering Corp, Rockledge, United States; Scaringe, Robert P., Mainstream Engineering Corp, Rockledge, United States; Pratt, David M., Mainstream Engineering Corp, Rockledge, United States
Abstract: Several adsorbent-refrigerant pairs have been examined which demonstrate that this innovative heat-pump-adsorption storage device (HPASD) can provide significant thermal storage in a vapor-compression heat pump. An adsorption bed was built to test the validity of the concept. The results of the laboratory experiments supported the information derived from the adsorption models. The thermal storage capacity of HPASD systems with methanol on calcium chloride as the adsorbent pair was 54.8 kJ/kg with a radiator area of 17 m2 for a 50-kW peak thermal load. Values for a pumped loop were 15 kJ/kg with a 202-m2 radiator area. Heat pumps with methanol as the working fluid have a storage capacity of 24 kJ/kg and a radiator area of 70 m2. Phase change materials have values in the range of 12.6 kJ/kg (n-octadecane with a 30 degree delta T) to 37 kJ/kg (gallium with a 10 degree delta T). The radiator areas for these phase change systems range from 225 to 43 m2 respectively. Data collected to date indicate that the HPASD device has superior thermal storage characteristics when compared with other systems under typical use conditions.
Index Keywords: Adsorption; Energy Storage; Fluids; Heat Pump Systems; Methanol; Gallium; Thermal Storage Devices; Spacecraft

Authors: Kay D., Highgate D., Knight C., Probert S.D.
Title: Fluidised beds as 'coolth' stores
Affiliations: Department of Applied Energy, Cranfield Institute of Technology, Bedford, MK43 0AL, United Kingdom
Authors with affiliations: Kay, D., Department of Applied Energy, Cranfield Institute of Technology, Bedford, MK43 0AL, United Kingdom; Highgate, D., Department of Applied Energy, Cranfield Institute of Technology, Bedford, MK43 0AL, United Kingdom; Knight, C., Department of Applied Energy, Cranfield Institute of Technology, Bedford, MK43 0AL, United Kingdom; Probert, S.D., Department of Applied Energy, Cranfield Institute of Technology, Bedford, MK43 0AL, United Kingdom
Abstract: High energy-density thermal storage at low temperatures is feasible using phase-change materials. Thus an energy-storage device has been conceived which uses water-absorbing cross-linked polymers, known as hydrophilic materials. These were produced in the form of particles, which can be hydrated. Experiments have been carried out in which hydrophilic particles were fluidised in oil, using concentrations of hydrated particles up to 40% by weight. Energy storage, regularly well in excess of 50% of the theoretical capacity, has been achieved, although, for the maximum value, it was necessary to reduce the mixture temperature to about -8° C. © 1991.
Index Keywords: Heat Transfer - Fluidized Beds; Polymers - Moisture; Cold Storage; Hydrophilic Polymers; Thermal Energy Storage; Energy Storage

Authors: Kostic M.
Title: Fluid viscoelasticity versus steady shear viscosity
Source title: American Society of Mechanical Engineers, Heat Transfer Division, (Publication) HTD
Affiliations: Northern Illinois Univ, DeKalb, United States
Authors with affiliations: Kostic, M., Northern Illinois Univ, DeKalb, United States
Abstract: Viscoelastic fluids in addition to the viscosity exhibit certain elastic properties such as the ability to store energy or deformation. Fluid elasticity is usually expressed by a characteristic (relaxation) time, which is often deduced from the steady shear viscosity measurements by using some model equation with a time constant in it. Such an empirical procedure is convenient but it is not always appropriate. A critical discussion compares this procedure with that of correlating a material strength to its hardness.
Index Keywords: Stresses--Shear; Relaxation Time; Steady Shear Viscosity; Storage Modulus; Fluids

Authors: Kerslake Thomas W.
Title: Experiments with phase change thermal energy storage canisters for Space Station Freedom
Source title: Proceedings of the Intersociety Energy Conversion Engineering Conference
Affiliations: Natl Aeronautics and Space, Administration, Cleveland, United States
Authors with affiliations: Kerslake, Thomas W., Natl Aeronautics and Space, Administration, Cleveland, United States
Abstract: The solar dynamic power module proposed for the growth Space Station Freedom uses the heat of fusion of a phase change material (PCM) to efficiently store thermal energy for use during eclipse periods. The PCM, a LiF-20CaF2 salt, is contained in annular, metal canisters located in a heat receiver at the focus of a solar concentrator. This paper discusses PCM canister ground-based experiments and analytical heat transfer studies. The hardware, test procedures, and test results from these experiments are discussed. After more than 900 simulated Space Station Freedom orbital cycles, no canister cracks or leaks were observed and all data were successfully collected. The effect of 1-g test orientation on canister wall temperatures was generally small while void position was strongly dependent on test orientation and canister cooling. In one test orientation, alternating wall temperature data were measured that supports an earlier theory of oscillating vortex flow in the PCM melt. Analytical canister wall temperatures compared very favorably with experimental temperature data. This illustrates that ground-based canister thermal performance can be predicted well by analyses that employ straight-forward, engineering models of void behavior and liquid PCM free convection. Because of the accuracy of analytical models and the relative insensitivity of 1-g performance to test orientation, canister performance in micro-g should be predictable with a high degree of confidence by removing gravity effects from the analytical modeling.
Index Keywords: Calcium Compounds; Heating--Heat Storage; Lithium Compounds; Solar Energy; Phase Change Materials; Space Station Freedom; Space Stations

Authors: Reardon S.A.
Title: Paper industry energy usage
Source title: National Conference Publication - Institution of Engineers, Australia
Affiliations: Univ of Tasmania
Authors with affiliations: Reardon, S.A., Univ of Tasmania
Abstract: The paper industry is heavily reliant upon energy to create value-added products from local forest resources. Both the generation of pulp from woodchips and the forming of the final paper sheet are energy intensive processes. Operations at Australian Newsprint Mills (ANM), Boyer, require more than 80 MW each of hydro-electricity and steam from a coal-fired boiler. Comparison of the three separate pulping streams at the mill shows the labour-intensive traditional method of stone-grinding to be less economically attractive than the electricity dependent thermo-mechanical pulping process which offers heat recovery in the form of low pressure steam as a by-product. In the area of paper-making energy costs are dominated by the use of steam-heated drying cylinders to evaporate water from the paper web. However, mill operations now proceed against the backdrop of reduced hydro water storages and the possibility of power rationing in the future. ANM's recently commissioned boiler offers the potential for 10-15 MW co-generated power and this may be exploited depending upon future events.
Index Keywords: Boiler Firing--Coal; Cogeneration Plants; Electric Power Generation; Mathematical Techniques--Numerical Methods; Paper and Pulp Mills--Equipment; Australian Newsprint Mills; Energy Intensive Processes; Energy Usage; Hydro-electricity; Paper-making Energy Costs; Stone-grinding; Paper and Pulp Industry

Authors: Tremblay D., Savoie P., Theriault R.
Title: Self-loading wagon power requirement for coarse chopping of forage
Affiliations: Universite Laval, Quebec, Canada
Authors with affiliations: Tremblay, D., Universite Laval, Quebec, Canada; Savoie, P., Universite Laval, Quebec, Canada; Theriault, R., Universite Laval, Quebec, Canada
Abstract: The self-loading forage wagon integrates a pick-up reel, a coarse cutting mechanism, a mechanical conveyor and a large capacity wagon. It replaces the traditional silage harvest system composed of a forage harvester, two or three traveling wagons from field to the storage site and an unloading mechanism. Power requirements were measured at harvest with a forage harvester at 6.35 mm theoretical length of cut (TLC) and with a self-loading wagon at 20, 40 and 60 mm TLC, and at two moisture levels (70 and 80% on a west basis). The forage harvester (New Holland 782) required an average specific energy of 26.5 MJ/t DM at a real length of cut of 11.3 mm. The self-loading wagon (TAARUP 1030) required an average specific energy of 5.2 MJ/t DM. The real lengths of cut were 42.4, 70.4 and 93.3 mm. A multiple linear regression was performed on the data collected with the self-loading wagon. The equation explained 60% (R2 adjusted = 0.60) of power requirement variance at the power take-off. A global equation was developed to evaluate overall tractor power requirement. The overall power, including a safety factor of 25%, varied between 47 and 81 kW. When comparing the self-loading wagon with a forage harvester, it was observed that the self-loading wagon would not reduce the harvest tractor size but it would reduce fuel, labor, and the number of tractors required for the same harvest rate.
Index Keywords: Agricultural Machinery - Energy Utilization; Agricultural Products - Processing; Machinery - Automation; Tractors - Testing; Forage; Power Requirements; Self-Loading Wagons; Agricultural Machinery

Authors: Csige I., Hunyadi I., Charvat J.
Title: Environmental effects on induction time and sensitivity of different types of CR-39
Affiliations: Inst of Nuclear Research, Debrecen, Hungary
Authors with affiliations: Csige, I., Inst of Nuclear Research, Debrecen, Hungary; Hunyadi, I., Inst of Nuclear Research, Debrecen, Hungary; Charvat, J., Inst of Nuclear Research, Debrecen, Hungary
Abstract: The track registration properties of different types of CR-39 solid state nuclear track detectors (MA-ND, Pershore, Tastrak) were studied in vacuum for alpha particles with different energies. The alpha particle response is characterized by the etch induction time and the etch rate ratio. It is found that the etch induction time increases and the etch rate ratio decreases in vacuum and different types of CR-39 show different behavior. The role of the pre outgassing time and post storage time in vacuum in the latent track formation is discussed. The effect of storage time in normal air at different temperatures was also studied in a three year period. A slow but definite decrease of sensitivity was observed, which was negligible at lower temperature.
Index Keywords: Alpha Particles; Cellulosic Resins; Etching; CR-39 Detectors; Solid State Nuclear Track Detectors; Particle Detectors

Authors: Nakhamkin M., Swensen E.C., Abitante P.A., Whims M., Weiner D., Vadasz P., Brokman S.
Title: Conceptual engineering of a 300-MW CAES plant part 1: cost effectiveness analysis
Affiliations: Energy Storage & Power, Consultants, Inc (ESPC), Mountainside, United States
Authors with affiliations: Nakhamkin, M., Energy Storage & Power, Consultants, Inc (ESPC), Mountainside, United States; Swensen, E.C., Energy Storage & Power, Consultants, Inc (ESPC), Mountainside, United States; Abitante, P.A., Energy Storage & Power, Consultants, Inc (ESPC), Mountainside, United States; Whims, M., Energy Storage & Power, Consultants, Inc (ESPC), Mountainside, United States; Weiner, D., Energy Storage & Power, Consultants, Inc (ESPC), Mountainside, United States; Vadasz, P., Energy Storage & Power, Consultants, Inc (ESPC), Mountainside, United States; Brokman, S., Energy Storage & Power, Consultants, Inc (ESPC), Mountainside, United States
Abstract: This paper presents the results of a project performed for the Israel Electric Corporation, Ltd. (IEC), with the objective of developing the most cost-effective and technically feasible 300-MW CAES-plant concept with underground storage in an aquiferous reservoir. Three conceptually different turbomachinery trains are analyzed, including one based on the use of state-of-the-art combustion turbine components with high firing temperatures. The results are reported for each turbomachinery train concept, optimized for the geological conditions of two alternative underground-storage sites. Along with other generic findings, the paper concludes with the selection of a turbomachinery train, its cycle parameters and configuration, and underground storage site to be used for further preliminary engineering and cost estimates. The results are generalized for use in future CAES projects.
Index Keywords: Cost Accounting; Gas Turbines; Power Plants - Costs; Product Design - Optimization; Turbomachinery; Compressed Air Energy Storage Plants; Cost Effectiveness Analysis; Turbomachinery Train Approach; Underground Storage Optimization; Compressed Air

Authors: Hollandsworth Roger P., Symons Philip C., Bailey Patrick G.
Title: Comparison of pem fuel cell systems for both open and closed loop applications
Source title: Proceedings of the Intersociety Energy Conversion Engineering Conference
Affiliations: Lockheed Missiles & Space Co, Palo Alto, United States
Authors with affiliations: Hollandsworth, Roger P., Lockheed Missiles & Space Co, Palo Alto, United States; Symons, Philip C., Lockheed Missiles & Space Co, Palo Alto, United States; Bailey, Patrick G., Lockheed Missiles & Space Co, Palo Alto, United States
Abstract: A specialized computer modeling technique was developed to evaluate possible candidates for the DARPA/Navy Unmanned Underwater Vehicle energy technology program and to compare them on a normalized basis. The computer model considered reactants and products chemistry, storage, electrochemical energy conversion efficiency, and the viability of using seawater as a reactant. The modeling results clearly indicate superior energy capacity for LiH, LiAlH4, or CaH2 fuels with liquid oxygen compared to any of the non-metal hydride fueled systems considered, including the Al/LOX and CH3OH/LOX systems. Details of the computer modeling technique are reported. In the hydride studies, water is assumed to react directly within a hydride fuel tank to produce the hydrogen gas required for operation of the fuel cell. The hydroxide product formed by this reaction remains in the tank. The tanks have been sized in these analyses to include the effects of possible larger volume required for the product (as in the case of CaH2 and LiAlH4), and also include a spatial void packing factor.
Index Keywords: Chemical Analysis; Hydrides - Applications; Aluminum Oxygen Battery; Closed Loop Fuel Cells; Fuel/Oxidant Computer Model; Hydride Chemistry; PEM Fuel Cell Systems; Product Pumping Effects; Fuel Cells

Authors: Wilkins E.
Title: Operation of a commercial solar gel pond
Affiliations: Department of Chemical and Nuclear Engineering, The University of New Mexico, Albuquerque, NM 87131, United States
Authors with affiliations: Wilkins, E., Department of Chemical and Nuclear Engineering, The University of New Mexico, Albuquerque, NM 87131, United States
Abstract: The solar gel pond is an innovative concept which overcomes many of the shortcomings of the conventional salt-gradient solar pond. In this paper, the design, construction and start-up details of a commercial scale pond (400 m2), built for a publishing company in Albuquerque, New Mexico will be presented. A pond with trapezoidal cross section was designed so that shadowing could be minimized and also the ratio of surface area to the volume of the storage zone could be maximized. The publishing company required a minimum of 1 GJ/day (1MBTU/day). Generally it has been noted that in ponds with large volume a lesser percentage of retained energy is lost as edge losses. Based on the above consideration a pond size of 400 m2 and 5 m deep with a gel thickness of 60 cm and a mass flow rate (for the heat extraction loop) of 1 × 10-4 to 1 × 10-3 kg/m2·sec was determined to be the optimum size for the publishing company's needs. Two to seven percent salt water was used mainly to keep the gel bags floating on the surface. Tedlar bags were used to contain the gel. During the first year of operation, while the pond was still heating up, the pond obtained a temperature of 60°C and the gel showed no signs of degradation. © 1991.
Index Keywords: Gels - Applications; Water Resources - Saline Water; Commercial Solar Gel Pond; Shadow Minimization; Trapezoidal Cross Section Pond; Solar Radiation

Authors: Schade D.W., Weise T.H.G.G., Braunsberger U.E., Salge J.G.H.
Title: Metal-to-metal-switches for large currents
Affiliations: Institut für Hochspannungstechnik, Technische Universität Braunschweig, Postfach 3329, D-3300, Braunschweig, Germany
Authors with affiliations: Schade, D.W., Institut für Hochspannungstechnik, Technische Universität Braunschweig, Postfach 3329, D-3300, Braunschweig, Germany; Weise, T.H.G.G., Institut für Hochspannungstechnik, Technische Universität Braunschweig, Postfach 3329, D-3300, Braunschweig, Germany; Braunsberger, U.E., Institut für Hochspannungstechnik, Technische Universität Braunschweig, Postfach 3329, D-3300, Braunschweig, Germany; Salge, J.G.H., Institut für Hochspannungstechnik, Technische Universität Braunschweig, Postfach 3329, D-3300, Braunschweig, Germany
Abstract: The operation of electromagnetic rail launchers requires switching large currents. For rail gun accelerators with driving currents of some MA it is important to keep the resistance of the total energy supply circuit small compared to that of the moving projectile, which is velocity dependent and low. Among the great variety of switches which can be used for this purpose those with metallic contacts offer the advantage that their ohmic resistance in the closed position can be kept more than an order of magnitude smaller than gas discharge or solid state switches. The paper reviews existing metal contact switches, originally developed mainly for nuclear fusion research experiments, and discusses their properties with respect to an application in large capacitor banks for linear mass accelerators. © 1991 IEEE
Index Keywords: Accelerators; Energy Storage; Nuclear Energy - Fusion Reactions; Capacitor Banks; Large Currents; Metal-To-Metal Switches; Electric Switches

Authors: Halama H.J., Foerster C.L.
Title: Comparison of photodesorption yields from aluminum, stainless and Cu-plated beam tubes
Affiliations: National Synchroton Light Source, Brookhaven National Laboratory, Upton, NY 11973, United States
Authors with affiliations: Halama, H.J., National Synchroton Light Source, Brookhaven National Laboratory, Upton, NY 11973, United States; Foerster, C.L., National Synchroton Light Source, Brookhaven National Laboratory, Upton, NY 11973, United States
Abstract: Photon Stimulated Desorption (PSD) from the walls of beam ducts constitutes the most serious gas load in storage rings and therefore exerts a great influence on both beam quality and lifetime. With the exception of the SSC which plans to use a Cu-plated beam tube, all existing and proposed machines use either aluminum or stainless steel beam tubes. In order to develop techniques for producing surfaces with the lowest PSD, we have studied the above materials using dedicated beam line at the National Synchroton Light Source (NSLS). Three meter long tubes were exposed to white light beams having critical energy of 500 eV and the desorption yields were measured as a function of beam dose. Several treatments commonly used for cleaning surfaces (prebaked, baked, fired, chemically cleaned and dc glow discharged) were investigated, and their relative merits are discussed. The results from sample tube measurements are compared with those from the X-ray ring Al beam tube during operation. The agreement is found to be quite good. Glow discharge cleaned stainless steel exhibited the lowest desorption yield. © 1991.
Index Keywords: Aluminum; Copper plating; Desorption; Glow discharges; Light sources; Tubes (components); Gases - Desorption; Photons - Effects; Cleaning surfaces; Critical energy; Desorption yield; National synchroton light sources; Photo-desorption; Photon stimulated desorption; Plated beams; White-light beams; Stainless steel; Accelerators; Beam Tubes; Photodesorption; Photon Simulated Desorption

Authors: Selvam P., Viswanathan B., Swamy C.S., Srinivasan V.
Title: Surface properties of LaNi5: A reinvestigation
Affiliations: Laboratory of Interdisciplinary X-ray Crystallography, University of Geneva, 24, Quai E. Ansermet, CH-1211 Geneva 4, Switzerland; Department of Chemistry, Indian Institute of Technology, Madras, 600 036 Tamil Nadu, India
Authors with affiliations: Selvam, P., Laboratory of Interdisciplinary X-ray Crystallography, University of Geneva, 24, Quai E. Ansermet, CH-1211 Geneva 4, Switzerland, Department of Chemistry, Indian Institute of Technology, Madras, 600 036 Tamil Nadu, India; Viswanathan, B., Department of Chemistry, Indian Institute of Technology, Madras, 600 036 Tamil Nadu, India; Swamy, C.S., Department of Chemistry, Indian Institute of Technology, Madras, 600 036 Tamil Nadu, India; Srinivasan, V., Department of Chemistry, Indian Institute of Technology, Madras, 600 036 Tamil Nadu, India
Abstract: Although a number of surface analysis reports are available on the LaNi5 system, yet a clear picture of the actual species involved and their consequences on the activation and deactivation processes has not been reached. Moreover, differences of opinion have been seen among the researchers. The present results distinctly indicate that the air exposed samples are completely contaminated with a variety of oxygenated species (such as oxides, hydroxides and carbonates) of the constituent elements, hitherto not reported by others. The protective nature of such species in regard to the durability of the alloy and the formation of supported-metal type species upon activation accounts for its excellent behaviour. The relative higher stability of LaNi5 over CaNi5 under cyclic operating conditions has been explained based on surface energy criteria of the constituent elements rather than the deterioration initiated by hydrogen and/or gaseous impurities alone. In addition, the specific importance of X-ray induced Auger electron spectroscopy (XAES) technique in conjunction with X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) has been highlighted in the identification of different species. © 1990.
Index Keywords: Energy Storage; Intermetallics--Surface Properties; Spectroscopy, Photoelectron; Hydrogen Storage Alloy; Intermetallic Compounds; Species Identification; Surface Analysis Measurements; Hydrogen

Authors: Harper Jr. William B., Facinelli William A., Boyle Robert V.
Title: Solar Dynamic closed Brayton Cycle power generating system ground demonstrator
Source title: Proceedings of the Intersociety Energy Conversion Engineering Conference
Affiliations: Allied-Signal Aerospace Co, Tempe, United States
Authors with affiliations: Harper Jr., William B., Allied-Signal Aerospace Co, Tempe, United States; Facinelli, William A., Allied-Signal Aerospace Co, Tempe, United States; Boyle, Robert V., Allied-Signal Aerospace Co, Tempe, United States
Abstract: Spacecraft in low earth orbit can experience significantly extended mission times and/or greatly reduced costs for launch and reboost through the use of SD (Solar Dynamic) Power Generating Systems. These benefits are the result of reduced aerodynamic drag, a lower initial launch mass, and a significantly longer life for Solar Dynamic Systems compared to static power conversion systems such as PV (photovoltaic). The higher conversion efficiency of SD systems compared with PV systems results in much lower equivalent normal drag area which significantly decrease orbital decay rates (and costly reboost). In addition, PV systems store energy for use in the eclipse portion of the orbit in relatively heavy batteries which have limited life, from 3 to 5 years. SD systems utilize the thermal energy storage capabilities of a phase-change material which has an unlimited life. Thus, replacement costs are eliminated and life in orbit is extended. Although the viability of Solar Dynamic CBC (closed Brayton Cycle) systems has been established through detailed analyses, conceptual/preliminary designs and component/technology development programs, the demonstration of a complete power conversion system, including thermal energy storage, is yet to be accomplished. This paper presents a concept for a ground-based test program, utilizing an existing CBC engine built for NASA (National Aeronautics and Space Administration) and the DoE (Department of Energy) in 1976. Other components utilized in such a demonstration program would be fabricated from existing designs or design concepts such as those developed for the Space Station Freedom. In this manner, the costs associated with the continued development/demonstration of the CBC-based solar dynamic power conversion system would be minimized.
Index Keywords: Electric Power Generation; Solar Energy; Thermodynamics--Brayton Cycle; Closed Brayton Cycle Systems; Solar Dynamic Systems; Spacecraft

Authors: Langworthy A.
Title: Intelligent power station control systems for remote area power supply. Practical experience in the northern territory with medium size diesel/battery power stations
Source title: National Conference Publication - Institution of Engineers, Australia
Affiliations: Powercorp Pty Ltd
Authors with affiliations: Langworthy, A., Powercorp Pty Ltd
Abstract: Multiple unit diesel driven power stations form the backbone of power generation in remote areas of inland Australia. The state of the art intelligent control system has been built and deployed under a unique arrangement between private enterprise and the Power and water Authority (PAWA). The results illustrate the benefit of applying modern technology to remote area power supply and show savings available both in fuel usage and reduced service. The inclusion of battery storage to the diesel stations enables later addition of renewable energy plant such as solar arrays or wind generators.
Index Keywords: Electric Batteries; Electric Power Systems - Rural; Solar Power Plants; Wind Power; Diesel/Battery Power Stations; Intelligent Power Station Control; Diesel Electric Power Plants

Authors: Woo S.W., Ryu H.W., Kim S.D.
Title: Heat transfer characteristics in a latent heat storage system
Source title: Proceedings of the Intersociety Energy Conversion Engineering Conference
Affiliations: Korea Inst of Science and Technology, Seoul, South Korea
Authors with affiliations: Woo, S.W., Korea Inst of Science and Technology, Seoul, South Korea; Ryu, H.W., Korea Inst of Science and Technology, Seoul, South Korea; Kim, S.D., Korea Inst of Science and Technology, Seoul, South Korea
Abstract: The thermal cycling tests in a test tube have been performed to upgrade the thermal energy storage performance of sodium acetate trihydrate. A thickened sodium acetate trihydrate mixture (2 wt% carboxy-methyl cellulose/1 wt% super-absorbent polymer as a thickener/ K2SO4 as a nucleating agent) is proposed as a latent heat storage material. Heat transfer characteristics during the heat storage and recovery stages in a thermal energy storage system (2.3 kWh) containing 60 tubes of gelled sodium acetate trihydrate have been determined. The effects of flow path, inlet temperature, and flow rate of heat transfer fluid (HTF) on the thermal performance have been determined. The top-bottom flow path of HTF is found to have superior heat transfer performance than that of the other flow modes in heat storage and heat recovery stages. The cumulative amount of thermal energy stored and recovered have been correlated with the Fourier, Stefan and Reynolds numbers to provide basic design information for the tube type heat storage systems.
Index Keywords: Energy Storage; Heat Transfer; Polymers; Sodium Compounds; Heat Transfer Fluids; Sodium Acetate Trihydrate; Thermal Energy Storage; Heating

Authors: Ehrlich Melvin P.
Title: Thermodynamically pumped IR laser
Source title: Proceedings of the Intersociety Energy Conversion Engineering Conference
Affiliations: Redel Research Corp, New Hyde Park, United States
Authors with affiliations: Ehrlich, Melvin P., Redel Research Corp, New Hyde Park, United States
Abstract: In this paper the theory of the ortho hydrogen to para hydrogen transition by radiation and other effects is presented. This molecular transition is of importance for its potential application to the development of devices such as a high power (1,000 Joules/mole) 'Super Radiance' source, an IR Laser, an energy storage or space power source, and the study of interstellar hydrogen clouds [1]. If the transition lifetime is of reasonable length this would indicate yet another mode of radiative energy transfer in interstellar space and another tool for the study of the distribution of matter in space. The existing theory which is rather limited in scope, deals primarily with the calculation of the lifetime of an isolated ortho hydrogen molecule, and the heterogeneous conversion of ortho hydrogen by paramagnetic gases and catalysts. A theoretical and experimental approach is presented which could be the precursors of useful devices.
Index Keywords: Heat Transfer--Radiation; Hydrogen; Infrared Radiation; Thermodynamics; Infrared Lasers; Interstellar Hydrogen Clouds; Super Radiance Sources; Thermodynamic Pumping; Lasers

Authors: Lehman P.A., Chamberlin C.E.
Title: Design of a photovoltaic-hydrogen-fuel cell energy system
Affiliations: Department of Environmental Resources Engineering, Humboldt State University, Arcata, CA 95521, United States
Authors with affiliations: Lehman, P.A., Department of Environmental Resources Engineering, Humboldt State University, Arcata, CA 95521, United States; Chamberlin, C.E., Department of Environmental Resources Engineering, Humboldt State University, Arcata, CA 95521, United States
Abstract: The design of a stand-alone renewable energy system using hydrogen (H2) as the energy storage medium and a fuel cell as the regeneration technology is reported. The system being installed at the Humboldt State University Telonicher Marine Laboratory consists of a 9.2 kW photovoltaic (PV) array coupled to a high pressure, bipolar alkaline electrolyser. The array powers the Laboratory's air compressor system whenever possible; excess power is shunted to the electrolyser for hydrogen and oxygen (O2) production. When the array cannot provide sufficient power, stored hydrogen and oxygen are furnished to a proton exchange membrane fuel cell which, smoothly and without interruption, supplies the load. In reporting the design, details of component selection, sizing, and integration, control system logic and implementation, and safety considerations are discussed. Plans for a monitoring network to chronicle system performance are presented, questions that will be addressed through the monitoring program are included, and the present status of the project is reported. © 1991.

Authors: Landry C.M., Noble C.D.
Title: Case study of cost-effective low-temperature air distribution, ice thermal storage
Affiliations: Turbo Refrigerating Co, Denton, United States
Authors with affiliations: Landry, C.M., Turbo Refrigerating Co, Denton, United States; Noble, C.D., Turbo Refrigerating Co, Denton, United States
Abstract: Ice thermal storage systems have often been viewed as a cost premium. When design considerations include more than just the refrigeration plant, significant cost reductions can be realized. Utilizing a low-temperature air distribution design (42°F to 51°F supply air) available with the 34°F to 38°F chilled water from ice storage, one can offset the capital cost associated with the refrigeration plant through savings in the peripheral air and water distribution equipment. This case study presents actual construction dollars for a low-temperature air distribution design. A comparative analysis is made to a design using an alternative conventional system. Projected operating cost savings of the low-temperature air distribution, ice thermal storage system are included, and often-ignored benefits outside the mechanical contract are discussed.
Index Keywords: Energy Conservation - Economics; Energy Storage; Ice - Manufacture; Office Buildings - Energy Utilization; Ice Thermal Storage; Low-Temperature Air Distribution; Air Conditioning

Authors: Bailey Bruce, Doty John, Perez Richard, Stewart Ronald, Huse William
Title: Utility investigation of a grid-connected photovoltaic system as a peak load reduction option
Source title: Proceedings of the Intersociety Energy Conversion Engineering Conference
Affiliations: AWS Scientific, Inc, Albany, United States
Authors with affiliations: Bailey, Bruce, AWS Scientific, Inc, Albany, United States; Doty, John, AWS Scientific, Inc, Albany, United States; Perez, Richard, AWS Scientific, Inc, Albany, United States; Stewart, Ronald, AWS Scientific, Inc, Albany, United States; Huse, William, AWS Scientific, Inc, Albany, United States
Abstract: Since the early summer of 1990, the Niagara Mohawk Power Corporation has been operating a grid-connected 15.4 kW photovoltaic system near Albany, NY. The purpose is to evaluate the summer peak shaving capability of PV systems serving commercial buildings. The roof-retrofitted system features 151 m2 of module surface area, three one-axis trackers, and a high efficiency power conditioning unit. This paper summarizes performance results for the July December, 1990 period. Since start-up, the PV system has operated 93% of the time. Module array output is 95% of the manufacturer's rating. The trackers lag the sun's position by an average of 5 degrees. Inverter conversion efficiency exceeds 90% with a power factor of 0.95 or greater for loads exceeding 21% of rated output. PV system energy yield is well in phase with building demand. Depending on the definition used for system rating (standard vs. design conditions), system output averaged between 54% and 70% of capacity during the building's 25 highest 10-minute loads. Future studies will evaluate battery storage for enhancing system availability during load peaks.
Index Keywords: Electric Power Systems - Load Management; Electric Utilities; Solar Power Plants - New York; Grid Connected Photovoltaic Systems; Peak Load Reduction; Photovoltaic Cells

Authors: Kumar B., Gist T.E., Fingers R.T., Flake R.A.
Title: Small magnetic energy storage systems using high temperature superconductors
Source title: Proceedings of the Intersociety Energy Conversion Engineering Conference
Affiliations: Univ of Dayton Research Inst, Dayton, United States
Authors with affiliations: Kumar, B., Univ of Dayton Research Inst, Dayton, United States; Gist, T.E., Univ of Dayton Research Inst, Dayton, United States; Fingers, R.T., Univ of Dayton Research Inst, Dayton, United States; Flake, R.A., Univ of Dayton Research Inst, Dayton, United States
Abstract: Magnetic energy storage for power systems has been considered for commercial utility power, air and ground mobile power sources, and spacecraft applications. Even at the current technology limits of energy storage (100 KJ/Kg), superconducting magnetic energy storage inductors do not offer a strong advantage over state-of-the-art batteries. The commerical utility application does not have a weight and volume limitation, and is under intense study in several countries for diurnal cycle energy storage and high power delivery. The advent of high temperature superconductors has reduced one of the penalties of superconducting magnetic energy storage in that refrigeration and cryocontainers become greatly simplified. Still, structural and current density issues that limit the energy density and size of superconducting inductors do not change. Cold weather starting of aircraft engines is an application where these limitations are not as significant, and where current systems lack performance. The very cold environments make it difficult to achieve high power densities in state-of-the-art batteries and hydraulically activated starters. The same cold environments make it possible to cool superconducting systems for weeks using a single charge of liquid nitrogen. At the same time, the ground carts can handle the size and weight of superconducting magnetic storage (SMES) devices.
Index Keywords: Cooling; Electric Batteries; Energy Storage; Power Plants--Mobile; Superconducting Devices; Superconducting Materials; Aircraft Engine Cold Starting; Liquid Nitrogen; Superconducting Magnetic Storage Devices; Magnetic Devices

Title: Overview of the cooperative program on hydrogen storage, conversion and safety of the international energy agency

Abstract: Work under the Hydrogen Agreement of the International Energy Agency on storage, energy conversion and safety was started in 1983 by Canada, the F.R.G., Japan, Sweden, Switzerland and the U.S.A. Some of the results achieved within the main areas of the program are summarized: hydrogen storage in metal hydrides and in liquid form, hydrogen as a fuel for ground transportation vehicles, hydrogen embrittlement of ferritic steels as well as the transition from deflagration to detonation of hydrogen-air mixtures. Based on the context of other projects, an outlook for the program is given. © 1991.

Authors: Seem J.E., Braun J.E.
Title: Adaptive methods for real-time forecasting of building electrical demand
Affiliations: Johnson Controls, Inc, Milwaukee, United States
Authors with affiliations: Seem, J.E., Johnson Controls, Inc, Milwaukee, United States; Braun, J.E., Johnson Controls, Inc, Milwaukee, United States
Abstract: This paper presents a simple algorithm for forecasting the electrical demand in a building. The algorithm should also be applicable for forecasting cooling loads. The algorithm has application in dynamic control strategies that use chilled water, ice, or building thermal mass as a thermal storage medium. Parameters of the forecasting model are adjusted over time to adapt to a specific building's characteristics. The algorithm is easily programmed and has small computational effort and memory requirements. Electrical demand data collected from a grocery store and a restaurant were used to demonstrate the accuracy and robustness of the algorithm.
Index Keywords: Air Conditioning - Optimization; Control Systems, Adaptive - Computer Applications; Energy Utilization - Control Systems; Mathematical Techniques - Algorithms; Building Electric Demand; Grocery Stores; Real Time Forecasting; Restaurants; Buildings

Authors: Gondhalekar Vijay, Downer James R., Eisenhaure David B., Hockney Richard L., Johnson Bruce G.
Title: Low noise spacecraft attitude control systems
Source title: Proceedings of the Intersociety Energy Conversion Engineering Conference
Affiliations: SatCon Technology Corp, Cambridge, United States
Authors with affiliations: Gondhalekar, Vijay, SatCon Technology Corp, Cambridge, United States; Downer, James R., SatCon Technology Corp, Cambridge, United States; Eisenhaure, David B., SatCon Technology Corp, Cambridge, United States; Hockney, Richard L., SatCon Technology Corp, Cambridge, United States; Johnson, Bruce G., SatCon Technology Corp, Cambridge, United States
Abstract: This paper describes two ongoing research efforts at SatCon Technology Corporation directed at developing advanced spacecraft momentum control flywheels. The first effort is directed at developing low-noise momentum wheels through the use of magnetic bearings. The use of magnetic bearings eliminates stiction and other noise effects in ball bearings and allows for the active control such that forces generated by the flywheel mass unbalance can be minimized. The second effort is directed at demonstrating critical subcomponents of an Integrated Power and Attitude Control System (IPACS) that stores energy as kinetic energy in mechanical rotors with the accompanying angular momentum available for attitude control of the spacecraft. This project has focused on the design of a system with energy storage density of 40 Whr/kg, charge/discharge round-trip efficiency exceeding 85%, and a momentum transfer and torquing capability commensurate with the Space Station requirements. This paper describes a ground experiment that will demonstrate an energy storage capability of 1 kWhr at a 40 Whr/kg energy density, a 1 kW electrical generation capacity at 85% round-trip efficiency and which will allow single degree of freedom gimballing to quantify experimentally the bearing power requirements for precessing the flywheel.
Index Keywords: Bearings--Magnetic; Control Systems; Energy Storage; Flywheels; Noise, Spurious Signal; Electric Generation; Gimbals; Integrated Power and Attitude Control System (IPACS); Spacecraft

Authors: Schlimme D.V., Smith M.A., Ali L.M.
Title: Influence of freezing rate, storage temperature, and storage duration on the quality of turkey frankfurters
Affiliations: Univ of Maryland, College Station, United States
Authors with affiliations: Schlimme, D.V., Univ of Maryland, College Station, United States; Smith, M.A., Univ of Maryland, College Station, United States; Ali, L.M., Univ of Maryland, College Station, United States
Abstract: Commercial turkey frankfurters were frozen to -18°C within 72, 96, and 120 hours of vacuum packaging. Samples were stored at -18°C and -9.4°C for 0, 1.5, 3, 6, 9, 12, and 16 months after freezing. Electric power usage during storage was monitored. Sensory and analytical quality evaluations were made after each storage period. Storage temperature and freezing rate had little effect on frankfurter quality. Quality was satisfactory at both storage temperatures for 16 months. Storage at -9.4°C reduced electric energy usage by 26%.

Authors with affiliations: Cassagnau, P., CNRS, Vernaison, France; Bert, M., CNRS, Vernaison, France; Verney, V., CNRS, Vernaison, France; Michel, A., CNRS, Vernaison, France
Abstract: Dynamic rheological measurements has been used to study and to characterize the mechanism of the exchange reactions of ester groups in the presence of dibutyltin oxide as a catalyst. A preliminary study has allowed us to point out the suitable domain (frequency, temperature) of the kinetic study of the chemical crosslinking reaction through the variations of the storage modulus G′ (t)ω,T. These kinetics curves obtained for different reactive blends (EVA, PP/EVA and PPf/EVA) has allowed us to evaluate the activation energy of the reaction and thus to specify the appropriate parameters (temperature and time) for carrying out the chemical reaction in a twin screw extruder.
