Authors: Heitner Kenneth L.
Title: Range extender hybrid vehicle
Source title: Proceedings of the Intersociety Energy Conversion Engineering Conference
Affiliations: US Dept of Energy, Washington, United States
Authors with affiliations: Heitner, Kenneth L., US Dept of Energy, Washington, United States
Abstract: Recently, there has been revised interest in the range extender concept for electric vehicles. A range extender vehicle is actually a hybrid vehicle, where a small engine generator is used to 'sustain' vehicle operation beyond the range provided by the batteries. Such a concept is useful in the near term, when commerically available batteries will not have adequate specific energy. Range extender designs are based on existing, well characterized electric vehicle designs. Well established driving cycles are used to define the basic energy and power needs to the vehicle systems. The designs use existing commercial lead acid batteries and on small commercially available engine generators. This study looks at the energy use patterns associated with this type of vehicle as well as the needs for emissions control. Current and potential future regulation be the EPA and California Air Resource Board are considered in accounting for vehicle emission standards. A range of likely vehicle operating patterns is considered.

Authors: McConaghy W.J., Lehnert R.A., Rasmussen R.W.
Title: Design & operational experience of the NUHOMS - 24P Spent Fuel Storage System
Affiliations: Pacific Nuclear Fuel Services Inc
Authors with affiliations: McConaghy, W.J., Pacific Nuclear Fuel Services Inc; Lehnert, R.A., Pacific Nuclear Fuel Services Inc; Rasmussen, R.W., Pacific Nuclear Fuel Services Inc
Abstract: The NUHOMS Spent Fuel Storage System provides a safe and economical method for the dry storage of spent fuel assemblies either at an at-reactor Independent Spent Fuel Storage Installation (ISFSI) or at a centralized away-from-reactor (AFR) storage facility. The system consists of three major safety related components: a dry shielded canister (DSC) which provides a high integrity containment boundary and a controlled storage environment for the fuel; a reinforced concrete horizontal storage module (HSM) which houses the stored DSC and provides radiation shielding, protection against natural phenomena, and an efficient means for decay heat removal; and a transfer cask which provides for the safe shielded transfer of the DSC from the plant spent fuel pool to the HSM. The NUHOMS system is designed and licensed to the requirements of 10 CFR 72 and ANS/ANSI 57.9 for ISFSIs. The NUHOMS concept was developed in the early 1980s and it was selected to be part of a cooperative demonstration program among the U.S. Department of Energy, the Electric Power Research Institute, Carolina Power and Light, and NUTECH.
Index Keywords: Nuclear Reactors--Spent Fuels; At-Reactor Independent Spent Fuel Storage Installation (ISFSI); Centralized Away From Reactor (AFR) Storage Facility; Dry Shielded Canister; NUHOMS Spent Fuel Storage System; Radioactive Wastes

Authors: Doherty E.Thomas
Title: Speech analysis techniques for detecting stress
Source title: Proceedings of the Human Factors Society
Affiliations: Veterans Affairs Medical Cent, San Francisco, CA, United States
Authors with affiliations: Doherty, E.Thomas, Veterans Affairs Medical Cent, San Francisco, CA, United States
Abstract: While attempts to assess the level of stress present in an individual by analyzing his speech have shown some success; current methodology is best described as being capable of determining whether a talker is presently experiencing either minimum or maximum stress. For example, Jones (1990) found that, for those extremes of stress, both the increase in speaking fundamental frequency and the decrease in vocal jitter were statistically significant. Neither measure, however, was capable of distinguishing any intervening levels. Researchers continue searching for acoustic measures that might more precisely indicate ongoing changes in stress to establish a metric capable of more than simply differentiating between the two extremes. The objective is to distinguish among several levels of stress or to furnish a continuous, concurrent estimate of the talker's state. Two main components are considered for improving the estimation of a talker's actual stress level: 1) refinements in the acquisition of signals and their processing; and 2) proposals concerning the choice of acoustic parameters. The first objective is intended to maintain signal fidelity which should enhance the potential to detect changes in the speaker's voice. For acquisition of the acoustic signal, direct sampling and storing to a computer is highly recommended, thus eliminating the potential distortion that is inherent in tape recording. During the analog-to-digital conversion phase, the highest sample rates attainable in the face of storage limitations and the finer amplitude resolution provided by 16 bit converters should also be beneficial. Concerning the selection of acoustic parameters, in addition to speaking fundamental frequency and jitter, certain variations in the waveform (spectrum) might be exploited. The maximum rate of change in amplitude during a pitch period or the ratio of the energy in various segments of the spectrum, after each has been appropriately normalized, might not only indicate stress levels but also be independent of speaker variability.
Index Keywords: Acoustic Waves--Spectrum Analysis; Biomechanics; Data storage, Digital; Human engineering--Psychophysiology; Signal processing--Digital techniques; Signal Fidelity; Stress Detection; Voice Jitter; Workload Estimation; Speech

Authors: Clements N.D., Johnson D.E.
Title: Opening switches for a 5 MJ, 1 MA energy storage transformer
Affiliations: IAP Research, Inc., 2763 Culver Avenue, Dayton, OH, 45429–3723, United States
Authors with affiliations: Clements, N.D., IAP Research, Inc., 2763 Culver Avenue, Dayton, OH, 45429–3723, United States; Johnson, D.E., IAP Research, Inc., 2763 Culver Avenue, Dayton, OH, 45429–3723, United States
Abstract: This paper compares two possible switch topologies used to switch the primary of an energy storage transformer. A series connected semiconductor/vacuum interrupter switch and an all solid-state switch are sized for a 5 MJ energy storage transformer. Gate-turn-off thyristors are used as the semiconductor switches. Total mass estimates, operating characteristics, and applicability to a space-based pulsed power system are discussed. Both designs store the commutation energy in capacitors. The commutation energy is then dissipated in resistors after switching has occurred. The capacitor mass is shown to dominate the total switch mass. Therefore, the mass of both switches is approximately equal. The advantages of the all solid-state switch include high reliability, no moving parts, proven design. and a high probability of future mass reduction with new semiconductor device developments. The all solid-state switch has a higher on-state power dissipation than the vacuum interrupter switch. We propose that the advantages of the all solid-state switch outweigh the disadvantage of higher power dissipation. © 1991 IEEE
Index Keywords: Capacitors; Electric Switches, Semiconductor; Semiconductor Devices - Switching; Thyristors; GTO Thyristors; Opening Switches; Electric Transformers

Authors: Marshall R.A.
Title: Distributed energy store railgun: The limiting case
Affiliations: WBM Stalker Pty. Ltd., 99 Leichardt Street, Brisbane, Qld, Australia
Authors with affiliations: Marshall, R.A., WBM Stalker Pty. Ltd., 99 Leichardt Street, Brisbane, Qld, Australia
Abstract: When the limiting case of a distributed energy store railgun is analyzed, i.e., the case where the space between adjacent energy stores become indefinitely small, three important results are obtained. First, the shape of the current pulse delivered by each store is sinusoidal with an exponential tail. Second, the rail-to-rail voltage behind the rear-most active store approaches zero. Third, it is not possible to choose parameters in such a way that capacitor crowbars can be eliminated. © 1991 IEEE
Index Keywords: Energy Storage; Distributed Energy Store Railguns; Electromagnetic Launchers

Authors: Klug R.B., Ford R.D., Jenkins D.J., Lupton W.H.
Title: Ten megacoulomb switching operation for the air force battery powered inductive storage launcher research facility
Affiliations: Air Force Armament Laboratory, Eglin Air Force base, FL, 2548, United States; Naval Research Laboratory, Washington D.C., 20375, United States
Authors with affiliations: Klug, R.B., Air Force Armament Laboratory, Eglin Air Force base, FL, 2548, United States; Ford, R.D., Naval Research Laboratory, Washington D.C., 20375, United States; Jenkins, D.J., Naval Research Laboratory, Washington D.C., 20375, United States; Lupton, W.H., Naval Research Laboratory, Washington D.C., 20375, United States
Abstract: Operation of the battery powered inductive energy storage research facility (BPS) at the Air Force Armament Laboratory, presents some unique switching problems. The energy storage system switch must be capable of conducting a peak current in excess of two MA for as long as five seconds. It must then be capable of opening with microsecond precision timing, to synchronize current commutation with the operation of various electromechanical as well as electrical load components. A solid conductor, explosive operated switch design has been selected as most suitable for meeting these needs. Switch design incorporates both a normally closed contact for inductor charging and a normally open contact for safety abort as well as for routine energy management after each launch sequence. Both contacts are installed on the BPS switch bus as “stand alone” devices which may be used independantly or sequentially, depending upon experiment requirements. The combination is used as the primary system switch for inductor charging, current commutaton to various loads including other switches, and energy management. This paper describes switch operating parameters in more detail, and presents results from preliminary system operation. © 1991 IEEE
Index Keywords: Electric Switches; Energy Storage; Inductive Storage Launchers; US Air Force; Electromagnetic Launchers

Authors: Bouirden L., Hilger J.P., Hertz J.
Title: Discontinuous and continuous hardening processes in calcium and calcium-tin micro-alloyed lead: influence of 'secondary-lead' impurities
Affiliations: Laboratoire de Thermodynamique Métallurgique, Université de Nancy I, URA CNRS 1108, B.P. 239, 54506 Vandoeuvre-les-Nancy Cedex, France
Authors with affiliations: Bouirden, L., Laboratoire de Thermodynamique Métallurgique, Université de Nancy I, URA CNRS 1108, B.P. 239, 54506 Vandoeuvre-les-Nancy Cedex, France; Hilger, J.P., Laboratoire de Thermodynamique Métallurgique, Université de Nancy I, URA CNRS 1108, B.P. 239, 54506 Vandoeuvre-les-Nancy Cedex, France; Hertz, J., Laboratoire de Thermodynamique Métallurgique, Université de Nancy I, URA CNRS 1108, B.P. 239, 54506 Vandoeuvre-les-Nancy Cedex, France
Abstract: Different transformations in leadcalcium and leadcaciumtin alloys are observed with various complementary techniques such as anisothermal microcalorimetry, optical and electronic microscopy, hardness measurements. Three alloy states are studied: as-cast, rehomogenised/water-quenched, rehomogenised/air-cooled. With binary leadcalcium alloys, three successive discontinuous transformations are observed, namely: an initial and complete discontinuous transformation with regular moving of the front of reaction; a second and incomplete discontinuous transformation (puzzle-shaped); a third and incomplete discontinuous transformation with precipitation of Pb3Ca. The role of secondary-lead impurities is complex: Ag reduces and Bi accelerates the rate of the discontinuous reaction, while Al refines the grain size. Leadcalciumtin are characterized by the Sn/Ca ratio. For very small values of this ratio, the hardening is similar to that of leadcalcium alloys. For high ratio values, the hardening takes place after an incubation period and proceeds via a continuous micro-precipitation of the (PbSn)3Ca Compound. For intermediate ratios, the different processes are able to operate separately in sequence. Ag increases the rate of the continuous precipitation and reduces the incubation time. No significant effects are observed with Bi or Al. The kinetic laws of the different transformations are presented and values for the energy of activation are determined. © 1991.
Index Keywords: Electrodes, Electrochemical--Materials; Lead Calcium Alloys--Morphology; Aging Phenomena; Effects of Impurities; Grid Alloys; Sealed Storage Batteries; Electric Batteries, Secondary

Authors: Jowdy A.K., Smith R.I.
Title: MRS transfer facility feasibility study
Affiliations: Ralph M. Parsons Co, Pasadena, United States
Authors with affiliations: Jowdy, A.K., Ralph M. Parsons Co, Pasadena, United States; Smith, R.I., Ralph M. Parsons Co, Pasadena, United States
Abstract: Under contract to the U.S. Department of Energy, Parsons was requested to evaluate the feasibility of building a simple hot cell (waste handling) transfer facility at the Monitored Retrievable Storage (MRS) site to facilitate acceptance of spent fuel into the Federal Waste Management System starting in early 1998. The Transfer Facility was intended to provide a receiving and transfer to storage capability at a relatively low throughput rate (approximately 500 MTU/yr) and to provide the recovery capability needed on the site in the event of a transport or storage cask seal failure during a period of about two years while the larger Spent Fuel Handling Building (SFHB) was being completed. Although the original study basis postulated an incremental addition to the larger, previously considered MRS configurations, study results show that the Transfer Facility may be capable of receiving and storing spent fuel at annual rates of 3000 MTU/yr or more, making a larger fuel handling structure unnecessary. In addition, the study analyses showed that the Transfer Facility could be constructed and put into service in 15-17 months and would cost less than the previous configurations.
Index Keywords: Nuclear Reactors--Spent Fuels; Federal Waste Management System; Hot Cell Waste Handling Transfer Facility; Monitored Retrievable Storage; Spent Fuel Handling Building; Transfer Facility Performance; Radioactive Wastes

Authors: Brewer Jeffrey C., Whitt Thomas H., Lanier Jr. J.Roy
Title: Hubble Space Telescope nickle-hydrogen bateries testing and flight performance
Source title: Proceedings of the Intersociety Energy Conversion Engineering Conference
Affiliations: NASA/Marshall Space Flight Cent, United States
Authors with affiliations: Brewer, Jeffrey C., NASA/Marshall Space Flight Cent, United States; Whitt, Thomas H., NASA/Marshall Space Flight Cent, United States; Lanier Jr., J.Roy, NASA/Marshall Space Flight Cent, United States
Abstract: The Hubble Space Telescope (HST), the largest scientific payload ever built for space, was launched on April 24, 1990. The HST electrical power system (EPS) is supplying between 2,000 and 2,400 W of continuous power to the electrical loads. The major components of the EPS are the 5,000-W back surface field reflector (BSFR) solar array (SA), the six nickel-hydrogen (Ni-H2) batteries, and the charge current controllers (CCC's), which, in conjunction with the flight computer, control battery charging. The Marshall Space Flight Center (MSFC) has several ongoing tests relating to the HST. A six-battery test has been running for over 2 years and is producing excellent data on the operation of a simulated HST EPS. A 22-cell 'flight spare' battery (FSB) has also been on test for almost 2 years. Since this battery is comprised of cells identical to those on orbit, it is the best ground-based simulation of the operation of a flight battery. This paper not only discusses the results of the HST Ni-H2 six-battery and FSB tests, but also describes the operation of the HST EPS and gives an oveview of the flight batteries' performance.
Index Keywords: Control Systems - Applications; Electric Batteries - Charging; Telescopes - Energy Storage; Battery Charge Control; HST Flight Batteries; HST Flight Spare Battery Test; Hubble Space Telescope (HST); Marshall Space Flight Center (MSFC); Six-Battery Test; Electric Batteries

Authors: Bailey Patrick G., Hollandsworth Roger P., Symons Philip C.
Title: Sensitivity analyses of pem fuel cell systems for both open and closed loop applications
Source title: Proceedings of the Intersociety Energy Conversion Engineering Conference
Affiliations: Lockheed Missiles & Space Co, Sunnyvale, United States
Authors with affiliations: Bailey, Patrick G., Lockheed Missiles & Space Co, Sunnyvale, United States; Hollandsworth, Roger P., Lockheed Missiles & Space Co, Sunnyvale, United States; Symons, Philip C., Lockheed Missiles & Space Co, Sunnyvale, United States
Abstract: A specialized computer modelling technique has been developed to evaluate fuel cell systems as possible candidates for various commercial applications. The computer model includes reactants and products chemistry, storage, electrochemical energy conversion efficiency, and the possibility of using seawater as a reactant. The results clearly indicate superior energy capacity for lithium hydride (LiH), lithium aluminum hydride (LiAlH4), or calcium hydride (CaH2) fuels with liquid oxygen (LOX) compared to all of the non-metal hydride fueled systems considered, including those using liquid oxygen with aluminum (Al/LOX) and methanol (CH3OH/LOX) systems. A description of the computer model is given and sensitivity results of various studies are reported. In the hydride studies, water is assumed to react directly within a hydride fuel tank to produce the hydrogen gas required for operation of the fuel cell. The hydroxide product formed by this reaction remains in the tank. The tanks have been sized to include the effects of a possible larger volume required for the product (as in the case of CaH2 and NaBH4/LOX. Sensitivity studies are included that contrast applications to an open loop system with no chemical product retention, a closed loop system with product retention and the various effects of system efficiencies, assumed filter cake volume fractions, and tank shapes.
Index Keywords: Computer Programming - Spreadsheet; Computer Simulation; Mathematical Techniques - Sensitivity Analysis; Closed Loop Battery Systems; Computational Spreadsheet Analysis Model; Fuel/Oxidant Computer Model; Lithium Aluminum Hydride Systems; Lithium Hydride Systems; Proton Exchange Membrane (PEM) Fuel Cells; Fuel Cells

Authors: Schubert Richard C., Hamelink L.Robert, Rathsack Peter, Hathaway Richard, Heins Conrad
Title: Sunseeker solar powered car. Western Michigan University/Jordan College
Affiliations: Western Michigan Univ, Kalamazoo, United States
Authors with affiliations: Schubert, Richard C., Western Michigan Univ, Kalamazoo, United States; Hamelink, L.Robert, Western Michigan Univ, Kalamazoo, United States; Rathsack, Peter, Western Michigan Univ, Kalamazoo, United States; Hathaway, Richard, Western Michigan Univ, Kalamazoo, United States; Heins, Conrad, Western Michigan Univ, Kalamazoo, United States
Abstract: Sunseeker 77 is the Western Michigan University-Jordan College solar powered vehicle which competed in GM SunRayce USA, 1990. Sunseeker was designed and constructed by students from both schools and finished eighth out of thirty-two entrants in a 1644 mile, 11 day race from Orlando, Florida to Warren, Michigan. Many factors were considered in the design of the vehicle including aerodynamics, solar array configuration, chassis, suspension, ergonomics and drivetrain. The 120 member team consisted of students with disciplines in mechanical engineering, automotive engineering, aircraft engineering, electrical engineering, industrial engineering, engineering technology, renewable energies and marketing. Safety and reliability were a major concern throughout the entire project. The final outer shell and structure consisted of an aluminum space frame, a teardrop-shaped composite shell and a lightweight suspension mounted on four modified bicycle wheels. The electrical and power system was comprised of crystalline silicon and amorphous silicon solar cells, D.C. Motor, continuously variable transmission and a final chain drive.
Index Keywords: Energy Resources; Solar Cells; Solar Energy--Applications; Storage Battery Vehicles; Automobile races; Solar-powered cars; Automobiles

Authors: Kanari K., Abe Y., Kamimoto M., Kato M.
Title: Molten salt latent thermal storage unit for cogeneration systems
Source title: Denshi Gijutsu Sogo Kenkyusho Iho/Bulletin of the Electrotechnical Laboratory
Authors with affiliations: Kanari, K.; Abe, Y.; Kamimoto, M.; Kato, M.
Abstract: This paper evaluates the feasibility of the application of molten salt latent thermal storage units to molten carbonate fuel cell (MCFC) cogeneration systems. Two examples were selected: a cogeneration system for a hotel with a 5000 m2 floor area in the private sector and one for a paper mill requiring 17,000 kW of steam in the industrial sector. Computer simulations showed good charge and discharge performance of the designed molten salt latent thermal storage units for both systems. The capital and running cost of MCFC cogeneration systems with molten salt latent thermal storage units were compared with those of alternative cogeneration systems with steam accumulators or without thermal energy storage units. Applications of molten salt latent thermal storage units to MCFC cogeneration systems are technically feasible and may possibly be cost-effective in the near future.
Index Keywords: Energy Storage--Costs; Fuel Cells--Electrolytes; Hotels--Energy Conservation; Paper and Pulp Mills--Energy Conservation; Salts--Molten; Energy Storage Cost Analysis; Latent Heat Storage Systems; Molten Carbonate Fuel Cells; Molten Salt Electrolytes; Private Cogeneration Systems; Cogeneration Plants

Authors: Leung T.T.
Title: Concept of a modified flywheel for megajoule storage and pulse conditioning
Affiliations: The MITRE Corporation, 7525 Colshire Drive, McLean, VA22102. (703)-883-7683#, United States
Authors with affiliations: Leung, T.T., The MITRE Corporation, 7525 Colshire Drive, McLean, VA22102. (703)-883-7683#, United States
Abstract: This paper introduces the concept of a flywheel with a variable moment of inertia for electromagnetic launch (EML). A flywheel is among the best energy’ density storage devices, The modified flywheel Will further improve upon the energy density and efficiency. Coupled to a pulse-duty generator, It could produce a near-square pulse or other desirable pulse shapes. The amount of energy, its rate, and its switching all could be controlled prior to electric energy conversion. The modified flywheel is structured with masses movable along radial paths. Potential energy is stored with respect to mass position and kinetic energy with respect to spin. This mass positioning provides a means to control the rate of energy discharge. Control with spring-loaded weight-the design presented here–would have near constant spin output. But a servomechanism scheme can provide the precise inward-moving positioning control of masses, and hence the other desirable output pulse conditioning. In the conventional flywheel, energy is always discharged in an exponential decay. In an EML system, a flywheel is the rotor of the pulse-duty generator, such as in the homopolar generator, compulsator, or the disk alternator. The flywheel could also be a separate component placed between the prime source and the pulse generator. The latter method is preferred because it provides much design flexibility and does not depend on the breakthrough of certain critical technology for the success of the EML concept. © 1991 IEEE
Index Keywords: Electric Generators, DC; Flywheels; Pulse Generators; Servomechanisms; Compulsators; Homopolar Generators; Megajoule Storage; Pulse Conditioning; Electromagnetic Launchers

Affiliations: Clin. Diabetes and Nutrition Section, Natl. Inst. of Diabet./Digest./K.D., National Institutes of Health, Phoenix, AZ 85016, United States; Clin. Diabetes and Nutrition Section, 4212 N. 16th St., Phoenix, AZ 85016, United States

Inst. of Diabet./Digest./K.D., National Institutes of Health, Phoenix, AZ 85016, United States; Ravussin, E., Clin. Diabetes and Nutrition Section, Natl. Inst. of Diabet./Digest./K.D., National Institutes of Health, Phoenix, AZ 85016, United States, Clin. Diabetes and Nutrition Section, 4212 N. 16th St., Phoenix, AZ 85016, United States
Abstract: Insulin resistance is commonly associated with obesity and noninsulin-dependent diabetes. Whereas it predicts the development of diabetes, its effect on body weight change is unknown. We measured glucose disposal rates at submaximally- and maximally-stimulating insulin concentrations in 192 nondiabetic Pima Indians and followed their weight change over 3.5±1.8 y (mean±SD). Results: (a) Insulin-resistant subjects gained less weight than insulin-sensitive subjects (3.1 vs. 7.6 kg, P < 0.0001). (b) The percent weight change per year correlated with glucose disposal at submaximally- (r = 0.19, P < 0.01) and maximally-stimulating (r = 0.34, P < 0.0001) insulin concentrations independent of sex, age, initial weight, and 24-h energy expenditure; the correlations were stronger for glucose oxidation than for glucose storage, (c) Weight gain was associated with an increase in insulin resistance more than four times that predicted from the cross-sectional data. We conclude that insulin resistance is associated with a reduced risk of weight gain in nondiabetic Pima Indians.
Author Keywords: Glucose oxidation; Insulin resistance; Noninsulin-dependent diabetes mellitus; Obesity; Weight gain

Authors: Karnopp D.
Title: State functions and bond graph dynamic models for rotary, multi-winding electrical machines
Affiliations: Department of Mechanical Engineering, The University of California, Davis, CA 95616, United States
Authors with affiliations: Karnopp, D., Department of Mechanical Engineering, The University of California, Davis, CA 95616, United States
Abstract: The mathematical modeling and computer simulation of the dynamics of systems containing alternators, synchronous or induction motors or other polyphase machines is aided by the description of multi-winding rotary devices based on energy and coenergy state functions. The basic theory is reviewed including the formula for electromagnetic torque based on energy and coenergy state functions. The electrically linear-but geometrically nonlinear- case is then studied. As an example, an ideal, smooth rotor, two-axis, four-winding machine is discussed. Bond graph IC-storage field models are developed and the use of the d-q transformation as embodied in a modulated transformer structure is illustrated. This transformation removes the rotor angular dependence from the inductance matrix. However, the angle dependence remains in the transformation from the real coil variables to the d-q variables and in the multi-port transformer laws. The bond graph models of the basic transduction can be augmented to account for electrical and mechanical losses and other dynamic effects in the creation of a system model. Other multi-port transformers can be used to convert polyphase systems to the two-axis machine models described in the paper. © 1990.
Index Keywords: Computer Simulation; Dynamics; Electric Energy Storage; Electric Losses; Equations of Motion; Bond Graph Dynamic Models; D-Q Transformation; Electromechanical Energy Transduction; Energy Storage Field Analysis; Rotor Dynamics; Electric Machinery

Authors: Zha Q.-Z., Chen W.-K.
Title: Broad-band impedance matching of the RLC generator and load
Affiliations: Department of Electrical Engineering and Computer Science, University of Illinois at Chicago, P.O. Box 4348, Chicago, IL 60680, United States
Authors with affiliations: Zha, Q.-Z., Department of Electrical Engineering and Computer Science, University of Illinois at Chicago, P.O. Box 4348, Chicago, IL 60680, United States; Chen, W.-K., Department of Electrical Engineering and Computer Science, University of Illinois at Chicago, P.O. Box 4348, Chicago, IL 60680, United States
Abstract: This paper presents a simple theory for the design of a broad-band impedance matching network which, when operating between a given RLC generator z1(s) and an RLC load z2(s), yields a Chebyshev low-pass or band-pass response. Using realizability conditions of double frequency-dependent terminations, we present a new theorem which states that if there exists a second-order all-pass function such that the resulting reflection coefficients are bounded-real and satisfy Youla's conditions at each zero of transmission of z1(s) and z2(s), a ladder equalizer exists. A method to realize such a ladder is described. After choosing the order n of the transfer function not smaller than the total number of the energy storage elements of z1(s) and z2(s), the result can easily be extended to any all-pole low-pass response for any non-Foster positive-real impedances z1(s) and z2(s) except for the case where z1(s) and z2(s) have a common finite zero on the jω-axis. © 1991.
Index Keywords: Impedance Matching - Optimization; Broad-Band Matching; Ladder Equalizer; Ladder Matching; Electric Networks

Authors: Sheredos S.J.
Title: Report on the evaluation of the VA/SEATTLE ankle
Source title: Journal of Rehabilitation Research and Development
Affiliations: Rehabilitation R and D Evaluation Unit, VA-PRDC, 103 S. Gay St., Baltimore, MD 21202, United States
Authors with affiliations: Sheredos, S.J., Rehabilitation R and D Evaluation Unit, VA-PRDC, 103 S. Gay St., Baltimore, MD 21202, United States
Abstract: The VA/SEATTLE Ankle was researched and developed by the Prosthetics Research Study (PRS), Seattle, WA under the sponsorship of the Rehabilitation Research and Development Service, Department of Veterans Affairs. This report presents an evaluation of the project conducted by the Rehabilitation R and D Evaluation Unit (REU), the VA Prosthetic and Sensory Aids Service (PSAS), and the PSAS at 13 VA Medical Centers. The ankle is a lightweight lower limb prosthesis of monolithic design weighting 300 g (10.5 oz.) with a maximum pylon length of 15 1/2 in. Energy storage and release and three-axis motion are all accomplished via a specifically designed convolution in the distal region (ankle) of the pylon. This convolution provides rotation (± 5 degrees), inversion/eversion (± 3 degrees) and dorsi/plantar flexion (± 5 degrees). The ankle showed no signs of fracture or wear through laboratory test procedures of 500,000 cycles of the ankle attached to a conventional type SACH foot under a dynamic load. Performance of the VA/SEATTLE Ankle was found to be acceptable and reliable with a wide variety of users and its commercial production was recommended.

Abstract: The authors present a conceptual framework for an integrated cogeneration/TES (thermal energy storage) system and develop an optimization model for such an application. The purpose of this model is to size equipment and select operating levels in order to maximize economic benefits to the end-user. One method of optimizing the operation is to minimize the total cost of energy using a linear programming model or graphical optimization within the system constraints. Authors: Tam Kwa-Sur, Zhang X., Yarali A.
Title: Using SMES as a multi-purpose interface in power generation, transmission and distribution systems
Source title: Proceedings of the Intersociety Energy Conversion Engineering Conference
Affiliations: Virginia Polytechnic Inst and State, Univ, Blacksburg, United States
Authors with affiliations: Tam, Kwa-Sur, Virginia Polytechnic Inst and State, Univ, Blacksburg, United States; Zhang, X., Virginia Polytechnic Inst and State, Univ, Blacksburg, United States; Yarali, A., Virginia Polytechnic Inst and State, Univ, Blacksburg, United States
Abstract: This paper presents a new SMES scheme, the MSMES system, which significantly broadens the ways in which SMES can be applied to electric power systems. On the generation side, the SMES system can convert low-quality power into high-quality power and enhances the utilization of all energy sources available to the power systems. Acting both as an energy storage device and a power flow control device, a MSMES system can act as a hub in a power transmission system. The use of multiple MSMES systems can provide many new solutions to the problems facing the transmission networks of the United States today. On the distribution side, MSMES systems can be used as advanced power distribution centers that supply high-quality power to the customers while providing desirable load shapes to the power systems. In addition to these functions, a MSMES unit can also perform functions such as damping of power oscillation, stability and dynamic performance improvement and other recognized benefits of the conventional SMES system. Functioning as a multi-purpose power processing units, the MSMES systems improve the economics of SMES technology and expand its potential market.
Index Keywords: Electric Power Distribution; Electric Power Systems; Electric Power Transmission; Magnetic Devices--Energy Storage; Power Generation; Multiterminal Superconducting Magnetic Energy Storage (MSMES) Systems; Superconducting Magnetic Energy Storage (SMES) Systems; Superconducting Devices

Authors: De Steese John G., Dagle Jeffery E.
Title: Benefit/cost comparisons for utility SMES applications
Source title: Proceedings of the Intersociety Energy Conversion Engineering Conference
Affiliations: Pacific Northwest Lab, Richland, United States
Authors with affiliations: De Steese, John G., Pacific Northwest Lab, Richland, United States; Dagle, Jeffery E., Pacific Northwest Lab, Richland, United States
Abstract: This paper summarizes eight case studies that account for the benefits and costs of superconducting magnetic energy storage (SMES) in system-specific utility applications. Four of these scenarios are hypothetical SMES applications in the Pacific Northwest, where relatively low energy costs impose a stringent test on the viability of the concept. The other four scenarios address SMES applications on high-voltage, direct-current (HVDC) transmission lines. While estimated SMES benefits are based on a previously reported methodology, this paper presents results of an improved cost-estimating approach that includes an assumed reduction in the cost of the power conditioning system (PCS) from approximately $160/kW to $80/kW. The revised approach results in all the SMES scenarios showing higher benefit/cost ratios than those reported earlier. However, in all but two cases, the value of any single benefit is still less than the unit's levelized cost. This suggests, as a general principle, that the total value of multiple benefits should always be considered if SMES is to appear cost effective in many utility applications. These results should offer utilities further encouragement to conduct more detailed analyses of SMES benefits in scenarios that apply to individual systems.
Index Keywords: Electric Power Transmission, HVDC; ELECTRIC UTILITIES; Magnetic Devices--Energy Storage; Superconducting Magnets--Energy Storage; Benefit Cost Analysis; Pacific Northwest; Superconducting Magnetic Energy Storage (SMES) Systems; Superconducting Devices

Authors: De Marco A., Miccio M., De Michele G., Prandoni W., Traniello Gradassi A.
Title: Model for the dynamic simulation of a pilot fluidized bed combustor. Predictions and first validation
Source title: Proceedings of the International Conference on Fluidized Bed Combustion
Affiliations: ENEL, Milan, Italy
Authors with affiliations: De Marco, A., ENEL, Milan, Italy; Miccio, M., ENEL, Milan, Italy; De Michele, G., ENEL, Milan, Italy; Prandoni, W., ENEL, Milan, Italy; Traniello Gradassi, A., ENEL, Milan, Italy
Abstract: With the aim of testing the use of fluidized bed boilers for electric power generation, ENEL (the Italian Electricity Board) has promoted a research project into a 10 MWth pressurized pilot fluidized combustor at the experimental station in Livorno (De Michele et al., 1991). The initial program of experiments on the ENEL pilot unit is carried out at atmospheric pressure (AFBC) in order to check the plant performances both at steady state and under dynamic conditions before future operation at higher pressure (PFBC). A simulation model for the whole plant has been developed in order to gain a better understanding of the process phenomena, to assess operating procedures, to define admissible operation ranges, to study the control and automation system and to produce a real time simulator to be used for training and as a plant analyzer. The dynamic mathematical model for the description of the combustor was developed taking into account fluid-dynamics, drying, devolatization, combustion and attrition of the coal particles, mass storage, transport and exchange of the gas-components, homogeneous gas phase reactions, energy storage and exchange among coal particles, gases, solids and cooling surfaces, and free-board phenomena. Submodels for calcium oxide formation from limestone, sulphur dioxide removal, NOx generation and destruction are still under development. The structure of the model and the main interaction between submodels are shown in Fig. 1. The model is currently used for atmospheric pressure operation. However its governing equations are also valid under pressure, with a few correlations and parameters modified appropriately. The model of the other plant systems (feed-water, in-bed and wall heat exchangers, air and flue gas, etc.) are based on the modelling method already used for conventional power plant training simulators (Busi et al., 1989). This paper is aimed at: describing the system model, with the assumptions and the governing equations considered in each submodel; discussing the model application at steady state with reference to experimental results obtained on a pre-pilot fluidized bed combustor at CNR/IRC in Naples; validating the model under dynamic conditions using the results of transient tests carried out on the ENEL pilot facility in Livorno.
Index Keywords: Computers--Applications; Control Systems--Applications; Fluid Dynamics; Heat Transfer; Mathematical Models; AFBC; Air Mass Flow Rate; Combustor Dynamic Model; Dynamic Simulation; Energy Storage; PFBC; Combustors

Authors: Toksoy M., Ilken Z.
Title: The effects of phase change during the stand-by period in latent heat energy storage systems
Affiliations: Dokuz Eylul University, Faculty of Engineering and Architecture, Mechanical Engineering Department, Bornova, Izmir, Turkey
Authors with affiliations: Toksoy, M., Dokuz Eylul University, Faculty of Engineering and Architecture, Mechanical Engineering Department, Bornova, Izmir, Turkey; Ilken, Z., Dokuz Eylul University, Faculty of Engineering and Architecture, Mechanical Engineering Department, Bornova, Izmir, Turkey
Abstract: When the boundary condition causing a phase change is interrupted, the phase change process continues until the temperature distribution in the whole system becomes uniform due to the temperature gradients existing in both phases. This continuing phase change during the so called "stand-by solidification" period should be taken into consideration especially at the design and the simulation stages of periodically charged/discharged latent heat energy storage systems. In this work, the effect of this freezing mechanism on the position of interface is analyzed for a semi-infinite region in cartesian coordinates and for both inward and outward solidification in cylindrical coordinates. The effects of both the Stefan number and the interface position at the time of interruption on the last interface position are given in graphical forms. Also, the actual heat removal time to solidify all the phase change material encapsulated in a cylindrical container is given. © 1991.

Authors with affiliations: Sulfredge, C.D., Univ of Kentucky, Lexington, United States; Chow, L.C., Univ of Kentucky, Lexington, United States; Tagavi, K.A., Univ of Kentucky, Lexington, United States
Abstract: Experiments were carried out to observe the solidification sequence and void distribution for two different experimental liquids (cyclohexane and butanediol) enclosed in Pyrex tubes. Both liquids exhibited about 10% volumetric shrinkage during the phase transition from liquid to solid. To evaluate the possibility of regulating void formation by soluble gases, tests were conducted both in the presence and absence of dissolved air. A physical model was developed which predicts the essential features of the solidification pattern under earth's gravity field of 1-g and allows extrapolation of the results to outer space conditions of 0-g. Finally, an attempt was made to determine analytically the final void shape which would result from each nucleation point in 0-g. Understanding these aspects of the solidification process is vital to development of better thermal energy storage systems for space power applications.

Authors: Crane Roger A., Dustin Miles O.
Title: Solar dynamic power/process heat generation for the proposed lunar oxygen production plant
Affiliations: Univ of South Florida, Tampa, United States
Authors with affiliations: Crane, Roger A., Univ of South Florida, Tampa, United States; Dustin, Miles O., Univ of South Florida, Tampa, United States
Abstract: Oxygen production is considered a primary objective of the proposed permanent lunar base. Reduction of Ilmenite ore is commonly considered as a leading technology for this process. The process is energy intensive requiring significant quantities of both electrical and thermal energy. If the plant is to operate continuously through the long lunar night, suitable provisions must be made for uninterrupted power. A concept is presented to provide for thermal energy storage using in-situ lunar materials. This system is to be utilized in conjunction with an Advanced Solar Dynamic Power Generation unit to provide a low deliverable mass energy source. The paper describes the overall power system as adapted to the process requirements, analyzes the power system mass and outlines the technological development requirements needed prior to system development.

Abstract: Materials and design of the vanadium redox battery are different from most conventional batteries.
