Title: Thermal properties of organic latent cold storage materials
Affiliations: Sektion Chemie, Bergakademie Freiberg, Germany; Sektion Chemie, Friedrich-Schiller-Universität Jena, Germany
Authors with affiliations: Bulgrin, R., Sektion Chemie, Bergakademie Freiberg, Germany; Naumann, R., Sektion Chemie, Bergakademie Freiberg, Germany; Emons, H.-H., Sektion Chemie, Bergakademie Freiberg, Germany; Holfter, U., Sektion Chemie, Bergakademie Freiberg, Germany, Sektion Chemie, Friedrich-Schiller-Universität Jena, Germany
Abstract: The thermal properties of organic compounds intended to be applied as latent cold storage substances were investigated by methods of analysis according to Tammann, and by DTA and DSC. Findings were made concerning the melting and solidification behaviour, subcooling, specific melting enthalpies and specific heat capacities of paraffin mixtures, low and high-molecular glycols, ethylenediamine hydrates and formamide. Ethylenediamines and ethylene glycol, with high storage densities of 200-300 MJ·m-3, appear to be promising cold storage substances if subcooling is reduced. Through the use of congruently melting low-molecular glycols and formamide, storage densities of about 170 MJ·m-3 are obtained. Paraffin mixtures and high-molecular glycols melt in wide ranges of temperatures and give values of about 100 MJ·m-3, which are not relevant to cold storage units. © 1991 Wiley Heyden Ltd., Chichester and Akadémiai Kiadó, Budapest.
Index Keywords: Energy Storage; Glycols; Paraffins - Mixing; Ethylenediamine Hydrates; Ethylenediamines; Formamide; Latent Cold Storage Substances; Lattice Transformation Processes; Organic Compounds

Authors: Hodges L.
Title: The hodges residence: The first ten years
Affiliations: Department of Physics, Iowa State University, Ames, IA, 50011, United States
Authors with affiliations: Hodges, L., Department of Physics, Iowa State University, Ames, IA, 50011, United States
Abstract: The Hodges Residence is a superinsulated direct gain passive solar home in Ames, lowa (latitude 42.0°N, longitude 93.8°W). The architect was David A. Block, A.I.A., and the solar system was designed by Block and Laurent Hodges. The home was designed in 1978 and built in 1978-1979; it was a winner in the 1978 National Passive Solar Residential Design Competition. A notable feature of the home was its innovative use of concrete cored slabs as heat storage. The home has been occupied for ten years and has proved to have a very low Home Heating Index of less than 0.7 W/°C.m2 (3 Btu/°F.day.ft2). The performance of the home during its first ten years of occupancy, its economics, and occupant reactions are described. © Ambient Press 1991.
Index Keywords: Economics; Energy Conservation; Heat Insulating Materials; Direct Gain; Mechanical Systems; Off-Peak Auxiliary Energy; Superinsulation; Houses

Authors: Bernier H., Raghavan G.S.V., Paris J.
Title: Evaluation of a soil heat exchanger-storage system for a greenhouse. Part II. Energy saving aspects
Affiliations: Inst de Technologie Agro-Alimentaire, La Pocatiere, Canada
Authors with affiliations: Bernier, H., Inst de Technologie Agro-Alimentaire, La Pocatiere, Canada; Raghavan, G.S.V., Inst de Technologie Agro-Alimentaire, La Pocatiere, Canada; Paris, J., Inst de Technologie Agro-Alimentaire, La Pocatiere, Canada
Abstract: A soil heat exchanger-storage system consisting of 26 non-perforated, corrugated plastic drainage pipes, 102 mm in diameter, was installed in a commercial-type greenhouse. Two rows of 13 pipes, 12 m long, were buried at 450 mm and 750 mm depths, respectively. The pipes run parallel to the horizontal axis of the greenhouse, and are spaced 450 mm apart. Ambient air from the greenhouse is circulated through the pipes at a flowrate of 0.91 m3/s. The system performance is more influenced by greenhouse air temperature than by incident solar radiation. Results indicate that solar energy contributed to 58% of the heating requirements from February to June and from September to December 1986. This contribution represents approximately a 33% energy saving. The payback period for the system is from one to five years, depending on costs and crop productivity improvements.
Index Keywords: Economics - Analysis; Energy Conservation - Analysis; Greenhouses - Heat Exchangers; Heat Exchangers - Testing; Soils - Energy Storage; Payback Periods; Soil Heat Exchangers; Soils

Authors: Smith D.O., Tajima N., Oura C., Toshimori K.
Title: Digital artery tortuosity and elasticity: A biomechanical study
Affiliations: 808 East Wakefield, Sikeston, MO 63801, United States
Authors with affiliations: Smith, D.O., 808 East Wakefield, Sikeston, MO 63801, United States; Tajima, N., 808 East Wakefield, Sikeston, MO 63801, United States; Oura, C., 808 East Wakefield, Sikeston, MO 63801, United States; Toshimori, K., 808 East Wakefield, Sikeston, MO 63801, United States
Abstract: The gross structure of the digital artery distal to the proximal interphalangeal joint is significantly different from its proximal portion. Previous research in this laboratory has revealed that over half of all fingers exhibit marked tortuosity of this artery in juxtaposition to the distal interphalangeal joint. Any structure with a large amount of bending will have the properties of a spring. An understanding of these properties may help in creating tension-free anastomoses during finger tip replantation. The elastic strength and energy storage capacities of the distal digital artery were measured in 26 cadaver arteries.
Index Keywords: article; autopsy; biomechanics; digital artery; elasticity; finger replantation; human; human tissue

Authors: Unsal Mazhar
Title: Long term performance of heat pumps with spherical underground thermal stores
Source title: Proceedings of the International Centre for Heat and Mass Transfer
Affiliations: Univ of Gaziantep, Gaziantep, Turkey
Authors with affiliations: Unsal, Mazhar, Univ of Gaziantep, Gaziantep, Turkey
Abstract: An analytical solution for the transient temperature field around a buried spherical thermal store with arbitrarily varying surface temperature is presented in this study. The solution to the transient heat transfer problem is obtained by the application of a similarity transformation and Duhamel's superposition principle. The solution obtained is applied to investigate the long term performance of a heat pump system with energy storage in an underground spherical vessel with yeararound charging of heat using solar collectors and extraction of stored thermal energy for space heating during winter months. Annual dimensionless store temperature and the annual performance of the heat pump system are estimated and presented in graphical form.
Index Keywords: Energy Storage; Heat Transfer; Temperature Distribution - Transients; Coefficient of Performance; Heat Pump Systems

Authors: Waugh W.J., Thiede M.E., Cadwell L.L., Gee G.W., Freeman H.D., Sackschewsky M.R., Relyea J.F.
Title: Small lysimeters for documenting arid site water balance
Source title: Lysimeters for Evapotranspiration and Environmental Measurements
Affiliations: Chem-Nuclear Geotech, Inc, Grand Junction, United States
Authors with affiliations: Waugh, W.J., Chem-Nuclear Geotech, Inc, Grand Junction, United States; Thiede, M.E., Chem-Nuclear Geotech, Inc, Grand Junction, United States; Cadwell, L.L., Chem-Nuclear Geotech, Inc, Grand Junction, United States; Gee, G.W., Chem-Nuclear Geotech, Inc, Grand Junction, United States; Freeman, H.D., Chem-Nuclear Geotech, Inc, Grand Junction, United States; Sackschewsky, M.R., Chem-Nuclear Geotech, Inc, Grand Junction, United States; Relyea, J.F., Chem-Nuclear Geotech, Inc, Grand Junction, United States
Abstract: Small weighing lysimeters consisting of plastic pipes with lifting and drainage fittings were installed at the arid U.S. Department of Energy (DOE) Hanford Site in southcentral Washington State to conduct factorial experiments comparing the influences of various waste site cover designs on soil water balance. Results of a comparison of erosion control designs indicate that gravel can be mixed into the soil surface to control soil loss without influencing the water balance. In contrast, an equivalent amount of gravel applied as a surface mulch suppressed evapotranspiration resulting in increased storage and drainage. Only slight differences were observed in a comparison of storage changes in the small lysimeters and adjacent large weighing lysimeters. Time series of soil temperature for the small lysimeters and for nearby soil profiles converged after insulation collars were installed.
Index Keywords: Radioactive Wastes - Monitoring; Water - Storage; Water Resources - Evapotranspiration; Arid Site Water Balance; Drainage Fittings; Lifting Fittings; Soil Temperature Effects; Weighing Lysimeters; Lysimeters

Authors: Mimikou M.A., Hadjisavva P.S., Kouvopoulos Y.S.
Title: Regional effects of climate change on water resources systems
Source title: IAHS Publication (International Association of Hydrological Sciences)
Affiliations: Natl Technical Univ of Athens, Athens, Greece
Authors with affiliations: Mimikou, M.A., Natl Technical Univ of Athens, Athens, Greece; Hadjisavva, P.S., Natl Technical Univ of Athens, Athens, Greece; Kouvopoulos, Y.S., Natl Technical Univ of Athens, Athens, Greece
Abstract: Regional effects of greenhouse warming on water resources and water management systems are assessed for a mountainous region of central Greece, by using plausible hypothetical scenarios of temperature and precipitation change. Basin response is examined by focusing on surface runoff series generated by a monthly conceptual model sensitive to temperature and precipitation changes. Results indicate that certain basin morphoclimatic characteristics such as snow cover, basin aridity and morphology, runoff coefficient etc., modify basin response considerably. The operation of a hydropower generation system in the area is then simulated under the assumed climate change scenarios and new risk levels are estimated with respect to firm water and energy supply. Increase of reservoir storage volume is examined as a means to compensate for the increased probability of system failure owing to adverse climate scenarios.
Index Keywords: Electric Power Plants; Greenhouse Effect; Hydroelectric Power Plants; Meteorology--Climatology; Rivers--Greece; RUNOFF; SNOW AND SNOWFALL; Climate Change; Energy Supply; Regional Effects; Water Management; Water Resources

Authors: Gorman Laurel T.
Title: Assessment of the nearshore zone at St. Marys Inlet, Florida
Source title: Coastal Zone: Proceedings of the Symposium on Coastal and Ocean Management
Affiliations: US Army Engineer Waterways, Experiment Station, Vicksburg, United States
Authors with affiliations: Gorman, Laurel T., US Army Engineer Waterways, Experiment Station, Vicksburg, United States
Abstract: St. Marys Inlet connects Cumberland Sound from the Atlantic Ocean and actually forms the coastline border between Georgia and Florida. Drumstick shaped barriers are located to the north (Cumberland Island) and to the south (Amelia Island). The mean tidal range is 1.8 m and wave heights average 0.6 m. Southerly directed longshore sediment transport is dominant due to alongshore wave energy increasing to the southeast. Nearshore processes, sediment distribution patterns, and ebb-tidal delta morphology are all being measured and used to document temporal change in the physical and environmental parameters of St. Marys Inlet. This investigation is ongoing and part of a five-year monitoring program sponsored by the U.S. Navy. This paper discusses wave, bathymetric profiles, and sediment data sets collected during August 1988 and August 1989. Inshore wave conditions during April-October 1989 ranged between 0.27 and 1.76 m for significant wave height and between 4.3 and 14.2 seconds for wave period. Spatial changes in nearshore subbottom elevation were evaluated within six distinct morphologic features. Bathymetric contours of the nearshore zone to the -10 m contour indicates three large areas of sediment storage and two embayment areas where sediments are moved alongshore and offshore. The average mean grain size generally decreased along both islands within the beach and nearshore zones between the summer of 1988 and summer 1989. This change is attributed to several factors: storm activity, beach nourishment activity on Amelia Island, and alongshore sediment movement.
Index Keywords: Flow of Water--Sediment Transport; Rivers--Estuaries; Tides--Effects; Bathymetric Profiles; Nearshore Wave Action; Offshore Barrier Island Inlets; Tidal Delta Complexes; Tidal Sediment Transport; Oceanography

Authors: Fathalah K., Aly S.E.
Title: Theoretical study of a solar powered absorption/MED combined system
Affiliations: Mechanical Engineering Department, King Abdul Aziz University, P.O. Box 9027, Jeddah 21413, Saudia Arabia
Authors with affiliations: Fathalah, K., Mechanical Engineering Department, King Abdul Aziz University, P.O. Box 9027, Jeddah 21413, Saudia Arabia; Aly, S.E., Mechanical Engineering Department, King Abdul Aziz University, P.O. Box 9027, Jeddah 21413, Saudia Arabia
Abstract: In this article, a theoretical study is presented for a solar powered combined system comprising a LiBrH2O absorption cooling machine and a multiple-effect distillator (MED). The MED has 8 VTE of the falling film type, and it replaces the condenser in conventional absorption machines. Steam released at the generator pressure is supplied to the effect which matches its conditions, and the condensate follows its usual route towards the evaporator of an A/C unit. Thus, the MED is powered by the waste heat of the absorption machine which improves the overall gain and the thermodynamic characteristics significantly. Governing equations for the combined system are given and are numerically solved. Medium parabolic concentrators are used to power the system, and a transient simulation for the combined arrangement is presented. Results are given for a typical design summer day in Jeddah, Saudi Arabia, for a range of firing temperatures 150-190°C with a storage temperature amplitude of 10-20°C over a daily working period of 12 h. For a given cooling load of 100 ton refrigeration, the system can produce up to 40m3 of fresh water at a specific collector area of 12.41. H2O plus 0.03 TR/m2. The overall COPo reaches 1.44, which is more than twice that of a conventional absorption machine at the same temperature levels. © 1991.
Author Keywords: Absorption; Cooling; Distillation; Multiple effect; Solar
Index Keywords: Distillation Equipment; Refrigerating Machinery - Condensers; Solar Radiation - Collectors; Waste Heat Utilization; Absorption Cooling Machine; Medium Parabolic Concentrators; Multiple Effect Distillator; Solar Powered Combined System; Solar Energy

Authors: Sorenson K.B., Brown N.N., Bennett P.C., Lake W.
Title: Evaluation of storage/transportation options to support criteria development for the Phase I MRSa
Affiliations: Sandia Natl Lab, Albuquerque, United States
Authors with affiliations: Sorenson, K.B., Sandia Natl Lab, Albuquerque, United States; Brown, N.N., Sandia Natl Lab, Albuquerque, United States; Bennett, P.C., Sandia Natl Lab, Albuquerque, United States; Lake, W., Sandia Natl Lab, Albuquerque, United States
Abstract: The Department of Energy's (DOE) Office of Civilian Waste Management (OCRWM) plans to develop an interim storage facility to enable acceptance of spent fuel in 1998. It is estimated that this interim storage facility would be needed for about two years. A Monitored Retrievable Storage (MRS) facility is anticipated in 2000 and a repository in 2010. Acceptance and transport of spent fuel by DOE/OCRWM in 1988 will require an operating transportation system. Because this interim storage facility is not yet defined, development of an optimally compatible transportation system is not a certainty. In order to assure a transport capability for 1998 acceptance of spent fuel, it was decided that the OCRWM transportation program had to identify likely options for an interim storage facility, including identification of the components needed for compatibility between likely interim storage facility options and transportation. Primary attention was given to existing hardware, although conceptual designs were also considered. A systems-based probabilistic decision model was suggested by Sandia National Laboratories and accepted by DOE/OCRWM's transportation program. Performance of the evaluation task involved several elements of the transportation program. This paper describes the decision model developed to accomplish this task, along with some of the results and conclusions.
Index Keywords: Nuclear Reactors--Spent Fuels; Radioactive Materials--Storage; Dry Fuel Transfer Criteria; Interim Storage Facility; Office of Civilian Waste Management; Radwaste Storage/Transportation; Radioactive Wastes

Authors: Masaharu Mitsunaga, Naoshi Uesugi
Title: Linear and nonlinear spectroscopy of Eu3+ in crystals
Affiliations: NTT Basic Research Laboratories, Musashino-shi, Tokyo, 180, Japan
Authors with affiliations: Masaharu Mitsunaga, NTT Basic Research Laboratories, Musashino-shi, Tokyo, 180, Japan; Naoshi Uesugi, NTT Basic Research Laboratories, Musashino-shi, Tokyo, 180, Japan
Abstract: Linear and nonlinear spectroscopic studies on the 7F0-5D2, -5D1, and -5D0 transitions of Eu3+ ions doped in YAIO3, YAG(Y3Al5O12), LaF3 and Y2O3 crystals are reported based on photoluminescence (PL) and photon echo (PE) measurements. Relaxation dynamics of the optically excited ions were investigated from the PL spectra and the wavelength-dependent PL decay time measurements. Two-pulse photon echoes were observed for the first time for these transitions and all the echoes were identified to be long-lived, with the storage time ranging from minutes to hours. Recently developed novel coherent transients using these samples are also reported. Specific stress is put upon the cw photon echo which enables a single shot measurement of the homogeneous dephasing time and the sublevel splitting frequencies of a medium. © 1991.
Index Keywords: Crystals; Photoluminescence; Relaxation Processes; Energy Level Transitions; Europium

Authors: Sato Eiichi, Isobe Hiroshi, Takahashi Kei, Tamakawa Yoshiharu, Yanagisawa Toru
Title: Fundamental studies for the high-intensity long-duration flash x-ray generator for biomedical radiography
Source title: Proceedings of SPIE - The International Society for Optical Engineering
Affiliations: Iwate Medical Univ, Morioka, Japan
Authors with affiliations: Sato, Eiichi, Iwate Medical Univ, Morioka, Japan; Isobe, Hiroshi, Iwate Medical Univ, Morioka, Japan; Takahashi, Kei, Iwate Medical Univ, Morioka, Japan; Tamakawa, Yoshiharu, Iwate Medical Univ, Morioka, Japan; Yanagisawa, Toru, Iwate Medical Univ, Morioka, Japan
Abstract: The fundamental studies for the repetitive high-intensity microsecond x-ray generator utilizing a cold cathode tetrode are described. This generator consisted of the following essential components: a constant high-voltage power supply, an energy storage condenser of 500nF, an main discharge condenser of 10nF, a turbo molecular pump, a repetitive trigger device, and an x-ray tube. The condenser was charged from 40 to 80kV, and the electric charges in the condenser were discharged repetitively to an x-ray tube by a trigger device. The x-ray tube was of the tetrode type which was connected to a turbo molecular pump and consisted of the following major parts: a rod-shaped long anode tip made of tungsten, a cathode rod made of graphite, a ring-shaped grid electrode, and a trigger electrode. The trigger electrode was mounted at the center of the cathode electrode and was insulated by a ceramic tube. The tube current was about 0.4kA with a charged voltage of 60kV. The x-ray pulse height and the time-integrated intensity increased when the condenser charged voltage was increased, and the intensity was less than 2.0μC/kg at 1m per pulse. The exposure times were about 20μs, about 20μs, and the repetition frequency was less than 50Hz.
Index Keywords: Biomedical Equipment; Radiography - X-Ray; X-Ray Tubes; Cold Cathode Tetrode; Focal Spot; Grid Electrode; High-Intensity Microsecond Flash; Repetition Frequency; X-Ray Generator; X-Ray Apparatus

Authors: Domschke T., Nietsch T., Schütt E.
Title: The temperature-dependence of hydrogen sorption in metal hydrides
Affiliations: Technische Universität Berlin, Fasanenstraße 89, 1000 Berlin 12, Germany
Authors with affiliations: Domschke, T., Technische Universität Berlin, Fasanenstraße 89, 1000 Berlin 12, Germany; Nietsch, T., Technische Universität Berlin, Fasanenstraße 89, 1000 Berlin 12, Germany; Schütt, E., Technische Universität Berlin, Fasanenstraße 89, 1000 Berlin 12, Germany
Abstract: Down to temperatures about - 100C and lower the sorption kinetic and the diffusion rate of the Ti Zr Laves phase hydride investigated here are very high. For this reason and because of the sorption enthalpy of about 25 kJ mol-1 it is difficult to establish isothermal measurement conditions. The result is a thermal ignition. With a very simple thermal ignition model based on an energy balance and first order kinetic the measurements at temperatures down to - 196°C are explained. The kinetic parameters taken for calculating the ignition model have previously been published by Bernauer et al. in this journal. The experimental and theoretical results presented here ensure that the sorption model previously presented is usable for hydride storage systems filled with such fast reacting hydrides. © 1991.
Index Keywords: Hydrides; Thermodynamics; Titanium Zirconium Alloys--Diffusion; Damkoehler Number; Metal Alloy DB 5800; Sorption Enthalpy; Thermal Ignition Model; Hydrogen Fuels

Authors: Ledjeff K., Heinzel A.
Title: Regenerative fuel cell for energy storage in PV systems
Source title: Proceedings of the Intersociety Energy Conversion Engineering Conference
Affiliations: Fraunhofer Inst for Solar Energy, Systems, Freiburg, Germany
Authors with affiliations: Ledjeff, K., Fraunhofer Inst for Solar Energy, Systems, Freiburg, Germany; Heinzel, A., Fraunhofer Inst for Solar Energy, Systems, Freiburg, Germany
Abstract: Regenerative fuel cells (RFCs) are of great interest for storing energy in various space applications. In general the systems are based on the electrolysis of water, the storage of hydrogen and oxygen, and the following recombination to water in a fuel cell. Three basic cell concepts have to be distinguished - dedicated, integrated, reversible. There are important differences between these concepts and additionally the performance of the RFCs is influenced by the type of electrochemical cell - alkaline, membrane. Solar systems in stand-alone applications suffer from the lack of availability of reasonable seasonal energy storage. RFCs are a very promising option for terrestrial photovoltaic installations and the feasibility will be demonstrated in the energetically self-sufficient solar house, which will be built in the near future.
Index Keywords: Energy Storage; Technology; Energetically Self-Sufficient Solar House; Hybrid Energy Storage System; Hydrogen-Oxygen Fuel Cells; Regenerative Fuel Cell (RFC) Technologies; Solid Polymer Electrolytes (SPFC); Terrestrial Solar Installations; Fuel Cells

Authors: Hirabayashi Toshihiko, Furuta Sigenobu, Satoh Hisakata
Title: Status of the 'Moonlight Project' on Advanced Battery Electric Energy Storage System
Source title: Proceedings of the Intersociety Energy Conversion Engineering Conference
Affiliations: New Energy and Industrial Technology, Development Organization, Tokyo, Japan
Authors with affiliations: Hirabayashi, Toshihiko, New Energy and Industrial Technology, Development Organization, Tokyo, Japan; Furuta, Sigenobu, New Energy and Industrial Technology, Development Organization, Tokyo, Japan; Satoh, Hisakata, New Energy and Industrial Technology, Development Organization, Tokyo, Japan
Abstract: The New Energy and Industrial Technology Development Organization (NEDO) has been conducting the Advanced Battery Electric Energy Storage System Project since 1980, as a part of the 'Moonlight Project' of the Agency of Industrial Science and Technology (AIST), the Ministry of International Trade and Industry (MITI). The Project aims at constructing advanced battery electric energy storage pilot plants and conducting operation test to obtain a good prospect of practical application of such plants. The total budget of the project, which begun in 1980 and extends over 12 years, is 17 billion yen. The developmental activities consist of five major items: R & D of Advanced Batteries; R & D of System Technology; Operational Research of Pilot Plants; Study of Total System; and Study of Application to Electric Vehicle Battery. About eleven years have passed since the beginning of the Project. The construction of two types of advanced battery pilot plants has almost completed, and test operations started in november 1990. This paper describes the results achieved so far and the present status of R&D on advanced battery pilot plants.
Index Keywords: Engineering Research; Storage Battery Vehicles; Advanced Battery Pilot Plants; Moonlight Project; Electric Batteries, Secondary

Authors: Brunner Daniel J., Wallace Keith G.Jr, Deen Justus B.
Title: Effects of natural ventilation pressure on the underground ventilation system at the waste isolation pilot plant
Source title: Proceedings of the US Mine Ventilation Symposium
Affiliations: Mine Ventilation Services, Inc.
Authors with affiliations: Brunner, Daniel J., Mine Ventilation Services, Inc.; Wallace, Keith G.Jr, Mine Ventilation Services, Inc.; Deen, Justus B., Mine Ventilation Services, Inc.
Abstract: This paper describes the impact of natural ventilation pressure (NVP) on the Nuclear Waste Isolation Pilot Plant in New Mexico (WIPP). The WIPP site is a U.S. Department of Energy underground facility for the disposal of low level radioactive transuranic defense generated waste. Because the facility is designed for the storage of nuclear waste, special design considerations are necessary to ensure containment of potential radioactive releases. The main design considerations which influence the ventilation system are the requirements of separate air splits for mining and storage operations and of air filtering before atmospheric discharge in the event of a radioactive release. The leakage between the two air splits must always be from the mining area to the storage area. The transient effects of natural ventilation pressures, caused by seasonal and diurnal surface temperature changes, impact the ventilation characteristics throughout the facility. This paper discusses the measurements taken to quantify the changes in NVP and the engineered systems designed to mitigate against the effects of NVP.
Index Keywords: Meteorology - Effects; Radioactive Wastes - Geological Repositories; Salt Deposits - New Mexico; Salt Mines and Mining - Pilot Plants; Natural Ventilation Pressure (NVP); NVP Effect; Underground Ventilation Systems; Waste Isolation Pilot Plant (WIPP); Mine Ventilation

Authors: Koebbe Rick S.
Title: Benefits and applications of modular hydroelectric pumped storage
Source title: Waterpower '91: A New View of Hydro Resources
Affiliations: Pacific Turbine Systems Inc, San Francisco, United States
Authors with affiliations: Koebbe, Rick S., Pacific Turbine Systems Inc, San Francisco, United States
Abstract: Hydroelectric pumped storage is the only proven and most efficient technology available for energy storage. It is used by utilities to provide peak and intermediate power and to optimize overall system performance. Because of increased environmental and regulatory constraints, few acceptable sites, long schedules, and huge financial commitments, large conventional pumped storage plants, typically ranging in size from 500 MW to 200 MW, are now virtually impossible to build. As an alternative, small modular pumped storage, with project sizes ranging 25 MW to 200 MW, was created to overcome the difficulties of conventional projects. The modular approach involves standardizing the elements of a pumped storage plant by utilizing specialized siting techniques and optimizing design, equipment, and construction. Compared with conventional pumped storage, the modular design can reduce cost and expedite schedule; reduce environmental concerns and permitting obstacles; and expand applications of energy storage on a utility's system.
Index Keywords: Electric Utilities; Energy Storage; Environmental Protection; Modular Hydroelectric Pumped Storage Plants; Small Modular Pumped Storage Plants; Hydroelectric Power Plants

Authors: Elleson J.S.
Title: High-quality air conditioning with cold air distribution
Affiliations: Dorgan Associates Inc, Madison, United States
Authors with affiliations: Elleson, J.S., Dorgan Associates Inc, Madison, United States
Abstract: Cold air distribution (42°F-49°F supply air) has been widely applied because of its benefits of reduced first cost, reduced building height, and reduced energy and electric demand cost. In addition, improvements in comfort and indoor air quality have been noted. However, it has been found that energy savings may be reduced or eliminated by the addition of fan-powered mixing boxes to a cold air distribution system. Direct supply of 42°F-49°F air to a space is practical and desirable, using currently available diffusers, to provide superior room air diffusion and maximum energy savings. More published test data on the performance of diffusers with 42°F-49°F air are needed.
Index Keywords: Air Pollution - Air Quality; Air Pollution - Indoor; Energy Conservation - Economics; Energy Storage; Cold Air Distribution; Air Conditioning

Authors: Sedgwick L.M., Kaufmann K.J., McLallin K.L., Kerslake T.W.
Title: Ground test program for a full-size solar dynamic heat receiver
Source title: Proceedings of the Intersociety Energy Conversion Engineering Conference
Affiliations: Boeing Aerospace & Electronics, Seattle, United States
Authors with affiliations: Sedgwick, L.M., Boeing Aerospace & Electronics, Seattle, United States; Kaufmann, K.J., Boeing Aerospace & Electronics, Seattle, United States; McLallin, K.L., Boeing Aerospace & Electronics, Seattle, United States; Kerslake, T.W., Boeing Aerospace & Electronics, Seattle, United States
Abstract: Test hardware, facilities, and procedures were developed to conduct ground testing of a full-size, solar dynamic heat receiver in a partially simulated, low-Earth-orbit environment. The heat receiver was designed to supply 102 kW of thermal energy to a helium and xenon gas mixture continuously over a 94 minute orbit, including up to 36 minutes of eclipse. The purpose of the test program was to quantify the receiver thermodynamic performance, its operating temperatures, and thermal response to changes in environmental and power module interface boundary conditions. The heat receiver was tested in a vacuum chamber using liquid nitrogen cold shrouds and an aperture cold plate. Special test equipment were designed to provide the required ranges in interface boundary conditions that typify those expected or required for operation as part of the solar dynamic power module on the Space Station Freedom. The support hardware includes an infrared quartz lamp heater with 30 independently controllable zones and a closed-Brayton cycle engine simulator to circulate and condition the helium-xenon gas mixture. This paper describes the test article, test support hardware, facilities, and instrumentation developed to conduct the ground test program.
Index Keywords: Computer Simulation; Heating--Heat Storage; Solar Energy; Thermodynamics--Brayton Cycle; Solar Dynamic Heat Receivers; Space Station Freedom; Space Stations

Authors: Richter Scott W.
Title: Technology development of fabrication techniques for Advanced Solar Dynamic Concentrators
Source title: Proceedings of the Intersociety Energy Conversion Engineering Conference
Affiliations: Sverdrup Technology, Inc, Cleveland, United States
Authors with affiliations: Richter, Scott W., Sverdrup Technology, Inc, Cleveland, United States
Abstract: In 1985, the NASA Lewis Research Center initiated the Advanced Solar Dynamic Concentrator Technology Development Program as part of an overall Advanced Solar Dynamic Power System Project. The objective of the Advanced Concentrator Program is to develop the technology that will lead to lightweight, highly reflective, accurate, scaleable and long-lived space solar dynamic concentrators. The Advanced Concentrator program encompasses new and innovative concepts, fabrication techniques, materials selection, and simulated space environmental testing. Fabrication techniques include methods of fabricating the substrates and coating substrate surfaces to produce high quality optical surfaces, acceptable for further coating with vapor deposited optical films. The selected materials to obtain a high quality optical surface include microsheet glass and Eccocoat EP-3 epoxy, with DC-93-500 selected as a candidate silicone adhesive and levelizing layer. The following procedures are defined; cutting, cleaning, forming, and bonding microsheet glass. Procedures are also defined for surface cleaning, and EP-3 epoxy application. The results and analyses from atomic oxygen and thermal cycling tests will be used to determine the effects of orbital conditions in a space environment.
Index Keywords: Epoxy Resins; Heating--Heat Storage; Solar Radiation--Concentrators; Solar Dynamic Systems; Solar Energy

Authors: Bolwin K., Hauff S.
Title: Reduction potential of the system mass of hydrogen/oxygen based regenerative fuel cell (RFC) systems for LEO applications
Source title: Proceedings of the Intersociety Energy Conversion Engineering Conference
Affiliations: German Aerospace Research, Establishment, Stuttgart, Germany
Authors with affiliations: Bolwin, K., German Aerospace Research, Establishment, Stuttgart, Germany; Hauff, S., German Aerospace Research, Establishment, Stuttgart, Germany
Abstract: A major disadvantage of conventional battery systems regarding their design point is the strong coupling of their capacity and rated power due to the entire surface area of the electrodes. For regenerative fuel cell systems these parameters are decoupled since their capacity is directly related to the fuel storage capacity, while the rated power still depends on the electrode area. This intrinsic advantage of the RFC system permits a design optimization by varying the current density of both, the electrolyser and the fuel cell stack and subsequent evaluating the masses of the considered subsystems. Mass optimization has been performed based on a dedicated electrolyser and fuel cell system, considering the masses of a photovoltaic array, a radiator and storages. The energy storage capacity has been designed for the limiting conditions of a LEO mission in a 450 km orbit and a mean power requirement of 25 kW. It is shown, that the system mass could be reduced for LEO missions assuming steady waste heat rejection due to the introduction of a thermal storage. The reduction potential has been estimated to be up to 10 percent of the system mass, depending on orbit hight and system characteristics.
Index Keywords: Electric Batteries; Energy Storage; Electrochemical Cell Analysis; Energy Storage Concepts; Environmental Control and Life Support (ECLS); Hydrogen/Oxygen Fuel Cells; Low-Earth Orbit (LEO) Battery Systems; Regenerative Fuel Cells (RFC); Fuel Cells

Authors: Milster T.D., Treptau J.P.
Title: Measurement of laser spot quality
Source title: Proceedings of SPIE - The International Society for Optical Engineering
Affiliations: Univ of Arizona, Tucson, United States
Authors with affiliations: Milster, T.D., Univ of Arizona, Tucson, United States; Treptau, J.P., Univ of Arizona, Tucson, United States
Abstract: Several ways of measuring spot quality are compared. We examine in detail various figures of merit such as full-width-at-half maximum (FWHM), full-width-at-1/e2 maximum, Strehl ratio, and encircled energy. Our application is optical data storage, but results can be applied to other areas like space communications and high-energy lasers. We found that the optimum figure of merit in many cases is Strehl ratio.
Index Keywords: Data Storage, Optical - Quality Control; Interferometry - Applications; Light - Coherent; CCD Cameras; Knife Edge Scanners; Laser Spot Quality; Laser Beams

Authors: Najafi M., Schaetzle W.J., Huang J.T.
Title: Latent heat storage applications in heat pump
Source title: Proceedings of the Intersociety Energy Conversion Engineering Conference
Affiliations: USL, Lafayette, United States
Authors with affiliations: Najafi, M., USL, Lafayette, United States; Schaetzle, W.J., USL, Lafayette, United States; Huang, J.T., USL, Lafayette, United States
Abstract: Latent heat energy storage has been an attractive strategy for shifting power demand to off-peak hours. Among many energy storage media clathrates have shown to be promising candidates. This paper reports on the operation of a heat pump/thermal energy storage system utilizing clathrate as a storage medium. The concentration will be on the system operation and performance for the cooling side and an analysis of the clathrate solidification for the heating side of the proposed heat pump. A closed-loop thermal energy storage heat pump has been constructed to build and store clathrate. For both the cooling and heating experimental runs have been performed utilizing basic Refrigerant 12 Clathrate. Algorithms have been implemented to provide energy balance for all runs. The experimental results demonstrate the system's potential as a thermal energy storage heat pump. Data obtained during the system operation in the heating mode provides relationships between the solidification rate of clathrate and degree subcooling.
Index Keywords: Computer Programming--Algorithms; Energy Storage; Heating--Heat Storage; Refrigerants; Clathrate; Latent Heat Storage; Subcooling; Heat Pump Systems

Authors: Steiner Dieter
Title: Development of a thermal storage system for automobile preheating
Source title: Proceedings of the Intersociety Energy Conversion Engineering Conference
Affiliations: Univ Stuttgart, Stuttgart, Germany
Authors with affiliations: Steiner, Dieter, Univ Stuttgart, Stuttgart, Germany
Abstract: The development and laboratory test of a 1,5 kWh prototype thermal energy storage system for a maximum storage temperature of 200°C is described. A water-antifreeze mixture is used as the storage medium. The store is designed to be charged by the exhaust gases of the combustion engine via an integrated gas-to-liquid heat exchanger. The store is discharged by flashing the pressurized storage medium via a pipe with a small cross-sectional area and releasing the stored heat at the atmospheric pressure level. Discharge capacity rates well above 10 kW suggest a direct injection of the discharging fluid into the cooling circuit for preheating the cold engine.
Index Keywords: Energy Storage; Heat Exchangers; Internal Combustion Engines--Exhaust Gases; Waste Heat Utilization; Water; Antifreeze; Thermal Energy Storage; Automobiles

Authors: Ibamoto Tadahiko, Tsubota Yuji
Title: Series of study and development of ice-on-coil type ice energy storage HVAC systems in Japan
Source title: Proceedings of the Intersociety Energy Conversion Engineering Conference
Affiliations: Tokyo Denki Univ, Tokyo, Japan
Authors with affiliations: Ibamoto, Tadahiko, Tokyo Denki Univ, Tokyo, Japan; Tsubota, Yuji, Tokyo Denki Univ, Tokyo, Japan
Abstract: This paper presents an outline of the 'Ice on coil type ice energy storage HVAC systems for the buildings in Japan.' The systems were developed as a part of the research efforts to reduce peak electricity load in summer. We developed two systems; one for large scale office buildings, the other for small ones. In case of the system for large scale buildings, firstly we made equipment to evaluate the general characteristics of the ice-on-coil system including thermal stratification, and to establish a design method for the system. For small buildings we developed a unit type ice energy storage system, which consists of a heat pump chiller, a panel tank with ice making heat exchangers and a micro-computerized controller. Both systems were installed in office buildings as pilot plants and measurements were made over one year. For the obtained data, under actual load operation, we made clear the characteristics of the systems and their equipment.
Index Keywords: Air Conditioning; Heat Exchangers; Heating; HOUSES; Office Buildings; Refrigeration; HVAC Systems; Ice-on-coil type ice energy storage; Japan; Ice

Authors: Udagawa Mitsihiro
Title: Linear simulation model of active solar space heating systems
Affiliations: Kogakuin Univ, Tokyo, Japan
Authors with affiliations: Udagawa, Mitsihiro, Kogakuin Univ, Tokyo, Japan
Abstract: In order to predict energy consumption and room thermal environment of active solar space heating systems, a simulation method with the linear subsystems model (LISM) to use one line linear equation for expressing the energy balance of each subsystem was proposed. For the modeling, the total solar space heating system including the building was divided into the solar heat collection system composed of solar heat collectors, heat storage tanks, heat exchangers, and piping and the room subsystem composed of building elements and space heating equipments. The method of conducting the one line equation of the single storage tank type of solar heat collection system and the procedure to combine the solar heat collection system with the room subsystems were described. Furthermore, the result of an example simulation of a single family house was also described.
Index Keywords: Buildings--Solar, Active; Solar Radiation--Collectors; Single family houses; Heating

Authors: Reinisch Ron F.
Title: Fretting wear in magnetic memory disk drives
Source title: Wear of Materials: International Conference on Wear of Materials
Affiliations: Seagate Technology, Scotts Valley, United States
Authors with affiliations: Reinisch, Ron F., Seagate Technology, Scotts Valley, United States
Abstract: Fretting wear has been identified as a potential source of particulate contamination in rigid disk drives using band-stepper motor mechanism to move the actuator arm. Understanding of the wear process permits control of the key variables critical to the production of band-stepper motor drives in high volume. The wear process was studied by airborne particle collection during drive operation, and macrophotography. Elemental analysis of the airborne particles was done by energy dispersive X-ray (EDX) while thiocyanate spot test was used to identify the wear particles as ferric oxide. Fretting wear process was confirmed by the scuff mark pattern tangential to the oscillatory motion of the band. Comprehensive attention to workmanship during band installation has been a major contributor to the overall reliability of band-stepper drives. Early identification and understanding of the wear process helps to avoid wear problems leading to particle production inside the drive cavity, by close attention to material quality at the procurement phase and workmanship during drive build.
Index Keywords: Disks - Wear; Electric Motors, Stepping Type - Applications; X-Ray Analysis; Band-Stepper Drive; Disk Drive Fretting Wear; Energy-Dispersive X-Ray; Magnetic Memory Disk Drives; Thiocyanate Spot Test; Data Storage, Magnetic

Authors: Wyczalek Floyd A.
Title: GM electric vehicle technology in the 1990's
Source title: Proceedings of the Intersociety Energy Conversion Engineering Conference
Affiliations: FWLilly Inc, Birmingham, United States
Authors with affiliations: Wyczalek, Floyd A., FWLilly Inc, Birmingham, United States
Abstract: This is an assessment of General Motors electric propulsion implementation policy, vision, goals, and vehicle development and commercialization strategy. It includes a historical review of key GM electric vehicle developments, a summary of the specifications for the new 1990 GM-Impact electric vehicle, and an outline of a future vision for battery electric propulsion in America. Electric propulsion technology has been under development in GM since the organization of the General Motors Company in 1908 and continued after GM was incoporated in 1916. Historically, during the period 1912 to 1922, GM was the largest producer of electric trucks in the United States. Since then, GM has established a record which shows a dedicated commitment to the continuing reassessment of electric propulsion. As examples, GM strategy has been to periodically build experimental vehicles, and evaluate the state and potential of the component technology relating to electric vehicles. The latest efforts, the GM-Impact and GM HX3 Hybrid gasoline/electric van have again focused attention on electric propulsion.
Index Keywords: Automobiles--Electric; Electric Propulsion; Gasoline; Motor Trucks; Propulsion--Electric Energy; Vehicles; Battery Electric Propulsion; Electric Vehicles; Hybrid Gasoline/Electric Vans; Storage Battery Vehicles

Authors: Saitoh T., Yoshioka M.
Title: Large scale seasonal solar energy heating system. Application to snow melting and airconditioning system for the airport
Affiliations: Tohoku Univ, Sendai, Japan
Authors with affiliations: Saitoh, T., Tohoku Univ, Sendai, Japan; Yoshioka, M., Tohoku Univ, Sendai, Japan
Abstract: In this paper, a seasonal solar energy heating system which can be applicable to large facilities including the airport was proposed. The present system provides energies for melting of snow covered the runaway and also for space heating/cooling of the airport buildings. The computer simulations were carried out for the two systems; One is a sensible heat storage system with a large water tank buried underground and another is a borehole storage system in which vertical boreholes as deep as 100 meters are drilled in the ground. From an economical viewpoint, the latter borehole system will be promising since no large structure such as the water storage tanks is required. The latter system also recovers the heat generated by the space cooling and refrigeration counters utilized in summer season. During the summer months, this excess heat is used for charging a heat store (borehole unit). This heat is then extracted during the winter season to heat the airport facilities and melting of snow covered the runaways.
Index Keywords: Air Conditioning; Airport Runways; Airports--Snow and Ice Removal; Snow and Snowfall--Melting; Solar Energy; Airport facilities; Seasonal solar energy heating; Heating

Authors: Ding Hai
Title: Charge build-up in polypropylene thin films
Affiliations: Tongji Univ, Shanghai, China
Authors with affiliations: Ding, Hai, Tongji Univ, Shanghai, China
Abstract: Irradiation of insulating polymer films with nonpenetrating electron beams results in long-lasting space charge. The charge storage properties of polymer electrets are most important for their application. The location of the charge and the radiation-induced conductivity are interesting both for production of foil electrets and for the investigation of charge phenomena in such materials. In this paper, charge build-up in 30 μm thick films of polypropylene irradiated with monoenergetic electron beams of 10-54 keV energy is investigated. Using the split-Faraday cap, the mean charge depth at the beginning of electron injection, at the termination of injection, and 10 min after injection are measured. It is found that the depth increases with time during charging, but decreases a little after injection of electron beams. The charge depth increases also with the amount of injected charge. From the dynamics of charge motion during irradiation, the radiation-induced conductivity is determined as a function of dose rate. It amounts to approximately 10-14 cm-1 at 104 rad s-1.
Index Keywords: Electron Beams - Effects; Plastics Films - Radiation Effects; Polymers - Conductive; Space Charges; Split Faraday Cap; Polypropylenes

Authors: Bisio G., Rubatto G.
Title: Refrigeration systems based on short-term storage by means of ice banks
Affiliations: Dipartimento di Ingegneria Energetica, Università di Genova, via all'Opera Pia, 15A, 16145 Genoa, Italy
Authors with affiliations: Bisio, G., Dipartimento di Ingegneria Energetica, Università di Genova, via all'Opera Pia, 15A, 16145 Genoa, Italy; Rubatto, G., Dipartimento di Ingegneria Energetica, Università di Genova, via all'Opera Pia, 15A, 16145 Genoa, Italy
Abstract: The aim of this paper is firstly of examining the ice banks with the energy method of analysis; to this purpose some topics of energy are dealt with, in particular the energy variation of a system in a fluctuating temperature environment. On these grounds the conditions for the technical and economical convenience of ice banks are examined. Various parameters that affect these plants are considered: (a) the variation of the system energy as a consequence of the variation of environment temperature; (b) the variability of the required refrigerating power; (c) the differential costs of the electrical energy; (d) the weight of the service reliability; (e) the heat transmission during the ice production. © 1991.
Index Keywords: Heat Transfer; Industrial Plants--Air Conditioning; Refrigeration; Thermodynamics--Entropy; Electrical Energy; Exergy Efficiency; Ice Bank Expediency; Short Term Storage; Ice

Authors: McNerney G., Blodgett D., Croyle J., Chertok A.
Title: Wind diesel system installed on the Taiwan Island of Chi-Mei
Source title: American Society of Mechanical Engineers, Solar Energy Division (Publication) SED
Affiliations: U.S. Windpower, Incorp, Livermore, United States
Authors with affiliations: McNerney, G., U.S. Windpower, Incorp, Livermore, United States; Blodgett, D., U.S. Windpower, Incorp, Livermore, United States; Croyle, J., U.S. Windpower, Incorp, Livermore, United States; Chertok, A., U.S. Windpower, Incorp, Livermore, United States
Abstract: Two USW 56-100 wind turbines and an energy storage system have been installed as a supplement to the diesel power network of the Island of Chi-Mei. The wind turbines were installed to reduce diesel fuel consumption on the island and the energy storage system to control disturbances to the frequency due to fluctuating wind power. Field measurements are available from tests in Altamont Pass, California to demonstrate how well this objective is being met.

Authors: Peterson D.R., Price J.H., Upshaw J.L., Weldon W.F., Zowarka R.C., Jr., Gully J.H., Spann M.L.
Title: Heavy-duty explosively operated pulsed opening and closing switches: Reducing cost and turnaround time
Affiliations: Center for Electromechanics, The University of Texas at Austin, 10100 Burnet Rd., Bldg. 133, Austin., TX, 78758–4497, United States
Authors with affiliations: Peterson, D.R., Center for Electromechanics, The University of Texas at Austin, 10100 Burnet Rd., Bldg. 133, Austin., TX, 78758–4497, United States; Price, J.H., Center for Electromechanics, The University of Texas at Austin, 10100 Burnet Rd., Bldg. 133, Austin., TX, 78758–4497, United States; Upshaw, J.L., Center for Electromechanics, The University of Texas at Austin, 10100 Burnet Rd., Bldg. 133, Austin., TX, 78758–4497, United States; Weldon, W.F., Center for Electromechanics, The University of Texas at Austin, 10100 Burnet Rd., Bldg. 133, Austin., TX, 78758–4497, United States; Zowarka, R.C., Jr., Center for Electromechanics, The University of Texas at Austin, 10100 Burnet Rd., Bldg. 133, Austin., TX, 78758–4497, United States; Gully, J.H., Center for Electromechanics, The University of Texas at Austin, 10100 Burnet Rd., Bldg. 133, Austin., TX, 78758–4497, United States; Spann, M.L., Center for Electromechanics, The University of Texas at Austin, 10100 Burnet Rd., Bldg. 133, Austin., TX, 78758–4497, United States
Abstract: This paper discusses improvements to heavy duty, explosively operated, opening and closing switches to reduce component cost, installation cost, and turnaround time without sacrificing reliability. Heavy duty opening and closing switches operated by small explosive charges (50 g or less) are essential to operation of the 60 MJ Balcones power supply. The six independent modules—a 10 MJ homopolar generator (HPG) and a 6μ H storage inductor—can be discharged sequentially, a valuable feature for shaping the current pulse delivered to loads such as high-energy railguns. Each delayed inductor must be isolated from the railgun circuit with a heavy duty closing switch capable of carrying megampere currents of millisecond duration. Similar closing switches are used to crowbar the railgun as the projectile approaches the muzzle: noise reduction, reduction of muzzle arc damage, and reduction of post-launch perturbation of projectile flight. The switches—both opening and closing-are characterized by microhm resistance in the closed state. Current is carried in metallic conductors. Metal-to-metal seams which carry current are maintained in uniform high pressure contact. Efficient. switching is crucial to efficient conversion: rotor kinetic energy to stored inductive energy with.~50% efficiency. stored inductive energy to projectile kinetic energy with ~30% efficiency. The switches must. operate with a precision and repeatability of 10–5 s, readily achievable with explosives. The opening switches must be structurally and thermally capable of carrying megampere currents for more than 100 ms (105 C) and develop 10 kV upon opening, stay open for 10–2 s, and safely and reliably dissipate megajoules of inductive energy in the event of a fault, a failure of the switch to operate or an attempt to commutate into an open circuit. An example of the severe switching duty: commutate 1.2 MA into a railgun already carrying 2 MA when the projectile is several meters into the gun and traveling several kilometers per second. © 1991 IEEE
Index Keywords: Ballistics - Projectiles; Electromagnetic Launchers - Rail Guns; Energy Storage; Explosives - Applications; Megajoules; Megampere Currents; Pulsed Switches; Electric Switches

Authors: Subramanyam S., Chetan M.S., Blumstein A., Mil'shtein S.
Title: Doped polypyridiniumacetylene salts electrical properties of a new class of conducting polymers
Source title: Polymeric Materials Science and Engineering, Proceedings of the ACS Division of Polymeric Materials Science and Engineering
Affiliations: Univ of Lowell, Lowell, United States
Authors with affiliations: Subramanyam, S., Univ of Lowell, Lowell, United States; Chetan, M.S., Univ of Lowell, Lowell, United States; Blumstein, A., Univ of Lowell, Lowell, United States; Mil'shtein, S., Univ of Lowell, Lowell, United States
Abstract: We describe the properties of a novel family of conducting ionic polyacetylenes that were synthesized recently in our laboratory. The presently described doped polyacetylenes have potential for applications in the area of energy storage and organic semiconductors and optical devices. Their solubility in common solvents renders them more processable and their good oxidative stability in comparison to doped, unsubstituted polyacetylene offer greater advantages for such applications. The optimization of the concentration and nature of dopants as well as their morphology for enhancement of electrical conductivity in these polymers is being currently investigated. Results show that there does not appear to be any trend relating ease of elimination with the conductivity of the final PPV. However, we found that water catalyses the elimination. Transmission IR spectra of the precursors revealed a significant quantity of water, evidenced by a broad band at around 3400 cm-1, in all PXT's except PXT acetate. Although the water content decreases in vacuum or dry nitrogen environment, small amounts remain which are apparently enough to catalyze the elimination.
Index Keywords: Electric Conductivity; Polymers - Synthesis; Polyphenylene Vinylene; Polyxylylidene Tetrahyrothiophenium Chloride; Plastics

Authors: He J.L., Zabar Z., Levi E., Birenbaum L.
Title: Transient performance of linear induction launchers fed by generators and by capacitor banks
Affiliations: Polytechnic University, 333 Jay Street, Brooklyn, NY, 11201, United States
Authors with affiliations: He, J.L., Polytechnic University, 333 Jay Street, Brooklyn, NY, 11201, United States; Zabar, Z., Polytechnic University, 333 Jay Street, Brooklyn, NY, 11201, United States; Levi, E., Polytechnic University, 333 Jay Street, Brooklyn, NY, 11201, United States; Birenbaum, L., Polytechnic University, 333 Jay Street, Brooklyn, NY, 11201, United States
Abstract: Computer simulation is used to investigate the transient performance of induction-type coilguns as a function of the dimensions, material properties, type of supply, firing sequence of switching elements, and connections of drive coils. The paper deals with the performance of both generator-driven and capacitor-driven coilguns. © 1991 IEEE
Index Keywords: Capacitors - Energy Storage; Electric Generators; Electric Motors, Induction; Electric Motors, Linear; Capacitor Banks; Coilguns; Electromagnetic Launchers

Authors: Horie Kazuyuki, Furusawa Akira
Title: Photochemical hole burning (PHB) for the characterization of low energy excitation modes in amorphous polymers
Source title: Polymeric Materials Science and Engineering, Proceedings of the ACS Division of Polymeric Materials Science and Engineering
Affiliations: Univ of Tokyo, Tokyo, Japan
Authors with affiliations: Horie, Kazuyuki, Univ of Tokyo, Tokyo, Japan; Furusawa, Akira, Univ of Tokyo, Tokyo, Japan
Abstract: Photochemical hole burning (PHB) is a phenomenon in which very narrow and stable photochemical holes are burnt at very low temperatures into the absorption bands of guest molecules molecularly dispersed in an amorphous solid by narrow-band excitation with a laser beam. The phenomenon of PHB has recently attracted considerable interest not only as a means for frequency-domain high density optical storage, but also as a tool for high-resolution solid state spectroscopy at low temperatures. In the present paper, phonon frequency, Es, and the temperature dependence of Debye-Waller factor, DW(T), obtained from PHB measurements are discussed for various polymers, in relation to the capability of hole formation above liquid nitrogen temperature in some polymers.
Index Keywords: Chemical Reactions - Photochemical Reactions; Spectroscopic Analysis; Spectroscopy; Amorphous Polymers; Debye Waller Factor; High Resolution Solid State Spectroscopy; Low Energy Excitation Modes; Photochemical Hole Burning; Polymers

Authors: Cook G.M., Spindler W.C.
Title: Low-maintenance, valve-regulated, lead/acid batteries in utility applications
Affiliations: Generation and Storage Division, Electric Power Research Institute, P.O. Box 10412, Palo Alto, CA 94303, United States; Batteries Included, 15174 Kellen, Riverside, CA 92506, United States
Authors with affiliations: Cook, G.M., Generation and Storage Division, Electric Power Research Institute, P.O. Box 10412, Palo Alto, CA 94303, United States; Spindler, W.C., Batteries Included, 15174 Kellen, Riverside, CA 92506, United States
Abstract: Electric power utility companies have various needs for lead/acid batteries, and also are beginning to promote customer-side-of-the meter applications for mutual benefits. Increasing use of lead/acid batteries in the future will depend heavily on improving performance and reliability of sealed, recombination designs, and on their versatility for many applications. Classifying various utility uses could be by cycling requirements, depth-of-discharge, power or energy (ratio of watts to hours), or by site (utility or customer). Deep-cycling examples are energy storage, peak-shaving and electric vehicles. Shallow-cycling examples are frequency regulation and reactive power control. Infrequent discharge examples are stationary service and spinning reserve. (Float service for telecommunications and uninterruptible power sources (UPS) applications are not addressed.) Some present and planned installations of valve-regulated lead/acid batteries are surveyed. Performance characteristics will be discussed, including recent results of testing both gel and absorptive glass mat (AGM) types of deep-cycling batteries. Recommendations for future research and development of valve-regulated cell technology are outlined, based on a recent conference organized by the United States Department of Energy (USDOE) and the Electric Power Research Institute (EPRI). © 1991.
Index Keywords: Lead Compounds--Performance; Deep Cycling; Gas Recombinations; Glass Mats; Storage Batteries; Valve-Regulated Batteries; Electric Batteries, Secondary

Authors: Anon
Title: Flexibility for CGCC power generation - LPM energy storage
Source title: Proceedings of the American Power Conference
Authors with affiliations: Anon
Abstract: Energy storage systems have long been used to increase the utilization of capital-intensive power generating assets. This paper describes a technology which provides energy storage to complement a Coal Gasification Combined-Cycle electric power facility. The concept is called the Liquid Phase Methanol (LPM) process which co-produces methanol along with electric power. Because of the synergy of the LPM process with the CGCC process, there are unusual efficiency, cost and flexibility benefits realized with this type of energy storage as compared to conventional systems.
Index Keywords: Coal Gasification; Energy Storage; Methanol; Liquid Phase Methanol Process; Electric Power Plants

Authors: Sato Eiichi, Isobe Hiroshi, Takahashi Kei, Tamakawa Yoshiharu, Yanagisawa Toru
Title: Repetitive flash x-ray generator operated at low-dose rates for a medical x-ray television system
Source title: Proceedings of SPIE - The International Society for Optical Engineering
Affiliations: Iwate Medical Univ, Morioka, Japan
Authors with affiliations: Sato, Eiichi, Iwate Medical Univ, Morioka, Japan; Isobe, Hiroshi, Iwate Medical Univ, Morioka, Japan; Takahashi, Kei, Iwate Medical Univ, Morioka, Japan; Tamakawa, Yoshiharu, Iwate Medical Univ, Morioka, Japan; Yanagisawa, Toru, Iwate Medical Univ, Morioka, Japan
Abstract: The fundamental studies for the repetitive flash x-ray generator operated at low-dose rates for a medical x-ray television system are described. This x-ray generator consisted of the following components: a high-voltage power supply, an energy storage condenser of 100nF, a coaxial cable condenser with a capacity of 1000pF, a repetitive impulse switching system, a turbo molecular pump, and an x-ray tube having a cold cathode. The condenser was charged from 40 to 70kV by a power supply, and the electric charges stored in the condenser were discharged repetitively by using a trigger electrode operated by an impulse switching system. The x-ray tube was of the triode-type which was connected to the turbo molecular pump and had a large discharge impedance in order to prevent the damped oscillations of the tube current and voltage. The maximum tube voltage was equivalent to the initial charged voltage, and the peak current was less than 70A. The durations were about 2μs, and the x-ray intensities were less than 1.0μC/kg at 0.5m per pulse. The repetition frequency was less than 50Hz, and the effective focal spot size was equivalent to the anode diameter of 3.0mm. For the x-ray television system used in conjunction with this repetitive pulsed x-ray generator, since the electromagnetic noise primarily caused by the high tube current was decreased, noise-free stroboscopic radiography performed by the television system could be realized.
Index Keywords: Electron Tubes, Triode; Photography, High Speed; Radiography - X-Ray; Television Systems; Fundamental Studies; Repetitive Flash; X-Ray Generator; X-Ray Apparatus

Authors: [No author name available]
Title: 1990 Fifth Symposium on Electromagnetic Launcher Technology
Abstract: This issue contains 129 conference papers. The topics dealt with include: the 10 km/s, 10 kg railgun; railgun performance with a two-stage light-gas gun injector; design and testing of 0.60 caliber augmented railgun; final design of an air-core compulsator driven 60 caliber railgun system; electromagnetic acceleration studies with augmented rails; a second-generation EMET railgun for secondary arc studies; mass sensitivity studies for an inductively driven railgun; conformal mapping calculation of railgun skin inductance; distributed energy store railgun: the limited case; time resolved optical diagnostic methods for electric gun systems; E/M launcher vibration and acceleration data analysis; a control algorithm for reluctance accelerators; visualization of plasma-fluid mixing through X-ray shadowgraphy; the Hart 1 augmented electric gun facility; post-shot analysis of plasma/rail interaction in a small-bore load driving EML; a review of armature research; large and small caliber railgun solid armatures; a new concept in solid armature design; design and testing of solid armatures for rail accelerator applications; a new approach to a high-efficiency inductive store; metal-to-metal for large currents; lightweight high-efficiency energy-storage transformers; studies to reduce material erosion in electrothermal launchers; the EMET railgun projectile; exploratory development of the Reconnection Launcher 1986-1990; and design of a reluctance accelerator. All papers are separately indexed and abstracted.
Index Keywords: Ballistics - Projectiles; Electric Arcs; Electric Machinery; Energy Storage; Plasma Devices; Capacitor Banks; Compulsators; EIREV; Plasma Armatures; Pulsed Power Supplies; Rail Guns; Electromagnetic Launchers

Authors: Sato Eiichi, Shikoda Arimitsu, Isobe Hiroshi, Tamakawa Yoshiharu, Yanagisawa Toru, Honda Keiji, Yokota Yoshiharu
Title: Kilohertz-range pulsed x-ray generator having a hot cathode triode
Source title: Proceedings of SPIE - The International Society for Optical Engineering
Affiliations: Iwate Medical Univ, Morioka, Japan
Authors with affiliations: Sato, Eiichi, Iwate Medical Univ, Morioka, Japan; Shikoda, Arimitsu, Iwate Medical Univ, Morioka, Japan; Isobe, Hiroshi, Iwate Medical Univ, Morioka, Japan; Tamakawa, Yoshiharu, Iwate Medical Univ, Morioka, Japan; Yanagisawa, Toru, Iwate Medical Univ, Morioka, Japan; Honda, Keiji, Iwate Medical Univ, Morioka, Japan; Yokota, Yoshiharu, Iwate Medical Univ, Morioka, Japan
Abstract: The fundamental studies for the repetitive pulsed x-ray generator utilizing a hot cathode triode operated at high repetitive rates in the kHz-range are described. This generator consisted of the following essential components: a constant high-voltage power supply, an energy storage condenser, a grid pulser, a DC-DC converter for supplying grid bias voltages, and an x-ray tube. The x-ray tube was of an enclosed-triode type and consisted of the following devices: an anode rod made of copper, a plane anode tip (target) made of tungsten, a grid made from tungsten wire, a focusing electrode made of iron, a hot-cathode (filament) made of tungsten, and a glass body. The condenser which was attached to the anode electrode was charged from 50 to 70kV, and the electric charges in the condenser were discharged repetitively by the grid electrode operated by the grid pulser. The pulse width was primarily determined by the pulse width from the grid pulser, the grid bias voltage, and the cut-off voltage for thermoelectrons, and could be controlled to about 1μs. The x-ray pulse height primarily increased according to increases in the charged voltage at a constant grid bias voltage. The x-ray intensity was 1.35nC/kg at 0.5m per pulse with a condenser charged voltage of 70kV, a grid bias voltage of -1.0kV, and the charged voltage of the grid pulser of 400V.
Index Keywords: Electron Tubes, Triode; Photography, High Speed; Radiography; Fundamental Studies; Grid Effects; Hot Cathode Triode; Kilohertz-Range Pulsed X-Rays; X-Ray Generator; X-Ray Apparatus

Authors: Edwards R.J., Im M.J., Hoopes J.E.
Title: Effects of hyperbaric oxygen preservation on rat limb replantation: A preliminary report
Affiliations: The Johns Hopkins Hospital, 600 N Wolfe St, Baltimore, MD 21205., United States
Authors with affiliations: Edwards, R.J., The Johns Hopkins Hospital, 600 N Wolfe St, Baltimore, MD 21205., United States; Im, M.J., The Johns Hopkins Hospital, 600 N Wolfe St, Baltimore, MD 21205., United States; Hoopes, J.E., The Johns Hopkins Hospital, 600 N Wolfe St, Baltimore, MD 21205., United States
Abstract: The effect of hyperbaric oxygen, administered during storage, on the survival of replanted limbs was evaluated in rats. The right hindlimbs of male Sprague-Dawley rats were severed and were replanted by microvascular anastomoses after storage in either room air or hyperbaric oxygen (100% oxygen at 2.9 atm absolute) at 23°C for 5 hours. The administration of hyperbaric oxygen during storage improved limb survival from 50% in the room-air, control rats to 100% (p < 0.05). The gastrocnemius muscle of limbs treated with hyperbaric oxygen demonstrated a higher level of energy reserves (creatine phosphate, adenosine triphosphate, glycogen, and glucose) than the same muscle in room-air, control rats. The mechanisms of the beneficial effect of hyperbaric oxygen on limb survival appears to be related to preservation of high-energy phosphates and glycogen.
Index Keywords: animal experiment; animal tissue; article; controlled study; hyperbaric oxygen; leg; limb replantation; microvascular surgery; nonhuman; rat; tissue oxygenation

Authors: Davies I.R., Brown J.C., Livesey G.
Title: Energy values and energy balance in rats fed on supplements of guar gum or cellulose
Affiliations: AFRC Institute of Food Research, Norwich Laboratory, Colney Lane, Norwich NR4 7UA, United Kingdom
Authors with affiliations: Davies, I.R., AFRC Institute of Food Research, Norwich Laboratory, Colney Lane, Norwich NR4 7UA, United Kingdom; Brown, J.C., AFRC Institute of Food Research, Norwich Laboratory, Colney Lane, Norwich NR4 7UA, United Kingdom; Livesey, G., AFRC Institute of Food Research, Norwich Laboratory, Colney Lane, Norwich NR4 7UA, United Kingdom
Abstract: In five experiments where guar gum (GG) or Solka-floc cellulose (SF) supplemented a semi-synthetic diet (100 g/kg) for male Wistar rats at 21°, it was found that GG acutely depressed both ad lib. and meal-fed food intakes by 40-50 %. The effect was temporary, with the GG having no effects on food intake in the longer term. Dietary energy balance over 28 d with animals fed on equal amounts of a basal ration showed partial digestible energy values, calculated from the intake and faecal loss of energy, for the supplements which averaged 0 kJ/g SF and 10 kJ/g GG, so that GG contributed substantial amounts of absorbable energy. Despite this additional energy from GG, there was very often no additional gain of body fat. Rather, in some experiments, fat deposition was actually decreased by supplementation with GG. GG is inferred to have a putative thermogenic effect which is often greater than the energy it supplies. This effect occurred to a greater extent in circumstances associated with a higher ‘energy status ‘, indicated by higher efficiencies of conversion of gross dietary energy to retained body energy, higher fat:lean tissue deposition ratios and the occurrence of larger deposits at the epididymal fat pad site. There was some evidence that deposition at this site was more extensively affected by GG than deposition of fat in the body as a whole. Possible implications of the present findings are discussed. © 1991, The Nutrition Society. All rights reserved.
Author Keywords: Cellulose; Energy balance; Guar gum; Non-starch polysaccharides; Rat
Index Keywords: cellulose; guar gum; polysaccharide; animal experiment; article; body composition; body fat; caloric intake; digestion; energy balance; energy expenditure; epididymis fat; food intake; high fiber diet; lean body weight; lipid storage; male; metabolism; nonhuman; priority journal; rat; thermogenesis; weight gain; weight reduction; Animal; Body Composition; Cellulose; Diet, Reducing; Dietary Fiber; Digestion; Eating; Energy Metabolism; Feces; Galactans; Male; Mannans; Rats; Rats, Inbred Strains; Support, Non-U.S. Gov't; Weight Gain; Animalia; Cyamopsis tetragonoloba; Rattus norvegicus

Authors: Ghoneim A.A., Klein S.A., Duffie J.A.
Title: Analysis of collector-storage building walls using phase-change materials
Affiliations: Laboratory of Physics, Mathematical Eng. and Eng. Physics Dept., Faculty of Engineering, Alexandria, Egypt; Solar Energy Laboratory, University of Wisconsin-Madison, Madison, WI 53706, United States
Authors with affiliations: Ghoneim, A.A., Laboratory of Physics, Mathematical Eng. and Eng. Physics Dept., Faculty of Engineering, Alexandria, Egypt; Klein, S.A., Solar Energy Laboratory, University of Wisconsin-Madison, Madison, WI 53706, United States; Duffie, J.A., Solar Energy Laboratory, University of Wisconsin-Madison, Madison, WI 53706, United States
Abstract: The use of thermal storage walls that serve both as solar collector and thermal storage is well known. The wall is usually composed of masonry or containers filled with water to provide sensible heat storage, i.e., storage resulting from the specific heat capacity of a material as it increases in temperature. An interesting alternative to the standard materials are phase-change materials (PCMs) which employ latent heat storage. Latent heat storage utilizes the energy associated with a change of state of a material such as the transition from a solid-to-liquid, or liquid-to-gas. The solid-to-liquid phase change is preferred for many applications because of the much smaller volume change resulting in this transition for a given amount of energy storage. This paper summarizes the results of a simulation study of the use of PCMs as a collector-storage wall. © 1991.
Index Keywords: Buildings--Walls; Heat Storage--Materials; Heat Transfer--Walls; Mathematical Models--Applications; Collector-Storage Building Walls; Latent Heat Storage; Phase-Change Materials (PCMS); Thermal Storage Walls; Solar Energy

Authors: Arques Ph.
Title: Pneumatic storage and reciprocating engine
Source title: Proceedings of the Intersociety Energy Conversion Engineering Conference
Affiliations: Ecole Centrale of Lyon, Ecully, France
Authors with affiliations: Arques, Ph., Ecole Centrale of Lyon, Ecully, France
Abstract: In order to resolve the conflicting and erratic situation between the production and the instantaneous consumption of electricity which occurs just a few hours a day, electric power companies have been led to adopt different solutions, from financially inciting some consumers to cut themselves off, to designing electric power stations with daily or weekly compressed air energy storage. In this case, air is compressed in a reservoir during off-peak hours; this air is reheated and expanded in an engine which drives an electric generator. The expansion engines which can be used in this instance are either rotating: gas turbines or volumetric: the reciprocating engine. This communication presents the design and the computed characteristics of a reciprocating engine running on a LENOIR cycle with a compressed air intake pressure alone or connected to exterior combustion chambers and gas turbines.

Authors with affiliations: Mauro, Robert L., Natl Hydrogen Assoc, Washington, United States; Serfass, Jeffrey A., Natl Hydrogen Assoc, Washington, United States
Abstract: The National Hydrogen Association (NHA) was formed in 1989 to develop U.S. industrial and research interest in hydrogen as an energy carrier; to develop plans for appropriate research and development; and to assess business opportunities in hydrogen production, transport, storage and utilization. In mid-1990, the National Aeronautics and Space Administration (NASA) and the NHA began a multi-layer cooperative project to evaluate hydrogen-related technologies and their application. The NHA's Technology Review Committee has been created to steer this project. The Hydrogen Technology Assessment has several components: Summaries of hydrogen-related technologies; Major U.S. hydrogen research programs; Hydrogen application strategies; Conclusion and recommendations. This paper presents a summary of the Phase 1 efforts. The many references and the complete results are contained in the Phase 1 report, available from the NHA.

Authors: Najafi M., Schaetzle W.J.
Title: Cooling and heating with clathrate thermal energy storage system
Affiliations: Univ of Southwestern Louisiana, Lafayette, United States
Authors with affiliations: Najafi, M., Univ of Southwestern Louisiana, Lafayette, United States; Schaetzle, W.J., Univ of Southwestern Louisiana, Lafayette, United States
Abstract: A heat pump/thermal energy storage system utilizing clathrate as a storage medium has been constructed to evaluate system performance in simulated heating and cooling cycles. The system utilizes a common thermal energy storage system for both cooling and heating and operates with direct-contact heat transfer between refrigerant and water or clathrate. Experimental runs have been performed utilizing basic Refrigerant-12 clathrate for both the cooling and heating systems. Algorithms have been implemented to provide energy balances and to compute the system's overall coefficient of performance (COP) for every run. The experimental results demonstrate the system's feasibility and potential to perform as a thermal energy storage heat pump system.

Authors: Jenkins Jason E.
Title: Design of the MSX NiH2 battery
Source title: Proceedings of the Intersociety Energy Conversion Engineering Conference
Affiliations: Johns Hopkins Univ, Laurel, United States
Authors with affiliations: Jenkins, Jason E., Johns Hopkins Univ, Laurel, United States
Abstract: The design of the Midcourse Space Experiment (MSX) 50 Ah nickel hydrogen (NiH2) battery must accommodate requirements of a four to five year low earth orbit (LEO) mission. This battery must survive a lifetime of 40% depth of discharge (DOD) cycles with occasional excursions to 70% DOD. Mass and volume constraints have driven the mechanical design to a single nonredundant unit. The electrical design has been influenced by the high charge and discharge rates associated with this variable load LEO application. The thermal design must maintain stringent thermal limits to preserve the performance of the NiH2 cells over the lifetime. The mechanical, electrical, and thermal designs have also been significantly affected by the addition of bypass electronics to counter nonredundancy. The MSX battery possesses the mechanical, thermal, and electrical designs which will enable it to successfully complete its goal mission.
Index Keywords: Electric Batteries - Temperature Control; Energy Storage; Spacecraft - Power Supply; Battery Thermal Control; Failed Cell Diode Dissipations; Low Earth Orbit (LEO) Mission; Midcourse Space Experiment (MSX); MSX Battery Thermal Limits; MSX Eclipse Time Profiles; Electric Batteries

Authors: Schneider Michael G., Brege Mark A., Heidenreich Gary R.
Title: Critical technology experiment results for lightweight space heat receiver
Source title: Proceedings of the Intersociety Energy Conversion Engineering Conference
